summary: Strong Truck Sales Help Chrysler Post Robust Profit Brisk sales of Jeeps, pickup trucks and mini-vans allowed Chrysler to announce unexpectedly strong results for the fourth quarter, closing out the company's second-most-profitable year ever. Chrysler earned $807 million in the quarter, down 22 percent from a year earlier but well above most analysts' predictions. For the year, Chrysler earned $3.53 billion. $(Page D2.$) Irish Bank in Pennsylvania Deal Allied Irish Banks, which operates here as First Maryland Bancorp, agreed to acquire Dauphin Deposit, a Pennsylvania bank company, for $1.36 billion. $(D2.$) Chase and Citicorp Profits Up a Bit Chase Manhattan and Citicorp reported small increases in their profits for the fourth quarter. Chase's earnings were held down by the costs of the merger with Chemical Banking, while Citicorp's were curtailed by a decline in credit-card profits. $(D2.$) Boeing Drops Plan for Bigger Jets Boeing stock rose sharply after the company decided not to proceed with a plan to develop larger versions of its 747 jet. The move appears to concede the high end of the market to Airbus Industrie, though analysts said they doubted that Boeing was giving up much. Market Place. $(D10.$) Stocks Continue to Gain Stock prices surged, with the Dow industrials rising 40.03 points, to close at 6,883.90. $(D10.$) Japanese stocks closed strongly today. The Nikkei index was up 655.72 points, or 3.78 percent.$(D10.$) A Strong Year for Salomon Salomon bounced back from a difficult 1995, as net income nearly doubled in 1996, driven by trading and investment banking. $(D2.$) Results Surge for Exxon and Shell Exxon and Shell reported big jumps in quarterly results as a result of sharply higher prices for crude oil and natural gas. $(D2.$) Specialty Services Help Bells Four regional telephone companies -- Pacific Telesis, SBC Communications, Nynex and Bell Atlantic -- reported generally healthy earnings, bolstered by profits from caller ID, call waiting and other specialty services. $(D4.$) New Bonds Begin Trading Inflation-indexed bonds began trading at surprisingly high prices and low yields as the Treasury Department announced plans for its first auction ever of such securities. $(D17.$) An Olive Branch in South Korea In a concession aimed at ending nearly a month of labor unrest, President Kim Young Sam of South Korea said that he was willing to allow the National Assembly to amend a new labor law, and he hinted at recognition of a union group that the measure outlaws. $(A8.$) Intel Loosens Its Tie Intel is planning a campaign that is infused with the kind of offbeat humor rarely found in computer advertising. One commercial features the actor Jason Alexander, who plays the whiny George on the NBC sitcom ''Seinfeld.'' Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D7.$) New Metro Business Coverage Today, The New York Times is introducing Metro Business, in the Metro Section. Appearing Tuesday through Friday, it will include news and features on local business, from real estate to retailing. $(B6.$) Microsoft has come from the West Coast to New York's Silicon Alley, seeking to buy original programming, but the seduction has not always been smooth as the software giant's suburban-office-park culture clashes with that of the downtown loft dwellers. $(B1.$)

headline: Sega to Acquire Bandai, Creating Toy-Video Giant
summary: Sega Enterprises, the Japanese video game maker, said today that it would buy the Bandai Company Ltd., the Japanese toy company famous for the Power Rangers, in a stock swap valued around $1 billion, creating the world's biggest toy and video-game company. The new company, to be called Sega Bandai, would have about $6 billion in revenue, more than Nintendo, Mattel or Hasbro. Its operations would range from Sega's video arcades, miniature theme parks and home video-game machines to Bandai's Sailor Moon dolls, and its music and video entertainment divisions.

headline: Talk of Takeover Lifts Fund Manager's Shares
summary: The shares of Mercury Asset Management Group P.L.C. jumped yesterday amid speculation that the company, Britain's largest fund manager, might be the target of a takeover bid. In addition, the SBC Warburg securities firm raised its investment opinion on Mercury, increasing the target share price to 1,500 pence from 1,390. Mercury shares rose 26.5 pence, to 1,382.5 ($2.26), yesterday.

headline: Latin Markets Again Run With the Bulls
summary: ANYONE who bought Latin American stock and bond funds a year ago can claim bragging rights at cocktail parties. The gains in both categories have been handsome, exceeding 40 percent in some cases. But a not-so-subtle shift has taken place early this year. After a two-year rally, bonds have been replaced by stocks as the winning investment in the region.

headline: Shedding State Companies, If Sometimes Reluctantly
summary: For men who defended the repression of blacks and secret wars in Africa by declaring that they were holding back Communism, the old white rulers of this country created a surprisingly socialist state. A startling 50 percent of South Africa's fixed assets are in government hands. The state owns all or almost all of the telephone company, the electric company, the national airline, the arms industry, the railroads, buses, ports, hospitals and television stations. It drills for gas, logs forests, runs water fun parks, mines some diamonds and grows a few mangoes.

headline: Kristina Foley, Thomas Hickey
summary: Kristina Elizabeth Foley, an account director at Foote, Cone & Belding NY, the advertising agency, was married yesterday to Thomas James Hickey, an executive director at SBC Warburg, the New York investment bank. The Rev. Richard Neilson performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York. Mrs. Hickey, 30, graduated cum laude from Pomona College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She received an M.B.A. from Columbia University. Her parents, Dr. Gloria Foley and Dr. Douglas Foley, live in Austin, Tex., where she is the director of assessment at Austin Community College and he is a professor of anthropology at the University of Texas. The bride's mother also has a private practice in psychology.

headline: Southwestern Bell to Sell Lucent Products
summary: Lucent Technologies Inc. announced an agreement yesterday under which the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company would market Lucent products to its business customers. The five-year deal is a coup for Lucent, which split off from the AT&T Corporation in September. And it is a black eye for the company's biggest rival, Northern Telecom Ltd., which had used Southwestern Bell, a unit of SBC Communications Inc., as a distributor of its own equipment for corporate telephone systems.

headline: Equity Issues To Be Offered During Week
summary: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week: Apollo Biopharmaceutics Inc., Cambridge, Mass., an initial public offering of 1.2 million units, consisting of one common share and one redeemable warrant. First United Equities Corp.

headline: Bell Atlantic, Nynex Merger Set to Advance
summary: New York State regulators are expected to give qualified approval today to the $22 billion merger of Bell Atlantic and Nynex. And in a victory for Nynex, the chairman of the Public Service Commission indicated that the regulators were reluctant to demand cuts in local telephone rates as a condition for endorsing the deal, according to people who attended the meeting. Executives at Nynex had expected the commission to rule on the merger yesterday. But after an uncharacteristically freewheeling discussion among the three commissioners, the chairman, John F. O'Mara, put off a final ruling until a special session scheduled for this morning.

headline: Big Board Record in Short Sales
summary: The number of shares borrowed and sold short among New York Stock Exchange issues has risen above three billion for the first time ever, the Big Board reported yesterday. And the American Stock Exchange said its short position had also set a record. The Big Board said short interest rose 5.5 percent in the month ended March 11, to 3.099 billion shares from 2.937 billion in the earlier comparable monthly period. At the American Stock Exchange, short interest rose 9.1 percent, to 148.2 million shares from 135.8 million.

headline: Accounts
summary: * National Association of Home Builders, Washington, to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore and Washington, as its first agency. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million. * SBC Advertising, Columbus, Ohio, received two accounts with combined billings estimated at $2.5 million: Central Benefits Mutual Insurance Co., Columbus, as the first agency to handle advertising and public relations, and GOJO Industries Inc., Akron, Ohio, to handle promotions and other projects for the skin care products marketer.

headline: SBC-Pacific Telesis Deal Wins Approval
summary: SBC Communications Inc. won approval today from California regulators to buy Pacific Telesis Group for about $16.3 billion, clearing the way for the first combination of two regional Bell operating companies. The California Public Utilities Commission voted 4 to 1 for approval, letting the transaction pass its last regulatory hurdle. The deal could be completed as early as tomorrow if boards of both companies give final approval.

headline: Chief Seeks Harmony, for Now, As He Tries to Cut Labor Costs
summary: It is the story of the airline industry these days. With carriers generating record profits, many union workers want raises, testing their leverage against executives who say big pay increases would make their airlines less competitive. Pilots and managers have squared off at American and United, and Continental's pilots said last week that they wanted a 38 percent raise. In this atmosphere of confrontation, the approach of Stephen M. Wolf, chairman and chief executive of US Airways, is an ambitious departure. Mr. Wolf wants to lower costs sharply, but he wants to do it with labor's help. As he tries to turn around the airline, which has lost $2.4 billion in the last decade, he has vowed that there will be no power struggle.

headline: Executive Changes
summary: LIBERTY FINANCIAL COS., Boston, said it had hired Andy Hilbert as senior vice president and its first chief financial officer.

headline: A Plodding Ma Bell and Her Precocious Child
summary: IT was not supposed to play out this way. When AT&T's chairman, Robert E. Allen, yielded the lectern to the chief operating officer, John R. Walter, at a meeting for analysts last month, the passing of the torch was almost painful to watch. Mr. Allen, pale and pinched from recent heart surgery, murmured an apology for AT&T's wobbly performance in 1996, while Mr. Walter, tanned and exuding the confidence of an heir apparent, promised to turn the company around.

headline: Phone Companies' Earnings Meet Forecasts
summary: Ameritech, GTE and Sprint reported first-quarter earnings yesterday that matched or exceeded Wall Street's expectations. The gains came on strength in the companies' core telephone businesses as well as in enhanced services like caller identification. The Ameritech Corporation, the regional Baby Bell based in Chicago, topped analysts' forecasts with a 12 percent earnings increase on a 26 percent rise in sales of call waiting, voice messaging and other high-profit products. The GTE Corporation, a local and long-distance provider, said earnings rose 7.95 percent, matching estimates, helped by a rise of 33 percent in sales of call-management services.

headline: Advertising Giant Likely To Break Up
summary: Cordiant P.L.C., the advertising agency company descended from the Saatchi brothers' empire, is expected to announce today that it will dissolve itself, spinning off to shareholders its main holdings, Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide and Bates Worldwide, executives with knowledge of the proposed transaction said last night. Under what is being called a ''demerger,'' Saatchi & Saatchi and Bates will become separate, publicly traded companies, said the executives, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Saatchi and Bates, in turn, are to hold a joint interest in Zenith Media, Cordiant's media-buying subsidiary, they said.

headline: MCI Says Earnings Were Flat Despite Long-Distance Gains
summary: The MCI Communications Corporation said today that profit was unchanged in the first quarter as losses from new wireless and local phone businesses offset an increase in long-distance profit. MCI, which is the nation's second-largest long-distance phone company, behind the AT&T Corporation, reported net income of $295 million, or 42 cents a share, the same as a year earlier. The earnings were one cent short of an average estimate by analysts of 43 cents a share, according to a survey by I.B.E.S. International Inc.

headline: Bell Partners' Next Hurdle Is Credibility Size of Deal for Nynex
summary: Now comes the easy part. Bell Atlantic and Nynex completed a regulatory steeplechase last week when the Justice Department announced it would not try to block their $22 billion merger. And though the companies tangled for more than a year with angry consumer advocates, balky state officials and skeptical regulators, their big deal came through without a scratch.

headline: Britain '97: Rich, Poor and a Little in Between
summary: On the eve of Britain's most important election in years, the nation's economic indicators are flashing green. After years of slashing payrolls, privatizations and big cuts in welfare under Margaret Thatcher's revolution, the economy has been growing steadily since 1993. Last month, the Government reported that unemployment was a slim 6.1 percent compared with double-digits in France, Germany and Italy and half the level in Britain a decade ago. Last year, growth here beat virtually every nation in Europe with a solid 2.6 percent gain, not far behind the United States.

headline: A Toy Maker in Search of a New Blockbuster
summary: Mayumi Nishiguchi loved her pet chicken Hanako like a child and took it everywhere. So when Hanako died Thursday, the 35-year-old shopkeeper held a funeral, putting its body on a pedestal, praying over it and lighting a cigarette in lieu of Japan's traditional incense-burning. ''After the funeral,'' she said, ''I pressed the reset button.'' And there, on a thumbnail-sized video screen, a new chick was hatched.

headline: SBC COMMUNICATIONS INC. (SBC,N)
summary: SBC Communications Inc. said yesterday that rainstorms in Northern California and expenses for new ventures weakened first-quarter profits, the first report combining its results with Pacific Telesis Group, which it acquired on April 1. The merged company, based in San Antonio, reported a 3.5 percent decline in pro forma net income to $857 million, or 94 cents a share, from $888 million, or 96 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Both periods included one-time gains of $90 million.

headline: Swiss Bank Steps Up to Buy Dillon, Read on Rebound
summary: The Swiss Bank Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Dillon, Read & Company, the New York investment company, for about $600 million, one day after the ING Groep of the Netherlands said that its talks with Dillon had broken off. The transaction, which was negotiated in just the last few weeks, is further evidence of the determination of big European banks to build investment banking franchises in the United States.

headline: SBC COMMUNICATIONS IN SETBACK ON SERVICE
summary: In a setback to SBC Communications Inc.'s quest to provide long-distance service to its own customers in Oklahoma, the Justice Department recommended yesterday that Federal regulators reject the application. In a filing to the Federal Communications Commission, the department's antitrust division said the request was premature because the company had not taken steps to open its local phone market to competition. The F.C.C. will ultimately decide SBC's request, but the law requires the commission to give the Justice Department's opinion substantial weight. The F.C.C. must act by July 10. The San Antonio-based company owns Southwestern Bell, which provides local phone service to nearly 1.6 million people in Oklahoma.

headline: Equity Offerings Set This Week
summary: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week: ABN Amro Holding N.V., Amsterdam, 14 million American depository shares each representing one ordinary share. ABN Amro Securities Inc.

headline: Monopolies Still Rule the Local Phone Markets
summary: Sixteen months after the Government opened the $100 billion local phone market to no-holds-barred competition, a new study has found that fewer than half of 1 percent of Americans receive their residential phone service from a competitor to the monopoly provider. Moreover, the most likely rivals to the local monopolies -- AT&T, MCI, and other long-distance carriers -- are entering the residential market only grudgingly, according to the study, which was compiled by the Yankee Group, a telecommunications research firm in Boston.

headline: AT&T and SBC Reportedly Talk of Huge Phone Merger
summary: In a deal that would reunite Ma Bell with the fastest growing of her progeny, the AT&T Corporation is discussing a merger with SBC Communications Inc., people familiar with the talks said yesterday. The deal, if completed, would be the largest corporate merger in history, with a value of more than $50 billion. And it would create a colossus that dwarfs even the other telecommunications giants created in the wake of deregulation. Together, AT&T and SBC would have 90 million long-distance customers, 30 million local customers and virtual dominion over SBC's two biggest states, California and Texas.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Coca-Cola Enterprises To Buy 2 Big Bottlers The world's largest bottling company, Coca-Cola Enterprises, plans to get even larger. It agreed to acquire bottling companies from the Coca-Cola Company in two of its strongest markets -- Canada and metropolitan New York -- for $1.01 billion in cash plus $650 million in assumed debt.

headline: Dow Up 37.50 to Reach Record 7,383.41
summary: Stocks advanced to new highs yesterday in a rally led by computer issues. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 37.50 points, to a record 7,383.41, led by I.B.M., which jumped 5 7/8, to 179 1/4, an all-time high. AT&T, the most widely held stock, contributed to the rally, rising 1 3/8, to 37 1/2. The stock rose after The Wall Street Journal reported that the company was in merger talks with SBC Communications Inc. SBC gained 3/4, to 57 5/8.

headline: INSIDE
summary: An Affluent Museum And Its Poor Cousin The new, lavishly appointed Museum of African-American History in Detroit stands in stark contrast to the city's dilapidated Institute of Arts. Financing for the institutions -- or the shortage of it -- is entangled in the politics of race, class and labor in a mostly black city ringed by mostly white suburbs. Page C11. AT&T Seen in Merger Talks AT&T and SBC Communications are said to be discussing a $50 billion-plus merger. But a deal would face many regulatory hurdles. Page D1. F.C.C. Chief to Step Down Reed E. Hundt, who oversaw sweeping changes in telecommunications, is leaving the Federal Communications Commission. Page D1. Chirac Steps Up Campaign President Jacques Chirac took to the airwaves to aid his conservative coalition, asking voters if they really wanted ''to put yesterday's Socialist ideas back in the saddle.'' Page A8. A Dry Run, and a Winner In a race put off two days by rain, Arie Luyendyk won the Indianapolis 500 by capitalizing on a rival's failure on the final lap. Page B9.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 NATO and Russia Sign Accord on Cooperation President Clinton and the leaders of other NATO countries signed an accord with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia on mutual cooperation and security. The accord was designed to assuage Russian fears about NATO's planned expansion, which will include countries formerly allied with Moscow in the Warsaw Pact. A1

headline: In SBC Talks, AT&T Head May Have Bet the House
summary: AT&T's chairman, Robert E. Allen, has not hesitated to roll the dice in his nine years at the helm of the nation's largest telephone company. But even by his riverboat standards, Mr. Allen's bid to merge the AT&T Corporation with SBC Communications Inc. is a breathtaking gamble. If he does not engineer a deal in the next few weeks, some experts said, AT&T could be left with neither a strategy nor a viable leader to enact it.

headline: DIARY
summary: TECHNOLOGY STOCKS Even Intel Is Mortal What? Intel isn't invincible? It can't be true -- but it is. On Friday, Intel broke the news that it wouldn't rake in quite the fortune it had expected to, and investors, fearing a high-tech judgment day, sent its shares down 15 percent within minutes. And since Intel is the world's largest maker of computer chips and since computers are where it's at these days, the whole market gave a little shudder -- especially the technology-heavy Nasdaq. By day's end, though, investors decided the digital world as we know it was not crashing, and Intel's shares were off just 7 percent, to $151.50. The Dow industrials barely changed, at 7,331, while the Nasdaq lost 2.7 percent. Nike, another company that seemed invincible -- or at least seemed to have endless cash to pay athletes to display its little swoosh -- also took a hit. Its shares fell 13 percent on Thursday after it predicted less-bouncy earnings, but recovered a bit Friday, closing the week at $57.25. REGULATORS A New F.C.C. Ball Game ''I hope we put the ball in the net more times than not,'' Reed E. Hundt said last week -- and no, he wasn't talking about basketball. But forgive him, please, for indulging in that all-too-American habit of lapsing into sports analogies at the drop of a bat. He's had a busy few years as head of the Federal Communications Commission and was announcing his decision to hang up his cleats. Just look what happened while he was on the mound: telephone deregulation, digital TV licenses, a push for cable competition, guiding the wireless revolution. And then, as further proof that his beat is a busy one, there were rumblings last week about a merger between AT&T and SBC Communications, a deal whose size would hit the old record out of the park. HOLLYWOOD The Dinosaurs of Summer Think of the great old movies -- ''Children of Paradise,'' say, or ''Notorious'' or ''Treasure of the Sierra Madre.'' If they had opened a week later, or a week earlier, would it have affected their greatness one iota? Of course not. But just look at summer movie madness now, at all the huffing and puffing about which mega-budget, mega-effects movie will land on a given weekend. Greatness? They don't need no stinkin' greatness -- they need blowout box-office numbers, and they need them now, before the next blockbuster barges in. ''Lost World'' certainly got them last weekend -- a record of more than $90 million. And for the blockbusters-in-waiting, lined up like snorting jumbo jets in the narrow alley out back, the summer suddenly seems a lot more spacious. Why? Because they learned that ''Titanic,'' the blowout of blowouts, with its $200 million price tag, won't be plowing into theaters until December. TELEPHONE ABUSE Just Let It Ring The telephone isn't all bad. None of its virtues come to mind, but there must be some. One big irritant: The oily voice comes on -- you can almost see the slicked-back hair, the loud tie -- promising breathlessly that if you buy a certain stock now, you'll be rich within minutes. Guaranteed. The more you balk, the oilier it gets -- flattery, knowing whispers, dramatic pauses, despairing sighs. (You pathetically timid worm, they seem to say.) Don't think for a moment, though, that these are spur-of-the-moment improvisations. Regulators from 20 states filed a flurry of lawsuits last week in an effort to crack down on penny-stock pestering -- a nuisance that has spread recently, feeding on a greed born of the soaring stock market. And the legal papers included dozens of scripts, laying out the whole oily sequence -- pause, flatter and sigh. TOBACCO WARS Blowing Smoke at Joe Camel R. J. Reynolds says its Joe Camel ads are not aimed at young smokers. But a Federal Trade Commission official called the ad campaign ''one of the most effective in decades,'' and the statistics bear that out: In 1987, when the ads first appeared in the United States, 3 percent of under-age smokers chose Camels; by 1993, it was 13.2 percent. And last week, for the first time, the F.T.C. made its displeasure official, accusing Reynolds of violating Federal laws by promoting lethal and addictive products to those not even old enough to buy them. Did this accusation add spice to the talks aimed at pinning down the tobacco industry's long-term liability? Perhaps. Last week antismoking advocates huddled in Chicago -- though not, presumably, in the proverbial smoke-filled room -- and urged negotiators not to rush into any deal. AUTOS Electric Cars, Humming Most people still think of electric cars as a pipe dream. But the cars are most definitely coming. They don't go far enough, you say? Well, their limited range seems to become less limited by the day. At the Tour de Sol recently -- a rally for such pipe dreams -- a converted Geo Metro went 249 miles without recharging. That's a record for ''production models'' -- which means at least five have been sold. More to the point, the average for production models jumped in a year from 141 miles to 168 -- closing in on the power of a tank of gas. But aren't they too slow? Not exactly. At the rally, one electric car was nabbed by police radar. One thing, though: being so quiet, will they sneak up on us, programmed as we are to listen, not always look, at intersections? Some are equipped with a pedestrian warning signal, but the driver must activate it. CAREER CHANGES Instant Journalist It was one of the more intriguing midcareer corrections, right up there with Sol Wachtler's segue from judge to felon, or Ronald Reagan's leap from Hollywood to the White House. Yes, when Susan Molinari, rising Republican star, turned her back on the political world -- for the moment, at least -- to become a CBS newscaster, some ungenerous souls pointed out that she sorely lacked journalistic credentials. But they were ignoring a central modern truth: a celebrity is a celebrity, period. If Michael Jordan turned up on the happy-talk news with one of those cute weather maps and told us it would snow tomorrow, we'd dig out the boots and shovels in a second. The question is: If snow falls on Republicans, will Ms. Molinari tell it like it is? And speaking of career switches: Jules Feiffer, indelibly linked with The Village Voice, left the paper last week. No, he wasn't downsized, but his paycheck would have been -- from $75,000 a year to zero -- even as the paper kept running his cartoons. BANKING, JUST BANKING Farewell, Cash-Flow Sonata Why would someone play a piano in a bank? It makes no sense, no sense at all. A bank is about money; music is about -- well, it's not about money. Harrumph. An official at Republic National's World Trade Center branch put it succinctly: ''This is a bank. It's not a concert hall.'' Yes, yes, a pianist named Anthony Polistina did delight bank customers there for 20 years, did add a multitude of soothing curves to an increasingly straight-ahead world, but that was clearly an aberration, an oversight. And last week Republic straightened out that oversight, banishing Mr. Polistina and his music to make way for new A.T.M.'s. There were cries of protest, of course, with customers circulating petitions and some even closing their accounts. But they just don't understand progress.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 French Left Is Victorious In Elections for Parliament French voters gave the Socialists and their allies a victory in parliamentary elections, rejecting President Jacques Chirac's austerity policies. Mr. Chirac had called the vote a year ahead of schedule, gambling that voters would allow his conservative coalition to continue cutting budgets to qualify France for a common European currency. Instead, the left won overwhelming support by promising to reduce France's 12.8 percent unemployment rate. A1 Albright Opens Link to Bosnia With Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright presiding, Croatia reopened a bridge to Bosnia in an important, if largely symbolic, step to comply with the Balkan peace accords. The ceremony was part of Ms. Albright's tour through the region to press leaders to live up to their commitments. It included stops yesterday in the Serbian-controlled part of Bosnia, making her the highest American official to visit there. A3

headline: Regulatory Hurdles in an AT&T Deal With SBC
summary: If last week's premature disclosure of merger talks between the AT&T Corporation and SBC Communications Inc. was an attempt to float a trial balloon, it is fair to say the balloon got shot out of the sky. Lawyers, lawmakers and lobbyists were almost unanimous in predicting that such a deal would never pass regulatory muster. Harold H. Greene, the Federal judge who issued the landmark ruling that broke up AT&T's Bell System in 1984, said in an interview, ''I don't think there is a great deal of competition in either local or long distance, which should be a prerequisite for recombining the Bell System empire.''

headline: Treasury Bond Prices Move Higher
summary: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, approaching the top of their most recent trading range as two reports on the economy and comments by a Federal Reserve official suggested that the economic growth rate was slowing. In a question-and-answer session after a speech on the prospects for the Alaskan and United States economies in Anchorage, Robert Parry, head of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, remarked that the key to whether the Fed would raise interest rates again ''is clearly whether this economy slows down or not to a sustainable rate of growth.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Dow Continues Its Surge, But Technology Stocks Fall Stock prices generally continued to climb, allowing the Dow Jones industrial average to again rewrite the record books. Despite some weakness in the broader market, particularly in technology stocks, investors' appetite for blue-chip issues was unabated. The Dow industrials gained 60.77 points to close at a record 7,539.27. But the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 10.35 points, to 1,401.69. $(Page D8.$)

headline: Without Saying 'SBC,' AT&T Chairman Applauds a Bell Deal
summary: In an implicit acknowledgment that AT&T may soon merge with a regional Bell telephone company, AT&T's chairman, Robert E. Allen, declared yesterday that such a deal would enhance competition. Mr. Allen declined to confirm reports that his company was negotiating a $50 billion merger with SBC Communications, nor did he mention the company by name. But in a speech to executives in Boston that seemed almost like a wink and a nod, Mr. Allen said that merging long-distance and local phone companies was not ''unthinkable.''

headline: Cable TV Finds A Stamford Home
summary: THE year was 1982 and along the Stamford oceanfront complaints were springing up about the tall building on Harbor Drive that glowed brightly through the night. The tenant, the broadcasting arm of Westinghouse known as Group W, was launching its all-news cable network, Satellite News Channel. ''We were operating 24 hours a day, and we were lit up like a Christmas tree,'' the then-senior executive at Group W, Lloyd A. Werner, recalled. ''We had to hire off-duty cops to shut the blinds at night. People were protesting outside, waving placards.''

headline: SBC Consolidates Accounts at Goodby
summary: SBC Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had consolidated the long-distance service accounts of Southwestern Bell and its recently acquired Pacific Bell unit at Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco. Though billings were not disclosed, estimates ranged from $40 million to as much as $90 million. Selim Bingol, a spokesman for SBC in San Antonio, confirmed reports of the consolidation this week in Advertising Age and Adweek.

headline: Lucent and Philips to Create $2.5 Billion Phone Venture
summary: Seeking to create a global powerhouse in wireless telephones, Lucent Technologies and Philips Electronics of the Netherlands said yesterday that they had agreed to combine their existing telephone-making operations into a new joint venture with about $2.5 billion in annual revenue. At Lucent, officials hope the venture will provide a strategy to revive its troubled consumer products business. For Philips, the deal fills a hole in its product line as the company focuses on consumer electronics.

headline: INSIDE
summary: Megan's Father Remembers Megan Kanka's father described his little girl for the jury that is considering the death penalty for her killer, who asked to live. Page B1. Have Kids, Will (Still) Travel The generation that delayed parenthood into its 30's and 40's is keeping up its busy night life -- with the children in tow. Page C1.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Turkish Leader Resigns After Military Pressure Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan, the first head of an Islamic party to lead Turkey, yielded to pressure from the military and resigned after nearly a year in power. President Suleyman Demirel did not indicate who he would name as Mr. Erbakan's successor. A1

headline: In Unusual Move, F.C.C. Chief Criticizes a Possible Deal
summary: Seeking to scuttle the largest corporate merger in history before it is even formally proposed, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission is expected to declare today that merging the AT&T Corporation with a regional Bell telephone company would be ''unthinkable'' under antitrust laws. ''I don't think people who are exploring deals should be left in the dark about what the Government is likely to say,'' the F.C.C. chairman, Reed E. Hundt, said in an interview yesterday. ''People need to be able to decide which board room discussions are a waste of time.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: U.S. Trade Deficit Grows, But Exports Stay Strong The trade deficit rose 7.8 percent in April, calling new attention to tensions with Japan and China as world leaders gathered for a summit meeting in Denver, left.

headline: AT&T Picks Vice Chairman and Stirs Speculation
summary: In a move that raises a fresh round of questions about the future leadership of the AT&T Corporation, the company yesterday promoted its top lawyer, John D. Zeglis, to vice chairman. Mr. Zeglis, who is 50, will remain AT&T's general counsel and will retain responsibility for the company's corporate strategy, business development, external affairs, and human resources. His wide-ranging portfolio underscores that Mr. Zeglis has emerged as one of AT&T's most powerful executives and perhaps the closest adviser to AT&T's chairman, Robert E. Allen.

headline: SBC Planning Charges Up to $2.3 Billion
summary: SBC Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would take charges of up to $2.3 billion in 1997 in connection with its purchase of Pacific Telesis Group as the combined company, representing the first merger between two regional Bell operating companies and creating the second-largest United States phone company behind the AT&T Corporation, pares operations to improve profit. SBC said $1.6 billion to $1.9 billion of the charges would be taken in the second quarter. Based on 912 million shares outstanding, that would reduce second-quarter results by up to $2.08 a share, resulting in a loss. Additional charges are expected in the second half, with full-year results reduced by up to $2.52 a share.

headline: DIARY
summary: TOBACCO SETTLEMENT A $360 Billion Answer Tobacco companies agreed to a $360 billion product liability settlement with state attorneys general and public health representatives. The agreement is subject to approval in Congress, where a tough fight is expected. President Clinton, whose backing is regarded as crucial, said he would review the pact. Under the deal, smokers would see dire new warnings on cigarette packs, get free medical help to kick the habit and be inundated with nationwide anti-smoking advertising. Tobacco ads would be strictly curbed. In return, tobacco companies and investors would get relief from the uncertainty posed by hundreds of pending lawsuits. The $360 billion would be paid out over 25 years. Tobacco stock prices, up during the week, fell after the deal was announced. THE GLOWING ECONOMY Washington and Wall St. Cheer Economic statistics were so favorable last week that stocks continued their winning ways -- and Washington cheered. In Denver, President Clinton, preparing to open the annual summit meeting of the major industrial nations, boasted, ''We host our partners at a time when America's economy is the healthiest in a generation and the strongest in the world.'' Indeed, if inflation has not been vanquished, it at least appears comatose. The Consumer Price Index rose a barely noticeable one-tenth of 1 percent in May; so far this year it is running at an annual rate of just 1.4 percent. Industrial production rose a strong four-tenths of a percentage point in May, and capacity utilization rose to 83.7 percent. The nation's foreign trade deficit increased 7.8 percent in April, to $8.4 billion, from a revised $7.8 billion in March -- but even that was not as bad as expected, thanks to surging export growth.

headline: DIARY
summary: TOBACCO SETTLEMENT A $360 Billion Answer Tobacco companies agreed to a $360 billion product liability settlement with state attorneys general and public health representatives. The agreement is subject to approval in Congress, where a tough fight is expected. President Clinton, whose backing is regarded as crucial, said he would review the pact. Under the deal, smokers would see dire new warnings on cigarette packs, get free medical help to kick the habit and be inundated with nationwide anti-smoking advertising. Tobacco ads would be strictly curbed. In return, tobacco companies and investors would get relief from the uncertainty posed by hundreds of pending lawsuits. The $360 billion would be paid out over 25 years. Tobacco stock prices, up during the week, fell after the deal was announced. THE GLOWING ECONOMY Washington and Wall St. Cheer Economic statistics were so favorable last week that stocks continued their winning ways -- and Washington cheered. In Denver, President Clinton, preparing to open the annual summit meeting of the major industrial nations, boasted, ''We host our partners at a time when America's economy is the healthiest in a generation and the strongest in the world.'' Indeed, if inflation has not been vanquished, it at least appears comatose. The Consumer Price Index rose a barely noticeable one-tenth of 1 percent in May; so far this year it is running at an annual rate of just 1.4 percent. Industrial production rose a strong four-tenths of a percentage point in May, and capacity utilization rose to 83.7 percent. The nation's foreign trade deficit increased 7.8 percent in April, to $8.4 billion, from a revised $7.8 billion in March -- but even that was not as bad as expected, thanks to surging export growth.

headline: Left Out of Succession Fight, A Rising Star Defects to Upstart
summary: What's the market value of being an AT&T alumnus? Tomorrow, at 9:30 A.M., when shares of Qwest Communications International Inc. begin trading in an initial public offering on the Nasdaq exchange, Joseph P. Nacchio will find out.

headline: Justice Dept. Deals Setback To Ameritech Long Distance
summary: In a major setback to expansion-minded local phone companies, the Justice Department recommended yesterday that the Ameritech Corporation be barred from offering long-distance service in Michigan. The department said Ameritech had failed to adequately open its existing local market to justify being allowed into a new one, though Joel I. Klein, the chief of the antitrust division, noted approvingly that ''local competition is beginning to take root in Michigan.''

headline: The Question of Succession
summary: With AT&T's ambitious merger plans apparently on hold, the nation's No. 1 long-distance carrier now faces an acute management problem. If AT&T had merged with SBC Communications, people familiar with the discussions said, SBC's chairman, Edward E. Whitacre, would likely have become chief executive of the combined company. That would have elbowed aside John R. Walter, the president of AT&T, whom the company's chairman, Robert E. Allen, recruited as his heir designate last November.

headline: INSIDE
summary: Phone Merger Said to Be Off AT&T ended its merger talks with SBC after regulatory criticism and internal disagreement about how to structure a deal, executives involved in the talks said. Page 35. Albright Visits Vietnam The Secretary of State tried to focus on the future, but her trip also rekindled bitter memories. Both sides were symbolized by a memento she got from the ''Hanoi Hilton.'' Page 4. Dissident Freed in Congo Congo's leading opposition politician was freed after a night's detention, which pointed to a growing confrontation between the new Government and opposition parties. Page 3. Serb Seized for War Crimes Investigators for a war-crimes tribunal made their first arrest, of a Serb charged in a massacre of 261 patients at a Croatian hospital, and took him to the Netherlands. Page 5.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL 3-5 Serb War Crimes Suspect Is Arrested in Slavonia A Serb charged in the 1991 massacre of 261 patients in a Croatian hospital in Vukovar was arrested and taken to The Hague by investigators with the international tribunal for war crimes in the former Yugoslavia. The arrest took place in Eastern Slavonia, a part of Croatia now administered by the United Nations, and was the first made by the tribunal's own investigators. 5

headline: AT&T Is Said to Break Off Merger Talks With SBC
summary: The AT&T Corporation broke off its merger talks with SBC Communications yesterday after a hailstorm of criticism from regulators and mounting internal disagreement about how to structure a deal, according to several executives involved in the talks. ''The deal is totally dead,'' said one executive familiar with the talks, who insisted on anonymity.

headline: Wall Street? Right Over There Through the Trees
summary: A COUPLE of hundred feet down the road from Orem's Diner, a Wilton mainstay since 1921, coffee, sugar and cocoa are changing hands. So are grain and pork bellies. In fact, since January, traders at the Louis Dreyfus Holding Company Inc., have been running a mini agricultural exchange out of an inconspicuous office building on Route 7. It's a long way from the World Trade Center, not to mention South Wacker Drive and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, and ''the trading that goes on is pretty low key,'' says Bruce Radley, a Louis Dreyfus vice president. Still, what transpires in the laid back Wilton office, he says, can flood the floors of major commodities exchanges with yelling and frenetic hand signals.

headline: The SBC Deal Shelved, What Tack For AT&T?
summary: For the AT&T Corporation, the big question is: Now what? On Friday, the nation's largest telephone company suspended negotiations to merge with SBC Communications -- talks that AT&T never formally acknowledged, though they consumed the company's top executives and drew fierce fire from Washington regulators.

headline: For Stocks, Quarter Was One of the Most Bullish
summary: Three months ago, investors were worried about the Big One. The stock market was sinking fast, headed toward its worst setback since 1990. And bearish strategists, many of whom had long forecast an end to one of the greatest bull markets in history, were gloating.

headline: AT&T Long-Distance Rates Cut and MCI Joins in Move
summary: Fulfilling a promise it made in May, the AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it would reduce its basic long-distance rates by 5 percent for day and evening calls and 15 percent for night and weekend calls. AT&T's new rates, which go into effect immediately, represent the company's first major rate decrease in five years. The MCI Communications Corporation immediately matched AT&T's cuts, while the Sprint Corporation said it was still deliberating how to respond.

headline: Stymied, SBC Seeks to Void Portion of Law
summary: One week after being rebuffed from entering the long-distance telephone business, SBC Communications Inc. sued the Government yesterday seeking to overturn a critical provision of the Telecommunications Act of 1996. In the lawsuit, which was filed in Federal District Court in Dallas, SBC contended that the act was unconstitutional because it prohibits SBC and the five other regional Bell telephone companies from offering long-distance service until they have opened up their local monopolies to competition.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Limited NATO Expansion Gets France's Blessing France said it would go along with President Clinton's wish to limit NATO expansion to Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary. But it reiterated its opinion that Romania and Slovenia fulfilled the conditions for joining the alliance. A1

headline: Blair Gains Tax Cut for Business, But the Rest of Britain Must Wait
summary: The new Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair gained passage of its first budget in Parliament today, giving top priority to a tax cut that will give British big business the lowest tax rate of any Western industrial country. In that way, business was reassured by the governing Labor Party that it would remain the locomotive of an expanding economy, while the middle class waits for tax relief and the working class fares only a little better. Indeed, many people will find they are paying more in indirect taxes under the new budget and getting less in tax relief for things like mortagage payments.

headline: AT&T to Join With Italians In 2 Regions
summary: AT&T and the Italian phone company, Stet S.p.A., seeking to better their odds in the emerging global telecommunications race, announced a broad agreement today to cooperate in Europe and Latin America. In Europe, Stet -- short for Societa Finanziaria Telefonica -- will enter a joint venture that AT&T has with Unisource, a consortium of phone companies from Sweden, Switzerland and the Netherlands. In Latin America, Stet and AT&T will form a 50-50 venture to run two operating companies, one specializing in global links for multinational corporations and the second to provide links for local phone companies.

headline: Trade Surplus Rose in May, Japan Reports
summary: Japan's current account surplus more than doubled in May from a year earlier, the Government said today. The increase in the current account -- the nation's broadest measure of trade in goods and services -- was slightly less than expected. Still, it was the fourth year-to-year gain in the last five months, and economists expect the surplus to soar at least through the end of the year despite a recent weakening in the dollar against the yen.

headline: BellSouth Seeks Added Florida Service
summary: The BellSouth Corporation said today that it had applied to begin offering long-distance phone service to its customers in Florida, the fifth state in the company's nine-state territory where it has made such a filing. The application was filed with the Florida Public Service Commission, which will review it before passing it on to the United States Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission. Whatever the Florida commission rules in its review, the final decision on whether BellSouth will be able to offer the service rests with the F.C.C.

headline: A Weak Antitrust Nominee
summary: The next head of the Justice Department's antitrust division will have a lot to say about whether the 1996 Telecommunications Act breaks the monopoly chokehold that Bell companies exert over local phone customers. He will rule on mergers among telecommunications companies and advise the Federal Communications Commission on applications by Bell companies to enter long-distance markets. Thus it is disheartening and disqualifying that President Clinton's nominee, Joel Klein, is scheduled to come up for confirmation today in the Senate with a record that suggests he might knuckle under to the powerful Bell companies and the politicians who do their bidding. Senators Bob Kerrey, Ernest Hollings and Byron Dorgan have threatened to block the vote today and put off until next week a final determination of Mr. Klein's fate. But the Administration would do its own telecommunications policy a favor by withdrawing the nomination and finding a stronger, more aggressive successor.

headline: After the Vote, Brighter Mexican Prospects
summary: Despite victories by many populist candidates who may put pressure on the Mexican Government to alter its orthodox economic policies, the balloting that ended seven decades of one-party rule here this week left many investors more encouraged about the nation's economic prospects than they were before the election. The hope is that Mexico's more open economy will be matched by a more open political system relying on checks and balances. ''We're very enthusiastic about Mexico now,'' said Robert Berges, Latin American strategist at Merrill Lynch, which has recommended shifting new investments from Brazil to Mexico. ''We're expecting a boom.''

headline: Report of Loss Sends Shares Of MCI Lower
summary: Underscoring the difficulty that long-distance telephone companies have faced trying to offer local service, the MCI Communications Corporation lost more than 17 percent of its market value yesterday after the company announced late Thursday that its local telephone operation could lose as much as $800 million this year -- twice the loss the company had previously forecast. The announcement, and yesterday's selloff, also raised new concerns about MCI's pending $24 billion acquisition by British Telecommunications P.L.C., whose American depository receipts lost more than 6 percent of their value yesterday. While few financial analysts expected the developments to scuttle the deal, some expect that British Telecom will try to renegotiate the financial terms of the deal to reflect MCI's reduced earnings.

headline: Big Wall St. Banks Gallop In, Guns Ablaze
summary: THE 7,000 metalworkers were full of righteous rage on March 25 as they marched past the headquarters of Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest bank. Roaring protests against ''Wild West'' bankers and ''Las Vegas'' tactics, union leaders accused the bank of destroying social peace by promoting a cold-blooded hostile takeover. The galvanizing event for the protest had occurred a week earlier: the Krupp-Hoesch consortium, Germany's second-largest steel manufacturer, had mounted an unprecedented hostile takeover attempt against Germany's top steel company, Thyssen A.G. Never before had Germany seen a hostile takeover even close to that magnitude, or one aimed so clearly at eliminating thousands of jobs and shutting down redundant factories. Even worse, in the minds of union workers, this affront had been supported and financed by two pillars of Germany's own financial establishment, Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank.

headline: Warburg Joint Venture With Firm in Russia
summary: SBC Warburg and Brunswick Investments Ltd. of Russia said yesterday that they had created a joint venture, Brunswick Warburg, to specialize in the Russian banking and brokerage market. SBC Warburg, the investment banking division of the Swiss Bank Corporation, will have a 50 percent stake in the venture. Brunswick, Russia's leading brokerage house, and its management will own the rest. Other financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Swiss Bank Makes Alliance in Japan
summary: The Swiss Bank Corporation and the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd. said today that they had formed an alliance under which each would take a 3 percent stake in the other. The two banks will concentrate on asset management and investment banking and plan to set up several joint ventures in those businesses.

headline: AT&T's New No. 2 Is Without Rivals
summary: John D. Zeglis is generally considered bright, articulate and competitive by people in the telecommunications industry. As of about 3:50 P.M. yesterday, he is also considered the clear No. 2 executive at the AT&T Corporation and the only insider with a legitimate chance to succeed Robert E. Allen as chief executive of the country's biggest telecommunications company. Mr. Zeglis, 50, whose litany of titles is almost as long as a list of AT&T's troubles, is finally without rivals. The ouster yesterday of John R. Walter, the former publishing executive who left after barely eight months as the company's president, leaves Mr. Zeglis near the end of a meteoric corporate ascent.

headline: After 9 Months, AT&T President Quits Under Pressure
summary: Barely nine months after he was recruited to lead the nation's largest telephone company, John R. Walter resigned abruptly yesterday as president and chief operating officer of the AT&T Corporation. Mr. Walter, whose contract called for him to succeed Robert E. Allen as chief executive next January, quit under pressure after AT&T's board told him that they had lost faith in his performance and that he would not get the top job.

headline: Disdaining Regulators, Whitacre Carves Out SBC Empire
summary: Most businessmen in this South Texas city were still contemplating their morning coffee. But Ed Whitacre was in full cry, excoriating what he called the Federal Government's unfair treatment of the local telephone industry. Then his own phone rang. Striding across his Texas-size office here, Mr. Whitacre picked up the receiver, listened intently and hung up without a word. Only a smile spreading across his craggy face hinted at the story: An appeals court in St. Louis had just thrown out the Federal Communications Commission's rules governing competition in the local phone market -- the same rules he had just been inveighing against.

headline: Privately held MacManus competes against publicly traded rivals for acquisitions.
summary: A year after the formation of MacManus Group as the world's ninth-largest agency company, it has made progress on several fronts: $500 million in billings gains by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications, a return overseas for N. W. Ayer & Partners, growth in specialty units like media services. And if at first MacManus does not succeed in solving problems in realms that range from interactive media to improving its creative output, executives have demonstrated a willingness to try, try again.

headline: BellSouth Move In Long Distance
summary: The BellSouth Corporation said this week that South Carolina regulators had approved its bid to begin long-distance service there. BellSouth, which is based in Atlanta, said the South Carolina Public Service Commission had unanimously concluded that BellSouth's entry into the long-distance market was in the best interest of consumers. BellSouth said it would ask the Federal Communications Commission for permission to begin service in the state.

headline: Courtney Walsh, Bradford Darby
summary: Courtney Anne Walsh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter D. Walsh of New York, was married yesterday to Bradford Thayer Darby, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis E. Darby of Whitefield, N.H. The Rev. John J. Fitzgerald, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Union Chapel on Shelter Island, N.Y. The bride, 27, and the bridegroom, 31, graduated from St. Lawrence University, she cum laude.

headline: No Clear Outlook From Tobacco Settlement
summary: FOR the tobacco industry, how good is last month's deal to settle most of the legal and regulatory conflicts that have long depressed its stocks? Health advocates, lobbying in Washington to include more restrictions and bigger payments, are certain that the proposed settlement is far too sweet. From Wall Street's perspective, though, there are still so many unknowns that it would be foolish for investors in the industry to light up victory cigars. Indeed, after tobacco stocks rose repeatedly on reports that a settlement was being negotiated, they fell after the deal, and, despite a modest recent rebound, have not regained their earlier levels.

headline: 7 Wireless Allies to Create Nationwide Mobile Network
summary: With the aim of creating a new transcontinental wireless-telephone system, seven regional wireless companies from the United States and Canada plan to announce an alliance today that would eventually allow customers to use the same mobile phone from Portland, Me., to Portland, Ore. The seven companies, including the Omnipoint Corporation in the New York area, are banding together in part because each has built its network around a digital wireless technology known as GSM, for global system for mobile communications.

headline: Executive Changes
summary: THE LIMITED INC., Columbus, Ohio, named Robert Bernard president and chief executive of Limited Stores, a chain of women's clothing stores. LIZ CLAIBORNE INC., New York, named Gaetano Sallorenzo president of Liz Claiborne Europe.

headline: Tracy Smith, Scott Fauver
summary: Tracy Leigh Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. William Smith Jr. of Norwich, N.Y., was married yesterday to Scott Clement Fauver, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John K. Fauver of Perrysburg, Ohio. The Rev. John R. Roos performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Cooperstown, N.Y. Mrs. Fauver is the director of marketing and international licensing for the Ralph Lauren Home Collection in New York. She graduated from Hamilton College. Her father is the the chairman of McLaren Engines, the automotive research and development company in Livonia, Mich., and owns Smith-Norwich Inc., automobile dealerships, in Norwich and Cooperstown. Her mother, Patricia Manley Smith, is the president of the Friends of Bassett, the fund-raising arm of Bassett Healthcare in Cooperstown, which operates a group of hospitals and community health-care centers in New York State.

headline: Rejection May Show Bells Way to Long Distance
summary: When is a rejection not a rebuff? Today, the Federal Communications Commission is expected to reject Ameritech's bid to offer long-distance service in its region, according to officials familiar with the decision. But far from a rebuff, the decision could be a step forward for the regional Bell company, which has been lobbying since 1993 to get into this lucrative market.

headline: Outrage on Nazi-era assets has not hurt Swiss banks' business.
summary: DESPITE an international black eye for their handling of the accounts of victims of the Nazis, the big three Swiss banks are staging a remarkable recovery from the worst year in their history. Last week, the Swiss Bank Corporation said that its profit surged 84 percent in the first half of 1997, to 1.326 billion Swiss francs ($872 million). Earlier, the Union Bank of Switzerland reported a 67 percent rise in first-half earnings, to 1.856 billion francs ($1.2 billion). Though Credit Suisse, the largest of the three in terms of assets, will not formally report its results until next week, it disclosed a 70 percent increase in first-half net income, to 1.41 billion francs ($928 million), last week when it announced a proposed $8.8 billion takeover of the Winterthur Insurance Company.

headline: F.C.C. Rejects Ameritech's Long-Distance Bid
summary: Federal regulators, as expected, today rejected the bid by the Ameritech Corporation to become the first Baby Bell to offer its customers long-distance phone service. In doing so, however, the Federal Communications Commission tried to spell out how the Bell companies could qualify in the future to enter the long-distance market.

headline: Saatchi & Saatchi, its solo hopes dashed, says no thanks to a role in the Bell Atlantic chorus.
summary: IN another surprising shift in how the competitive telecommunications industry pitches products and services, the Bell Atlantic Corporation and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York said yesterday that they had agreed to part ways. The reason for the abrupt, unexpected parting was that Bell Atlantic -- unlike other marketers in telecommunications and other fields undergoing rapid changes -- had decided against reducing the number of agencies that handle its accounts.

headline: British Telecom's Chairman Makes Fateful Trans-Atlantic Pledge to MCI
summary: Sometimes the most tortuous negotiations can be teased along with a grand gesture by a single person. Sir Iain Vallance, the chairman of British Telecommunications, made such a gesture last week during a pivotal moment in the talks to salvage his company's acquisition of the MCI Communications Corporation. MCI had agreed to accept a 22 percent reduction in the value of the deal. But the company's directors wanted a guarantee that the transaction would finally close without further snags, according to people with knowledge of the talks.

headline: New-Media Executives Often Lose Their Way
summary: For nearly two years, Stephen A. Weiswasser has worked in Los Angeles but lived in Washington. The coast-to-coast commute has been brutal, but he said he was determined not to uproot his family for his job. Today, that looks like a shrewd move. The company Mr. Weiswasser joined, Americast, has shut down two divisions, laid off more than a dozen of its 100 employees, and throttled back its ambitions to develop a futuristic television service for its five telephone company backers.

headline: Cash-Depleted Mexican Bank To Be Acquired by Citicorp
summary: Citicorp plans to acquire Confia S.A., a cash-short Mexican bank, in a transaction valued at as much as $245 million. Under the agreement, Citicorp will pay $45 million in cash to Abaco Grupo Financiero S.A., Confia's parent, and provide as much as $200 million in fresh capital to the bank, Winston Lacayo, director of investment banking for SBC Warburg, said today. SBC Warburg served as the agent on the sale.

headline: Chief of Hughes Again Emerges as a Top Candidate to Head AT&T
summary: Seven weeks after embarking on yet another search for a chief executive, AT&T is once again closely scrutinizing C. Michael Armstrong, chief executive of Hughes Electronics, according to several executives close to the deliberations. Mr. Armstrong, who was a candidate during the AT&T Corporation's last executive search, has emerged as one of the top outside contenders to succeed the company's chairman, Robert E. Allen, several executives close to AT&T said yesterday. But he still faces strong competition from John D. Zeglis, AT&T's vice chairman and a popular internal candidate.

headline: Accounts
summary: * TDK Europe, Luxembourg, to Doner Cardwell Hawkins, London, a unit of W. B. Doner & Co., to handle its pan-European brand image account, previously at Havas Advertising's Euro RSCG unit in Paris. Billings were estimated at $16 million.

headline: Market Place; Petrofina of Belgium tiptoes into Big Board trading.
summary: PETROFINA S.A., the Belgium-based oil and petrochemical company, made its debut on the New York Stock Exchange earlier this month, at a time when the few analysts who have followed the company are beginning to warm up to its stock. ''It was our surprise stock,'' said Susan Graham, an analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company in London, who has followed the company for many years. ''It's been a pleasant surprise.''

headline: Eloise Reddy, Paul Donofrio
summary: Ellen Louise Reddy and Paul Michael Donofrio, financial executives, were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. John Bucki performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in New York.

headline: SASSABY DEAL OPENS MASS MARKET TO ESTEE LAUDER
summary: The Estee Lauder Companies agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Sassaby Inc. in a move aimed at expanding its line of cosmetics aimed at preteen and teen-age girls. Terms were not disclosed. Sassaby owns the cosmetics brand Jane, which tries to appeal to 12- to 19-year-olds in the United States. Jane includes face, lip, eye and nail products. The acquisition will move Estee Lauder into the mass market, Peter Schaeffer, an analyst at SBC Warburg Dillon Read Inc., said. Jane products, all of which cost $2.99, are sold in major drugstore and discount chains. Sassaby, based in Hunt Valley, Md., has annual retail sales of $30 million to $50 million. New York-based Estee Lauder is one of the world's leading makers of skin care products, makeup and fragrances.

headline: SBC to Sell Stakes In 2 Cable Systems
summary: Prime Cable said yesterday that it would acquire, with the backing of the Carlyle Group, two cable television stakes from SBC Communications for $887 million. Prime said it would buy a 94.6 percent stake from SBC Communications in two cable systems in the Washington metropolitan area.

headline: Offerings Of Equity Scheduled This Week
summary: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week: American Italian Pasta Co., Excelsior Springs, Mo., an initial public offering of 5.9 million class A shares, 4.7 million in the United States and Canada. Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Co.

headline: Republic Selling Security Unit To Ameritech for $610 Million
summary: The Ameritech Corporation said today that it would buy the security business of Republic Industries for $610 million, giving Ameritech more residential customers and a wider reach for its fast-growing theft-protection unit. The purchase, which is subject to regulatory approval, would add 310,000 clients to Ameritech's 566,000 security customers, making Ameritech's Securitylink No. 2 behind ADT, the nation's largest security company, as it gains 35 markets in the Midwest and Southeast.

headline: For Salomon, as Adviser, Millions Plus Revenge
summary: The only company with as much to gain from Worldcom's $30 billion bid for MCI as Worldcom itself may be Salomon Brothers. For Salomon, which is advising Worldcom on its audacious offer for MCI Communications, the deal represents a chance to stake its claim as the premier investment firm to the deal-happy telecommunications industry. It would also be sweet revenge for the $100 million in losses that Salomon's trading desk suffered when the value of MCI's existing deal with British Telecommunications was revised downward in August.

headline: AT&T Talking To GTE About Teaming Up, Executives Say
summary: Seeking a partner to invigorate its torpid local telephone strategy, the AT&T Corporation is discussing a merger with the GTE Corporation, executives close to the talks said yesterday. A deal to merge the two companies could be worth $48 billion or more and would be the largest corporate takeover in American history, dwarfing Worldcom Inc.'s unsolicited $30 billion bid, announced last week, to acquire the MCI Communications Corporation.

headline: SPURNED TAKEOVER OFFER LIFTS SHARES OF CORESTATES
summary: Shares of the Corestates Financial Corporation traded higher yesterday on speculation that the Mellon Bank Corporation's rebuffed bid could set Corestates in play for a takeover. ''People are speculating that Mellon hasn't gone away,'' said Anthony Davis, a bank analyst at SBC Warburg Dillon Read. Shares of Corestates rose $1.4375 yesterday, to $73.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Mellon's shares went the other direction, slipping $1.9375, to $52.9375. Based on the rejected offer of $88 a share, or $18 billion, a merger between Corestates, based in Philadelphia, and Mellon, based in Pittsburgh, would have been the largest bank merger in history.

headline: Offerings Set For Equities During Week
summary: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week: Advanced Energy Industries Inc., Fort Collins, Colo., 2.5 million shares. UBS Securities Inc.

headline: Worldcom Fancies Itself Muffler of the Local Bells
summary: When Bernard J. Ebbers, the chairman of Worldcom Inc., wanted to convince MCI Communications shareholders on Friday that his company would be a better mate for MCI than British Telecommunications P.L.C., the main reason he gave was that Worldcom owns local phone networks around the United States, while British Telecom does not. Lost in the din over the potential implications of combining the No. 2 and No. 4 long-distance carriers is the fact that the $33.9 billion MCI-Worldcom transaction that Mr. Ebbers proposed could create the most significant new competitor in the market for local telephone service, still the largely unchallenged domain of the five regional Bell companies.

headline: Local Bells Win Another Victory To Block Rivals
summary: The plans of long-distance telephone companies to get into local telephone markets were dealt a major blow yesterday as a Federal appeals court threw out regulations that were intended to foster competition with local telephone incumbents. The ruling, by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, in St. Louis, stemmed from the court's decision in July to strike down key elements of the Federal Communications Commission's rules for opening up local telephone markets. Yesterday's ruling was a further setback to the commission's agenda for increasing competition just as its chairman, Reed E. Hundt, prepares to step down.

headline: Suzanne Meadow, Peter Glaser
summary: Suzanne Meadow, a daughter of Marla W. Frankel of Larchmont, N.Y., and David Meadow of Victor, Mont., is to be married this afternoon to Peter Michael Glaser, a son of Carole Glaser of Southbury, Conn., and Dr. Howard S. Glaser of Newtown, Conn. Town Justice Harold S. Klein of Greenburg, N.Y., is to officiate at Estherwood, a historic house on the grounds of the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The bride, 31, is the development manager in New York for the American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra. She graduated from Cornell University. Her father retired as a senior vice president of Drexel Burnham Lambert, the New York securities firm. Her mother is a broker at Burbank Whittemore, a real estate company in Larchmont.

headline: AT&T Is Expected to Pick Chief From Hughes
summary: The AT&T Corporation plans to wrap up its three-month search for a chairman and chief executive on Monday by selecting C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman and chief executive of the Hughes Electronics Corporation, an executive close to the one of the companies said yesterday. The executive, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said Michael T. Smith, the vice chairman of Hughes, is expected to replace Mr. Armstrong. Mr. Smith is a brother of John F. Smith Jr., the chairman and chief executive of Hughes's parent, the General Motors Corporation.

headline: Praising the Power of Intel
summary: THE Intel Corporation's ubiquitous slogan -- ''Intel Inside'' -- could just as well apply to the November batch of personal-finance magazines as it does to personal computers. The semiconductor giant is the object of mostly affectionate articles in Worth, Money and Kiplinger's, and the Oct. 27 issue of Fortune.

headline: Once AT&T Names New Leader, Climb Back to Top Will Be Tough
summary: When the AT&T Corporation names a new leader, it will be a long-awaited move in the company's effort to regain unquestioned leadership of one of America's fastest-growing industries. The company, which hired a presumed heir apparent for the top job last year only to reject him nine months later, is now widely expected to appoint C. Michael Armstrong, the head of Hughes Electronics, as AT&T's new chairman and chief executive. That announcement could come as soon as today.

headline: A Late Starter, AT&T Is at Sea In Global Race
summary: The AT&T Corporation, readying itself for its third change of top management in the last two years, remains conspicuously adrift in global waters. The telecom battles in the United States have focused on the shifting boundaries between local, long-distance and wireless service, and European companies are stalking each other's once-protected geographic territories. But the big game on both sides of the Atlantic involves setting up global networks that conveniently offer all services to far-flung multinational corporations.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Bailout of Auto Maker Lifts South Korean Market The South Korean Government's decision to take over Kia Motors, a big auto maker in which Ford owns a stake, sent stock prices to their biggest one-day gain and halted a decline in the nation's currency. But economists cautioned that a number of broader problems remained. [Page D7.]

headline: Pointcast Names Chief Executive
summary: David Dorman, the former chairman and chief executive of Pacific Bell, has agreed to become the chief executive of Pointcast Inc., the Silicon Valley start-up company that delivers news and information to more than one million personal computers. Mr. Dorman was the only senior manager from Pacific Bell to retain a job when the regional Bell's parent company, Pacific Telesis, was acquired by SBC Communications Inc. for $16.7 billion earlier this year.

headline: DIARY
summary: TRADE The Chinese Connection The United States trade deficit deepened in August to $10.4 billion, the widest gap since January, driven by a record $5.2 billion gap with China. Benefiting from a strong economy and a higher dollar, American importers have been stocking up on Chinese toys and decorations for the Christmas shopping season. William M. Daley, the Secretary of Commerce, referring specifically to China, said, ''The mounting trade deficit remains a major concern for this Administration.'' BOEING Business Is Good. That's Bad. Boeing stunned Wall Street by announcing it was suffering from too much of a good thing. Deluged with orders for its commercial planes, the company has not been able to keep up, despite hiring 14,500 workers this year. Earlier, it halted production of 747's for 20 workdays and 737's for 25 workdays because of parts shortages and other production problems. Now Boeing, the leading aerospace manufacturer and the biggest United States exporter, says it will take a charge against earnings of $1.6 billion for the third quarter, resulting in a loss, and a $1 billion charge for the fourth quarter.

headline: Will Wall Street Now Have to Pull In Its Horns?
summary: The not-quite-finished office building in Stamford, Conn., is an apt symbol of Wall Street's health and boundless optimism. It cost some $200 million to build, contains an up-to-date trading floor and by year-end will have created some 2,200 new jobs for the region. For SBC Warburg Dillon Read, the building's proud owner, the project's scale signals the firm's ambitions as an aspiring Wall Street powerhouse, despite its site an hour out of New York.

headline: U.S. Opposes Application By BellSouth
summary: Dealing another blow to the ambitions of the regional Bell telephone companies, the Justice Department recommended yesterday that the BellSouth Corporation not be allowed to offer long-distance service in South Carolina. Weighing the third application by a Baby Bell to enter the $80 billion long-distance arena, the department said that BellSouth had not done enough to open its local network to warrant permission to compete for the customers of the AT&T Corporation and the other large long-distance carriers.

headline: Metro Business; Bell Atlantic Applies For Long Distance
summary: The Bell Atlantic Corporation says it has applied to New York to offer long-distance telephone service, seeking to be the first regional Bell company to offer such service. Bell Atlantic is the largest local phone company. It merged in August with the Nynex Corporation. The utility is the fourth Baby Bell to apply to provide service in the $70 billion-a-year long-distance market.

headline: Habitats/303 Park Avenue South; Three Men in a Loft Find A 4th to Share the Rent
summary: LEE W. HIGGINS'S first Manhattan apartment was a one-bedroom divvied up for three in an Upper East Side doorman building. ''One guy lived in the dining room, with no window,'' Mr. Higgins said. ''We split the living room in half for my bedroom.''

headline: Nissan's Profits Jump as Exports Offset Slump in Japan
summary: The Nissan Motor Company said today that pretax profit rose 47 percent in the fiscal first half as cost reductions and higher exports offset a slump in Japanese sales. Nissan, Japan's second-largest auto manufacturer, is fighting to increase domestic sales by focusing on the booming market for sport utility vehicles and station wagons, where it has trailed its rivals, including the Toyota Motor Corporation, the nation's biggest car company.

headline: A Pragmatic Agenda For Residential Service
summary: Bernard J. Ebbers, the president of Worldcom Inc., has built his company into a powerhouse and a Wall Street favorite by sidestepping the dregs of the telecommunications industry -- the messy, less profitable business of catering to residential phone customers. Yet Mr. Ebbers spoke eloquently yesterday of how Worldcom's $36.5 billion merger with the MCI Communications Corporation would create a ''stronger, more capable player'' in the industry, an aggressive innovator that would certainly ''benefit American consumers.''

headline: Stocks Stage a Retreat, With the Dow Falling by 28.73
summary: Most stock indexes fell yesterday, as continued concerns about slower growth in international markets, particularly Southeast Asia, erased early gains. The declines came despite improved performance yesterday in Brazil and South Korea, two markets that were under pressure last week.

headline: In MCI-Worldcom Theory, New View of Competition
summary: Consolidation is good for competition. That is the conventional wisdom emerging within the telecommunications industry, and it seems to contradict the goals of the Telecommunications Act of 1996. Or does it?

headline: Calmer Trading Overseas Helps Bolster U.S. Stocks
summary: Stocks ended higher yesterday, bolstered in part by calmer markets overseas and by expectations that economic slowdowns in Asia and Latin America would keep United States interest rates low. Such expectations overcame, at least for a day, concerns on how the overseas turmoil will hurt profits of American companies. Investors confidence was heightened in part by comments from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. He told the House Banking Committee that the problems in Asia and other regions would not threaten prosperity in the United States and could even help hold down inflation.

headline: For Vencor, Ambition and a Sagging Stock
summary: VENCOR INC., the nation's largest operator of long-term hospitals and the second-largest operator of nursing homes, is surrounded by a big question mark. With more than $3 billion in revenues this year, Vencor is widely acclaimed as innovative, well-run and highly diversified. Nevertheless, investors slammed its stock in the third week of October when Vencor said it expected lower earnings for the fourth quarter of 1997 and the first quarter of 1998 and also reported slightly disappointing results for this year's third quarter.

headline: Merrill to Acquire Mercury, British Firm, for $5.3 Billion
