summary: In the most expensive acquisition ever in the money management business, Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Mercury Asset Management Group P.L.C. of Britain, one of Europe's largest investment firms, for about $5.3 billion in cash. The deal reflects a push by financial service companies, including banks, brokerage firms and investment companies, to get in on the rapidly growing money management business, in which the pace of consolidation -- particularly cross-border deals -- has been accelerating.

headline: Chairman of RJR Food Unit Will Retire
summary: H. John Greeniaus, the chairman and chief executive of the food subsidiary of RJR Nabisco, will retire at the end of the year because of a health problem, the company announced late yesterday, stunning analysts who were still at their desks. He will be replaced by James Kilts, who was most recently an executive vice president of the Philip Morris Companies, in charge of the Kraft Foods Worldwide division. The RJR food business, Nabisco Holdings, has had a difficult year; sales of its Snackwell's products and weaknesses in other foods have caused a softness in the company's earnings growth. In the third quarter, the company's earnings rose 15 percent as it reduced costs to offset sales declines of 2.2 percent in the United States and flat sales abroad. For the year, earnings per share are expected to rise 14 percent. While investors have been unimpressed with these results, Mr. Greeniaus's retirement did not seem in the offing.

headline: The No. 1 Customer: Sorry, It Isn't You
summary: THE information revolution arrived at Merrill Lynch on Feb. 7, 1995. That day, two of Merrill's technology chiefs suggested to Edward L. Goldberg, the firm's executive vice president for operations, that the $25 billion brokerage giant find an outside company to run its communications network.

headline: Banks in Japan Struggle Despite Cash Aid
summary: Japanese banks found it increasingly difficult and expensive to borrow money today despite an enormous injection of cash into the troubled financial system by the Bank of Japan. The problems faced by even relatively healthy banks heightened the sense of financial crisis and raised the possibility that they could be dragged into a credit squeeze that has engulfed three of their weaker competitors in the last two weeks.

headline: Bailout for Korea Is Left Unresolved As Seoul Hesitates
summary: An agreement for the economic rescue of South Korea unraveled Monday and negotiations began again, as Seoul resisted taking the severe steps, such as closing insolvent banks, that were advocated by the International Monetary Fund. By this morning, some Government officials were saying that a new agreement had been reached, and a Cabinet meeting was called to discuss the plan. All three major television networks here were reporting that South Korea had partly capitulated, agreeing to close more than half of the 12 banks that are overwhelmed with bad debts.

headline: Technology Issues Lead Stocks Higher
summary: A recovery in technology issues led a late rally in stocks yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average rebounded from a 56-point drop to close higher for the fourth consecutive session. The Dow gained 13.18 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 8,032.01. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.09, or a half of 1 percent, to 976.77, less than 7 points from its Oct. 7 closing high. Western Atlas, which does seismic surveys, was the top gainer, rising 4 1/8, or 6 percent, to 71 1/2.

headline: Terms of Bailout Vague on How Reluctant Koreans Will Enforce It
summary: Details of South Korea's record bailout agreement released today depict a broad and bold attempt to reform the world's 11th-largest economy, but the agreement also contains vague provisions that are raising doubts about how it will be enforced. The aftermath of the Government's agonizing decision on Thursday to formally accept the harsh terms of the agreement negotiated with the International Monetary Fund also acquired an increasingly political edge, coming only a few weeks before national elections. A former political dissident, Kim Dae Jung, who is a leading presidential candidate, said he might renegotiate the deal, reversing a pledge he made earlier this week to honor it.

headline: Those Ho-hum Utilities Have Started to Sizzle
summary: AS Southeast Asia's economic tumble has sent investors in search of calmer waters, one staid domestic sector -- the common stocks of utility companies -- has been showing new strength. The ranks of best-performing specialty funds for the quarter so far are dominated by those that invest in utilities, be they electric power utilities, water companies or long-distance phone carriers. Phone stocks, in fact, are a staple of utility investors and have contributed greatly to the sector's recent advance.

headline: Equity and Convertible Debt Set to Be Offered This Week
summary: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week: Alaska Air Group Inc., Seattle, 3 million shares, 2.6 million in the United States and Canada. Merrill Lynch & Co.

headline: 2 of the Big 3 Swiss Banks To Join to Seek Global Heft
summary: In deciding to merge and form the world's second-largest bank, the Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation appear to be reasoning that if they are going to remain players globally during a time of ever-larger mergers, they, too, must take on the necessary critical mass. Union Bank, Switzerland's second largest, and Swiss Bank, the third biggest, formally announced today, after days of speculation, that they would merge. The stock-swap deal will form a huge new bank with total assets of more than $590 billion. It would be second only to the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi of Japan, which controls $696 billion in assets.

headline: Performance Of New Bank Relies on U.S.
summary: The prospects for the United Bank of Switzerland, the combination of two leading Swiss banks that was proposed yesterday, rest heavily on whether it can be successful in the North American investment, securities and banking businesses. For Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation, their proposed merger reflects the latest European effort to compete with Wall Street rivals like Merrill Lynch & Company and the Travelers Group. To do so, the Swiss behemoth must increase its presence on its rivals' home turf, which has the world's largest financial and investment markets.

headline: KOREANS PRESSING U.S. AND JAPANESE FOR SPEEDIER AID
summary: With investor confidence again starting to erode despite the international rescue of its economy, South Korea's Government called on the United States and Japan today to quickly provide some money that they had pledged only as a last resort. But within hours, Clinton Administration officials made clear that any early injection of American funds would be firmly rejected. The Japanese Finance Ministry said its funds would only be available as a backup and the original terms of the bailout should be honored.

headline: U.S. Faults BellSouth Bid on Louisiana Long-Distance Service
summary: Continuing to douse the aspirations of the regional Bell telephone companies, the Justice Department recommended yesterday that the BellSouth Corporation not be allowed to offer long-distance service in Louisiana. Weighing the fourth application by a Baby Bell to enter the long-distance market, the department said that BellSouth had failed to adequately open its local network in Louisiana to justify being allowed to compete for long-distance customers.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Hires Ohio Agency
summary: The Sherwin-Williams Company said yesterday that it had named SBC Advertising in Columbus, Ohio, the agency of record for the stain group section of its consumer brands division in Memphis. The account, which includes brands like Thompson's, had been handled for 16 years by Hanft, Byrne, Raboy, Abrams & Partners in New York. Billings were estimated at $12 million.

headline: DIARY
summary: SOUTH KOREA The Crisis Deepens Barely a week after South Korea signed a record $57 billion bailout agreement, the nation plunged deeper into crisis when the Korea Development Bank, the largest state-owned bank, abruptly postponed a $2 billion bond offering that had been intended to help pay off billions of dollars in debt coming due within weeks. The postponement rattled the world's financial markets and raised fears that South Korea might become the first Asian nation to default on its debts since an economic crisis began spreading through the region in the summer. Earlier in the week, the Finance Ministry suspended the operations of five more banks and said it would put money into securities companies to help keep them afloat. Nevertheless, the South Korean won continued to plunge in currency markets.

headline: Will GTE, Long Seen as the Tortoise, Win the Race?
summary: ALTHOUGH the GTE Corporation made a bold, if unsuccessful, bid for MCI Communications earlier this fall, Wall Street has remained largely unimpressed by the company. So far this year, GTE shares have risen just 8.1 percent, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has surged 28.7 percent. ''They've done a couple of things that have made investors nervous,'' said Robert B. Wilkes, telecommunications analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman. For example, GTE announced in May that its 1997 and 1998 earnings would suffer as the company spent $2.5 billion over the next five years to upgrade its data network, including its Internet business. And GTE, which is based in Stamford, Conn., is widely perceived as stodgy and old-line, even though it is trying to transform itself into a dynamic, fast-growing telecommunications provider.

headline: Christie's Is Bid $825 Million, But for Itself
summary: Christie's International P.L.C., the renowned art auction house, has received the biggest single bid in its 231-year history: $825 million, for itself. The takeover bid for Christie's comes from the Swiss-owned investment firm SBC Warburg Dillon Read, officials close to the firm said yesterday. Directors of Christie's met in London last night to consider the offer, but executives of the company would not disclose what action, if any, the board had taken.

headline: When Will Bells Be Allowed Into Long Distance? Maybe After Rivals Get Local Access
summary: In the middle of the holiday season in a skeptical time, it would require the faith of a child for most average consumers to believe they now have a choice of local telephone company. The Justice Department's stinging report last week that the BellSouth Corporation had failed to adequately open its Louisiana network to rivals confirmed that residential local phone competition is as elusive as Santa Claus. The Justice Department's report was part of a recommendation that the Federal Communications Commission reject BellSouth's bid to offer long-distance telephone service in Louisiana. The commission is almost certain to follow it.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Crossed Wires In South Africa; Can Phone Service Improve In Absence of Competition?
summary: Monopoly and Government control have long been the way of doing business in South Africa, and for years, the national phone company was perhaps the worst offender. The hallmarks of the company, SA Telkom, were high prices, slow service, an aloof bureaucracy, a bloated work force and a network engineered for white neighborhoods. Suddenly, everything is changing. In the eyes of some South Africans, it's a miracle: the company is now being run by Americans, people famous for technical skill. In the eyes of others, it's a disaster: the company is now being run by Americans, people famous for arrogance.

headline: The year closes as it began, with big marketers shuffling multimillion-dollar assignments.
summary: THE year is ending as it began, with a flurry of changes by big advertisers. The most recent shifts involved advertising, interactive media and direct marketing accounts with billings of more than $325 million. The Dell Computer Corporation in Round Rock, Tex., named the J. Walter Thompson Company, part of WPP Group, as the first agency to handle a branding assignment, with billings estimated at $70 million.

headline: BellSouth Long-Distance Bid In South Carolina Is Rejected
summary: The Federal Communications Commission today rejected the BellSouth Corporation's application to enter the long-distance telephone business in South Carolina. The decision had been expected. The five-member commission unanimously concluded that the Atlanta-based Baby Bell had not sufficiently opened its local telephone markets in South Carolina to competition. Under last year's telecommunications law, the big regional phone companies can enter the $90 billion long-distance market only after their local markets are open to competition.

headline: KOREAN COMPANIES ARE LOOKING RIPE TO FOREIGN BUYERS
summary: South Korea, already humbled by having to accept an international bailout, is facing what could be another blow to its national pride: a wave of takeovers of its companies by American and other foreign corporations. The nation's plummeting stock market and currency have made Korean companies potential bargains for foreign companies, just as the International Monetary Fund's economic rescue is forcing the nation to open up to foreign investment.

headline: Phone Market Is Opening Up For Europeans
summary: After New Year's Day, German telephone customers will have something they never had before: a choice. ''Why are you still waiting?'' asks the redheaded model in one of the ubiquitous advertisements by Mannesmann Arcor. Beginning on Friday, Mannesmann will offer to undercut the long-distance prices of Deutsche Telekom by up to 39 percent, and two other consortiums are right behind.

headline: A U.S. Judge Strikes Down Parts Of '96 Telecommunications Act
summary: A Federal judge yesterday struck down major sections of the 1996 act that deregulated the telecommunications industry, saying that the law unfairly kept the regional Bell telephone companies out of the long-distance business. If the judge's ruling withstands appeals, it would allow the Bell companies nationwide to offer long-distance service for the first time since the AT&T Corporation was broken up under court supervision in 1984. Long-distance giants, which could face a range of new competitors, are almost certain to challenge the decision.

headline: Stocks Rally After Bonds Rise Sharply
summary: Stocks rose yesterday, bolstered by a rally in the bond market. The rally in bonds was set off by a report showing restrained growth in United States manufacturing activity last month. The prospect for continued mild inflation and low borrowing costs emphasized the fundamentals that have fueled the stock market's strong three-year rally.

headline: 1997 HIGHLIGHTS
summary: Homespun Suitor Wins Fight for MCI It seemed like the perfect marriage for a decade of globalization: MCI and British Telecommunications, which already had an international alliance, would form a trans-Atlantic colossus. But after it appeared that MCI's dowry might not be as large as anticipated -- MCI disclosed unexpectedly high costs in its effort to move into the local telephone business -- the British company and its shareholders turned cool. That opened the door to two United States rivals: GTE and a young suitor, Worldcom, with a more humble background but ambitious plans. In the end, Worldcom swept MCI and Wall Street off their feet with a $36.5 billion winning bid.

headline: Phone Companies Race To Find Their Suitors
summary: There was a time when following the telecommunications industry meant following the actual business of telecommunications. Those days, like rotary telephones, are long gone. In 1997, takeovers became almost as important to this industry as dial tones. Clearly beating out the year's No. 2 telecommunications story -- the failure of any regional Bell company to offer long-distance service -- mergers, proposed and actual, became the biggest story in one of the nation's most dynamic industries (notwithstanding a Federal judge's bombshell ruling six hours before the year's end that invalidated broad swaths of the Telecommunications Act of 1996). And 1998 promises more of the same, at least on the merger front.

headline: INSIDE
summary: Jury Weighs Nichols's Fate After hearing tales of loss from the prosecutors and of mercy from the defense, jurors in the Oklahoma City bombing trial of Terry L. Nichols began considering whether to sentence him to death. Page A10.

headline: A Big Western Bell Rides East to Buy Connecticut Phone Company
summary: Expanding far beyond its home territory in the West, SBC Communications Inc., the nation's largest local telephone company, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation, the local telephone company for nearly every Connecticut resident, for $4.4 billion in stock. The acquisition would give SBC, the parent of Southwestern Bell and Pacific Bell, a beachhead in the region controlled by one of its biggest rivals, the Bell Atlantic Corporation. The deal would mean the end of one of the biggest local non-Bell phone companies and would move the headquarters of Connecticut's main phone carrier from New Haven to San Antonio.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Netanyahu Survives Vote, But Peace Talks Loom Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu cleared his first Parliamentary hurdle since his Government was shaken by the resignation of his Foreign Minister, David Levy, winning approval for his 1998 budget by a vote of 58-52. But a new battle loomed with the arrival of the American mediator for the Middle East to discuss the stalled peace talks with the Palestinians. A3

headline: Corrections
summary: An article in Business Day yesterday about a proposed acquisition of Southern New England Telecommunications by SBC Communications misstated SBC's status among the nation's local telephone companies. It is the second-biggest local phone company; the biggest is Bell Atlantic.

headline: SBC Emerging as a Bull in the F.C.C.'s China Shop
summary: By persuading a Federal judge to strike down vital elements of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 last week and by agreeing on Monday to acquire Connecticut's main telephone company for $4.4 billion, SBC Communications Inc. is clearly emerging as the iconoclast of the telecommunications industry. Last week's court ruling, which could be a bonanza for SBC and the other Bells, will probably be stayed from going into effect soon and could well end up in the Supreme Court. And SBC's takeover of the Connecticut company, the Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation, could be rejected by regulators.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Stocks Fall Worldwide As Asia Tremors Linger Stock markets around the world continued to be weakened by concerns over Asia's financial crisis and its potential deflationary effects. The Dow Jones industrial average recovered from an 111-point deficit to end down 3.98 points, at 7,902.27, but broader market barometers fell sharply. The Nasdaq composite index fell 18.44 points, or 1.17 percent, to 1,561.70.

headline: AT&T to Pay $11.3 Billion For Teleport
summary: In an attempt to ride the current turmoil in the telecommunications industry back into the local phone business, the AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Teleport Communications Group Inc., one of the nation's largest alternate local telephone companies, for $11.3 billion in stock. If the deal goes through, it would give AT&T, the No. 1 long-distance carrier, a significant presence in local telephone markets for the first time since the company was forced to spin off its local operations as part of an antitrust settlement in 1984.

headline: Stirrings in the Phone Market
summary: Two events last week raised hopes that the 1996 Telecommunications Act, which was intended by Congress to bring competition to local telephone markets, was not passed in vain. SBC Communications, the parent of Southwestern Bell and Pacific Bell, proposed to take over Southern New England Telecommunications, the local phone company for Connecticut. Then, AT&T proposed to buy Teleport, a New York company that provides local phone service in more than 60 cities. Yet these are modest moves. So far, the 1996 act has spawned more court suits than competition. The SBC merger merely replaces one phone company with another, providing Connecticut no additional choices. But the merger does hold out the possibility that SBC will use Connecticut as a springboard to enter long-distance and local service for residential customers in the Northeast as a whole, thereby giving Bell Atlantic-Nynex a long-awaited run for its customers.

headline: DIARY
summary: WHEELS All Very Swiftian No need to be shipwrecked on an exotic island to have your sense of scale demolished: a modern Gulliver need go no farther than Detroit. At the auto show last week, Volkswagen rolled out its new Beetle, which returns to the Lilliputian end of the United States market after a 21-year absence, while just a few booths away Ford unveiled its Brobdingnagian new F-250, a pickup whose hood ornament is further off the ground than Dr. Ruth Westheimer's chin. Car makers and critics braced for a struggle over the Yahooish way light trucks have of mangling most any car they hit broadside; manufacturers are quietly pushing to have new side-impact standards set no higher than in Europe, where, unlike here, big light trucks are scarce. But the news on the environmental front might please the Houyhnhnms, Swift's race of selfless, sagacious horses: the Big Three and several Japanese companies are talking seriously about making new high-technology, high-mileage cars in the next few model years, and Ford says it will voluntarily upgrade its light trucks to meet the much tougher emissions standards imposed on cars. PRICES Won't Be Undersold Wholesale prices fell two-tenths of a percent in December and 1.2 percent for all of 1997, the Labor Department announced, and the ''core'' rate, which excludes the volatile food and energy numbers, fell for the first time in memory last year. Analysts are calling the inflation outlook the best in a generation, with even the labor markets -- tight, by historical standards -- on good behavior. Among economists, fretting about inflation is beginning to give way to fretting about possible deflation and the economic harm that would come. JOBS Won't Be Idle The latest evidence from the astrophysics lab says the universe will keep expanding forever, a characteristic that the American economy and labor force seem to share these days. An unexpectedly plentiful 370,000 new jobs were created in December, but unemployment actually ticked up slightly because an even greater number of new workers entered the labor force, the Labor Department reported. A record 64.1 percent of American adults are now in the labor force, but it wasn't a salary bidding war that drew them in: Real hourly wages rose just 0.1 percent last month. BUDGETS You Mean There's Extra? President Clinton said he planned to submit a balanced budget to Congress for fiscal 1999, three years ahead of schedule, and predicted a comparatively trivial Federal deficit of about $22 billion for 1998. Wall Street yawned, having long since predicted that the strong economy would erase the deficit, but political leaders dived gleefully into an unaccustomed task: arguing over what to do with spare money. The President is expected to discuss new initiatives on child care and the environment in his State of the Union message later in the month; House Speaker Newt Gingrich is talking about tax cuts. Consumers are way ahead of Washington this time: They unexpectedly reversed a three-year borrowing binge in November, reducing their total indebtedness by $4.2 billion, according to Treasury Department figures released last week. ASIAN TURMOIL, PART I Rescues Needing Rescues It turns out not to be quite as simple as tossing out a multibillion-dollar life preserver and hauling in the rope. Financial rescue plans sponsored by the International Monetary Fund for several Asian countries showed signs of unraveling last week, largely because of the reluctance of the recipients to swim along quietly in the specified direction. Indonesia announced a new budget that blithely ignored the I.M.F.'s fiscal advice, and when the rescuers' displeasure became known, the country's currency and its stock market sank like stones. Dire rumors, panic buying and fears of political instability swept the country. And in Thailand, which was the first Asian domino to fall, I.M.F.-required austerity measures are already pinching too hard for the Prime Minister, who asked for an easing of the terms. ASIAN TURMOIL, PART II Devil in the Details Compared with Southeast Asia, South Korea seems calm. Its streets are quiet, and the stock market has stanched its bleeding. But the particulars of the debt restructuring the country badly needs are proving thorny. After a week of squabbling, creditor banks were near agreement on a plan to give the country a breather of 30 to 90 days on loan payments. Still to be sorted out is what happens next: who will buy a proposed bond issue and what kinds of government guarantees they will get. COMPUTERS New Year, New Prospects January is the time of year Steven Jobs likes to spring surprises: He introduced the Macintosh computer with a stunning ''1984''-themed commercial that ran just once, during that year's Super Bowl; since then new products from Apple Computer have often been announced at the January MacWorld trade show. Mr. Jobs's show stopper this year was his announcement that Apple had managed a small profit in the first quarter of its 1998 fiscal year. The crisis is far from over for the company Mr. Jobs founded -- and is now trying to turn around after a three-year slide in other hands -- but Wall Street was delighted by the progress so far, pushing Apple's stock up 20 percent. TELECOMMUNICATIONS Buying Local Why invent what you can buy instead? SBC Communications, which bought Pacific Telesis in 1996 in the first merger among the Baby Bells, has announced a deal to acquire Connecticut's phone company, Southern New England Telephone, one of the few remaining sizable independents, for $4.4 billion. One lure: S.N.E.T. has regulatory permission to sell long-distance service to its local customers, a privilege so far denied to SBC and its former Bell siblings. And AT&T was attracted by a 26-state local franchise when it agreed last week to buy Teleport Communications for $11.3 billion in stock. The deal would spare AT&T the aggravation and cost of building its own new local service from scratch, and had been expected for months.

headline: INSIDE ART
summary: Lichtenstein Gets His Wish Before his death in September, Roy Lichtenstein made plans to give three top American museums important paintings to fill a significant gap in their Lichtenstein holdings. The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, the Museum of Modern Art and the National Gallery of Art in Washington have all been notified that in his will, the pop artist had left each institution a major painting he knew they wanted.

headline: F.C.C. Is Criticized By a Commissioner
summary: A court case challenging portions of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 should serve as a ''stern wake-up call'' to the Federal Communications Commission that it needs to do a better job reviewing regional Bells' applications to provide long-distance service, Michael K. Powell, an F.C.C. commissioner, said today.

headline: Accounting Change Urged to Help Japan's Banks
summary: Japan's governing party wants to change an accounting rule so that banks can increase their dwindling capital by trillions of yen. Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and other leaders of the Liberal Democratic Party today endorsed a plan under which banks and other companies could, for bookkeeping practices, put values on their land holdings that are based on current market prices. Currently, property assets are kept on the books at the prices at which they were acquired.

headline: Voice Technology Appears Ready to Recognize Bottom Line
summary: When Charles Schwab, the brokerage company, decided late last year to switch to an automated phone system for taking customer calls, it put its trust in speech-recognition technology, which it would have spurned a few years earlier. Schwab was skeptical at first, because the technology, long hyped, had often proved disappointing. ''We knew American Express had been playing with it for about 10 years and hadn't really been able to make a go of it,'' said Alan Nathan, head of new products.

headline: WAVE OF MERGERS IS RECASTING FACE OF BUSINESS IN U.S.
summary: Not since a wave of industrial takeovers created the great oil, steel and auto companies at the beginning of the century has corporate America been reshaped by a sweep of merger activity as broad as the one taking place today. Last year alone, a record $1 trillion in mergers took place involving American companies, a pace almost unrivaled in business history.

headline: VENTURE PROMISES FAR FASTER SPEEDS FOR INTERNET DATA
summary: Three titans of the personal computer industry have joined with most of the nation's largest local telephone companies to enable consumers to receive Internet data over regular telephone lines at speeds much higher than are currently possible, according to executives involved with the alliance. The Compaq Computer Corporation, the Intel Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation intend to announce the venture next week at a communications conference in Washington, the executives said.

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Fall
summary: Open positions of short sales declined in the most recent period on both the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange. Open short positions declined 2.5 percent on the Big Board from a record 3.67 billion shares to 3.58 billion shares.

headline: Choosing Between Phone and Cable for Internet Access
summary: WHEN Wall Street learned last week that most of the Baby Bells were joining with three computer giants to offer consumers superfast access to the Internet, there were some short-term stock gyrations and some long-term speculation about the meaning of it all. The biggest question: Will the telephone companies or the cable companies win the battle to offer this service? The new consortium, which is scheduled to announce its venture this week, so far includes GTE and U S West Communications, BellSouth, SBC Communications and Ameritech, together with the technology giants Microsoft, Intel and Compaq Computer. The companies hope to develop new modems and software that will be up to 30 times faster than today's telephone modems.

headline: Conglomerates Feel the Heat
summary: With South Korea's economy in crisis, the family-controlled companies that have been its rulers are facing the end of an era. That era began in the 1960's, when South Korea's military rulers chose the companies, called chaebols, to industrialize the nation and favored them with loans from a banking sector controlled by the Government.

headline: GGT Group, battered by the loss of big accounts, has agreed to be brought into Omnicom's fold.
summary: A WEEK after the big loss of its Procter & Gamble Company accounts plunged GGT Group P.L.C. into crisis, the agency company agreed to be acquired by a much larger competitor, Omnicom Group, for $234.2 million in cash. At the same time, two top executives have left Wells BDDP in New York -- the beleaguered GGT agency that lost the P.& G. accounts, which had billings estimated at $125 million.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Agreement Is Reached On South Korean Loans South Korean banks and their international creditors reached an agreement to extend payment on $24 billion in short-term loans. The agreement, which ended three weeks of often tortuous negotiations, grants the country an important reprieve in the financial crisis that has afflicted many countries in Asia, providing a measure of relief. [Page A1.]

headline: SBC Operating Profit Rises, but Net Falls
summary: SBC Communications Inc.'s operating profit rose 22 percent in the fourth quarter, lifted by an increase in phone lines and wireless customers and cost restraints, but a large charge caused net income to decline. SBC, which acquired Pacific Telesis Group last April, said today that it had added 390,000 phone lines in the fourth quarter, a 5 percent increase. Operating expenses rose 4.1 percent -- less than half the 10 percent growth in the third quarter.

headline: Consortium May Abandon Rail Contract
summary: London and Continental Railways will abandon its $8.3 billion contract to build a high-speed link to the Channel Tunnel and to run the Eurostar passenger train service after failing to raise more money, an executive of the troubled consortium said today. The consortium's decision signals more setbacks for the 31-mile tunnel that connects Britain and France, one of the most expensive and drawn-out public works projects in Europe.

headline: Stock Offerings Planned During the Week
summary: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Offerings Scheduled This Week For Equity and Convertible Debt
summary: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Korea's Other Big Problem: $300 Billion in Domestic Debt
summary: The Nasan Group was a successful apparel manufacturer with a stable of popular local brands until it began an ambitious expansion in 1988, backed by banks that are now suffering the consequences. Flush with easy credit, it branched out into golf courses, resorts and hotels, then added a health club subsidiary and acquired a construction company. ''Our chairman felt that housing was another medium of fashion,'' explained Yeom Moon Nam, assistant director of planning. ''In the same way that clothing evolved from simply something to keep you warm into a fashion statement, houses are not just for refuge any more.''

headline: Labor Group's Talk of Strike Threatens Korean Layoff Deal
summary: An agreement to legalize layoffs negotiated last week by business, Government and labor leaders, and regarded as a big victory for President-elect Kim Dae Jung -- is in danger of foundering over a labor federation's threat to strike unless the accord is renegotiated. The warning issued late Monday by the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions, which represents roughly 500,000 workers at some of South Korea's biggest companies, was regarded as a temporary setback to Mr. Kim, who is expected to seek a compromise solution before he officially takes office Feb. 25.

headline: U.S. Judge Stays His Ruling On Long-Distance Service
summary: A Federal judge in Texas yesterday temporarily stayed his year-end decision that invalidated major portions of the Telecommunications Act of 1996. Yesterday's action keeps the telecommunications industry in the regulatory status it had before Dec. 31, when Judge Joe Kendall of the Federal District Court in Wichita Falls, Tex., ruled that local Bell telephone companies should be allowed to sell long-distance service without passing a rigorous review by the Federal Communications Commission.

headline: Loans Extended by South Korean Banks
summary: In a sign the Government's grip on the banking system remains strong, South Korean lending institutions agreed Wednesday to extend by two months nearly $9 billion of loans to domestic businesses due in March. The extension, which bankers said was made at the request of the Finance Ministry, provided a reprieve for borrowers afflicted by a severe cash shortage, high interest rates and a devalued currency. But it is unclear whether the extra time to repay will help them or merely delay an inevitable cascade of defaults.

headline: For a Shaky Japanese Economy, The Premier Is a Hesitant Steward
summary: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto comes across these days not as the captain of one of the world's most powerful ships of state, but rather as a man overboard, bobbing in waves of unpopularity, threatened by an economic typhoon on the horizon. The puzzle is that he seems unsure whether to inflate his life jacket.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Stocks Keep Climbing, Paced by Nike Shares Stock prices rose again, sending the Dow industrials to their sixth consecutive record. While strong earnings at technology companies have supported the rally, merger activity -- and speculation about possible deals -- has also helped. The most intriguing of the talk has centered on Nike, whose stock has risen 9 percent in two days amid market rumors that the investor Warren E. Buffett is adding to his 2 percent stake in the company. [Page D9.]

headline: Christie's Ends Talks On Takeover By Swiss
summary: Christie's put itself on the auction block in December, but after two months of intense negotiations, it did not attract a bid high enough to accept. Yesterday Christie's, the London-based auction house, announced that talks with a consortium lead by the Swiss-owned investment firm SBC Warburg Dillon Read about a possible takeover had ended despite fierce denials earlier this week and statements that talks were continuing.

headline: INSIDE ART
summary: Money for Monet And a Rotunda The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston has had two recent windfalls: one for an exhibition and the other to restore the museum's upper rotunda and colonnade, which includes its John Singer Sargent ceiling murals. First, the exhibition money. With the success of Monet shows (most recently, the record-breaking crowds at the Brooklyn Museum to see ''Monet in the Mediterranean,'' which closed on Jan. 18), Fleet Financial Group in Boston is giving the museum $1.2 million to mount ''Monet in the 20th Century.'' The museum said it was the largest single sponsorship gift in its 122-year history.

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Rise on the Big Board and Amex
summary: Open positions of short sales increased in the most recent period on both the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange. Open positions increased 4.2 percent on the Big Board, to a record 3.73 billion shares, from 3.58 billion shares a month ago.

headline: Pitfalls in Cutting Korea's Lifetime Work Force
summary: When this country's most militant labor union shelved a potentially crippling strike early this month, fears started to fade that the chances for South Korean economic recovery would be set back by debilitating labor unrest. But the pace and scope of change in the nation's labor practices, regarded as an indispensable part of getting the Korean economy back on its feet, are of increasing concern to foreign investors and economists.

headline: Severed Phone Cable Cuts Service Around New York
summary: Thousands of businesses and consumers in the New York area went largely without telephone service yesterday afternoon after a sliced fiber-optic cable in Illinois led to scattered telephone shutdowns across the nation. The New York Mercantile Exchange, a marketplace for oil, natural gas, gold and silver, shut down prematurely after its telephone lines to the outside essentially stopped working at 1:50 P.M.

headline: Halliburton Said to Acquire Oilfield Rival
summary: The Halliburton Company, the Dallas-based energy services concern, is expected to announce today that it is acquiring a rival in the field, Dresser Industries, for $7.7 billion. The deal would be a tax-free stock swap, a person close to the talks said. A deal would come at a time when oil services companies have had trouble meeting surging demand for their business -- which covers all equipment involved in oil drilling, from rigs to helicopters for ferrying workers and equipment. Exploration and drilling efforts have increased in the last few years, particularly in offshore fields and overseas, even though crude oil prices have recently fallen.

headline: 2 Regional Bells In Satellite Deal
summary: The Bell Atlantic Corporation and SBC Communications Inc. signed agreements today with DirecTV and the United States Satellite Broadcasting Company to sell satellite-television services to their telephone customers. Financial terms were not disclosed. The regional Bell phone companies will offer service from DirecTV and U.S. Satellite Broadcasting, two of the nation's largest satellite-TV providers.

headline: SBC Files to Sell Long Distance
summary: SBC Communications Inc. filed an application today with the Texas Public Utilities Commission seeking permission to offer long-distance phone service to customers in the state. SBC, based in San Antonio, is also seeking to offer long-distance phone service to its customers in Oklahoma, Arkansas and Kansas.

headline: Weekly Schedule of Offerings Of Equity and Convertible Debt
summary: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Another Setback in Quest To Marry TV and Phones
summary: The much-heralded but still-unfulfilled convergence of television and telephone took another step back toward the drawing board last week as Stephen A. Weiswasser, a former senior executive at Capital Cities/ ABC, announced that he would step down from his job running Americast, a television venture of four big local phone companies and the Walt Disney Company. Dashed expectations have become a staple of the hodgepodge of theorists, venture capitalists and corporate executives who not long ago seemed to have a bead on the future as they proclaimed that almost every sort of electronic media would soon become one indistinguishable digital mass.

headline: Qwest Set to Acquire LCI For $4.4 Billion in Stock
summary: Making a major leap into the consumer long-distance telephone business, Qwest Communications International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire LCI International Inc. for $4.4 billion in stock. The deal, assuming Worldcom Inc.'s pending acquisition of the MCI Communications Corporation goes through, would make Qwest the nation's fourth-largest long-distance carrier with as much as $3 billion in revenues this year.

headline: Treasuries Rise Slightly as Investors Await Retail Sales Report
summary: The prices of Treasury securities were only slightly higher yesterday, as oil prices stemmed their downward slide, removing one of the bond market's most recent sources of support. Trading volume was again light. The price of the 30-year bond was up 3/32, to 102 12/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 5.95 percent from 5.96 percent.

headline: A $4 Billion Global Issue by the World Bank Sells Quickly
summary: The World Bank priced its largest dollar-denominated global bond issue ever yesterday, as solid demand from investors insured its quick sale and oversubscription. While the recent cascade of corporate financings scheduled to be priced has weighed on the Treasury market, the World Bank deal did not because it was completed quickly.

headline: List of Favorite Stocks Is Updated Today
summary: The New York Times today updates its list of favorite stocks, which are defined as the 16 stocks owned by the most accounts at Merrill Lynch. The new list is based on holdings at the end of 1997, replacing a list that was based on holdings on May 31, 1996. New stocks on the list are Ameritech, Coca-Cola, Compaq Computer, Johnson & Johnson and Microsoft. They replace Airtouch Communications, Disney, Motorola, U S West and Wal-Mart Stores.

headline: Alltel to Buy Big Carrier of Cellular Calls
summary: The Alltel Corporation announced an agreement yesterday to acquire the 360 Communications Company, a big cellular telephone carrier, for more than $4 billion in stock. The deal would make Alltel, an independent local telephone company, a major factor in wireless phone markets throughout the Southeastern and mid-Atlantic states.

headline: Market Continues Its Climb, With Indexes Hitting Highs
summary: The stock market soared further into record territory yesterday, sending all the major indexes to all-time highs. The Dow Jones industrial average, rising steadily for almost two months, gained 25.41 points, to 8,775.40, its third consecutive record. In a year when few Wall Street analysts expected to Dow to gain double-digits, the blue-chip average is already up 11 percent, one of its best starts this decade. After three spectacular years of share price gains, the market is once again strengthening against a backdrop of solid economic growth, heavy cash flows into mutual funds and speculation that more and more companies will merge, pushing share prices even higher. The brokerage industry -- one of the prime benefactors of this bull market -- has been both a source of tremendous profit growth, driven by an increasingly investment-hungry populace, and heavy speculation about new banking combinations. Yesterday, for instance, talk that the Chase Manhattan Corporation might merge with Merrill Lynch sent Merrill's shares up more than 9 percent, despite denials among industry insiders that a deal was pending. Chase and Merrill declined comment. Shares of Chase also rose a day after the nation's biggest commercial bank said it would cut 4,500 jobs, by laying off 2,250 employees and not replacing the others, in the next 18 months. In the last three years, brokerage stocks, as calculated in the American Stock Exchange's security and broker-dealer index, are up about 500 percent, partly because of new combinations such as Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter and the merger of Salomon Brothers and Smith Barney, which is part of the Travelers Group. Shares of several regional telephone companies also rose yesterday after Edward Whitacre, Jr., the chairman of SBC Communications, said he might be interested in buying another local phone company. It has been that kind of a market. Earnings growth may be eroding, but analysts say investors believe the economy will remain strong, and the eagerness to own stocks is greater than ever. Since the Dow fell 554 points last Oct. 27 to hit 7,161.15 on fears of a deepening economic crisis in Southeast Asia, the average has risen 1,614 points, or 22.5 percent. Even ardent bulls are wondering whether the market has risen too fast. ''The momentum unleashed in the last few weeks means we're going to go to the extreme on the greed side,'' said Alfred Goldman, director of market analysis at A. G. Edwards Inc. ''People have lots of money and they don't want to leave a winning game.'' Shares of energy companies gained after oil prices rebounded from a series of declines. Exxon and Chevron were among the leading Dow component stocks. Investors also bought up technology shares despite recent profit warnings. The Nasdaq composite index rose 8.98 points to close at a record 1,788.28. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 5.07 points to close at a record 1,085.52. The Russell 2000 index of small-company stocks rose 1.07, to a record 427.18. Richard Eakle, an analyst and president of Eakle Associates in Fair Haven, N.J., said the market has been buoyed by middle-aged investors who see stocks as the fountain of wealth. ''The primary catalyst is the baby- boomer generation liquidity situation,'' he said. ''That generation is going to invest as much as they can.''

headline: Q&A/Guy R. Mazza; Counsel for Keeping Utility Bills Down
summary: THE Office of Consumer Counsel represents customers of the state's five regulated utilities -- gas, electric, cable, water and telephone. The name doesn't ring bells with most people, but it probably should. The Consumer Counsel's primary task is to keep those monthly bills reasonable. When a utility makes its case for a rate increase before the Department of Public Utility Control, the Office of Consumer Counsel is there to argue the customers' case. ''Generally we determine that what the company asks should be reduced,'' said Guy R. Mazza, who has been Consumer Counsel since June.

headline: All Too Soon, New F.C.C. Chief Finds Warm Welcome Is Cooling
summary: The honeymoon is over for William E. Kennard, if there ever was one. When he became chairman of the Federal Communications Commission last fall, he talked of his open mind and said his willingness to weigh differing views would help him usher in the age of widespread telecommunications deregulation.

headline: Offerings of Equity Set for This Week
summary: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week: American Medical Providers Inc., Houston, an initial public offering of 3.7 million shares. A. G. Edwards & Sons.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS; Returns that Don't Rely on Power and Light
summary: Many utility fund managers have wandered far afield from utilities stocks and are only modestly invested in segment, even though, ironically, 1997 was banner year for utilities because of deregulation and mergers; list of top-performing utilities funds over last three years (S)

headline: Stock Offerings Expected This Week
summary: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Business Travel; Airlines Coddle High Fliers At Expense of Coach Class
summary: Last month, business travelers paying full coach fare on Trans World Airlines began receiving white-glove service in St. Louis. A special skycap now checks their bags at the curb, issuing a large, gilt-edged tag that is intended to insure that the luggage will be the first off the plane. Elite fliers are also given a white ticket envelope -- as opposed to the dark blue ones issued to the hoi polloi -- so that T.W.A. employees know to give them the ''extra level of customer service they deserve.'' And T.W.A. scrapped a three-year effort to offer the most spacious coach cabin in the industry to make room for more first-class seats.

headline: Anger Over Bank Merger Spills Onto Web
summary: The joke tellers said that UBS stood for ''Unemployed Before Summer'' and that Union Bank of Switzerland might as well be the Titanic. But the sarcasm about the proposed merger of the company and the Swiss Bank Corporation was not just limited to conversations in corporate hallways. A Web site critical of the proposed merger reflected the depths of Union Bank employees' resentment about the prospect of dismissals in one of the biggest banking mergers in history. But this time, unlike other mergers where emotions run high among employees, the authors vented their anger in public.

headline: GTE Expects $174 Million Quarter Loss
summary: The GTE Corporation said yesterday that it would post a loss for the first quarter and sell billions in assets as the big local telephone company continues to remake itself to compete in the increasingly hectic telecommunications industry. The company also said it had formally withdrawn its offer to buy the MCI Communications Corporation, the No. 2 long-distance provider, for $28 billion in cash. Many analysts already considered GTE's offer moot because MCI's shareholders last month approved a rival $37 billion bid for the company from Worldcom Inc.

headline: Peril of Politics in Japan
summary: As the world's second-largest economy lurches to a standstill, possibly threatening to cause a global slowdown, paradoxically the fundamental reasons are not economic. Instead, they are political. Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto is a weak leader governing with a fragile coalition of parties and factions that seldom agree with each other, so the Government finds it difficult to shift economic directions even as it becomes clear that the Japanese ship of state is heading toward an iceberg. And the Japanese system is based on consensus, which has always made decision-making here difficult in a crisis.

headline: Equity and Convertible Debt Offerings Set
summary: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Conseco and Green Tree, an Improbable Merger
summary: On Wall Street, where disputes about arcane accounting practices can lead to blows and lawsuits, almost no company is argued over more than Conseco Inc. -- except maybe Green Tree Financial. Yesterday, they announced they were merging to become one very controversial company. Conseco is an insurance conglomerate that has grown swiftly by buying 19 smaller businesses since 1982, using accounting methods that some analysts say has made the company's business hard to value. Green Tree, which lends money to people who buy mobile homes, recently had to restate its 1996 earnings, which forced its chairman, Lawrence M. Coss, to return about $23 million of the $102 million bonus he received for the year.

headline: SBC and Union Agree to Deals
summary: SBC Communications Inc. said today that it had reached tentative agreements with the Communications Workers of America for contracts covering 74,000 of the phone company's union workers. The three-year agreements, which must be approved by the union's members, cover 40,000 Southwestern Bell workers in Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri, Oklahoma and Texas, and 34,000 Nevada Bell and Pacific Bell employees in Nevada and California. The agreements replace the current contracts, which expire on Aug. 8.

headline: The settlement of a bitter family dispute leaves France's Publicis facing a more secure future.
summary: A BITTER family feud that threatened to unravel Publicis S. A., the No. 2 French agency company, appears to have been resolved with a settlement between battling sisters that was reached almost two years to the day after the death of their father, which had intensified the long-running dispute. The deal, announced yesterday in Paris, was brokered by Maurice Levy, the chairman and chief executive of Publicis, who in late January began trying to settle the fight between the sisters.

headline: Researchers Crack Code In Cell Phones
summary: In successfully cracking a widely used encryption method designed to prevent the cloning of digital cellular phones, a group of University of California computer researchers believe they have stumbled across evidence that the system was deliberately weakened to permit Government surveillance. The method that was cracked is known as G.S.M., for the Groupe Speciale Mobile standard. The world's most widely used encryption system for cellular phones, G.S.M. is employed in about 80 million of the devices worldwide and by as many as two million phones in the United States.

headline: A $30 million campaign will strive to make the Yellow Pages directories appear less musty.
summary: THE publishers of the nation's Yellow Pages will sponsor their first comprehensive advertising campaign, meant to convince consumers that their directories are as relevant in the information age as they were when most telephones still had dials. The Yellow Pages Publishers Association, a trade group whose members account for 95 percent of directory ad revenue in North America, has selected the Martin Agency, a hot creative shop in Richmond, to create the campaign. Plans call for the television, print and promotional effort to be tested in the late fall in seven or eight markets across the country and then introduced nationally in early 1999.

headline: Foreigners Buy Korea Stock but Not Companies
summary: While foreigners have been buying South Korean bonds and pouring cash into the country's resurgent stock market, direct foreign investment in Korean companies remains sluggish. Since the nation flirted with default on its international loans in December, only two outright acquisitions of South Korean companies by foreigners have been confirmed: BASF's purchase of the Daesung group's lysine business for $600 million last month, and the impending acquisition of Samsung Heavy Industries' construction equipment unit by Volvo for $765 million.

headline: Annelise Skofteland, E. R. Eschmann
summary: Annelise Skofteland and Edward Richard Eschmann were married yesterday at Immanuel Lutheran Church in New York. The Rev. Gregory P. Fryer performed the ceremony. Ms. Skofteland Eschmann, 31, is the associate director of Latin American corporate-bond research at SBC Warburg Dillon Read, an investment bank in New York. She graduated with honors from Eckerd College in St. Petersburg, Fla. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. The bride is a daughter of Laila and Per Skofteland of Germantown, Md.

headline: Has the I.M.F. Cured or Harmed Asia? Dispute Rages After Months of Crisis
summary: When pollsters asked children in Thailand recently about the I.M.F., 30 percent described it as a kind of unidentified flying object. The International Monetary Fund is indeed a mysterious outside force that is suddenly reshaping the lives of millions of Asians. But is it a friendly force or a hostile one?

headline: Japan Offers New Package For Economy
summary: Digging deeper into its purse, the Government announced a record $128 billion program of spending and economic stimulants today aimed at pulling the economy out of a seven-year slump and easing apprehension that Japanese weakness will cause a global slowdown. In raising spending more than $15 billion beyond amounts in a blueprint of the package released a few weeks ago, the Government seemed to be trying to demonstrate its resolve to the world. American officials have been badgering Japan to revive its economy through large and long-term tax cuts that would prompt consumers to spend more, but the package contained no permanent or major tax reductions.

headline: Catherine Sitrick, A. R. B. Shepard
summary: Catherine Baker Sitrick, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Baker Sitrick of New York, was married yesterday to Alexander Richard Broadley Shepard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Giles Shepard of Nether Wallop, England. The Rev. Charles H. Clark, the former headmaster of St. Paul's School, performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. Mrs. Shepard, 24, is an assistant account executive at Young & Rubicam, the advertising agency in New York. She graduated from St. Paul's and from Hamilton College. The bride's father is a senior partner in Coudert Brothers, the New York law firm of which he was the chairman from 1982 to 1993. He is also a trustee of the Pierpont Morgan Library and of the Folger Shakespeare Library, and the chairman of the English Chamber Orchestra Society of America.

headline: Polish Aid Fund Turns Profit, Posing a Problem
summary: When the United States sent a special package of money to stimulate the Polish economy in the aftermath of Communism, everyone in Washington thought that it was a nice gesture to brave people. Like most foreign aid, the money was something that they thought they would never see again. But now Washington is faced with a new species that it does not know how to handle, a successful aid program that can pay back its money to the United States Treasury.

headline: Stock Offerings During the Week
summary: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Worldcom Deal For MCI Studied
summary: United States antitrust officials are examining whether Worldcom Inc.'s proposed $41.8 billion purchase of the MCI Communications Corporation could thwart competition from companies that enter the long-distance phone business by reselling services they purchase from the major long-distance carriers. GTE, Sprint and four of five Baby Bell phone companies -- Bell Atlantic, BellSouth, Ameritech and U S West -- all received civil subpoenas from the Justice Department seeking documents related to the wholesale long-distance phone market, company officials said.

headline: Frenchman Gets Big Stake In Christie's
summary: A wealthy French takeover investor whose diverse empire includes France's biggest department store, Samsonite luggage and a Colorado ski resort, has bought 29.1 percent of Christie's, raising the prospect that ownership of the famed London auction house could pass from British hands for the first time in its 232 years. Under an agreement announced yesterday, Francois Pinault paid an undisclosed sum for the 49.4-million-share stake to Abel Inc., a trust established by Joseph Lewis, a British financier. The sale makes Mr. Pinault Christie's largest shareholder and gives him 27.2 percent of the voting rights.

headline: Playstation Sales Lift Sony Profits
summary: The Sony Corporation's earnings jumped 50 percent in the latest half, lifted by sales of the Playstation home video-game player and software. ''Sony keeps doing things better, keeps finding new ways to improve itself, and while it keeps on doing that I'll buy,'' Reinier Dobbelmann, an analyst at SBC Warburg Japan Ltd., said today. The Japanese electronics company ''is two or three years ahead of its competitors,'' he said.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Japan's Auto Makers Go It Alone; Tradition Creates Resistance to Industry's Consolidation
summary: Standing inside the dormitory he manages for the Nissan Motor Company, Mutsumi Goto looked a bit befuddled by the whirlwind on the other side of the world. ''It's an epoch-making event and I feel a little bit left behind,'' he said.

headline: Into the Island Lair of a Currency-Trading Tiger
summary: JOSEPH C. LEWIS is a private man. He lives regally, but quietly, in a low-slung, beachfront manse that abuts a golf course and a yacht-filled marina in this luxurious, palm-swept enclave. His neighbors include others who value their privacy, and the island's tax-haven status: the actor Sean Connery; the novelist Arthur Hailey; Fahad Al Sabah, a member of the Kuwaiti royal family; the mutual fund legend Sir John Templeton. Like many of these men, Mr. Lewis's public acts make waves. Last week, he sold a $244 million stake in Christie's International P.L.C., the auction house, to the French businessman Francois Pinault. Mr. Lewis is also the owner of a world-class art collection, which includes a Picasso and a Miro, and owns Isleworth, a Windermere, Fla., country club community that is home to the golfer Tiger Woods, the baseball star Ken Griffey Jr. and the basketball player Shaquille O'Neal.

headline: 2 BELL COMPANIES ARE SET TO REJOIN IN $60 BILLION DEAL
summary: SBC Communciations Inc., the West's dominant local telephone company, is expected to announce today that it is acquiring the Ameritech Corporation for about $60 billion in stock, people close to the talks said. The deal would recreate much of the old Bell system. The proposed deal is the latest in a string of corporate blockbusters. In size, it is the second-largest in corporate history, edging out the BankAmerica-Nationsbank merger announced last month and trailing only the $70 billion deal in March between Citicorp and Travelers Group.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Netanyahu Wins Delay On Withdrawal Decision Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel won another two-week reprieve in the battle over the 13 percent withdrawal from the West Bank that the United States has set as the threshold for continuing peace negotiations with the Palestinians. A1 Flood Victims Buried in Italy Ninety-five carved wooden coffins were lined up in a soccer field for an outdoor funeral in Sarno, Italy, the worst hit of the five villages smothered in mud after torrential rains on Tuesday. A7

headline: For Long-Term AT&T Investors Stock Has Skyrocketed Since '84
summary: AT&T Corporation investors who have held their shares since the 1984 breakup of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company have earned returns of 1,128 percent. That gain includes the values created by stock splits, reinvested dividends, spinoffs and mergers. The Standard & Poor's 500 index, by contrast, returned 958 percent, including reinvested dividends, in the same period.

headline: $62 BILLION DEAL TO SHIFT BALANCE IN PHONE INDUSTRY
summary: The announcement that SBC Communications Inc. would acquire the Ameritech Corporation for about $62 billion significantly shifts the balance of power in the United States telecommunications industry. The deal announced yesterday would create the nation's largest local phone company and threaten the remaining regional Bells with the specter of having to compete eventually with a wealthy, aggressive leviathan that will control about a third of the nation's local phone lines. Forged by an executive determined to create a phone empire with a breadth unmatched since the Federal Government broke up the AT&T Corporation in 1984, the new SBC would dominate local phone markets in a swath through the middle of the nation from Detroit to El Paso, as well as in California and Connecticut. With more than $40 billion in sales, it would be the nation's No. 2 carrier, behind the AT&T Corporation.

headline: TELEPHONE GIANT: THE INDUSTRY -- Giving Old Ma Bell New Lease on Life; More New Math: Promoting Competition by Addition, Not Division
summary: Fourteen years after the Government forced the breakup of the old American Telephone and Telegraph Company -- a policy step taken to promote competition and consumer choice -- much of the old Bell System is being put together again. The biggest move yet came yesterday when SBC Communications announced plans to buy Ameritech for $62 billion. The combination would reduce to four the remaining Baby Bell regional phone companies, down from the original seven spun off from AT&T in 1984. If regulators bless the merger, SBC would own nearly one-third of the nation's phone lines, controlling the local phone service in 12 states including Texas, California and Illinois.

headline: Paths of 2 Executives In a Proposed Merger
summary: They both started out working for Ma Bell while still in college, one stringing telephone line and the other washing trucks. And Edward E. Whitacre Jr. and Richard C. Notebaert both flourished in the upheavals following the Federal Government's successful drive to break up the old American Telephone and Telegraph Company's monopoly. First Mr. Whitacre, and then Mr. Notebaert, grabbed the distinction of becoming the youngest chief executive of one of the eight regional local-service phone companies created by the breakup.

headline: Concern About Rate Rise Cuts the Size of a Dow Rally
summary: News of a huge telephone deal pushed stock prices higher early yesterday, but concern about rising interest rates overshadowed the merger euphoria, leaving stocks mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average rose more than 135 points at one point, buoyed by SBC Communications' proposed acquisition of Ameritech, before falling back to close up 36.37 points at 9,091.52.

headline: Shuttle Diplomacy Leads to New Corporate Marriage
summary: SBC Communications Inc.'s agreement to buy the Ameritech Corporation in a $62 billion stock swap got its start over dinner in a St. Louis restaurant in early March. Ameritech's chief executive, Richard C. Notebaert, who had expressed interest in hooking up with another company for two years, and SBC's chairman, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., who wanted to rule the telecommunications world, had talked by phone for months.

headline: Arguing Against Stock Deals
summary: Wall Street adores stock-for-stock mergers, like SBC-Ameritech, but long term, two finance professors contend, cash is king. Page D1.

headline: Will That Takeover Be Cash or Stock?
summary: Another day, another deal. And another reason for the stock market to go up. Some 444 deals, worth around $630 billion, have been announced so far this year. That puts Wall Street well on its way to a banner year in mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Enlarging Already Big Holdings in Europe
summary: SBC Communications Inc.'s plan to buy Ameritech for $62 billion in stock and assumed debt is likely to expand the already sizable investments in Europe made by Ameritech, analysts said today. Ameritech is the biggest non-European investor in the region's telecommunications industry, with about $7.5 billion in European assets generating more than 25 percent of quarterly earnings. SBC, by contrast, has a sparse presence, mainly in France and Switzerland.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: SBC Communications Says It Will Acquire Ameritech SBC Communications formally announced plans to acquire Ameritech for about $62 billion, creating a telecommunications giant controlling a third of the nation's local phone lines. Analysts said the deal would increase the number of mergers in the communications industry as companies defend their turf from the new SBC-Ameritech empire, which will be the second-largest communications carrier behind AT&T. [Page A1.]

headline: In Phoneland, It Gets Lonely At the Middle
summary: When is huge not big enough? In the telecommunications industry, it is when your company serves more than 20 million customers, has a market value of $50 billion, reaps revenue of $16 billion and has net earnings of $2.3 billion.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; An accounting method favored in mergers may get a new name
summary: WALL STREET deal makers have come to count on a certain accounting method almost as much as they count on bubbles in their celebratory champagne. They broke it out for SBC Communications Inc. and Ameritech, Daimler-Benz A.G. and the Chrysler Corporation, and even Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc. The three mega-deals will use the accounting method known as a pooling of interest, as will more than 60 smaller deals that have been announced this year.

headline: Economic Scene; Do Mergers Really Yield Big Benefits?
summary: Boeing-McDonnell Douglas, Worldcom-MCI, Citicorp-Travelers, BankAmerica-Nationsbank, Daimler-Chrysler -- and now SBC-Ameritech: Sometimes it seems that a primitive urge to merge has been unleashed, a dread that corporations will cease to matter unless they can conjure up a market value of $50 billion. Every merger in the brave new world of global capitalism is different, of course. And in some, the rationale that bigger is more efficient really does hold up. But for every case of successful cost-cutting or marketing synergies, there is another story of the failure to integrate information systems or corporate cultures. Consider, for example, the Union Pacific-Southern Pacific merger, which has snarled rail traffic in the Southwest for a year.

headline: Some Restrictions on Baby Bells Are Upheld
summary: A Federal appeals court, ruling in a closely watched case, today upheld regulations that restrict the nation's regional Bell companies from entering the electronic publishing business. The case was brought by the BellSouth Corporation, the Atlanta-based regional phone company, which argued that the Federal Communications Commission restrictions were unconstitutional because they singled out the Bells by name. BellSouth also argued that the rules violated First Amendment rights of free expression.

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; A Convergence Of Companies, And of Futures
summary: Ameritech Corp chairman-chief executive Richard C Notebaert article on SBC Communications Inc's proposed acquisition of Ameritech; says at core of merger is recognition that fundamental nature of communications is changing; holds convergence--gradual blurring of telecommunications, computers and the Internet--is about fundamental changes in the way we live, work--even behave; says customers do not care how their application arrived; says what matters is whether application is fast and reliable and makes life easier; drawing (M)

headline: DIARY
summary: BABY BELLS Dial 'M' for Merger Can Edward E. Whitacre Jr., chairman of SBC Communications, put Humpty-Dumpty back together again? It seems as though wants to reassemble the telephone monopoly the Government broke up in 1984 when it forced AT&T to divest itself of the Baby Bells. SBC, based in San Antonio and the dominant local telephone company in the West, announced that it would acquire Ameritech of Chicago for about $62 billion in stock. The deal, which follows SBC's acquisition last year of Pacific Telesis and an agreement in January to acquire Southern New England Telecommunications, would re-create much of the old Bell system and make SBC by far the nation's biggest local phone company. Enough? No, Mr. Whitacre said; SBC will aggressively seek to move into the playgrounds of other Baby Bells. New York City is the prime target.

headline: The Nation; When Mega-Mergers Are Mega-Busts
summary: MARRY reliable old Daimler-Benz with go-go Chrysler? The union is bound to yield better cars. How about SBC and Ameritech, the telecommunications giants? Streamlining their front offices and linking all those zillions of phone cables into one awesome network ought to save billions. With industrial regulation out of fashion, even the largest mergers are greeted sanguinely by the stock market -- and Washington. Last week the House passed a bill that would end Depression-era controls on banking, opening financial industries to new mega-mergers.

headline: The Nation: Corporate America Plays Scrabble; Name That Behemoth
summary: IT is wedding season on Wall Street, and the most vexing issue faced by titans of industry as they prepare to tie the corporate knot is the same one pondered by a modern bride-to-be: Should she take his name? Keep her own? Hyphenate? So far, the uninspiring names adopted to symbolize the unions created by the latest megabillion-dollar mergers show it isn't an easy decision: SBC-Ameritech, DaimlerChrysler and Citigroup.

headline: Kathryn Maris, Herman Deetman
summary: Kathryn Anne Maris, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peter J. G. Maris of Old Westbury, N.Y., was married yesterday to Herman Jan Deetman, the son of Geertruida M. C. Deetman of Windsor, England, and the late Arie Deetman. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos, the dean of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York, performed the ceremony at the cathedral. Ms. Maris, 27, is keeping her name. She is a poet and an instructor in poetry and nonfiction for the Gotham Writers' Workshop in New York. She graduated from Columbia University and received a master's degree in creative writing from Boston University. Her father is an ophthalmologist in private practice in Hempstead, N.Y.

headline: Equity Offerings Set This Week
summary: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Short-Sellers Show Increasing Interest in Compaq
summary: Short-sellers continued to increase their bets against the Compaq Computer Corporation last month. The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that open positions of short sales in Compaq -- the number of shares that have been borrowed and sold but not yet repurchased -- rose to 78.6 million as of last Friday, from 74.9 million a month earlier. Compaq has been having problems with declining profit margins even as its inventories have been rising.

headline: MERRILL LYNCH IN TALKS WITH REGENT PACIFIC GROUP
summary: Merrill Lynch & Company is in talks to buy the East European and Russian businesses of Regent Pacific Group Ltd., a Hong Kong-based fund manager and securities firm, according to reports circulating in London. The purchase, which would be for $20 million to $30 million, would be the first for Merrill in Eastern Europe and would make Merrill one of Russia's five largest brokerage firms. Securities firms, including Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, SBC Warburg Dillon Read and Robert Fleming Holdings Ltd., view Russia as one of the fastest-growing emerging markets. Shares of Merrill rose $1.625 today, to $93.875.

headline: Corrections
summary: An article last Sunday about how corporations choose new names referred incorrectly to the company formed by the merger of SBC Communications and Ameritech. It will be called SBC Communications, not SBC-Ameritech.

headline: In the Region/Connecticut; Re-using an Industrial Area on Stamford's Fringe
summary: FOR three decades, businesses of all sorts have sought out the prestige of tenancy in the imposing office buildings in the heart of this city. Now, with first-class commercial space extremely tight, Stamford's dormant and underutilized industrial buildings in fringe areas of the city are being salvaged for re-use as nontraditional locations for offices, shops, health clubs, art galleries and even a trading floor.

headline: Sprint in Plan To Enter Local Phone Market
summary: The Sprint Corporation, the No. 3 long-distance telephone carrier, plans to announce today its long-awaited strategy for competing in local communications markets, executives close to the company said yesterday. The strategy is based on an ambitious plan to deliver high-speed access to cyberspace, the executives said.

headline: Travelers to Get 25% Stake in Japanese Brokerage House
summary: The Travelers Group and the Nikko Securities Company formally announced an agreement today that will give the Wall Street powerhouse a 25 percent stake in Japan's third-largest securities brokerage firm for $1.6 billion. The deal immediately raised questions about how quickly the Japanese financial industry would consolidate. The Travelers-Nikko alliance, which had been expected since reports of it first appeared here on Friday, came as Japan is undergoing a broad-based financial restructuring aimed at making its markets as flexible as those in New York and London by 2001. Japanese and foreign companies are exploring possible combinations that will help them better compete in this new arena, and in markets around the world.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Cuisinart of Phone Technology Fails to Whip Up Enthusiasm
summary: When the Sprint Corporation decided to whip up attention for a planned new communications network, it followed a careful plan. On Monday, it invited stock analysts and reporters to come the next day to the Richard Rodgers Theater in Times Square for an announcement about ''a revolutionary capability that will change the way businesses and homes use telecommunications.'' Once at the theater, Sprint's guests were treated to a dazzling multimedia display that included a cutaway replica of a technology-energized house on stage.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; When the Deal Doesn't Carry a Premium
summary: Call it the mystery of the vanishing premium. Typically, when a company is taken over, shareholders get a fat premium over the current stock price in order to entice them to sell. But this week, shareholders of the Monsanto Company were offered a mere 19 cents a share over Monsanto's stock price of $55.375 to fall into the arms of American Home Products, the big pharmaceuticals company. Though another bidder may emerge, and a shareholder suit was filed Tuesday seeking to block the deal, investors seem likely to go along.

headline: BELLSOUTH TO BEGIN OFFERING TV SERVICE TO ATLANTA
summary: The BellSouth Corporation plans to announce today that it has begun to offer television service to Atlanta residents using digital wireless technology. The company says it will offer the service, which includes more than 160 channels, to more than 700,000 households in the Atlanta area. The service's introduction there is expected to be good news for Americast, a television venture of BellSouth, Ameritech, GTE, Southern New England Telecommunications and Walt Disney. Americast is locked in a legal battle with SBC Communications Inc., which has withdrawn from the group, over whether SBC owes the venture more money. The service began in New Orleans last fall, and BellSouth plans to expand it to cover more than two million homes in Florida by the end of the year.

headline: Acquisition of Ciena by Tellabs, and the Power of Lucent
