summary: Just as the Ciena Corporation was announcing yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Tellabs Inc. for about $7.1 billion in stock, Lucent Technologies Inc. was illustrating why Ciena saw little future in remaining independent. Ciena had an early lead on Lucent -- and the rest of the telecommunications industry -- in making a complex type of equipment that can increase the capacity of long-distance networks by a factor of 16 or more.

headline: Investment Banks Set In Indonesia Privatizing
summary: The Indonesian Government named seven investment banks yesterday to advise it on the reorganization and privatization of 12 state-owned companies, with Goldman, Sachs & Company and Lehman Brothers Inc. appointed overall advisers to the program. The sale of the 12 companies, five of which have already been partly privatized, is expected to raise more than $2.5 billion for the Government and to generate $50 million to $100 million in fees for the investment banks.

headline: Connecticut Official Wants Rate Cut From Phone Merger
summary: The merger between Connecticut's primary telephone company and a Texas-based telecommunications giant should not be approved unless it includes a substantial rate reduction, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said today. The $4.4 billion deal that would allow SBC Communications of San Antonio to acquire Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation of New Haven was announced in January, but hearings by the State Department of Public Utility Control on whether to allow the deal to go forward started today.

headline: Samsung Curbing Output of Chips to Cut Back Inventories
summary: The Samsung Electronics Company of South Korea, one of the largest semiconductor manufacturers, said today that it would suspend all production of memory chips and much of the production of nonmemory chips for a week to reduce inventory and strengthen prices. Chris Lee, a spokeswoman for Samsung Electronics, said the company would all but shutter its operations at Kiheung in South Korea, though its other manufacturing sites, which produce home appliances and telecommunications components, would continue running.

headline: Gloom Over Asia Economies Spreads as Yen Drops Again
summary: It has been close to a year since Thailand devalued its currency, igniting a financial firestorm that hopscotched across Asia. Now, far from recovering, Asia's economies may be heading into a worsening decline. In dismal succession over the last two weeks, Hong Kong, Malaysia, and Indonesia confirmed that their economies shrank in the first quarter of 1998, and were likely to keep contracting the rest of the year. Japan, South Korea and Thailand are also in retreat, and even those that have managed to keep growing -- Taiwan, the Philippines, Singapore and China -- are slowing dramatically.

headline: JAPAN'S ECONOMY APPEARS BLEAKER
summary: The world's second-largest economy sank at a stunning annual rate of 5.3 percent in the first quarter of this year, according to official figures released today that painted an even bleaker picture than many economists had expected. While Japan's economy has been troubled for years, the latest, official numbers confirmed that economic output had declined for two consecutive quarters -- the definition generally accepted by economists for a recession. The numbers mean that for the first time since the oil shock of 1974, the economy declined for a full year -- falling by an annual rate of seven-tenths of a percent for the fiscal year ended March 31. It was Japan's worst postwar economic performance.

headline: Equity and Convertible Debt Set to Be Offered This Week
summary: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week: Allied Capital Corp., Washington, 5.75 million shares, 4.6 million in the United States and Canada. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. Alstom, Paris, an inital public offering of 109 million ordinary shares. Credit Suisse First Boston/Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: A Media Specialist Is Leaving Salomon
summary: Frank D. Yeary, head of the media and telecommunications investment banking group at Salomon Smith Barney, is joining Carlyle Group. Mr. Yeary joined Salomon Brothers in 1990 where, as a member of the firm's well-regarded telecommunications group, he worked on some of the most visible deals in the sector. He participated in a number of major transactions at Salomon, including SBC Communications Inc.'s purchases of the Ameritech Corporation and Pacific Telesis and the sale of McCaw Cellular Communications to the AT&T Corporation.

headline: Big Board Posts 2.3% Rise In Uncovered Short Sales
summary: Open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange increased 2.3 percent in the last month, to 4.02 billion shares as of June 15, up from 3.93 billion a month earlier, the exchange reported yesterday. The new figure equaled 1.8 percent of all shares listed on the Big Board.

headline: Equity and Convertible Debt Set to Be Offered This Week
summary: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Telecommuncations Issues Send the Dow Up by 95.41
summary: The stock market rose sharply yesterday on the strength of demand for shares in telecommunications equipment makers and cable companies after the AT&T Corporation agreed to buy Tele-Communications Inc. The transaction raised expectations that the demand for such equipment will surge in the consolidation of the telecommunications industry.

headline: Hooking Up The Nation
summary: A telephone giant agrees to acquire the cable company Tele-Communications Inc. in a bold move that promises to redefine the communications landscape. Sound familiar? It should. Nearly five years ago, another big phone company, Bell Atlantic, struck a merger agreement with the same cable giant. But that deal, which soon unraveled, was based on the vague plan of transforming telephone and cable networks into an ''information highway'' with 500 channels of interactive television -- something no one could be certain consumers even wanted.

headline: WITH CABLE DEAL, AT&T MAKES MOVE TO REGAIN EMPIRE
summary: The announcement yesterday that AT&T would acquire the nation's No. 2 cable television company, Tele-Communications Inc., for $31.8 billion in stock drew an initially favorable response from regulators but a concerned reaction on Wall Street. In the most ambitious result yet of Congress's 1996 deregulation of the telecommunications industry, the two companies said they wanted to begin selling digital phone and data service over the cable system by the end of next year but would not commit yesterday to a firm timetable. The companies said they would begin to bundle and jointly market each other's existing services even before the deal closes.

headline: For Local Bells, a Bright Side to the AT&T Deal
summary: After the AT&T Corporation said on Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire Tele-Communications Inc. for $31.8 billion, the stock of the five local Bell telephone companies dropped by almost 4 percent on average, shaving about $11 billion from their combined market value. AT&T, the thinking went, had moved to lessen its need to use the Bells' networks to reach local customers. By linking to consumers through TCI's extensive cable television system, which reaches 10.5 million homes, AT&T could reduce the amount it pays the Bells to begin and end long-distance calls, while building a platform to offer local phone service and high-speed access to the Internet.

headline: Hillary Smith, James Ehlen 3d
summary: Hillary Elizabeth Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. C. Bowen Smith of Claiborne, Md., was married yesterday to James Gordon Ehlen 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ehlen Jr. of Windsor, Vt. The Rev. Edward B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Universalist Church on Nantucket, Mass. Mrs. Ehlen, 26, is to begin studying in September for a teaching certificate from the Upper Valley Teacher Training Program in Lebanon, N.H. She graduated cum laude from Wheaton College and received a diploma from Christie's fine and decorative arts program. Her father is a managing director at SBC Warburg Dillon Read, the investment banking firm in New York. Mr. Ehlen, 28, is the founder and an owner of Madhouse Munchies, a snack food company in Wilder, Vt. His father is also an owner of the company and is the sole owner of Verdun Hill Partners, a holding company in Windsor for businesses in Vermont and New Hampshire. The bridegroom's mother, Carol D. Ehlen, is a freelance writer.

headline: New York Officials to Impose Sanctions on Swiss Banks Sept. 1
summary: Officials of the City and State of New York said yesterday that they would begin imposing sanctions on Swiss banks on Sept. 1, hoping that the two-month ''cooling off period'' would persuade Swiss bank officials and lawyers for Holocaust survivors and heirs to reach a settlement. Barring Swiss banks from bidding on overnight deposits, which average more than $2 billion just for the city, would be the first step, followed in stages by barring other business, canceling existing contracts and selling all stocks in Swiss companies.

headline: Compressed Data; A Line of Computers Without Windows
summary: As a market test, Ralph Nader's Consumer Project on Technology recently tried to order a personal computer from a dozen companies without Microsoft's Windows as the operating system. No luck, reported David Chun, the Nader summer intern who made the calls to Dell Computer, Gateway, I.B.M. and others -- not even when he asked for a PC with no operating system at all. He should have called VA Research in Mountain View, Calif. The upstart computer maker specializes in machines that run Linux, a freeware version of the Unix operating system. Linux (pronounced (LINN-uks) originated in 1991, written by a young Finnish programmer, Linus Torvalds.

headline: MacManus Loses Out In SBC Consolidation
summary: SBC Communications said yesterday that it had consolidated consumer advertising for its Southwestern Bell and Pacific Bell units at two of its roster agencies, GSD&M in Austin, Tex., and Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco. As a result, the St. Louis office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications, part of MacManus Group, was eliminated from the company's roster after almost 30 years. ''The decision was made solely on the basis of cost efficiencies,'' said Larry Solomon, a spokesman for SBC in San Antonio. ''It was not a matter of performance.''

headline: Technology; The big battleground in communications isn't in fast-track mergers, but in molasses-slow courts.
summary: MULTIBILLION-DOLLAR mergers are the most glamorous events in the telecommunications business. But potentially the most important development in the industry continues to be the legal battle between the Bell local phone companies and the Justice Department over the soul of the Telecommunications Act of 1996. The battlefront last week was in New Orleans, where the Federal Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit heard arguments in the Government's appeal of a December decision that would give the Bells what they most desire: immediate entry into the $80 billion long-distance market.

headline: Sprint Is Laying Out Details Of Plan to Revamp Network
summary: The Sprint Corporation has been laying out fresh details of an ambitious program to revamp its communications network to provide integrated data and video information at high speeds. Sprint, the No. 3 long-distance telephone company, announced the plan amid much fanfare last month, but investors were largely underwhelmed because the company provided few financial and technical details of its agenda. The company said it was building an advanced network but offered little to explain how it wanted to deploy and market the service and how it intended to work with local phone companies.

headline: Value of U.S. Mergers Tops $1 Trillion
summary: Domestic merger and acquisition volume topped $1 trillion for the year yesterday, shattering last year's record and moving quickly toward the $2 trillion projected for 1998, according to the Securities Data Company, which tracks merger activity. Financial institution mergers dominated headlines, with 226 deals valued at $224 billion announced in the sector alone. April was the most notable month, with announcements by Travelers Group and Citicorp, as well as the Nationsbank Corporation and the BankAmerica Corporation.

headline: Nasdaq Tops 2,000 as Dow and S.& P. Gauges Also Hit Highs
summary: The Nasdaq composite index topped 2,000 yesterday, powered by the high-technology stocks that dominate the index and investors' preference for big, well-known companies at a time when the market outlook is uncertain. In a day of choppy trading, the Nasdaq had trouble holding on at the 2,000 level. It broke through early, then fell as low as 1,982.48. It popped above 2,000 again early in the afternoon and near the end of trading.

headline: F.C.C. May Act to Aid Home Internet Access
summary: Moving to accelerate the delivery of high-speed Internet access to American consumers, the staff of the Federal Communications Commission is close to recommending that the big local telephone companies be allowed to build data systems without having to resell their use to competitors, officials said yesterday. The recommendation could come as soon as today, the officials said. If adopted, the plan would represent the F.C.C.'s biggest move in favor of the Bell local telephone companies since the telecommunications laws were overhauled in the Telecommunications Act of 1996. For the first time since the act became law, the Bells would be allowed to expand their networks without having to resell their systems to other telecommunications carriers.

headline: SBC and Ameritech, Awaiting a Merger, Beat Earnings Estimates
summary: SBC Communications Inc. and the Ameritech Corporation, which plan to merge, reported earnings yesterday that were slightly better than expected. At SBC, which is based in San Antonio, operating profit rose 20 percent from a year earlier. Ameritech, of Chicago, reported an increase of 11 percent in earnings from continuing operations. On a net basis, SBC swung to a profit from a loss a year earlier, while Ameritech's earnings more than tripled.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Lockheed Calls Off Merger With Northrop Grumman Faced with continued resistance from the Government, Lockheed Martin has abandoned its planned $8.3 billion acquisition of the Northrop Grumman Corporation. The decision followed months of negotiations between the companies and the Government to avoid a court fight. The deal's breakup signals the end of a wave of consolidation that swept through the military industry after the cold war ended. [Page A1.]

headline: LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES AND SBC SIGN $2.4 BILLION CONTRACT
summary: Lucent Technologies received a five-year contract worth up to $2.4 billion to provide switching telecommunications equipment to SBC Communications Inc. and its telephone subsidiaries. Lucent also received two contracts from the Saudi Telecommunications Company worth a combined $810 million. Under a $699 million contract, announced on Monday, Lucent will expand Saudi Arabia's G.S.M. mobile phone network, and under a $111 million arrangement modernize Saudi Telecommunications' telephone switch systems, which cover more than 900,000 telephone lines. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., builds communications networks.

headline: AT&T and British Telecom Merge Overseas Operations
summary: Creating a powerful new player in the fast-growing market for global communications, the AT&T Corporation and British Telecommunications P.L.C. announced a deal yesterday to merge most of their international operations into a jointly owned company that would have $10 billion in revenue. The alliance between AT&T, the nation's largest communications company, and British Telecom, Britain's leading communications provider, is a stark demonstration that even the brawniest of communications giants no longer feel big enough to take on the global marketplace on their own.

headline: TWO PHONE GIANTS REPORTED MERGING IN $52 BILLION DEAL
summary: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, which dominates the local telephone business from Maine to Virginia, has agreed to acquire the GTE Corporation, the nation's largest independent local and long-distance company, for $52.8 billion in stock, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday. The companies plan to announce the deal this morning, the executives said. The board of each company approved the acquisition last night, they said.

headline: Telephone Mergers: A Heated Game of Musical Chairs
summary: It would be a stretch to say that the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the GTE Corporation, two of the nation's biggest local phone companies, have agreed to a $52.8 billion merger out of fear. But not much of a stretch. The pace of deal-making in the telecommunications industry has quickened to the point that it resembles a high-stakes version of the children's game ''duck-duck-goose,'' with multibillion-dollar corporations desperate to get one of the gargantuan seats that will allow them to remain at the top tier of communications carriers in the next millennium.

headline: Phone Stocks Fall in Wake Of Merger Deal
summary: It isn't often that a merger announcement drives down the prices of stocks across an industry. But it happened yesterday, as investors absorbed the news that Bell Atlantic was paying $52.9 billion in stock for the GTE Corporation in a deal structured as a merger of equals. At the end of the day's trading, the Bell Atlantic-GTE combination looked more like the pin that burst the telecommunications stock bubble than a go-go megamerger. The group, which had traded at a price-earnings multiple of 27 earlier this year, was down to a below-market multiple of 21 yesterday. Months of merger hype and investor hopes went pop. Like that.

headline: Questions Arise on Bell Atlantic's Acquisition of GTE
summary: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the nation's largest local phone company, announced its $52.9 billion acquisition of the GTE Corporation yesterday, but critical questions began to mount about its structure and significance to consumers. A major theme coming from the companies yesterday was that the deal would be a true merger of equals, despite its financial setup as Bell Atlantic's acquisition of GTE.

headline: Contract for U.S.-Japan Undersea Link
summary: The French company Alcatel and the Japanese concerns NEC, Fujitsu and KDD-SCS have won a $1.1 billion contract for an undersea telecommunications network linking Japan and the United States, according to Alcatel. The sub-Pacific network, which will be 12,500 miles long, is intended to cope with a sharp increase in trans-Pacific telecommunications traffic.

headline: Phone Wars Leave F.C.C. In a Political Combat Zone
summary: After more than two years in the regulatory wilderness, the local Bell telephone companies are finally winning battles of influence at the Federal Communications Commission. Their biggest victory yet came last week when the commission recommended that the Bells, along with the GTE Corporation, be allowed to keep their local data networks to themselves instead of having to resell them to competitors.

headline: Competition Lags For State Phone Service
summary: FOR years, the Canon-Greater Hartford Open golf tournament had been sponsored in part by Southern New England Telecommunications, which provided telephone service in exchange for tickets and promotion. But in a cost-cutting effort SNET withdrew from the arrangement. So this year, the Connecticut Jaycees went looking for another company to help sponsor their fund-raising event. The replacement: Connecticut Telephone, a subsidiary of USN Communications in Chicago. ''They handled everything from the cellular service for the tournament managers, 160 phone lines on the golf course, a total of about 60 pagers, and all of our pay phone service as well,'' said Edward F. Kiernan, the tournament manager. ''No one noticed any difference.''

headline: 34,000 Telephone Workers On Strike Against U S West
summary: U S West and union representatives held no talks today on the first day of a strike that followed two days of negotiations with a Federal mediator. The 34,000 members of the Communications Workers of America are on strike against U S West, a regional Bell based in Denver that provides telephone service to 25 million customers in 14 states. The workers, who represent more than half of the company's 51,000 employees, walked off the job at midnight. They include operators, customer service representatives and field technicians, whose three-year contract expired today.

headline: Strikes Raise Key Issues Of How Bells Can Compete
summary: The stock of the Bell Atlantic Corporation has lost 11.8 percent of its value since Aug. 3, when the 73,000 of its employees who are represented by the Communications Workers of America authorized the union to call the strike that began the next weekend. Over the same period, shares of the other four local Bell telephone companies -- each with their own big union contingents -- have declined by an average of 3.8 percent. While three of them -- Ameritech, BellSouth and SBC Communications -- have signed new labor contracts since last spring, about 34,000 union workers at U S West walked off the job early Sunday after failing to reach an accord over contract issues that include a new performance-based pay structure.

headline: SNET Talks to Resume
summary: Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation, which provides phone service in Connecticut, and a union representing 6,300 of its workers are to restart informal negotiations today on a new contract. The Communications Workers of America, whose leaders last week rejected a tentative agreement that would have raised union wages 11 percent over 32 months, contends that the raises would not put SNET's pay in line with other phone companies and that some workers in the same jobs within SNET are not paid equally.

headline: Uncovered Short Positions Down Slightly on Big Board
summary: Open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange declined slightly last month, to 4.1 billion shares last Friday, the exchange reported yesterday. The decrease of 28.7 million shares in open short positions, less than 1 percent, was the first monthly decline since January. The latest short-interest figure was equal to 1 percent of all shares listed on the Big Board.

headline: Strike Called By Workers At SNET Over Contract
summary: Workers at Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation went on strike early this morning after a midnight deadline for a new contract passed without a settlement. SNET, which provides phone service to nearly three million people in Connecticut, and the Communications Workers of America, which represents 6,300 workers negotiated through last night, but talks broke down and workers called a strike at one minute past midnight.

headline: Resist the Urge to Merge
summary: OP-Ed article by RCN Corp chairman David C McCourt says wave of megamergers within nation's telecommunications monopolies are unlikely to create great companies; says industry is entering era of profound and dramatic change in which future is being powered by Internet and consumers' demand for competition; says big, traditional telecommunications companies do not understand Internet and have no interest in competition (M)

headline: Metro Business; Connecticut Allows Telephone Merger
summary: Connecticut regulators give final approval to merger between Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation and SBC Communications (S)

headline: Court Bars Bells From Offering Long Distance
summary: Dashing the main hope of the Bell local telephone giants for quick entry into the $80 billion long-distance business, a Federal appeals court in New Orleans reversed a lower court's decision yesterday that would have removed the main barrier between the Bells and the long-distance market. In a split decision, a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit restored the cornerstone of the Telecommunications Act of 1996. That provision requires the Bells to convince Federal regulators that they have opened their local networks to potential competitors before they are allowed into the long-distance market.

headline: A Local Phone Company Aims High
summary: Joseph P. Clayton, chief executive of the Frontier Corporation, wears his heart on his bumper. There, on the license plate of one of his three Cadillacs, is the clearest expression of Mr. Clayton's ambitions for the phone company he has run for a year: ''FRO 50''

headline: Amy Brunski, Thomas Hudson
summary: Amy Lynn Brunski, a daughter of Jill and David Brunski of Shrewsbury, N.J., was married there yesterday to Thomas Hudson, a son of Marilyn Hudson of Oklahoma City and the late Jim Hudson. The Rev. C. David McKirachan performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church. Mrs. Hudson, 28, is a technical writer in Stamford, Conn., for SBC Warburg Dillon Read, the investment banking concern. She graduated from the University of Delaware and received a master's degree in performing arts administration from New York University. Mr. Hudson, 30, is a researcher at Allure magazine in New York and a freelance writer. He graduated from Duke University and completed the Radcliffe Publishing Course.

headline: Fear and Loathing at a Growth-Stock Gathering
summary: ANYONE wondering what was on the minds of money managers attending the Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities investment conference last week got their answer Monday afternoon at a presentation by Judith Estrin, chief technology officer at Cisco Systems. After declaring that she would not talk about Cisco's sales or earnings, or even its products -- which link millions of computers around the world -- Ms. Estrin enthused over her vision of the ''new paradigm'' taking shape through the convergence of data, voice and video technologies. When she finished, a hand went up in the audience. ''Can you tell us,'' the questioner asked, ''how this convergence will affect revenues?''

headline: DELL, AT&T AND OTHERS OFFER INTERNET PACKAGE
summary: The Dell Computer Corporation teamed with the AT&T Corporation, Excite Inc. and SBC Communications Inc. yesterday to offer a package of Internet hookups intended to attract the growing number of people who buy personal computers mostly to get on line. Terms were not disclosed. Buyers of Dell computers will be offered Internet service through AT&T and then will be taken directly to an Excite site on the Web. The move by Dell, the No. 1 direct seller of PC's, follows similar offerings from the Compaq Computer Corporation and Gateway Inc. SBC Communications said that starting early next year it would offer Dell users faster A.D.S.L. technology, which speeds the delivery of Internet content over regular phone lines.

headline: Kirsten Botts, James Ward
summary: Kirsten Mary Botts and James Cameron Ward were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church on Nantucket. The Rev. Dr. Katharine Black, an Episcopal priest, officiated, and the Rev. Charles O'Bryne, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony. The couple work at McCann-Erickson Advertising in New York. The bride is a media supervisor and the bridegroom is a vice president of account management.

headline: For Sale: Free Software; Backers of Linux Say System Is Basis For Revolutionizing Computer Business
summary: In an experiment that is half business model and half populist movement, a small company called Red Hat Software is charging $50 for an operating system called Linux that anyone can get free on the Internet, and it is paying programmers decent wages to write code that it will give away. While that might seem the most contrarian of business plans, Red Hat is attracting blue-chip investors to the notion that free can be profitable.

headline: Small Network Consultant Prospers on Backs of Technology Giants
summary: Bell Atlantic had a problem. A big corporate client in New Jersey was convinced that there were problems with a new network that Bell Atlantic had built for it. Bell Atlantic knew it could exonerate the system but simply could not spare enough engineers with the right technical skills to set things straight. So the big telephone company did something that once might have been unthinkable for a bearer of the Bell legacy: it sought outside help.

headline: AT&T Buying Vanguard to Extend Reach
summary: Expanding its wireless network in the Northeast from big cities into smaller markets, the AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Vanguard Cellular Systems Inc. for about $900 million in stock and cash. Buying Vanguard could allow AT&T to further exploit the success of its new Digital One Rate pricing plan. That plan has shaken up the wireless communications business by eliminating long-distance fees and ''roaming'' charges for using phones outside of home areas.

headline: When Bad News Is Good News
summary: BASICALLY, two winning themes emerged in a quarter so dismal that gains of less than 2 percent could catapult a mutual fund into the top 10 among domestic diversified stock funds: plays on falling interest rates, and an overall search for safety. The Vanguard Wellesley Income fund, with a combination of stocks and bonds that neatly tied together both themes, ranked seventh among diversified domestic stock funds; its quarterly return was 1.65 percent. Many of its stocks are utilities, which have come into their own after struggling in red-hot markets.

headline: F.C.C. Likely to Halt BellSouth Long Distance Bid
summary: The Federal Communications Commission will reject the BellSouth Corporation's latest application to offer long-distance service in Louisiana, people close to the process said yesterday. The rejection, expected to be announced today, will surprise few in Washington or in the telecommunications industry; this latest petition, BellSouth's third, was generally given little chance to succeed.

headline: Battle of Phone Giants Has a Long Day in Court
summary: As the Microsoft antitrust lawsuit lurched toward trial, another important technology case, consolidating eight suits about local phone service, had a hearing before the Supreme Court last week. The complexity of the case -- oral arguments lasted two hours, twice as long as the Court usually permits -- should not obscure its importance to consumers. The litigation has potentially slowed the timetable for allowing residential consumers to choose their local service providers, a step that could save Americans billions of dollars on their phone bills.

headline: EASY MONEY: A special report.; For Russia and Its U.S. Bankers, Match Wasn't Made in Heaven
summary: The House of Unions, like so many buildings in Russia, has served many different masters. In the 18th century, a Crimean prince commissioned its construction in Moscow. Russian nobles later converted it to a private club. Lenin, Stalin and Brezhnev lay in state behind its bright green facade. And in June, as Russia lurched toward a financial crisis that set off global shock waves, the House of Unions was rented for a glittering celebration of capitalism, with one of the country's most ardent bankers, Goldman, Sachs & Company, as its host. Goldman flew in former President George Bush, paying him more than $100,000, and entertained Russia's former Prime Minister. But between toasts to United States-Russian ties, the talk was about what really mattered to Goldman and many Wall Street brethren: deals.

headline: Kia Motors' Suitor Must Now Face Reluctant Bankers
summary: Now that the Hyundai Motor Company has won the auction to take a controlling stake in the bankrupt Kia Motors Corporation and its Asia Motors subsidiary, it remains to be seen whether Kia's creditors will agree to the bid. Two previous auctions failed after the creditors, mainly large banks, rejected the demands of the bidders to write off large chunks of the two manufacturers' combined 16 trillion won, or $12.1 billion, of debt.

headline: SBC COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY 4% OF CONCENTRIC NETWORK
summary: SBC Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would buy 4 percent of the Concentric Network Corporation for about $21.9 million as part of a deal to sell Concentric's Internet-based data services to SBC's business customers. SBC, the No. 2 United States local phone company, will buy 906,000 shares for $24.15 each from Concentric, or will buy the shares on the open market. Concentric, of Cupertino, Calif., closed at $20.8125, down 31.25 cents, while SBC, of San Antonio, rose 68.75 cents, to $42.875. SBC also asked the Supreme Court to hear an appeal of a Federal court ruling that would make entry into the long-distance market for it and the other Bells conditional on convincing Federal regulators that their networks were open to competition.

headline: Metro Business; S.N.E.T. Sale Is Completed
summary: SBC Communications has completed its $6.5 billion purchase of the Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation, allowing SBC to move into the Bell Atlantic Corporation's northeastern territory. SBC said yesterday that the combined company would have annual revenue of about $27.1 billion, based on 1997 sales, and employ 129,000 people. Southern New England will continue to operate under the S.N.E.T. name at its headquarters in New Haven, Conn. Bell Atlantic is the largest local phone company in the United States; SBC is the second-largest. S.N.E.T. provides local, long-distance and wireless service, mainly in Connecticut. The acquisition moves SBC into Bell Atlantic's Northeastern market, which extends from Maine to Virginia.

headline: A Phone Fee Quirk Benefits New Providers
summary: As new local phone companies have taken on old communications giants, some of the upstarts have come to rely on a quirk of negotiation and technology that has grown into a cash cow. It goes by the name of reciprocal compensation. Reciprocal compensation, which is meant to make up for some of the new carriers' expenses, is costing the regional Bell companies and the GTE Corporation hundreds of millions of dollars a year, so it is not surprising that they think it is little more than an unfair loophole. By the end of this week, the Federal Communications Commission will almost certainly begin heading down a regulatory road that could mean the cash cow's demise.

headline: From 'Hello, Central' to 'Hello, Conglomerate'
summary: MORE than 60 years later, John T. Steck still vividly remembers the day he rescued a man clinging to a tree amid floodwaters near the Housatonic River in New Milford. ''The water was ice cold,'' Mr. Steck said of that day in 1936. ''Ice was coming down the river in big chunks 20 feet square and 2 feet thick. The chunks were so big they were knocking trees down.''

headline: Uncovered Short Sales on Big Board Fall 5%
summary: Open positions on the New York Stock Exchange fell by 5 percent last month, to 3.93 billion shares. On the smaller American Stock Exchange, uncovered short sales decreased by 7 percent, to 181.6 million shares. Open positions of short sales are those shares that have been borrowed and sold, but not yet covered by repurchase. If the share price falls, an investor can profit by buying shares at a lower price to replace the borrowed ones.

headline: BellSouth Is Seen Preparing For Next Financial Battles
summary: Wall Street has been waiting months for the BellSouth Corporation to do something dramatic in response to the consolidation that is happening among phone companies all around it. So far, BellSouth has not obliged. But yesterday BellSouth showed that it was determined to lay up supplies, in the form of value in its stock, in preparation for the next round of financial battles. The company said it would split its stock, raise its dividend and buy back up to $3 billion worth of its shares.

headline: Merger Wave Spurs a New Scrutiny
summary: With a huge plateful of large and complex corporate mergers to review and a host of major civil enforcement cases against corporate America's biggest names, antitrust officials are experiencing a renaissance. Federal officials report that they have filed a record number of challenges this year to mergers and other anticompetitive practices and have collected record amounts in civil fines and other penalties.

headline: Profit Woes Cause Broad Stock Losses
summary: Stocks fell again yesterday, pulled down by a host of year-end concerns that are not likely to be resolved for weeks, if not longer. Topping the list, according to analysts and traders, were worries about fourth-quarter earnings. Moreover, few expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates again anytime soon. And problems in important international markets like Japan and Brazil are continuing, and developments over the weekend in Washington did little to clarify how -- or when -- President Clinton's political future would be determined.

headline: Three Proposed Telecommunications Mergers Draw Challenges at an F.C.C. Hearing
summary: Three of the largest proposed telecommunications mergers in history were challenged today by consumer groups and rival companies at a hearing that raised fundamental questions about whether the broad deregulation of the industry, intended to promote competition, was starting to have the opposite effect. The hearing was held by the Federal Communications Commission, which faces some of its most significant decisions in years as it considers what to do. If completed, the deals would reshape the ownership of local and long-distance telephone service in the United States.

headline: Metro Business; Long-Distance Delay
summary: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the largest local phone company in the United States, says it will not seek approval to enter the $8 billion-a-year New York State long-distance market until the first quarter, later than expected. Bell Atlantic had planned to ask permission from the Federal Communications Commission by the end of 1998 to offer long-distance service to its local phone customers in New York. That has been delayed because state regulators, who will make recommendations to the F.C.C. on Bell Atlantic's application, have yet to finish evaluating the computer systems Bell Atlantic uses to process rivals' customer service orders.

headline: AT&T Passes Hurdle in Plan To Buy TCI
summary: The Federal Government took a big step toward redefining the Internet today when the Justice Department approved the proposed $31.8 billion acquisition of the cable giant Tele-Communications Inc. by AT&T. The deal, announced in June, still cannot be closed without the consent of the Federal Communications Commission, where officials said today that the agency's staff was still more than a month away from finishing its review under different standards and laws than those considered by the Justice Department.

headline: After $2.5 Trillion in Combinations in 1998, the Sky's the Limit in 1999
summary: You would think that after last year's more than $2.5 trillion in announced mergers worldwide -- the largest on record -- corporate executives might take 1999 off. Think again. With the stock market for the most part continuing its upward march, investors can expect even more mergers in the next 12 months. But unlike last year, when mergers were concentrated primarily in the telecommunications, banking and insurance industries, the frenzy this year will spread to other industries as well, merger professionals say. Even more international combinations are expected in the months ahead, along with a shift in activity to include industrial companies as well as increased activity in the burgeoning high-technology industry.

headline: The Urge to Merge Continues Among Telecommunications Concerns
summary: Every year is a big year for mergers in the telecommunications industry. At least, that's the way it has seemed since the Telecommunications Act of 1996 kicked off the biggest round of changes in the industry since AT&T was divided into eight pieces in 1984. But AT&T can still throw its weight around, as it did in forging the most important communications deal of 1998 - its agreement to acquire Tele-Communications Inc., the No. 2 cable company, for $32 billion. And that was in addition to taking over Teleport Communications Group for $11.3 billion, and putting together a $10 billion joint venture with British Telecommunications. The big local phone companies also continued to consolidate: In May, Ameritech agreed to become part of SBC Communications for $56 billion; in July, Ivan Seidenberg, far left, chief executive of Bell Atlantic, and his counterpart at GTE, Charles R. Lee, announced the planned $52 billion merger of their companies. Worldcom Inc.'s 1997 pact to acquire the MCI Communications went through last year, as well, but only after MCI agreed to sell its Internet business to Cable and Wireless of Britain for $1.75 billion.

headline: Corporate Medici Lost to Mergers, Arts Groups Fear
summary: The record number of mergers of large companies into even larger ones last year has raised concerns at many arts organizations and other nonprofit groups that a decline in corporate donations may be an unfortunate byproduct. Several of the merging companies say they will maintain their contributions. But ''what usually happens is that the combined companies do not give as much as each company was giving individually,'' said Ann E. Kaplan, research director of Giving USA, which tracks contributions. ''Companies by their nature are not philanthropic. They are giving to advance their business interests.''

headline: One Nation, Unplugged; The Titans of Wireless Are Tearing Down Regional Fences
summary: George F. Schmitt, president of Omnipoint Communications, a small wireless phone carrier, recalls sitting in his kitchen in Montville, N.J., one morning last May with Omni, his pet blue and gold parrot, and hardly believing what he was hearing. In a public conference call, top executives from the AT&T Corporation, the nation's biggest communications company, were explaining how they meant to rewrite the de facto rules for pricing wireless calls. Not only would AT&T do away with long-distance charges for wireless, but it said it would also end the additional ''roaming'' fees for using a phone when traveling to an area covered by a different company's network -- a charge that consumers had been resenting since the first mobile phones made their debut in the 1980's.

headline: Shares End Mixed as Nasdaq Rallies but Blue Chips Falter
summary: Stocks ended mixed yesterday, with many issues pulling back after last week's rally to record highs raised investors' concerns that the market was getting too expensive. The Intel Corporation was among the prominent exceptions, rallying on expectations that its earnings, which are scheduled for release today, will exceed forecasts.

headline: SBC TO OFFER HIGH-SPEED INTERNET ACCESS BY YEAR-END
summary: SBC Communications Inc. said yesterday that it planned to offer high-speed access to the Internet to 8.2 million residential customers and 1.3 million businesses by the end of the year. SBC, based in San Antonio, will offer Asymmetrical Digital Subscriber Line access, which uses traditional copper telephone lines to deliver fast Internet service. The technology, which requires special equipment and installation, is the response by Bell telephone companies to cable modems, which deliver fast Internet access via coaxial cable lines.

headline: At Last, a New Strategy for AT&T
summary: THE future of the AT&T Corporation is not hard to find -- if you can read a floor plan. It is in Room 4430G2 at AT&T's sprawling headquarters in Basking Ridge, N.J. There are five PC's in Room 4430G2, a big-screen television and a bunch of phones. Nothing special in any of that. What distinguishes the setup is what's missing: telephone wires. All the key equipment links to the outside world through a single cable television line. And the line is providing lightning-quick Internet connections, crisp video images and, of course, a dial tone.

headline: To Chief of Airtouch, a Deal Seizes a 'Bell Opportunity'
summary: Sam Ginn's gamble has paid off, hugely. With the acquisition of Airtouch Communications Inc. by Vodafone Group P.L.C., Mr. Ginn, the chairman and chief executive of Airtouch, will walk away with hundreds of millions of dollars from stock and options that he owns. The $60 billion being paid for Airtouch and Mr. Ginn's personal windfall represent a vindication of the big decisions that have defined his career. In 1992, as chief executive of Pacific Telesis Group, then the regional Bell company of California, Mr. Ginn decided to spin off the company's cellular phone operations into a separate company, Airtouch. And when the spinoff occurred in 1994, Mr. Ginn surprised many people by vacating his wood-paneled corner office at giant Pacific Telesis to run the smaller Airtouch.

headline: Internet Service Is Planning $6 Billion Deal to Buy Excite
summary: At Home Network, a high-speed Internet service aimed at cable television subscribers, is expected to announce on Tuesday that it is acquiring Excite Inc., a leading Internet destination, in a transaction valued at about $6 billion, according to a person involved in the deal. If completed, the deal would be one of the biggest in a flurry of recent Internet acquisitions, exceeding even the $4.2 billion purchase of Netscape by America Online announced two months ago.

headline: How the Bells Can Feel Like Helpless, Pitiful Giants
summary: It's hard being a regional Bell these days. When regulators are not shooting down your latest scheme for getting into the long-distance business or opposing your merger plans, your powerful unions might be threatening to strike or some upstart telecommunications wunderkind is breaking up a promising deal. That pretty much summed up the feelings of executives at the Bell Atlantic Corporation yesterday after finishing second with their bid to acquire Airtouch Communications Inc. Instead of creating the world's largest wireless communications carrier with a strong base in the Northeast, they watched Airtouch announce in London that it was joining forces with Vodafone Group P.L.C., Britain's biggest wireless company.

headline: New Service for High-Speed Net Users
summary: Snap, an Internet company partly owned by NBC, has developed a service that is tailored for the small but growing number of users who have high-speed connections to the World Wide Web. An announcement is expected today. The high-speed service, called Cyclone, has lined up partners including telecommunications carriers like Bell Atlantic, GTE and SBC Communications and on-line programmers offering a variety of information on travel, personal finance and entertainment.

headline: Supreme Court Roundup; 'Three Strikes' Challenge Fails, but Others Are Invited
summary: A California prison inmate, serving a sentence of 25 years to life under the state's ''three strikes'' law for shoplifting a $20 bottle of vitamins, failed to persuade the Supreme Court today to hear his argument that the law imposes unconstitutionally cruel and unusual punishment. But four Justices said the case raised ''serious questions'' that warranted further judicial scrutiny. Only one of the four, Justice Stephen G. Breyer, said the Court should take up this particular case at this time. But a statement by Justices John Paul Stevens, David H. Souter and Ruth Bader Ginsburg, labeling the issue ''obviously substantial,'' essentially invited other prisoners to bring challenges and urged the California and Federal courts to pay attention. The prisoner in this case, Michael W. Riggs, can pursue his constitutional argument through a petition for a writ of habeas corpus in Federal court, they said.

headline: SBC Communications to Buy Comcast Cellular Operations
summary: As part of continuing consolidation in the cellular telephone industry, SBC Communications Inc. has agreed to acquire the cellular telephone operations of the Comcast Corporation for $400 million in cash and $1.27 billion in assumed debt. SBC will add Comcast's 800,000 cellular customers, most in the Northeast, to the 6.5 million cellular subscribers it already has, also concentrated in the Northeast.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: 12% Gain in I.B.M. Profit Beats Wall Street Forecast I.B.M. reported a 12 percent gain in earnings, exceeding Wall Street analysts' estimates by 2 cents a share, as strong gains in software and services offset the economic turmoil in Asia and Latin America and pricing pressure on key products. For the quarter, I.B.M. reported earnings of $2.35 billion, or $2.47 a diluted share, compared with $2.09 billion, or $2.11 a share. Revenue rose 6 percent, to $25.13 billion. Before the earnings were announced, shares of I.B.M. rose $2.50, to $197. [Page C2.] Sun Microsystems, one of the biggest makers of computers that run the Internet, said its second-quarter earnings rose 22 percent. [C7.] Currency and Stocks Fall in Brazil A day after the Brazilian Congress approved austerity measures perceived by investors as a crucial test of the country's commitment to reduce systematic overspending, its currency and stock market fell, and fears mounted that Brazil is running low on dollars to pay for debts, imports and other expenses. [A3.] Judge Questions Microsoft Witness The judge in Microsoft's antitrust trial asked the company's expert witness on economics a series of skeptical questions, suggesting that the software giant may have a difficult time with one of its defenses -- that it does not have a monopoly in the market for personal computer operating systems. [C5.] Profit Falls 54% at Bankers Trust Bankers Trust, posting its next to last earnings report before the expected completion of its acquisition by Deutsche Bank, said its profit in the fourth quarter plunged 54 percent. [C2.] Promotion Within Insurance Family Jeffrey W. Greenberg, the eldest son of one of the country's most influential insurance executives, Maurice R. (Hank) Greenberg, was named president of Marsh & McLennan and was designated its next chief executive and chairman. As the eventual chief of Marsh, Mr. Greenberg will be heading a company that mainly arranges insurance coverage for corporations with American International Group, run by his father, and other insurers. [C7.] Rough Times for Drug Stocks After soaring 49.9 percent last year, the Standard & Poor's drug index, a bellwether of industry stocks, has become one of Wall Street's laggards. Not only has the index trailed the five-tenths of a percent gain of the Standard & Poor's 500, it has also notched a negative 5.49 percent return this year. Market Place. [C8.] Two Plead Guilty in Stock Scheme Two reputed organized crime figures pleaded guilty to charges that they participated in a conspiracy to manipulate the price of a stock in a scheme that the authorities have called the most ambitious yet by organized crime to infiltrate Wall Street. [B6.] Lucent Earnings Climb 26% Lucent Technologies said that earnings before charges and gains rose 26 percent in its fiscal first quarter, more than analysts expected, but that sales growth lagged behind forecasts because the company could not complete the paperwork on some orders in time. The shares of the telephone-equipment maker fell $8.875, or 7.7 percent, to $106.625. [C5.] SBC Communications reported a 17.8 percent increase in fourth-quarter profits driven by growth in services such as caller identification and voice messaging. [C5.] Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the securities firm, said its fourth-quarter earnings declined 32 percent as trading revenue fell. [C8.] Exxon, the largest oil company in the United States, said its fourth-quarter income fell 30 percent as crude oil prices plunged and profit from chemical sales fell. [C7.] Sears, Roebuck's profits fell in the fourth quarter after the retailer took one-time charges and suffered from falling clothing sales. [C7.] Boeing Close to Settling Bias Suit Boeing is close to settling a racial discrimination suit brought by hundreds of its workers nationwide, people close to the talks said. [C6.]

headline: Everything but a Dial
summary: IF it's true that choice can be a curse, then curses are raining down on consumers these days as they go to Best Buy and Circuit City to purchase what used to be the most elementary of instruments: a telephone. Long gone are the days when one telephone and one phone number satisfied a family's communications needs. Not only are most American households besotted with telephones, but more and more families are living among a tangle of phone lines and a confusion of services from phone companies.

headline: AT&T Plan Is a Search For Loyalty
summary: Let the battle of the bundles begin. When the AT&T Corporation said last week that it would start selling a communications package that charged an identical 10 cents a minute for long-distance calls made from either a standard home telephone or a wireless mobile phone, the announcement was about much more than savings for consumers. It was a sign that the long-simmering battle among the nation's giant phone companies to provide an integrated yet easy-to-understand basket of communications services had moved to the front burner. Look now for things to heat up in the battle of the nation's network titans, which besides AT&T includes companies like the Sprint Corporation, MCI Worldcom Inc. and the regional Bell companies.

headline: Nasdaq Has Another Record Day, While Dow Slips a Bit
summary: Stock prices finished mixed yesterday after investors, faced with uncertainty about the future course of interest rates, chose to take some profits in late trading. The afternoon selling choked off what had been a fairly broad-based advance. Still, the Nasdaq composite index rose to a new record.

headline: The Bell That Would Be King; Despite Recent Setbacks, Investors See a Brighter Future
summary: This year is only a month old, but by some measures it already seems that 1999 will not be kind to the Bell Atlantic Corporation, the nation's biggest local phone company. Last month, Bell Atlantic -- which serves 21.5 million households and more than 2 million businesses from Maine to Virginia -- lost out in the bidding to acquire Airtouch Communications Inc., one of the world's top wireless phone companies. Then the AT&T Corporation unveiled a uniform 10-cents-a-minute communications package aimed at least partly at Bell Atlantic's existing wireless business.

headline: Serious Talk About Funny Business; So Many Executives, So Few Light Bulbs
summary: Kathy Passanisi stood before more than 100 managers at Bausch & Lomb headquarters here and asked one what he would say if his son came home with spiked green hair and a cluster of earrings. ''You're starting to look more like your mother,'' came the reply.

headline: SBC to Acquire Stake in Unit Of Williams
summary: Trying to become a national communications provider, SBC Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would buy up to 10 percent of the Williams Companies Inc.'s communications unit, which is building a coast-to-coast fiber optic network. The deal between SBC, the No. 2 local phone company, and Williams could be worth as much as $500 million and would be the first significant investment in a long-distance carrier by one of the Bell local phone companies. While none of the Bells -- Ameritech, Bell Atlantic, BellSouth, SBC

headline: Cellular Companies Agree To Make Networks Compatible
summary: Two groups of cellular telephone companies and equipment makers agreed today to make wireless networks that use competing digital technologies work together. The agreement would primarily affect networks in the United States and Europe. The Universal Wireless Communications Consortium and North American G.S.M. Alliance groups represent such companies as the AT&T Corporation, SBC Communications Inc., the Omnipoint Corporation, Lucent Technologies Inc. and Ericsson A.B.

headline: Phone Product Under Testing Joins Voice and Data Features
summary: Northern Telecom Ltd. said today that SBC Communications Inc., the second-largest local phone company in the United States, was testing products that Northern Telecom developed to combine existing voice technology with new networks meant to carry heavy data traffic. The products, called Succession, allow phone companies to offer features like call waiting and 911 emergency service on data networks using traditional voice switches. Northern Telecom, the No. 2 maker of phone equipment in North America, behind Lucent Technologies said that the Succession line was compatible with switches made by competitors and that it planned to begin shipping the products in the fourth quarter.

headline: AMERITECH IS BUYING NETWORK DESIGNER
summary: The Ameritech Corporation, which is soon to be acquired by SBC Communications Inc., agreed to buy the computer-network design unit of Anixter International Inc. for $200 million in cash to add more data services for corporate customers. Ameritech, the fifth-largest American local telephone company, said yesterday that it expected to complete the purchase by April. Ameritech is trying to enhance its services as it prepares for increased competition from data-focused long-distance providers like MCI Worldcom Inc. Shares of Ameritech rose $2.1875, to $66.25. Shares of Anixter rose 50 cents, to $12.8125. Both companies are based in Chicago.

headline: Bonds Falter, Taking Stocks With Them
summary: Bond prices tumbled for the third consecutive session yesterday, pushing interest rates to their highest levels since August as reports of stronger-than-expected factory orders, jobs and home sales gave traders little reason to suspect the pace of economic activity is slowing. In turn, the rout in the bond market sent stocks sharply lower for much of the morning, but major market gauges later stabilized and then pared most of their losses during the afternoon.

headline: Markets Rally Sharply as Economic Fears Fade
summary: Investors, who were braced for bad news from the February jobs report, got a pleasant surprise yesterday that helped push bond yields down sharply and stocks higher. The Dow Jones industrial average set a new high, rising 268.68 points, to 9,736.08 -- just 264 points from 10,000. Instead of a jobs report reflecting surprisingly strong growth and threatening higher interest rates, investors got a more benign result.

headline: Metro Business; Bell Atlantic Deal Cleared by New York
summary: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the nation's largest local phone company, said its planned purchase of the GTE Corporation for $79.9 billion was approved by the New York State Public Service Commission, the 24th state regulator to either approve or decline jurisdiction over the transaction. The companies still await decisions from 15 more states affected, the Federal Communications Commission and the Justice Department. Bell Atlantic, which is based in New York, announced in July that it planned to buy GTE of Irving, Tex., the third-largest local phone company. SBC Communications Inc. of San Antonio is the second largest.

headline: INVESTING WITH: Bruce E. Behrens and Liam D. Burke; Flag Investors Communications Trust
summary: BRUCE E. BEHRENS assumed command of a sleepy-sounding mutual fund, Flag Investors Telephone Income Trust, at its inception in January 1984. At the time, its shareholders probably had no inkling of the breathtaking voyage ahead. The fund was conceived as a vessel for managing clients' investments in eight companies born with the breakup of AT&T; the original focus was on dividend income. But over the years, Mr. Behrens has branched out into other areas of the fast-growing communications industry, and he has shifted his focus from income to total return. Last year, the fund was renamed Flag Investors Communications Trust to reflect the changes, which have paid off spectacularly.

headline: MacManus Creating New Marketing Unit
summary: MacManus Group is creating a relationship marketing division in New York, Dialogue Works, by consolidating Ayer/Deare & Partners in New York, the relationship marketing division of N. W. Ayer & Partners, with two accounts and 25 employees of Clarion Direct in New Greenwich, Conn., part of Clarion Marketing and Communications.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: U.S. Trade Officials Warn Of Danger of Steel Quotas Facing a wave of protectionist sentiment, two top trade officials contended that a House-passed measure to impose quotas on steel imports would hurt the American economy, lead to raw material shortages and rising prices and could set off a trade war. Speaking before the Senate Finance Committee, United States Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky and Commerce Secretary William Daley said the quotas could disrupt the steel market. In spite of these warnings, the steel industry and some Senators vowed to push for quotas. [Page C6.]

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Revlon Shares Soaring On Takeover Speculation Shares of Revlon surged $5.1875, or 30.4 percent, to $22.25, on speculation that a buyer may soon step in and rescue the cosmetics giant from its huge debt and weak performance lately in the powder and perfume business. Revlon stock has risen 54 percent over the last two days on heavy volume. Investors are reacting to growing speculation that Revlon and the billionaire Ronald O. Perelman, who controls 83 percent of its shares, may be near a deal to sell the struggling company, which makes Revlon, Colorstay and Almay cosmetics, to a larger consumer-products concern. The two names mentioned most often by bankers and analysts as potential buyers are Unilever of the Netherlands and Procter & Gamble in Cincinnati. Market Place. [Page C12.] F.A.A. Grounds Kiwi International A day after Kiwi International Airlines thought it had won a reprieve from a Government-imposed death sentence, the Federal Aviation Administration grounded the carrier, saying that it was unsafe to fly. [B1.]

headline: Ameritech to Buy 20% Stake In Unit of Canadian Carrier
summary: The Ameritech Corporation, the local phone company set to be acquired by SBC Communications Inc., said today that it would buy a 20 percent stake in Bell Canada for $5.1 billion (Canadian), or $3.4 billion (United States), to take advantage of deregulation. BCE Inc., the parent of Bell Canada, the nation's leading carrier, said it would use the proceeds to invest in electronic commerce, satellite services and other fast-growing businesses. As part of the agreement, Bell Canada is being reorganized to include some assets previously held by BCE.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: CBS to Buy King World For $2.5 Billion in Stock As expected, CBS announced that it had agreed to buy King World Productions, the syndicator of television hits like ''The Oprah Winfrey Show,'' ''Wheel of Fortune'' and ''Jeopardy,'' for $2.5 billion in stock.

headline: Optimism Over the Internet's Growth Leads Shares Higher
summary: Stocks rose yesterday as Yahoo's acquisition of Broadcast.com raised expectations for consolidation in the on-line industry and lifted prices for SBC Communications and other telephone companies on optimism that the Internet's growth will increase demand for data transmission. ''People say the Internet is one of the best inventions since the Industrial Revolution,'' said Robert Bloom, the chief executive at Friends Ivory & Sime, which manages $4 billion. ''As long as the I.P.O.'s with the dot-coms after their names keep going up, this thing will continue.''

headline: F.C.C. Chief's Letter Raises Concern on Merger Plans
summary: In a rare public step, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission encouraged the Ameritech Corporation and SBC Communications Inc. yesterday to help draw up terms that would promote competition so the commission would approve the companies' pending $62 billion merger. William E. Kennard, the F.C.C.'s chairman, said in a letter to the chairmen of the two local telephone companies that ''at this stage, I have serious concerns'' about whether the deal would serve the public interest. But he gave no indication that he would prefer to reject the merger outright, a move that many communications experts continue to consider highly unlikely.

headline: Accounts
summary: * Thompson's Co., Upper Saddle River, N.J., part of the Sherwin-Williams Woodcare Group division of Sherwin-Williams Co., to Hanft Byrne Raboy & Partners, New York, to handle creative and media planning duties on the Thompson's Wood Protector account, which had been at SBC Advertising, Westerville, Ohio. Billings were estimated at $10 million. IDM International, New York, retains media buying duties.

headline: Ameritech to Sell Half of Wireless Business to GTE
summary: In perhaps the first major telecommunications acquisition to be described as a ''step forward'' for racial diversity, the Ameritech Corporation yesterday announced a deal to sell roughly half of its wireless telephone business to a venture led by the GTE Corporation for about $3.3 billion in cash. For Ameritech's pending $62 billion acquisition by SBC Communications Inc. to win regulatory approval, one of the two companies had to sell a big piece of its wireless operation. Federal rules prohibit companies from owning multiple wireless phone licenses in a single market. Because SBC and Ameritech's wireless units overlap in the Chicago and St. Louis areas, eliminating the conflict was a clear prerequisite to completing the deal.

headline: Refereeing The Future
summary: AS Bill Kennard raced through a whirlwind of meetings in Southern California one day last month, his passions and preoccupations as the nation's top telecommunications official quickly became clear. To a small group of studio and network executives in a screening room at the William Morris Agency, Mr. Kennard, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, offered his assurances that he had no interest in regulating the Internet, the medium on which many people in Hollywood are staking new fortunes.

headline: Some Profitable Broadening For the Boss's Portfolio
summary: How do you send a chief executive's compensation soaring if his own company's shares are merely doing well? In the case of SBC Communications, one of the Baby Bells, the board's answer seems to have been to sweeten the pay of its top executive, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., with shares in a hot telecommunications software company he doesn't even run. In addition to a 1998 pay package worth $15 million, including SBC stock options, Mr. Whitacre received a ''special retention award'' of $12.5 million worth of units, at the initial offering price, representing stock in Amdocs Ltd., in which SBC has a 23 percent interest.

headline: Telecom Italia Fails to Get Quorum to Oppose Olivetti
summary: Telecom Italia S.p.A., Italy's No. 1 phone company, has failed to win shareholder support for fending off Olivetti S.p.A.'s $65 billion hostile offer. The rejection opens the way for foreign rivals to join the bidding. Only 22.4 percent of Telecom Italia's shareholders attended a meeting in Turin on Saturday, too few for a vote on the company's proposed takeover defense. The proposal needed the backing from 30 percent of all investors, and the presence of one-third for a quorum. Olivetti had threatened to withdraw its bid if the proposal were accepted.

headline: How One Man Used Corporate Affirmative Action in Ameritech Deal
summary: Chester C. Davenport, the managing director of a private investment firm in Bethesda, Md., does not deny that he got a piece of the Ameritech Corporation's $3.3 billion sale of half of its wireless telephone business, at least in part, because he is black. But he will also tell you that after years of struggle, he has no problem with the concept of corporate affirmative action.

headline: Telecom Italia Seeks a Rival Suitor
summary: Telecom Italia S.p.A., Italy's biggest phone company, is seeking investors that will top Olivetti S.p.A.'s $65 billion hostile takeover bid, after shareholders foiled the management's defense plan on Saturday, a senior executive said yesterday. With the opening of Olivetti's offer at 11.5 euros a share less than a month away, Italy's former phone monopoly is talking to foreign competitors and some Italian companies about a rival bid, the executive said.

headline: A New Player Enters Italian Phone Contest
summary: Telecom Italia S.p.A., trying to thwart a hostile takeover bid by its main domestic rival, is discussing a possible merger with Deutsche Telekom A.G., Italian officials and others close to the companies said today. An agreement is far from certain, but such a combination would create one of the world's biggest companies, with a a stock market value of $216 billion and annual revenue totaling $63 billion.

headline: Capital One, a marketer steeped in information about its customers, picks its first outside agency.
summary: A FINANCIAL services giant that is helping to rewrite the rules of consumer marketing with intensive data mining -- using information to sell in unconventional ways -- is hiring its first outside agency. The company is the Capital One Financial Corporation in Falls Church, Va., one of the nation's 10-largest issuers of credit cards, with 16.7 million customers and total balances of $17.4 billion. The agency is D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications in New York, a unit of MacManus Group best known for campaigns for longtime clients like General Motors, M&M/Mars and Procter & Gamble.

headline: BellSouth Agrees to Acquire 10% of Qwest
summary: Seeking to expand into data communications, the BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 10 percent of Qwest Communications International Inc., the No. 4 long-distance carrier, for about $3.5 billion in cash. The deal could become the most important strategic move for BellSouth, one of the biggest local telephone companies in the nation, since it split from the AT&T Corporation in 1984. It is the company's first major response to the wave of deal-making that has swept the communications industry since passage of the Telecommunications Act of 1996.

headline: Income Higher At 4 Major Telephone Companies
summary: Several of the nation's largest phone companies -- the Sprint Corporation, the BellSouth Corporation, the Ameritech Corporation and SBC Communications Inc. -- reported strong gains in first-quarter earnings yesterday as customers bought extra services like voice mail and businesses used more high-profit data services. Ameritech led the group with a 20 percent increase, followed by a 14 percent gain at Sprint, a 13 percent increase at SBC and a 12 percent rise at BellSouth, excluding the effect of currency devaluation in Brazil.

headline: Phone Giants Say Merger Hinges on Role Of Germany
summary: Telecom Italia and Deutsche Telekom tentatively agreed on a merger pact tonight to form the world's largest telecommunications provider, but they said a final deal required assurances that the German Government abdicate its voting rights in the combined company. Telecom Italia's board, which met for a second consecutive day to discuss the merger, said it ''approved in principle.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: All Major Indexes Rebound A Day After a Big Selloff Shares of technology companies rebounded in heavy trading after Monday's selloff, and investors were seen moving out of economically sensitive cyclical stocks, like industrial and oil companies, which have been rallying. The Nasdaq composite index recovered 64.03 points of its 138-point loss on Monday and closed at 2,409.64, up 2.7 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 8.02 points, or one-tenth of a percent, to 10,448.55, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 16.69 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,306.17. [Page C14.]

headline: AT&T Profit Surges 42% On Cost Cuts
summary: Even as it continued its flurry of deal-making, the AT&T Corporation reported strong financial results for the first quarter yesterday, exceeding analysts' expectations. But investors did not rush to buy AT&T's shares as uncertainty continued about the company's unsolicited $58 billion bid to acquire Mediaone Group Inc., the big cable television company. Earnings for AT&T, the nation's biggest communications company, rose 42 percent from the first quarter of last year, largely because of an aggressive cost-cutting campaign by C. Michael Armstrong, the company's chairman of 18 months. More important, AT&T showed signs of finally emerging from the revenue funk it had been stuck in for years, increasing sales by more than 6 percent over the corresponding period of 1998.

headline: Plan by SBC Advances a Step
summary: Texas regulators yesterday signaled conditional approval of SBC Communications Inc.'s application to offer long-distance services in the state. SBC, however, must still file documents with the Public Utility Commission of Texas, detailing the terms under which it will work with rival local-telephone companies. And the company also needs to complete tests showing that competitors would have equal access to services and other elements that SBC uses.

headline: SBC-Telmex Deal Seeks Phone Carrier In Puerto Rico
summary: Betting on both wireless phones and the Caribbean economy, SBC Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had joined with Telefonos de Mexico S.A. in an agreement to acquire Cellular Communications of Puerto Rico Inc., the biggest wireless phone carrier on that island and in the United States Virgin Islands, for $464 million in cash. The deal, including $350 million in assumed debt, was the first move into the Caribbean for SBC, the No. 2 local phone company in the United States after the Bell Atlantic Corporation. SBC is the dominant local phone company in Texas and California and owns 10 percent of Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex, Mexico's dominant phone company.

headline: CONCERNS RAISED AS AT&T PURSUES A NEW FOOTHOLD
summary: A whirlwind of deals surrounding the AT&T Corporation's cable television ambitions raised concerns in Washington and in many high-technology quarters yesterday about the prospects for competition in the fast-growing communications industry. Having cleared the way to become the nation's biggest cable television company by acquiring Mediaone Group Inc., AT&T yesterday also moved to the brink of a partnership with the Microsoft Corporation, the software giant, to increase Microsoft's role as a supplier to AT&T's cable systems.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Russia and West in Accord On Need for Kosovo Force The Western allies and Russia agreed for the first time on the need for an international military presence in Kosovo to keep any eventual peace. But the composition of such a force and conditions for its deployment remained unresolved. A1 A senior Kosovo Liberation Army official said the guerrilla force would not allow itself to be disarmed, a central tenet of the peace proposal. A15

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Every U.S. Income Group Seems to Be Spending More American consumers are spending faster than they did last year. In the first four months of this year, sales in stores open at least a year rose 6.7 percent, one of the biggest jumps in years. That came on top of a dizzying 5.1 percent increase last year.

headline: F.C.C. Staff Cites Flaws in Phone Deal Plan
summary: The proposed $62 billion combination of SBC Communications Inc. and the Ameritech Corporation, two of the nation's largest regional telephone companies, ''flunks the public interest test'' and should be blocked unless conditions to encourage competition are imposed, according to staff investigators for the Federal Communications Commission. Thomas Krattenmaker, who has overseen the agency's review, summarized the staff's concerns yesterday at the opening of a public hearing on the deal in Washington. Mr. Krattenmaker stopped short of endorsing any of the deal-killing restrictions that have been suggested by opponents of the merger, such as requiring that the two companies first demonstrate that they have met the goals of 1996 legislation aimed at stimulating local phone competition. Nor were any of the five commissioners who must eventually vote on the deal present.

headline: Fast-Growing Phone Concern Said to Discuss U S West Deal
summary: Proposing what would be a formidable challenge to regulators, Global Crossing Ltd., an acquisition-hungry communications upstart, is in talks to merge with U S West Inc., the smallest of the Baby Bell local phone giants, in a stock swap valued at more than $30 billion, executives close to the talks said yesterday. While the negotiations are far from over and talks could fall apart at any time, the two companies could announce a deal as early as next week. Executives close to the companies said the boards of both concerns planned to meet this weekend.

headline: In the Region /Connecticut; Stamford's First Spec Office Building in a Decade
summary: THE first speculative office building in Stamford in a decade is to be built on the city's waterfront. The building is being planned by Collins Enterprises, which pioneered the waterside neighborhood but has not been active there for 20 years, and which faced opposition to the project from residents of some of the buildings it had built earlier. The 75,000-square-foot, $15-million office building is expected to be completed by the fall of next year. The developer, Arthur Collins Sr., chairman of Collins Enterprises, L.L.C. of Greenwich, was a major builder of luxury homes, residential condominiums and offices in Fairfield County from the late 70's through the 80's. Over the last five years the company has recovered from losses suffered during the collapse of the building boom in the early 90's.

headline: Sound of F.C.C. Silence in a Big Merger
summary: In all of the analysis of yesterday's $37 billion merger of U S West Inc., the smallest of the regional Bell phone giants, and Global Crossing Ltd., the international communications upstart, the most telling commentary may have been the sound of silence coming from the Federal Communications Commission. Under the Telecommunications Act of 1996, none of the Bells are currently allowed to sell long-distance voice or data communications in their traditional service areas. Through its pending acquisition of the Frontier Corporation, Global Crossing is set to become the nation's No. 5 long-distance carrier with about 10 percent of its domestic long-distance revenue generated in U S West's 14-state region.

headline: A Convert to the Cult of the Deal
summary: ON May 10, a week before his company announced a $37 billion merger with Global Crossing Ltd., Solomon D. Trujillo, chairman and chief executive of U S West Inc., used lunch at a midtown Manhattan hotel to emphasize his familiar philosophy on corporate consolidation. ''There are some that believe that bigger is better,'' he said. ''I'm not necessarily a subscriber to that theory. It is helpful, but it is not sufficient.''

headline: MCI Will Pay $1.3 Billion To Buy Skytel
summary: After denying earlier this week that it was in talks to acquire Skytel Communications Inc., MCI Worldcom announced an agreement late yesterday to buy Skytel, one of the nation's largest paging companies, for $1.3 billion in stock.
