The deal, announced after the stock market closed, will add wireless paging services such as two-way messaging and wireless data communications to the stable of local and long-distance telephone services of MCI, the nation's second-largest long-distance company after AT&T.

headline: 2 Senators Seek Limits on F.C.C.
summary: Firing their latest shot at the Federal Communications Commission, Senate leaders have introduced legislation that would eliminate the agency's authority to review most mergers in the industries it regulates. Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who heads the Commerce Committee, announced the legislation on Wednesday, the same day his committee held a politically charged oversight hearing on the F.C.C.'s operations.

headline: An American in Warsaw; U.S. Businesswoman Challenges Old Phone Monopoly
summary: The lobby of the Sheraton Hotel here was packed with dark-suited bankers last Wednesday, when Barbara J. Lundberg blazed in. Her strawberry-red hair, bright enough to spot across the huge room, had once again begun to rebel against her efforts to tame it. But her freckled face scrunched up in easy laughter.

headline: SBC Settles Case on Long-Distance Service
summary: SBC Communications and the Federal Communications Commission reached a settlement today stemming from a six-month F.C.C. investigation of the Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation's offering of long-distance services in SBC's territory. SBC, the largest of the regional Bell companies, purchased the Connecticut-based company known as SNET last October for $6.5 billion. While SNET is permitted by law to offer long-distance service to its customers, SBC and the other Bell companies are restricted from providing such service to customers in their regions until they prove to the F.C.C. that their local phone markets are open to competition -- something they have not so far done.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Serbs Protest Milosevic In a Devastated City About 10,000 people packed the central square of Cacak, a war-damaged manufacturing city in Serbia that is controlled by the opposition, to demand the resignation of President Slobodan Milosevic. Speakers said he had shamed Serbia, ruined the economy and tried to cover up his failures with a campaign of lies. A1 NATO troops mistakenly detained two top commanders of the Kosovo Liberation Army, believing that they were in violation of the demilitarization agreement. A10

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Phone Merger Approved, Subject to Unusual Rules Federal officials tentatively approved the $72 billion acquisition of Ameritech by SBC Communications provided that the new company not only open its market to competition but also offer local telephone service in 30 cities outside its existing region. Officials said the unusual regulatory approach for approving the acquisition was intended to drive down phone bills by encouraging competition in markets that have been dominated by one phone company. SBC and Ameritech executives said that regulators would impose stiff financial penalties if the new company failed to offer residential and business telephone service. [Page A1.]

headline: $72 BILLION DEAL OF PHONE GIANTS CLEARS BIG HURDLE
summary: Federal officials said today that they had tentatively agreed to approve the $72 billion acquisition of the Ameritech Corporation by SBC Communications Inc. provided that the new company not only open its market to competition but also offer local telephone service in 30 cities outside its existing region. Officials said the unusual conditions were intended to drive down phone bills by encouraging competition in markets that have been dominated by one local phone company. SBC and Ameritech executives said today that regulators would impose stiff financial penalties if the new company, which will be the nation's largest local telephone company, failed to offer residential and business telephone service in cities like Miami, Seattle and Boston within 12 months and New York, Washington and Phoenix within 18 months.

headline: A 'Practical' Solution; F.C.C.'s Give and Take in SBC-Ameritech Merger Deal
summary: At first blush, the $72 billion deal announced Tuesday with the Federal Communications Commission seems a high-stakes gamble -- with SBC Communications Inc. betting as much as $2.3 billion that it can compete in 30 new markets within 30 months for the right to acquire Ameritech. And in truth, SBC is agreeing to steps as radical as any phone company has ever taken to appease the F.C.C. in return for regulatory approval for a takeover. In addition to the commitment to expand into new markets, including New York, it accepted a long list of highly technical alterations to its network and business structure that seem sure to increase competition within its territory and that will require many dollars and many hours of engineering work to accomplish.

headline: Now, AOL Everywhere
summary: OVER the last year, the walls of America Online's rapidly expanding headquarters here have been dotted with plaques declaring the company's mission: ''To build a global medium as central to people's lives as the telephone or television . . . and even more valuable.'' But wait. Aren't telephones everywhere? And don't Americans watch seven hours of TV each day? How can Stephen M. Case, chairman of America Online, dare to think that his company -- which just a few years ago lurched from one crisis to the next and was largely a chat service for lonely teen-agers -- belongs in the same league?

headline: Compressed Data; 2 Officials at F.C.C. Say Merger Isn't Done
summary: The media coverage of last week's merger-approval deal between the staff of the Federal Communications Commission and SBC Communications Inc., which is trying to acquire the Ameritech Corporation, rubbed at least a couple of the five commissioners the wrong way. Though at least some news organizations, including The New York Times, said the agreement meant that SBC had cleared a big hurdle in winning approval for the merger, two of the commissioners said, in effect, not so fast. ''Contrary to the suggestion of some press accounts, neither we nor the full commission has indicated even tentative approval of the SBC-Ameritech transaction or conditions, Commissioner Gloria Tristani, a Democrat, and Commissioner Harold W. Furchtgott-Roth, a Republican, said on Wednesday. ''Indeed, to do so before the record has even closed would be improper.''

headline: BRITISH INTERNET PROVIDER SOLD
summary: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. said it had bought Internet Network Services Group, Britain's largest independent Internet service provider, but did not state the price. The company also declined to comment on news reports of an imminent bid for Cable and Wireless itself. The reports spurred a 6.6 percent increase in Cable and Wireless stock to $:8.33 ($13.1364). The Sunday Times of London said Cable and Wireless had been approached by would-be buyers including Deutsche Telekom A.G., France Telecom S.A., the Bell Atlantic Corporation and SBC Communications Inc. Alan Cowell

headline: Jumping Off the Bandwidth Wagon
summary: IN a dingy warren of cables and wires on Manhattan's Upper East Side, phone calls are starting to look a lot like pork bellies. There, in his cramped office above the Pulse Night Club, Alex Mashinsky, 33, has created an electronic trading floor for telephone service that resembles nothing so much as the international market for traditional commodities.

headline: MCI Worldcom In Deal to Build Internet Access
summary: MCI Worldcom Inc. made a big move into the consumer market for high-speed Internet access yesterday, announcing a partnership with Earthlink Network Inc. to sell retail services in as many as 25 markets by the end of the year. MCI Worldcom's Uunet operation, the No. 1 supplier of wholesale Internet access, has conducted high-speed tests with America Online Inc., the leading retail provider of Internet and other on-line services. But America Online has come to focus on the regional Bell local phone giants as partners for delivering high-speed Internet service to consumers.

headline: SBC-DirecTV Deal Is Set, Executives Say
summary: Adding television to its portfolio of digital communications services, SBC Communications Inc., one of the nation's biggest local phone companies, has agreed to a wide-ranging marketing and distribution partnership with DirecTV Inc., the big satellite broadcaster, executives close to the deal said yesterday. The companies plan to announce the deal on Monday at the Satellite Broadcasting and Communications Association's convention in Las Vegas, Nev., the executives said.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 New Israeli Leader Says He's Ready to Talk to Syria Prime Minister Ehud Barak told President Clinton that Israel would embark on a ''serious effort'' in coming weeks to reopen talks with Syria, which is still formally at war with Israel. But Mr. Barak laid down several conditions as the price of peace, an Israeli official said. A8

headline: Wireless TV Finally Gets Validation
summary: The telecommunications industry is not known for being cyclical, but don't tell that to Matthew Oristano. Last October, a share of the People's Choice TV Corporation, a so-called wireless cable television company based in Shelton, Conn., that Mr. Oristano leads as chief executive, cost as little as 15.625 cents. On Friday, those shares closed at $9.50, a gain of about 6,000 percent. (For those of you keeping score at home, that means that a $500 investment in People's Choice last fall would be worth more than $30,000 today.)

headline: Neat Package Hides Issues In Phone Deal
summary: As the smoke clears from the communications industry's latest takeover battleground, the companies that recently fired so many billion-dollar salvos -- Global Crossing, Frontier, Qwest and U S West -- have left unresolved questions scattered like so many shell cases. Judging by the news releases, it all looks fairly simple -- a win-win web of deals that leaves each company in a stronger position to profit from the expanding demand for advanced communications. U S West Inc., the smallest of the Bell local phone giants, is to merge with Qwest Communications International Inc., the long-distance upstart, while Global Crossing Ltd., an undersea cable company, acquires the Frontier Corporation, which owns an advanced national communications network.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: G.M. Profit Beats Forecast But Market Share Shrinks Pocketing higher profits even as its market share continues to erode, General Motors said that it earned $1.73 billion in the second quarter, a vast improvement over the $306 million it earned from continuing operations during the period last year, when there was a costly strike. The results amounted to $2.66 a share and beat analysts' expectations of $2.56 a share. Second-quarter revenue rose to $45.07 billion from $37.27 billion, allowing G.M. to maintain its position as the world's largest company, ahead of Ford. In a down market, shares of G.M. fell $1.8125, to $66.50. [Page C2.]

headline: 2 Internet Companies Have Solid Quarter
summary: Despite a slowdown in the growth of on-line use in the spring, two of the largest Internet companies reported results yesterday that largely confirmed analysts' expectations for the quarter ending on June 30. America Online, the dominant provider of Internet services for home users, earned $160 million, slightly ahead of expectations, as its advertising revenue grew briskly.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Merger Deal With Plenty Of Intrigue
summary: Yesterday's $2.1 billion agreement by Cincinnati Bell to acquire IXC Communications clearly lacked the cachet of last weekend's merger deal between U S West and Qwest Communications International, but it said at least as much about the telecommunications industry's strategic direction -- and it involved even more board room bloodshed. IXC could have had Qwest's fabulous success as an upstart long-distance communications carrier. Qwest now has a market value of more than $22 billion. In 1996, IXC was first to offer shares to the public on plans to build a nationwide fiber optic communications network, just like Qwest, which did not go public until a year later.

headline: Compressed Data; Large Phone Contract From South Africa
summary: The newly renamed American company Telcordia Technologies Inc. plans today to announce a big contract to help modernize Telkom South Africa's antiquated telephone systems and bring phone service to millions of South Africans for the first time. The exact size of the deal was not revealed, but the contract will be worth hundreds of millions of dollars to Telcordia over roughly three years, executives close to the agreement said last Friday.

headline: What's in a name? Well, no more TCI. After the acquisition, AT&T goes on a rebranding tear.
summary: IF the Mercedes-Benz brand name can be affixed to a sport-utility vehicle, if the Heinz brand name can appear on mustard and if the Fritos brand name can be attached to chili, then why not use the AT&T brand name for cable television service? The AT&T Corporation is doing just that, announcing yesterday an ambitious ''rebranding'' program to change the name of all products and services offered by Tele-Communications Inc., which AT&T acquired in March for $59.4 billion. Beginning Tuesday, the TCI Cable name will disappear, to be replaced by the moniker AT&T Cable Services, part of a unit known as AT&T Broadband and Internet Services, as well as the AT&T blue-globe logo.

headline: Setting Federal Policy A Town at a Time
summary: Op-Ed article by Michael Yaki, member of San Francisco Board of Supervisors, says United States Government has given local governments responsibility to referee issues on future of America's huge telecommunications industry; describes scene at San Francisco City Hall when lobbyists, lawyers, public relations consultants and political consultants descended to plead case of various telecommunications companies; drawing (M)

headline: 6 Phone Companies Seek to Cut Fees for Long-Distance Carriers
summary: Six of the country's largest telephone companies have proposed to cut the fees local companies charge long-distance companies to complete calls by a total of about $5.6 billion a year for five years. The long-distance companies AT&T and Sprint and four regional companies -- GTE, Bell Atlantic, BellSouth and SBC Communications -- filed the proposal with the Federal Communications Commission late last week. The agreement, covering so-called access charges, is subject to F.C.C. approval.

headline: G.M. and Daewoo Sign Deal That May Lead to Alliance
summary: The General Motors Corporation today signed an agreement that could lead to an alliance with the Daewoo Motor Company, the core of South Korea's struggling Daewoo Group. G.M., the world's largest auto maker, could end up buying assets from Daewoo or taking a stake in the company, possibly even a controlling stake, said Alan G. Perriton, president of General Motors Korea and head of new business ventures and strategic alliances in the Asia-Pacific region.

headline: INVESTING WITH: Rand L. Alexander; Hartford Stock Fund
summary: MANY money managers focus on their stocks and ignore the economy, but Rand L. Alexander is a big-picture guy. ''We look at macroeconomic data to see what sectors and industries in the U.S. will grow fastest over the next 12 to 18 months, given our economic outlook,'' said Mr. Alexander, manager of the $1.02 billion Hartford Stock fund and a partner in the Wellington Management Company, a money manager in Boston that is also subadviser for other funds, like Vanguard Wellington and Vanguard Windsor.

headline: TECHNOLOGY: The Outlook for Cable Access; An AT&T-AOL Deal Would Rain On Excite@Home's Parade
summary: As the AT&T Corporation, the nation's biggest telephone company, has marched into the cable television business, it has found itself locked in a battle of legal briefs, lobbying salvos and public relations campaigns against America Online Inc. The fight over ''open access'' to AT&T's cable systems has raged in local communities from Broward County, Fla., to Portland, Ore., and America Online, the nation's largest gateway to cyberspace, has consistently argued that AT&T must let Internet carriers link directly to AT&T's cable systems. Such connections would bypass communications systems and Web services developed by Excite@Home, an Internet-over-cable company that is backed by many big cable television players -- including AT&T.

headline: Metro Business; Bell Atlantic Takes A Step in Phone Deal
summary: Bell Atlantic Corporation, the largest local telephone company in the country, says it has cleared a major hurdle in its effort to enter the $80 billion long-distance market. On Friday, KPMG Peat Marwick, which operates a performance review service, released the final results of a monthslong test in New York of Bell Atlantic's computer systems to make sure they can handle large volumes of customer service orders from competitors.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Fund Manager Planning to Come Off the Sideline
summary: It has been a busy summer for Julian H. Robertson Jr., who runs $11 billion in several hedge funds at Tiger Management. The hedge-fund manager is fighting to remove the chairman of the SK Telecom Company, the largest mobile-phone company in South Korea, while he tries to raise the sagging stock price of one of his largest holdings, U S Airways Group. Now Mr. Robertson is pledging to become even more active, playing a stronger role influencing the managements of some companies in which he invests. In a letter dated Aug. 6, he told investors why he is taking this position and described steps to improve Tiger's recent poor performance, including a loss of 6.2 percent in July.

headline: Appeals Court Overturns F.C.C. Phone Rule
summary: A United States Federal appeals court has overturned a Federal Communications Commission rule that limits phone companies' ability to use customer information to market products and services. The Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit ruled on Wednesday that the rule violated the First Amendment's free speech protections. The regulation prohibited companies from using the information to market services unrelated to those that consumers already subscribed to. For instance, the information could not be used to sell cellular service to a local phone customer.

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; Consumers keep saying they want personal information kept private. What will it take to get industry to listen?
summary: IF privacy is indeed the pivotal concern for people who use data networks -- and by every objective indication to date, it is -- then why are companies and law enforcement agencies still getting away with monitoring and collecting, and using and selling, as much of our personal data as they can get their hands on? What is it about ''no'' that these folks don't understand?

headline: Global Crossing Is Expected To Sweeten Bid
summary: In an attempt to reinvigorate its flagging effort to acquire the Frontier Corporation, one of the nation's biggest long-distance telephone carriers, Global Crossing Ltd. has offered to modestly sweeten its bid in exchange for Frontier's commitment to spurn other suitors, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday. Frontier's board met last night to consider Global Crossing's latest offer, the executives said. If Frontier's board does approve the new deal, the companies will probably announce the agreement today.

headline: Boards Study Bell Atlantic-Vodafone Deal
summary: The boards of the Bell Atlantic Corporation, the nation's largest local phone company, and the international wireless giant Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C. are expected to meet today to approve the combining of the companies' United States wireless businesses. The board of GTE, which agreed to be bought by Bell Atlantic for $52 billion in a deal set to close next year, is also meeting to discuss the transaction. If the boards approve the deal, valued at $70 billion to $80 billion, the companies plan to announce it tomorrow morning at a news conference in New York. Even as late as last night, though, executives and advisers for the companies were working out last-minute details, including who would be on the management team. Bell Atlantic and GTE have not announced their own management team of those combined companies.

headline: Small, Local Phone Carriers Go in Search Of Big Suitors
summary: Psst, wanna buy a phone company? That is not quite how Wall Street takeover pitches are made, but it captures the gist of the calls that have gone out across the telecommunications industry recently as at least a few competitive local exchange carriers -- young communications companies trying to compete against the Bells in local phone and data communications markets -- look to be acquired.

headline: BECAUSE OF SBC TAKEOVER, AMERITECH ENDS BUYBACK PLAN
summary: The Ameritech Corporation, the No. 5 local phone company, said yesterday that it was rescinding the remaining portion of a $2 billion stock buyback plan because of the SBC Communications Corporation's $76.9 billion purchase of the company. The Chicago-based Ameritech did not say how much stock it had repurchased under the plan. Ameritech began the plan in January 1998 to increase the value of its stock. SBC, the No. 2 local phone company, is buying Ameritech to form the biggest United States local telephone company. The purchase is under review by Federal officials. Ameritech's shares fell $1.5625 each, to $62.1875.

headline: F.C.C. Says Bells and GTE Needn't Share Internet Gear
summary: New Federal rules will not force the regional Bell telephone companies and the GTE Corporation to lease equipment for high-speed Internet service to competitors. Focal Communications Inc. and other new competitors had argued that they needed low-cost access to such special equipment to compete for new customers. The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the BellSouth Corporation, the Ameritech Corporation, SBC Communications Inc., U S West Inc. and GTE said they would lose the financial incentive to spend the hundreds of millions of dollars needed to deploy the new technology if, after making the investment, they had to sell those services to competitors at a discount.

headline: Long Distance By Bell Atlantic Expected Soon
summary: Fifteen years after the court-supervised breakup of AT&T, a part of the old Ma Bell stands a good chance of being allowed to offer customers both long-distance and local service. The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the nation's biggest local telephone company, plans to ask Federal regulators, perhaps as soon as today, for permission to sell long-distance communications services in New York State. Approval would make it the first Baby Bell to enter the $80 billion long-distance market.

headline: Now Found in Bell Atlantic's Corner: New York Regulators
summary: At about 8:30 yesterday morning, workers dispatched by the Bell Atlantic Corporation, the nation's biggest local telephone company, began unloading 30 boxes of documents from trucks outside the Washington offices of the Federal Communications Commission. The boxes contained three copies of Bell Atlantic's application to sell long-distance communications services to consumers and businesses in New York State. If the petition is granted, Bell Atlantic will become the first regional Bell admitted to the $80 billion long-distance market.

headline: F.C.C. Expected to Approve SBC-Ameritech Merger
summary: Clearing the way for SBC Communications Inc. to become the nation's biggest local phone company, albeit temporarily, the Federal Communications Commission is set to approve SBC's $72 billion deal to acquire the Ameritech Corporation as soon as today, people close to the commission said on Friday. Although there has been resistance to the merger from Capitol Hill and by at least one F.C.C. commissioner, a majority of the five members of the regulatory agency appear to be lined up in support of the deal.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Vulcan Agrees to Invest, $1.7 Billion in RCN Vulcan Ventures, making its biggest move yet into the telecommunications industry, has agreed to invest about $1.7 billion in the RCN Corporation. Vulcan, the investment shop controlled by Paul Allen, is expected to announce the deal today. RCN, based in Princeton, N.J., is the biggest of the companies competing against the regional Bell carriers in local phone markets for the business of residential consumers rather than corporate customers. [Page C2.]

headline: Dueling Bids Emerge for Sprint, 3d-Largest Long-Distance Carrier
summary: A takeover battle for the Sprint Corporation, the nation's third-largest long-distance company, erupted over the weekend as two suitors emerged with competing offers, people close to the companies said. If either of the current offers was accepted, the deal would be the largest business takeover yet.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Russia and U.S. Consider Ways to Monitor Test Ban Top Russian and American nuclear officials said they have begun considering new ways to prevent cheating on a landmark treaty banning nuclear weapons tests, as the White House and Senate Republicans prepare for a bruising battle over the treaty. Energy Secretary Bill Richardson said that he had proposed several measures to strengthen monitoring of the pact, and Russia's Minister of Atomic Energy said he was willing to open talks on the proposals. A1 Russia Raids Chechen Villages Russian missile strikes hit villagers and farmhouses in the Chechen villages of Dargo and Benoy. Russian officials have hinted that they intend to continue the assaults, and even send ground troops, until they can create a buffer along the border with Dagestan, to protect it from militants who want set up an independent Islamic state. A1

headline: MCI TO BUY SPRINT IN SWAP OF STOCK FOR $108 BILLION
summary: MCI Worldcom Inc., the nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company, has agreed to acquire the Sprint Corporation in a stock swap valued at $108 billion, people close to the talks said yesterday. The boards of both companies approved the merger last night. The deal, which is expected to be announced today, would be the largest acquisition in corporate history and caps a days-long takeover battle for Sprint, the nation's third-largest long-distance company. Sprint had been discussing a merger with MCI Worldcom for two weeks but received a $100 billion unsolicited offer on Saturday from BellSouth, the Atlanta-based regional Bell company, prompting MCI Worldcom to raise its bid yesterday.

headline: F.C.C. Chief Says Phone Deal Faces Stiff Review
summary: The head of the Federal Communications Commission sharply questioned today how MCI Worldcom's $115 billion agreement to buy Sprint could benefit consumers and warned that the companies would have to meet a high standard to persuade him to approve the deal. William E. Kennard, the commission chairman, has typically been circumspect in his public pronouncements about large mergers destined to come before him. But talking to reporters after delivering a speech here this morning, he was uncharacteristically blunt, raising the prospect that the companies were in for a tough time with at least one of the two Federal agencies whose approvals are required.

headline: F.C.C. Begins Rewriting Rules For Industry in Consolidation
summary: Federal officials this week began setting the conditions they will impose on a wave of proposed mergers that promises to consolidate, blur and redefine the nation's phone, cable and broadcast industries in a matter of months. Today, the Federal Communications Commission approved SBC Communications Inc.'s $72 billion takeover of the Ameritech Corporation, but imposed conditions that officials said were intended to force SBC to be more competitive with other regional and local phone companies.

headline: OWNERSHIP RULES IN CABLE INDUSTRY LOOSENED BY F.C.C.
summary: The Federal Communications Commission decided today to loosen substantially the rules that keep one company from controlling too much of the cable industry. The new rules clear the way for AT&T to own more than a third of the nation's franchises offering subscribers television, telephone and high-speed Internet services as well as own major interests in a number of major video producers and television programmers. Coming after a wave of huge telecommunications mergers, the decision lays down the second important policy marker of the week -- that the Government is willing to tolerate heavy concentration in one industry, like cable television, if it holds the promise of offering competition in another, like local telephone service.

headline: Control of the Electronic Highway
summary: A bewildering series of mergers and regulatory actions in the telecommunications industry in the past two weeks could ultimately improve telephone service to consumers. But some of the mergers designed to make local phone service better risk constraining what viewers can see on their cable systems, threatening the diversity of information that is central to democracy. A scorecard was needed to keep track of all the recent maneuvers. Bell Atlantic, the largest local phone company, asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to enter long-distance service, where it would take on AT&T, MCI Worldcom and Sprint, thereby increasing competition. But then MCI Worldcom and Sprint decided to merge, a move that would lessen competition. Meanwhile, the commission approved the merger of SBC Communications and Ameritech, two large regional Bell companies. It also approved rules that will make it easier for AT&T, a huge cable operator, to take over another cable company, Mediaone, putting about 60 percent of American households within reach of AT&T's cable programs.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Bear Stearns Securities To Pay $3.5 Million More Bear Stearns Securities, which processes securities transactions for thousands of smaller firms, has agreed to pay an additional $3.5 million to cover losses incurred by customers of A. R. Baron, a defunct brokerage firm whose trades it cleared. The payment settles the claims against Bear Stearns brought by the trustee appointed to liquidate A. R. Baron. It brings to $42 million the total fines, restitution and court costs the firm has agreed to pay. [Page C2.]

headline: SBC Communications to Offer High-Speed Internet Connections
summary: Firing the latest salvo in the local telephone industry's battle against cable television providers, SBC Communications Inc. intends to announce today that it will spend $6 billion in the next three years to deploy high-speed Internet systems, people close to the company said yesterday. Within three years, SBC intends to offer high-speed cyberspace links to 80 percent of its customers using a technology called digital subscriber line, or D.S.L., which uses normal telephone lines. SBC recently completed its acquisition of the Ameritech Corporation, the Midwestern telephone giant, making SBC the local phone provider for about a third of the nation's roughly 100 million households. That deal made SBC the nation's No. 1 local telephone company, at least until the Bell Atlantic Corporation completes its merger with the GTE Corporation.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Pakistani General Forms Panel to Govern Nation Pakistan's military ruler, saying his nation had ''hit rock bottom,'' redrew its Government, creating a military and civilian council to run the country and giving no timetable for relinquishing the absolute power he seized five days ago. Gen. Pervez Musharraf said he would unilaterally withdraw troops from India's border and pursue peace talks. A1 Montenegro May Add Currency The president of Montenegro, Milo Djukanovic, said the Government would create a second currency tied to the German mark within days if Belgrade formally devalued the Yugoslav dinar. This would be one more step toward independence from Slobodan Milosevic's Yugoslavia. A6

headline: New York Backs Bell Atlantic In Bid to Offer Long-Distance
summary: Bolstering the Bell Atlantic Corporation's bid to sell long-distance communications services to New York consumers by the end of the year, the New York State Public Service Commission told Federal regulators yesterday that the company had opened its local networks to competitors. Shortly after Bell Atlantic, the No. 2 local phone company in the nation, filed its long-distance application for New York with the Federal Communications Commission last month, the New York commission's chairwoman, Maureen O. Helmer, signaled that she was inclined to support the petition. Yesterday's formal comments in support of Bell Atlantic appeared to set in motion a chain of government approvals that will probably result in Bell Atlantic's becoming the first Baby Bell to win long-distance entry.

headline: Another Company Gives Up Its State Flag
summary: Article on growing number of companies based in Connecticut that are being bought by outsiders and moving out of state; focuses on Northeast Utilities, based in Berlin, Conn, which has agreed to merge with Consolidated Edison; photos (M)

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 U.S. Officials Had Doubts About Attack in Sudan Interviews with key participants indicate that the decision by the Clinton Administration to attack a pharmaceutical plant in Sudan 14 months ago was far more difficult to make than the Administration has acknowledged and that there were numerous voices of dissent. A1

headline: INSIDE
summary: Dow to Change Lineup The Dow Jones industrial average will drop four lagging stocks and substitute four companies that have done much better: Microsoft, Intel, Home Depot and SBC Communications. -- PAGE C1

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Dow Takes On a New, High-Technology Look
summary: THE Dow Jones industrial average, whose performance has trailed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in recent years, dropped four lagging stocks yesterday and substituted four companies that have done much better. By adding two high-flying technology companies, the Microsoft Corporation and the Intel Corporation, the editors of The Wall Street Journal, who determine the index's components, made it likely that the Dow will be more volatile than it has been. Whether it will also be a better performer is likely to turn on the question of whether large technology stocks remain market leaders.

headline: Shares Trade Mostly Lower; The Dow Falls 47.80 Points
summary: Stock prices fell yesterday, led lower by retailers and four companies that are being replaced in the Dow Jones industrial average. Two stocks about to join the ranks of the 30 component issues of the Dow industrials rose -- Intel was up 3/16 a share, to 71 7/16, and SBC Communications climbed 1 5/16, to 45 9/16.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Hewlett-Packard Shares Fall on Earnings Concern Hewlett-Packard shares fell 12.6 percent, to $67, after an analyst suggested that the company might have an earnings shortfall in its fourth quarter, which ends this month. Hewlett-Packard warned on Oct. 1 that sales growth might slow but said it expected to meet earnings projections. Since then, it has expressed concerns to analysts. [Page C2.]

headline: Shares Surge Again, With Nasdaq in Lead
summary: Stocks extended their powerful rally yesterday as the Nasdaq composite index moved into record territory and blue-chip stocks pulled to within 5 percent of the record they set in August. Seventy years ago to the day, on the historic Black Tuesday, the market crashed 11.7 percent.

headline: After Its Latest Facelift, A Younger, Sexier Dow
summary: THE Dow Jones industrial average has long been viewed as the most prominent measure of the financial health of corporate America. Maybe now it should be seen as a barometer of how fast the economy is changing. Last week the keepers of the Dow -- the editors of The Wall Street Journal -- announced plans to boot four perfectly respectable companies and replace them with younger and better-performing substitutes. It was the third time in the 1990's that such a thing had happened. All told, 11 of the 30 stocks in the Dow are new in this decade.

headline: This time it's Interpublic doing an internal merger to add another giant to Madison Avenue.
summary: FOR the second time in less than two months, a big merger reshaping Madison Avenue is a result of an internal realignment rather than an acquisition or takeover. The Interpublic Group of Companies in New York is combining two of its four global agency networks: Ammirati Puris Lintas and the Lowe & Partners Worldwide unit of Lowe Group. The merged Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide will have offices in 80 countries and billings of more than $11 billion, ranking it fourth among all agency networks.

headline: Dow Falls in Mixed Trading As Nasdaq Hits a New High
summary: Stock prices were mixed yesterday as traders and investors took some profits after the big run-up in market gauges over the last two weeks. ''It was a consolidation-type day,'' said Bryan Piskorowski, a market analyst at Prudential Securities. ''There was a little bit of profit taking, and word of another earthquake in Taiwan got people a little scared and took a little of the froth out of the Nasdaq.''

headline: SBC In Wireless Purchase
summary: SBC Communications, the No. 1 United States local phone company, has agreed to buy the closely held Radiofone Inc., adding 200,000 wireless-telephone customers in Louisiana and Michigan. Terms were not disclosed. Wireless companies in the United States are consolidating to gain coast-to-coast coverage and lower their costs.

headline: Making Alterations For the New Dow 30
summary: An overhaul of the Dow Jones industrial average was completed last week, but it caused barely a murmur in the mutual fund universe. After all, very few funds explicitly track that venerable benchmark, which on Monday dropped four issues -- Union Carbide, Goodyear, Chevron and Sears, Roebuck -- while adding four standard-bearers of the new economy -- Microsoft, Intel, Home Depot and SBC Communications. But the makeover meant a lot to Richard Moroney, co-manager of the $110 million Strong Dow 30 Value fund. It indexes half of its portfolio to the Dow, then uses various Dow valuation theories to weight the other half, which also holds only Dow stocks.

headline: Technology Too High? And Now Microsoft
summary: WHAT a week it was for true believers in technology stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average almost doubled its weighting in technology shares last Monday when it added Microsoft, Intel and SBC Communications to its 30-company list. And on Wednesday, white-hot technology shares propelled the Nasdaq composite above the 3,000 mark for the first time. At Friday's close, the Nasdaq composite was up a blazing 41.48 percent this year. Not surprisingly, investors are flocking to mutual funds that invest in technology stocks. For the week that ended on Nov. 3, almost $700 million went into technology funds, roughly double the amount that migrated there in other recent weeks. According to AMG Data Services, assets in equity and technology mutual funds grew more in that week than they have since the week that ended on Oct. 21, 1998.

headline: Dividend Meetings
summary: A partial list for this week.

headline: Vodafone Bids $106 Billion for Mannesmann and Is Rebuffed
summary: Mannesmann A.G., the German telecommunications giant, rejected a $106.4 billion friendly takeover offer made today by Vodafone Airtouch of Britain, possibly setting the stage for the largest hostile takeover attempt ever and a potential trans-Atlantic bidding war. Hoping to avoid a hostile bid, Christopher Gent, the chief executive of Vodafone, the world's leading mobile phone operator, flew with advisers to Mannesmann headquarters in Dusseldorf this afternoon to present an all-stock offer to Klaus Esser, the chief executive of Mannesmann.

headline: German Company Standing Firm Against Vodafone
summary: As chairman of Mannesmann A.G., Klaus Esser is hardly a stranger to take-no-prisoners pragmatism. ''We find new things, accentuate our strengths and pull ourselves out of weak areas,'' he remarked in a recent interview with the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung.

headline: SBC Makes Deal to Transfer Internet Customers to Prodigy
summary: SBC Communications Inc., the regional telephone giant, said yesterday that it would transfer all of its residential Internet customers to the Prodigy Communications Corporation, the online service that has long been overshadowed by America Online, in return for a 43 percent stake in Prodigy. SBC, which does business as Ameritech, Pacific Bell and Southwestern Bell, said Prodigy would assume day-to-day management of SBC's 650,000 residential and small-business Internet customers. SBC also said it had agreed to make Prodigy its Internet service for consumers and small businesses.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Talks to Avert Bankruptcy At German Company Fail Philipp Holzmann, the biggest construction company in Germany, appeared headed toward bankruptcy after late-night talks brokered by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder failed to reach a compromise among banks trying to arrange a $2.6 billion bailout. Holzmann has been on the brink of insolvency since last week, when it said it had suddenly uncovered $1.3 billion in soured real estate loans. The German chancellor had raised some optimism of a solution by arranging talks among the banks and political leaders, but negotiations collapsed. [Page C4.]

headline: Stung, House G.O.P. Seeks More Business Cash
summary: Alarmed and embarrassed by the recent financial success of House Democrats, top fund-raisers for House Republicans issued an urgent appeal this week to business interests to increase their giving to Republican candidates and committees. The Republican concern arises from a startling shift in political donations from businesses to the House fund-raising committees. After long benefiting from a huge disparity in contributions from corporations and trade groups, Republicans saw their advantage virtually disappear in the first six months of this year.

headline: Off the Hook On Phone Stocks
summary: Brokers at Merrill Lynch don't have to hold their phone pitches after all. When Merrill lost its top telecommunications stock analyst, Dan Reingold, to a rival last week, the firm's brokers were suddenly prohibited from calling clients and urging them to buy shares of some of the nation's biggest companies, including AT&T and MCI Worldcom. Under a longstanding rule, Merrill's 14,000 brokers cannot solicit purchases of stocks that the firm's research department doesn't follow. The abrupt defection of Mr. Reingold and two other analysts to Credit Suisse First Boston knocked the stocks they had covered off the firm's list of recommended stocks, putting them ''under review,'' in brokerage parlance.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Conseco, Its Stock Sagging, Focuses on Balance Sheet Conseco, an insurance holding company with a sagging stock price, announced a reversal of strategy. It cut its common stock dividend and agreed to raise $478 million by selling convertible preferred stock on extraordinarily generous terms to a private investment firm. Conseco's shares rose $1.6875, to $20.25, on the news. And Moody's Investors Service said that when the financing by the investment firm is completed, it would raise Conseco's rating from junk bond level to investment grade. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [Page C18.]

headline: SBC Ponders The Issuing Of 2 Stocks
summary: SBC Communications Inc., the nation's largest local phone carrier, is considering issuing separately traded tracking stocks to follow the company's wireless communications unit and its international operations, SBC said yesterday. The company's management has not reached a final decision on either initiative and has not presented them to the board for formal consideration.

headline: Researchers Crack Code In Cell Phones
summary: Two Israeli researchers say they have found an efficient way to crack the code that protects the privacy of conversations and data transmissions over a type of wireless telephone used by more than 215 million people worldwide. The encryption method is part of the Groupe Speciale Mobile, or G.S.M., wireless phone standard. Though not dominant in the United States, it is the world's most widely used cellular technology. More than 215 million digital phones use it worldwide, including more than 100 million in Europe and 5 million in the United States.

headline: Dividend Meetings
summary: A partial list for this week. MONDAY Armstrong World Inds Inc Associated Estates Rlty Corp Cigna Corp Cincinnati Bell Inc Elcor Corp General Mls Inc Lubrizol Corp Phillips Pete Co Potomac Elec Pwr Co Tcf Finl Corp

headline: Telecommunications Powerhouse; Goldman Sachs Rules as Industry Is Transformed in Europe
summary: For a brief period last month, it seemed that the Goldman Sachs Group might become a victim of its own international success. Mannesmann, the German telecommunications giant, had filed a conflict-of-interest suit in London, arguing that Goldman should be barred from advising the British wireless company Vodafone AirTouch. On what grounds? Because Goldman had advised an investor in Orange of Britain, a wireless company Mannesmann itself wanted.

headline: Brands that shaped marketing in the 20th century, and some with promise in the 21st.
summary: AS the second millennium draws to a close, it's easier to compile a list of milestones in advertising than in other fields. The first few centuries were pretty much marketing-free, it seems, unless someone discovers that the Luddites carried posters during the Industrial Revolution with the slogan ''Just undo it.'' And while there were some rudimentary forms of advertising in the 18th and 19th centuries, it was not until the turn of the 20th century -- when mass-produced, name-brand products began to be promoted through mass media like billboards and magazines -- that Madison Avenue assumed its familiar form.

headline: From the Princes of Capitalism to the Bread Lines, How Fortunes Fared
summary: Mirror, mirror on the wall. Who's the richest of them all? There is no doubt that the wealthiest American as the century ends is William H. Gates III, the Microsoft chairman and chief executive. His net worth - as estimated by Forbes Magazine in October - was $85 billion, although it fluctuates daily as Microsoft's stock price rises or falls.

headline: FIRST BABY BELL TO GAIN APPROVAL FOR LONG DISTANCE
summary: Bell Atlantic will become today the first of the Baby Bell local phone carriers allowed into the $80 billion long-distance market, signaling a new era of competition in telecommunications markets, people close to the decision said yesterday. As the communications industry continues its torrid pace of consolidation, the announcement expected today from the Federal Communications Commission would allow Bell Atlantic, already the No. 2 local phone company, to expand into a broad new market covering long-distance services ranging from phone calls to advanced data communications.

headline: The Morning After, Some Questions on Bell Atlantic's Feat
summary: When Reed E. Hundt was asked Tuesday evening to comment on the Federal Communications Commission's imminent approval of the application by Bell Atlantic to sell long-distance services in New York State, his first words were, ''Talk about a better-late-than-never situation.'' As chairman of the F.C.C. from 1994 to 1997, Mr. Hundt was hardly a champion of the long-distance aspirations of the Baby Bells. He seemed to believe, in fact, that the local offsprings of Ma Bell had not opened their networks enough to merit approval.

headline: Nasdaq Index Ends Session At New High
summary: The Nasdaq composite index sustained a much-anticipated round of profit taking yesterday, but later rose to its eighth consecutive record high, pulled up by big jumps in Internet favorites like Qualcomm, JDS Uniphase and Yahoo. The Nasdaq index, which has risen more than 45 percent since October, started the day on a strong note as it raced through 4,000 for the second consecutive trading session.

headline: McCain Urged F.C.C. Action On Issue Involving Supporter
summary: Senator John McCain, who has made fixing the corrosive influence of money in politics the cornerstone of his campaign, twice demanded in recent weeks that a regulatory agency take action in a matter that ultimately benefited a major contributor to his presidential campaign. Once in November and again last month, Mr. McCain wrote letters to the Federal Communications Commission seeking a speedy vote on a complicated swap of television station licenses in Pittsburgh that would enable the contributor's company, Paxson Communications, to buy one of the stations in the only big market where it lacks one.

headline: Issue for McCain Is Matching Record With His Rhetoric
summary: Eleven years ago, Senator John McCain defended himself against ethics accusations for his ties to a corrupt savings association and a campaign contributor by saying that he had performed a legitimate constituent service when he met with regulators who were preparing to seize the institution. ''I have done this kind of thing many, many times,'' Mr. McCain, an Arizona Republican, said in 1989, explaining that helping Charles H. Keating Jr., who had lent him his company jet and whose associates had contributed $112,000 to his campaign, was like ''helping the little lady who didn't get her Social Security.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: AOL Deal for Time Warner Spurs Stocks to Big Gains Stock prices posted sharp gains, spurred in part by America Online's $165 billion takeover of Time Warner. The deal touched off demand for entertainment and Internet shares as investors piled into companies that might be merger candidates. The Nasdaq composite index recorded its biggest one-day point gain, rising 167.05 points, or 4.3 percent, to 4,049.67. Led by Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M. and Intel, the Dow rose 49.64 points, to 11,572.20. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 16.13 points, or 1.12 percent, to 1,457.60. [Page C17.]

headline: SBC Seeks U.S. Permission For Long-Distance in Texas
summary: Trying to follow Bell Atlantic's trailblazing path into the long-distance communications market, SBC Communications Inc., the largest local phone company, asked federal regulators yesterday for permission to sell long-distance services in Texas. SBC's application with the Federal Communications Commission will probably not be resolved until April, but many communications analysts say that the petition stands an excellent chance of being approved. Approval would make SBC, which does business in Texas as Southwestern Bell, the second Bell company allowed into the $80 billion long-distance market.

headline: A Rush to Provide High-Speed Internet Access
summary: For most Americans, linking to cyberspace from home is akin to trying to eat a vat of thick, rich soup with a straw. With their $165 billion merger deal, America Online and Time Warner intend to start handing out ladles. The agreement between America Online, the No. 1 Internet provider, and Time Warner, the media and cable television titan, is reverberating throughout the communications and media industries. But the most important impact for consumers may be how the deal advances the deployment of high-speed Internet access.

headline: 3 Rules of D.S.L.: Location, Location, Confusion
summary: MEASURED against other struggles that throw a family into crisis -- war, disaster, control of the television remote control -- the trials and tribulations of ordering D.S.L. service may not loom large. But it has been a bit of a tough time recently for Peggy Stout and her three adult children, all members of one family, to be sure, but not all able to get fast D.S.L. connections for their computers. Those who do not own computers -- 60 percent of the population -- may laugh. People who are just getting dial-up modems may smile. But bandwidth envy is real enough, and there is a D.S.L. stampede nationwide. Ms. Stout and her children are in the middle of one in Los Angeles.

headline: Broadband: How Broadly? How Soon?; A Technology's Promised Arrival May Finally Be Here
summary: It was eight years ago that John C. Malone, the cable television baron, brashly proclaimed that the average American home would soon be able to receive 500 channels of information and entertainment. But since then, the arrival of two-way, high-capacity, high-speed services has been next year's story. Like some mythical wild beast that is described but never seen, broadband -- as such high-speed links are known -- has always been out there somewhere, just over the horizon. Next year, the analysts and executives promised, next year.

headline: Mannesmann, Under Attack, Looks to France
summary: Trying to ward off a hostile takeover by Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C., Mannesmann A.G. is in discussions with Vivendi of France over a complex merger that would effectively give the German company control over Vivendi's valuable telecommunications assets, people close to the talks said today. Mannesmann's chief executive, Klaus Esser, has repeatedly said he would like to reach some sort of deal with Vivendi, a conglomerate with businesses ranging from water systems to wireless telephones. And talk of some sort of agreement has intensified in the last week. Analysts have said that Mannesmann is most interested in Vivendi's prize 44 percent stake in Cegetel, a holding company that owns the French mobile phone company SFR and Cegetel 7, a struggling competitor to France Telecom in fixed-line communications.

headline: 3 Marketers Award Accounts
summary: Three companies have made decisions about their accounts. The J. M. Smucker Company in Orrville, Ohio, awarded its account to the Chicago Creative Partnership after five years at Leo Burnett U.S.A. in Chicago. Billings were estimated at $8 million to $10 million.

headline: Mexican Retail Conglomerate Buying Rest of CompUSA
summary: A retail group controlled by the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Helu announced today that it was buying CompUSA Inc., the biggest chain of personal computer stores in the United States. Mr. Slim's leap into United States retailing is one of the biggest Mexican purchases of a prominent American business. It is also part of his drive to transform Telefonos de Mexico, the formerly state-owned phone company Mr. Slim controls and which is his flagship business, into a fast-paced, Web-savvy multinational giant.

headline: GTE Offers Internet Sale to Aid Merger
summary: The Bell Atlantic Corporation and the GTE Corporation proposed today to sell 90 percent of GTE's Internet business to the public and invest $500 million outside their local regions to win approval of their $84.4 billion combination. The proposal filed at the Federal Communications Commission is intended to let Bell Atlantic comply with rules that bar regional phone companies from transmitting voice and Internet calls over long distances until local markets are open to rivals. GTE is not subject to the restrictions, so Bell Atlantic must resolve the issue before the transaction can be approved.

headline: Bell Atlantic and GTE Swap Wireless Systems With Alltel
summary: In the first of several billion-dollar wireless telephone deals that Bell Atlantic and the GTE Corporation are likely to make early this year, the two telecommunications giants announced yesterday that they would swap wireless operations in 13 states with the Alltel Corporation. Bell Atlantic, the No. 2 local telephone company and one of the nation's biggest wireless providers, has agreed to merge with GTE, and the two companies have agreed to fold their combined United States wireless unit into a joint venture with Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C. of Britain, the world's biggest wireless carrier.

headline: TERAYON, CABLE MODEM MAKER, AGREES TO BUY TYCO UNIT
summary: The cable modem maker Terayon Communications Systems Inc. said late on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire Tyco International's Raychem Access Network Electronics unit for $90 million in stock. The acquisition is part of Terayon's plan to provide voice, data and video services over a variety of media. Raychem Access makes digital subscriber line systems, which allow fast Internet access over regular phone lines. Its products are used by SBC Communications, Bell Atlantic, BellSouth and GTE, among others. Separately, Terayon, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it had agreed to acquire Combox Ltd. of Israel, a privately held maker of cable data systems, for 775,000 shares, or about $89 million.

headline: Tracking More Sectors
summary: Last week, Merrill Lynch introduced two versions of one of its hottest investment products -- Holdr's (pronounced ''holders''), securities that track specific industry sectors. The new securities, Telecom Holdr's and Pharmaceutical Holdr's, were listed on the American Stock Exchange and began trading at $87.875 and $91.875, respectively.

headline: Justice Dept. Opposes SBC In Texas Bid
summary: Using unexpectedly strong language, the Justice Department said yesterday that SBC Communications Inc., the No. 1 local phone company, should not be allowed to sell long-distance communications services to its customers in Texas. Last month, SBC applied to the Federal Communications Commission for approval to sell long-distance services there. The Justice Department has an advisory role in the process, with the F.C.C. giving ''substantial weight'' to the department's recommendations.

headline: SBC Agrees To Acquire Sterling for $3.9 Billion
summary: In the biggest move by a major local phone company into the torrid electronic commerce business, SBC Communications said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Sterling Commerce for almost $3.9 billion in cash. As competition increases in every sector of the communications industry, established companies like SBC and AT&T are trying to de-emphasize the sale of raw communications pipes and offer instead more complex services that can carry richer profits.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Microsoft Presses Defense As Trial Draws to a Close After 16 months of testimony and argument the antitrust suit against Microsoft drew to a close. A verdict is expected in the next few weeks, but even then the court is likely to hold separate hearings on remedies if, as expected, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson rules that Microsoft violated antitrust laws. As Microsoft and the government concluded the trial, their representatives were still continuing to meet in Chicago in search of a settlement in mediation talks. [Page A1.]

headline: Biggest Canadian Phone Company Offers to Buy TV Network
summary: The owner of Canada's largest telephone system, BCE Inc., made a $1.6 billion cash offer for the country's No. 2 television network today, a move to give it more programming to carry into battle against cable television and Internet services. BCE is offering 2.3 billion Canadian dollars, or 38 dollars a share, for CTV Inc., a 22 percent premium to the closing price on Thursday.

headline: Spanish Customers Focus of New Venture
summary: Rapp Collins Worldwide in New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group devoted to direct marketing, has formed a joint venture with HispanAmerica Response Marketing in Newfoundland, Pa., a unit of Direct Merchants, focused on work for marketers seeking to instill loyalty among their Spanish-speaking customers. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Hong Kong's Local Preference; Shrinking an Empire to Fit
summary: When Graham Wallace became chief executive of Cable and Wireless P.L.C. a year ago this week, he had been expected to be the consummate company man, reluctant to shake up the far-flung telecommunications company that once symbolized Britain's imperial reach. But Mr. Wallace quickly began selling pieces of his company, orchestrating a number of large deals that culminated with the sale of the Cable and Wireless stake in Cable and Wireless HKT, the Hong Kong phone company, to Pacific Century CyberWorks Ltd. of Hong Kong. In so doing, Mr. Wallace has proved that he is willing to shake things up.

headline: Qwest Explores Renegotiating Its Agreement With U S West
summary: Prepared to cash out, Qwest Communications International Inc.'s top executive, Joseph P. Nacchio, and its biggest investor, Philip P. Anschutz, are highly interested in selling their company, even as they explore renegotiating Qwest's agreement to acquire U S West Inc., executives close to the company said yesterday. The leading candidate to acquire Qwest, an upstart long-distance company based in Denver, has been Deutsche Telekom of Germany, Europe's largest communications carrier. But around the middle of this week, Deutsche Telekom cooled its negotiations with Qwest as the German company became newly aware of the many factors that would complicate such a deal, executives close to the talks said.

headline: A New Lasso for the Sector Corral
summary: WHEN an investment product makes a hot debut, investors may want to look closely before they leap. That may well be the case with sector Holdrs, a type of equity trust invented by Merrill Lynch last year that is fast becoming its signature financial product. Last week, Merrill announced three new versions of these Holding Company Depositary Receipts -- whose acronym is pronounced ''holders.'' And the firm says that more, a lot more, are on the way. As of Friday, the seven existing sector Holdrs had garnered assets of over $6 billion.

headline: Lowe Lintas to Close Its Chicago Office
summary: Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide in New York will close its Chicago office after losing the account of its largest client there, SBC Communications, with billings estimated at $85 million. A Lowe Lintas predecessor, Ammirati Puris Lintas, opened the office in 1998 after winning the account of the regional Bell operating company Ameritech. Last year, though, SBC acquired Ameritech and Ammirati Puris was merged with a sibling, Lowe & Partners/SMS, to form Lowe Lintas, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: The View From GreenMountain; Financier Mixes Business, the Environment and Politics
summary: A 1998 concert in Philadelphia promoting alternative energy featured James Taylor and Kenny Loggins and exhibits like a Veggie Van, a purple mobile home fueled by used french-fry oil. The event's sponsor: GreenMountain.com, which markets electricity from sources like solar power and wind energy. The company's chairman, Sam Wyly, still exhibits a flair for the dramatic, though his latest effort -- a $2.5 million advertising campaign that attacked the environmental record of Senator John McCain -- has raised questions about his tactics.

headline: Robert E. Hillard, 82, Public Relations Executive
summary: Robert E. Hillard, a durable public relations man who co-founded the St. Louis-based public relations firm Fleishman-Hillard and helped lay the base for an almost eightyfold growth in its annual billings in two later decades, died on Wednesday at his home near Caledonia, Mo. He was 82. The cause was emphysema, the firm announced.

headline: Donors Wary Of Gore's Plan On Financing
summary: Political donors and fund-raisers approached Vice President Al Gore's latest campaign finance proposal warily, concerned that it would diminish their influence with candidates and create an unwieldy government bureaucracy. Calling big-money contributions to politics a ''cancer on our democracy,'' Mr. Gore today proposed the elimination of the unlimited donations known as soft money and the creation of a $7.1 billion endowment to finance all general election campaigns for Congress.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Strategist Suggests Curb On Stocks, and Prices Fall Stock prices fell as investors took profits and Abby Joseph Cohen, the influential stock market strategist at Goldman, Sachs, recommended that her firm's clients reduce their allocation of stocks to 65 percent from 70 percent. It is the first time Ms. Cohen has reduced the stock allocation since January 1999. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 89.74 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,936.11. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slumped 16.13 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,507.73, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 124.67 points, or 2.5 percent, to 4,833.89. [Page C15.] The decline in stock prices lifted bond prices modestly. The yield on the benchmark 30-year issue was unchanged at 5.98 percent. [C15.]

headline: F.C.C. Is Expected to Reject SBC's Long-Distance Proposal
summary: It is almost certain that the Federal Communications Commission will thwart SBC Communications' efforts to enter the $80 billion long-distance telephone market early this year, according to people close to the commission. In recent days, these people have said that the F.C.C. appears almost certain to reject SBC's application to offer long-distance service in Texas, because the company has not provided sufficient evidence that it has opened its local communications networks in the state to potential competitors. The F.C.C. probably will not announce a decision until April 10.

headline: Bell Atlantic to Promote Its New Wireless Brand
summary: What is Verizon? It is the new brand that Bell Atlantic's wireless communications unit has chosen to adopt as the unit merges with the United States wireless operation of Vodafone AirTouch. According to people close to the campaign, Bell Atlantic has spent months preparing a big advertising campaign meant to convert its wireless customers, and perhaps those of Vodafone, into loyal users of the Verizon brand.

headline: Competitors of Telmex Say It Still Acts Like a Monopoly
summary: If any company represents the marriage of Mexico and modern business, it is Telefonos de Mexico, the telecommunications giant that towers over its industry at home and is the Mexican stock that Wall Street investors love to own. Since it was sold by the government a decade ago to a private consortium headed by Carlos Slim Helu, now Latin America's wealthiest man, Telmex more than any other enterprise has symbolized Mexico's passage from an inward-looking state-controlled economy to a thriving globalized free market.

headline: 2 Phone Giants Said to Be Near Deal to Merge Wireless Units
summary: Hoping to create a national giant in wireless communications, BellSouth and SBC Communications are near a deal to merge their North American wireless operations, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday. The companies' boards were scheduled to meet last night to approve the deal, the executives said, and the companies hope to announce the agreement as soon as today.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Japan's Governing Party Moves to Pick Successor The Liberal Democratic Party chose Yoshiro Mori to succeed Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, who has been in a coma since Sunday. Mr. Mori, 62, who was second to Mr. Obuchi in the party hierarchy, is expected to be elected prime minister by Parliament today. Earlier, the cabinet resigned to expedite the transition. A1

headline: The Tortoise Proves There's Life In It Yet
summary: THE Nasdaq composite index may one day rise above its venerable blue-chip cousin, the Dow Jones industrial average, and stay there. Until a couple of weeks ago, it seemed that day would come sooner rather than later. Though the Nasdaq is still higher than it was at the end of 1999, and may zoom ahead in the months to come, the recent sharp skid did some damage.

headline: The New Israel: Land of Milk and Money
summary: WITH his collarless black shirt, close-cropped hair and wire-rim glasses, Gil Shwed looks like a 20-something denizen of the local coffeehouse scene. But he says he doesn't get out of the office much, unless he is traveling to one of his other offices -- in California, Singapore, Germany, Japan, France or Australia. Besides, there is a cappuccino machine just down the hall, next to the treadmills and stair machines that Mr. Shwed provides for his headquarters staff, now almost 300 strong and expanding daily.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Earnings Top Forecasts At EMC, Intel and I.B.M. Three of the technology blue chips -- Intel, EMC and I.B.M. -- reported earnings that exceeded Wall Street's expectations. The laggard of the three was I.B.M., whose earnings rose but whose revenue declined 5 percent. But both EMC and Intel reported strong advances in revenue as well as quarterly profits. They join other leading technology companies that are benefiting from the increased investment in technology as corporations retool their operations for the Internet. [Page C12.] AOL Has Record Revenue and Profit America Online reported record revenue and earnings in its third quarter, crediting subscription growth, advertising sales and online commerce fees as it handily beat analysts' estimates. Before it announced its results, shares of America Online closed up $2.0625, to $60.50, but they remain down sharply from their 52-week high of $95.8125. [C5.]

headline: Cisco and SBC Expect Alliance
summary: Cisco Systems, the data networking company based in San Jose, Calif., is expected to announce today that it has entered into a multibillion-dollar alliance with SBC Communications, which is based in San Antonio. Executives at the two companies said that SBC, the nation's biggest local phone company, would be among the largest buyers of Cisco's routers and switches that are used to build the Internet's infrastructure. Tom McGrath, president of SBC DataComm, would not disclose the value of the equipment SBC planned to buy.

headline: SBC Communications Sued By Workers on Stock Sale
summary: California employees of SBC Communications, the nation's largest local telephone company, sued the company yesterday, accusing it of costing 45,000 employees and retirees $1.1 billion by selling shares of a lucrative investment that was in their company-controlled retirement accounts. A group of 18 employees, retirees and spouses, who are seeking class-action status for their suit, accused the company of selling shares in AirTouch Communications from their 401(k) accounts after a series of mergers made AirTouch an SBC competitor.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Numbers Don't Explain the Woes of AT&T
summary: After a day like yesterday, it is easy to see that C. Michael Armstrong, chairman of AT&T, may have the toughest job in corporate America. It was the worst day for AT&T's investors in more than a dozen years, and Mr. Armstrong probably had not had such an unpleasant professional experience since he took over the company in 1997.

headline: Night of the Living D.S.L.
summary: JONATHAN TELLER resorted to an appeal to the chairman of Bell Atlantic. Denise Klarquist lost her telephone service entirely. Bill Hipps sent letters to his local newspaper. For weeks James Williams couldn't figure out why he was dropped at precisely the same time every night. They are strangers to one another, living different lives thousands of miles apart. Yet they have the same problem: all were thwarted in their attempts to establish and maintain D.S.L. service in their homes. All four reached levels of vexation that they did not know were possible when dealing with their local phone companies.

headline: At $500,000, Democrats Gala Ticket Tops Record
summary: For its annual gala here on May 24, the Democratic Party is offering tickets ranging from an affordable $50 to a platinum price of $500,000, the highest amount either party has charged for admission to a fund-raising gala. The donors and fund-raisers who give or collect $500,000 will be given a package of perks that includes an invitation to a private dinner with President Clinton at a Washington restaurant on the eve of the gala and front-row seats, in the so-called ''platinum section'' of the MCI Center, for the gala's entertainment. The comedian Robin Williams leads the list, along with the musicians Stevie Wonder and Lenny Kravitz.

headline: BellSouth Said to Be in a Deal With G.E. Satellite Division
summary: Moving to offer digital television service throughout the Southeast, BellSouth intends to announce today that it has signed a long-term contract to purchase satellite services from General Electric, an executive close to the deal said yesterday. BellSouth had been rumored to be in discussions with Loral Space and Communications, a G.E. rival in the satellite industry.

headline: SBC Scores a Point in Long-Distance Effort
summary: SBC Communications Inc., the nation's No. 1 local telephone carrier, took a small step toward entering the long-distance market yesterday when the Justice Department said the company had alleviated one of the department's concerns about opening its networks to competitors. SBC is seeking approval from the Federal Communications Commission to offer long-distance services in Texas. To do that, the company must convince the F.C.C. that it has opened its local systems to potential competitors. So far, Bell Atlantic is the only Bell phone company to have won long-distance approval, for New York State.

headline: Vodafone to Sell Cegetel Stake To Vivendi, Its French Partner
summary: Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C., the world's largest wireless telephone operator, will sell its 15 percent stake in the French telecommunications operator Cegetel to its French partner, Vivendi, the companies announced today. Vodafone's sale of the stake, which Vodafone saw as having little strategic value, gives Vivendi majority control of Cegetel, which controls the French wireless operator SFR.

headline: WorldCom, With or Without Sprint
summary: AFTER being a forgotten word for two decades, ''antitrust'' is again a part of the government's vocabulary. As if seeking a breakup of Microsoft wasn't enough, Justice Department lawyers recommended last week that WorldCom's $115 billion takeover of Sprint be blocked.

headline: An Oops in Time Warner's Battle for Internet
summary: In the annals of corporate espionage, the plot to learn about one of Time Warner's leading competitors in the fiercely competitive high-speed Internet market was not particularly subtle. A flier accompanying the paychecks of Time Warner Cable's Houston employees this month offered them a choice of free Internet service or the chance to win $100. ''To qualify,'' it said, ''we need your help in accomplishing our objective which is to locate areas in Houston that Southwestern Bell (our competitor) can and cannot service with their high-speed online service.''

headline: FPL TO LEASE FIBER OPTIC LINES TO SBC COMMUNICATIONS
summary: FPL Group Inc. agreed to lease fiber optic lines covering major cities in Florida to SBC Communications Inc. for as much as $110 million. SBC, the largest United States local-telephone company, will use the lines to provide voice and data services to customers in Miami, Orlando, Boca Raton, Fort Lauderdale, St. Petersburg, Tampa and West Palm Beach. FPL FiberNet, a unit of the FPL Group, based in Juno Beach, Fla., operates a 1,600-mile fiber optic network in Florida and is installing lines in more than 150 cities statewide.

headline: New Homes Are Now Wired For a Lot More Than Lights
summary: Michael Levine wanted what many people would in a new house: a safe neighborhood and low upkeep. But what really sold him on Centennial, a 900-home development north of Indianapolis, was the wiring -- a ready-to-use, high-speed Internet connection as well as cable and phone service, all provided by the builder. The Internet service is ''so much faster than anything I've ever seen,'' said Dr. Levine, a retired surgeon who moved in with his family in March. Since Internet access no longer requires a phone line and can go to more than one computer, ''nobody complains, 'Gee, I can't get online,' '' he said. ''While one kid is doing research, the other one is talking to her friend.''

headline: Stocks Make Strong Showing; Nasdaq Soars a Record 7.9%
summary: The Nasdaq composite index surged to its biggest percentage gain and the second-largest point gain in its 29-year history yesterday as investors snapped up technology heavyweights like Intel, Cisco Systems and Oracle. The index shot up 254.37 points, or 7.9 percent, to 3,459.48. Of the stocks that make up the Nasdaq 100 index, 98 rose in price and 2 lost ground.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Leaders of Two Koreas Confer in Pyongyang Opening formalities at the first summit meeting between North and South Korea seemed surprisingly relaxed, exceeding the expectations of many people, including perhaps those of the principals themselves, Kim Jong Il of the North and Kim Dae Jung of the South. During a 27 minute-meeting, they discussed the need to establish a hotline, and talks today are expected to focus on issues that divide the two countries. A1

headline: Justice Dept. Grants SBC's Texas Petition
summary: In a major victory for SBC Communications Inc., the Justice Department recommended yesterday that the company, the nation's biggest local phone carrier, be allowed to sell long-distance communications services to its almost 15 million customers in Texas. If the Federal Communications Commission agrees with the recommendation, as expected, SBC will become the second regional Bell company allowed into the $80 billion long-distance market. In December, the Bell Atlantic Corporation was permitted to begin selling long-distance services to its customers in New York.

headline: New York Life Sued Over Fees on Its Pensions
summary: Top executives of the New York Life Insurance Company were accused in a racketeering lawsuit yesterday of enriching themselves by charging tens of millions of dollars in excess fees to the retirement plans that the insurer maintains for its workers and agents. Officials of the company, which was also sued, denied the accusations and said they were confident that they would prevail in court.

headline: F.C.C. Approves Bell Atlantic-GTE Merger, Creating No. 1 Phone Company
summary: The Federal Communications Commission approved the proposed merger of the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the GTE Corporation today, clearing the final obstacle to the creation of the nation's largest telephone company.

headline: AT&T Paying $3.3 Billion To Add Wireless Systems
summary: The AT&T Corporation agreed yesterday to pay $3.3 billion in cash for wireless telephone systems in Houston, San Diego and San Francisco to expand its fast-growing wireless telecommunications business. As a result of the transactions, the AT&T Wireless Group, the company's mobile-phone arm, will add 1.3 million customers and 1,400 employees. AT&T will acquire operations in San Francisco from Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C., in San Diego from the GTE Corporation and in Houston from PrimeCo PCS, once a venture of Bell Atlantic and Vodafone.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Philip Morris and Reynolds To Buy Parts of Nabisco The Philip Morris Companies, owner of Kraft Foods, said it had reached an agreement to buy Nabisco Holdings, maker of Oreo cookies and Grey Poupon mustard.
