After that sale is completed, Nabisco Group Holdings, which holds an 80.6 percent stake in the Nabisco operating company, said it would accept an offer from its former unit, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco. [Page A1.]

headline: New Economy; Bell Atlantic takes advantage of an F.C.C. rule change to pursue long-distance customers.
summary: IT is not often in the telecommunications industry that a big company hits an immediate, unmitigated home run with consumers. AT&T's Digital One Rate wireless phone offering a couple of years ago, which eliminated roaming and long-distance fees, was one example. The 10-10 ''dial-around'' long-distance plans from MCI (now WorldCom) came close. Now, Bell Atlantic, the local phone giant, is in the middle of a positively Ruthian blast into the long-distance market in New York. By the end of next month, Bell Atlantic will almost surely announce that it has signed up a million long-distance customers in New York just since the beginning of this year.

headline: Phone Giants Reconnoiter as Merger Stalls
summary: WorldCom and the Sprint Corporation have not yet called off their merger, but already the rumors are swirling about who might try to buy either company. Yesterday, telecommunications executives around the globe huddled with their advisers to figure out what the Justice Department's opposition to the WorldCom-Sprint merger might mean for them. For the moment, all they can do is wonder.

headline: Telecommunications Show May Eclipse G.O.P.
summary: When the Republicans gather here this month for their national convention, to some it might be hard to tell the difference: Is this a political convention or a telecommunications trade show? While the main event at the convention here -- and the Democratic convention to be held in August in Los Angeles -- is, of course, nominating a presidential candidate, a big corporate sideshow is being planned as well. And in that effort, no single industry is better represented than telecommunications companies.

headline: SBC's Long-Distance Rates For Texas Will Be Set Today
summary: SBC Communications plans to announce today the long-distance rates it will charge in Texas, the second state after New York in which a local phone company will also offer long-distance service. Starting on Monday, SBC will offer long-distance plans to individual and corporate customers that will compete with service offered by companies like WorldCom, AT&T and Sprint. Verizon Communications, the former Bell Atlantic, entered the long-distance market in New York at the beginning of this year.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Online Business Exchanges May Raise Antitrust Issues As companies in nearly every industry rush to join business-to-business exchanges on the Internet, regulators are growing concerned that they will face a rash of new antitrust questions for which they are not prepared. The exchanges create a place for companies in the same industry to buy and sell goods, potentially saving millions of dollars. But the sites, which can compile huge amounts of sensitive data and are often jointly owned by corporate rivals, also create opportunities for collusion and price-fixing that did not exist before, antitrust experts say. [Page A1.]

headline: With AT&T at the Brink, Pressures Rise at the Top
summary: IT was the evening of Monday, May 1, and C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman of AT&T, needed help. Huddled in a conference room at the company's headquarters in Basking Ridge, N.J., with key members of his executive team, Mr. Armstrong said he turned for advice to two Wall Street analysts, later identified by people close to the meeting as Frank J. Governali of Goldman, Sachs and Jack Grubman of Salomon Smith Barney. Mr. Armstrong asked the two just how he should tell investors that some of AT&T's core businesses had stumbled. At least as important, Mr. Armstrong also wanted their assessment of how AT&T's shares, one of the nation's most widely held stocks, would react to the bad news.

headline: Wireless Unit Makes Sprint A Likely Takeover Target
summary: Mention the word ''footprint'' and images of an ill-fated Himalayan expedition in search of the Yeti might come to mind. But when you mention footprint to people familiar with the Sprint Corporation, their eyes light up with optimism over what the future may hold. In the argot of the mobile telecommunications world, footprint refers to the breadth of network coverage, and perhaps no company has matched Sprint the last couple of years in its speed and efficiency in building a nationwide wireless communications business.

headline: Untangling The Wireless Web; Cellular Internet Is a Format War For the Carriers
summary: Back in Reykjavik, Skuli Mogensen saw the wireless Internet craze that was sweeping his native Iceland and had an inspiration: why not try to export the revolution by taking his company's software for mobile wireless devices to the United States? So he has been preparing his company, OZ.com, to be a trans-Atlantic wireless contender. ''I had no doubt this thing will explode in America,'' said Mr. Mogensen, 31, who incorporated OZ in San Francisco. ''The U.S. market has relatively high usage of the Internet, PC's, cable modems, Palm devices and cell phones, so why shouldn't the wireless Internet be used to unite all of these things?''

headline: WorldCom and Sprint End Their $115 Billion Merger
summary: WorldCom Inc. and the Sprint Corporation officially abandoned their $115 billion merger yesterday, bowing to pressure from regulators, who were concerned that the creation of such a large telecommunications company would stifle competition. Far from dampening the outlook for ever-larger communications concerns, the dissolution of the agreement, which had been expected for several days, fueled speculation about consolidation among large telecommunications companies.

headline: Prodigy Heads for Texas, With Incentives at Issue
summary: Prodigy Communications Corporation, the nation's third-largest Internet service provider, is leaving White Plains for Houston, but not before possibly having to return some economic incentive benefits to Westchester County. ''Our attorneys are talking to their attorneys,'' said Teri Waivada, executive director of the county's Industrial Development Agency. ''There are possible penalties based on the number of jobs that will be lost and when they will be lost.''

headline: A Gusher of Technology In Downtown Tulsa
summary: A DECADE ago, Tulsa was a played-out oil-and-gas town. Today, the town's boosters have recast it in the role of telecommunications superpower. The area has more than 54,000 high-technology jobs, which account for roughly 8 percent of local employment, a share that matches well-known technology centers like Raleigh-Durham, N.C.; Dallas; and Stamford, Conn. In the next three years, a recent survey of area employers showed, the region is expected to add up to 6,000 positions in telecommunications alone.

headline: In the Region/Westchester; Office Leasing Strengthens and Vacancy Rate Drops
summary: DURING the first six months of this year, a record amount of office space was leased in Westchester County and the vacancy rate dropped to its lowest point in more than a decade. The county, benefiting from a lack of available space in surrounding markets, had an increase of 1.8 million square feet of leased space, a rate that was up 44 percent from a year earlier. Westchester's overall vacancy rate of 12.8 percent is down from 16.7 percent at the same time last year, according to Insignia/ ESG, the real-estate services company. ''That's the lowest it's been in the 12 years since we've been keeping records,'' said Dean J. Shapiro, executive director of Insignia/ESG's Westchester-Connecticut office in Stamford, Conn.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-A8 Camp David Talks Seen at Crucial Point President Clinton returned to negotiations at Camp David and American officials suggested that the talks, now centered on the future of Jerusalem, could break apart in the next day or solidify into a deal. A1

headline: SBC to Disclose Series of Steps To Raise Profile In Cyberspace
summary: Joining the raft of big communications companies trying to capitalize on Internet commerce, SBC Communications Inc. plans a series of moves this week meant to enhance the company's presence in cyberspace. In addition to acquiring control of a small company that manages Web sites for businesses, SBC intends to announce partnerships with Commerce One Inc., the software maker, and with the consulting firms Deloitte Consulting and Proxicom, people close to the company said.

headline: AT&T WIRELESS AGREES TO BUY SBC INDIANAPOLIS UNIT
summary: The AT&T Wireless Group agreed yesterday to acquire the Indianapolis wireless system of SBC Communications Inc. for about $530 million in cash. AT&T Wireless said the deal would add more than 113,000 subscribers. So far this year, AT&T Wireless has acquired or announced plans to acquire wireless systems in the San Francisco Bay area, San Diego, Houston and Florida. AT&T Wireless, based in Redmond, Wash., is the second-largest mobile phone operator in the United States. SBC, based in San Antonio, is the second-largest local phone provider in the United States.)

headline: The Telecommunications Circle of Life
summary: NOT even ''Melrose Place'' had as many intrigues as the telecommunications industry. Let's see. Deutsche Telekom, after failing in its bid to woo Qwest Communications, made VoiceStream Wireless a $50.7 billion offer that it could not refuse. This is the same VoiceStream that had been courted by Nippon Telegraph and Telephone of Japan, the world's largest telephone company.

headline: Compressed Data; Alltel-SBC Deal Expected on Wireless Unit
summary: The Alltel Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest wireless communications carrier, is expected to announce today the acquisition of wireless operations in Louisiana from SBC Communications for about $400 million. Under the agreement, Alltel, which is based in Little Rock, Ark., expects to gain about 165,000 wireless customers and 300,000 paging customers in New Orleans and Baton Rouge. The transaction also includes some rural services.

headline: SBC TO SELL WIRELESS UNITS IN LOUISIANA TO ALLTEL
summary: SBC Communications Inc., the No. 2 United States local-telephone company, agreed yesterday to sell some wireless assets in Louisiana to the Alltel Corporation for about $400 million to clear the way for a joint venture with BellSouth. Alltel, based in Little Rock, Ark., said it would gain 160,000 cellular-phone and 300,000 paging customers in New Orleans and Baton Rouge when the purchase closes later this year, adding to earnings in 2001. The accord is contingent on the completion of the SBC-BellSouth venture, which is still under regulatory review. The sale resolves some of the antitrust issues created when SBC and BellSouth agreed in April to combine their wireless businesses and form the No. 2 United States mobile-phone carrier behind Verizon Wireless, SBC said.

headline: With Phone Strike Near, A New Offer
summary: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest wireless and local phone company, moved yesterday to avoid a strike by more than 86,000 telephone workers from Maine to Virginia by submitting a proposal addressing some of its unions' main contract concerns. Still, the possibility of a walkout may have increased after Verizon skirted other important issues like union organizing attempts among its wireless work force, the contracting out of some labor, and the loss or migration of jobs as a result of mergers in the last several years.

headline: Review Under Way For Phone Venture
summary: BellSouth in Atlanta and SBC Communications in San Antonio, have begun a review for a joint venture of the merged North American wireless operations of the two companies, a deal which is still under regulatory review. Larry Solomon, a spokesman for SBC, confirmed a report of the review that appeared in Advertising Age this week.

headline: The Battle of the Bandwidths; Space Is Coveted as Wireless Expands
summary: Traveling recently through Morocco, Lowell W. Paxson marveled when he used his cell phone to view a street map enabling his driver to find an obscure restaurant there. But to his critics in the telephone and regulatory worlds, Mr. Paxson, the chairman of Paxson Communications, which owns a string of mostly small television stations, now seems to be one of the biggest impediments to the proliferation of such technology in the United States.

headline: NORWEGIAN PHONE STAKE SOLD
summary: The top Danish phone company, Tele Danmark, and its main shareholder, SBC Communications of San Antonio, agreed to sell their joint 40 percent stake in NetCom of Norway to its Swedish rival, Telia, ending a two-month deadlock. SBC, which owns 42 percent of Tele Danmark, said it would book a pretax gain of about $500 million in the third quarter from the sale, while the Danish company will make a gain of 1.7 billion Danish kroner ($206 million).

headline: Metro Business; SBC Wants Out of Cable
summary: SBC Communications Inc. has asked Connecticut regulators to let it shut down its cable television business in the state, where it has 30,000 customers in 26 cities and towns.

headline: Editorial Observer; Two Candidates, Seeking Votes With Salsa
summary: Still exulting in President Clinton's performance, delegates and party faithful celebrated on Monday night at the Latino Committee 2000's block party in downtown Los Angeles, featuring the queen of salsa, Celia Cruz. The bash felt like a neighborly small-town festival, to the extent that an event brought to you by AT&T, SBC Communications and Verizon -- to mention only the phone companies chipping in -- can manage to feel neighborly. Corporate America is wooing the Hispanic vote for the same reason Gov. George W. Bush has gone bilingual on the campaign trail. Indeed, if America were a corporation, Wall Street would be crying for a spinoff of its Hispanic subsidiary, its hottest growth prospect. Over the next 30 years, Hispanics, now 12 percent of the population of the United States, will account for 47 percent of its growth, according to Census Bureau projections.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Hewlett-Packard Reports A 23% Jump in Earnings Hewlett-Packard reported quarterly earnings that beat analysts' estimates, driven primarily by strong sales of personal computers and printers. Its board also approved a stock split. Analysts said that a large part of the 23 percent jump in earnings came from higher-than-expected interest income, a more favorable tax rate and other nonoperating contributors. [Page C9.]

headline: Nippon's Wireless Unit Is Said to Be in Talks on U.S. Venture
summary: The wireless arm of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone of Japan, the world's biggest communications company, is in preliminary negotiations to acquire a minority stake in the pending wireless joint venture between the BellSouth Corporation and SBC Communications Inc., two of the local Bell telephone giants, people close to the talks said yesterday. Details of the discussions were unclear yesterday, but one person close to the talks said the Japanese wireless unit, known as NTT DoCoMo, was negotiating to buy no more than 20 percent of the SBC-BellSouth venture.

headline: TELLABS GETS NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
summary: Richard C. Notebaert, former chairman of the Ameritech Corporation, has agreed to become chief executive of Tellabs Inc., the medium-sized maker of communications equipment. Mr. Notebaert takes the reins on Sept. 18. Michael J. Birck, one of the company's founders and the current chief executive, will give up that title and become the company's chairman. Previously, Tellabs did not have a chairman, though Mr. Birck filled that role informally. Mr. Notebaert, 53, left Ameritech, one of the Bell local phone giants, when that company was acquired last year by SBC Communications Inc. The move to Tellabs may be fitting because Ameritech was based in Chicago while Tellabs is based in Lisle, Ill., a Chicago suburb. Tellabs has long been more respected for its technology than for its business acumen. The company is best known for its products that connect fiber optic communications rings to one another. From a business standpoint, however, the company's acquisitions generally have not been fantastically successful. Tellabs shares rose $1.0625, to $62.6875, yesterday in Nasdaq trading. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

headline: Corporations Underwrite The Democrats' Convention
summary: Barely an hour after Vice President Al Gore issued a call for reforming the ways political campaigns are paid for, he headed back to the fund-raising circuit for a concert that raised $5.2 million for the Democratic Party. In his acceptance speech tonight, Mr. Gore vowed to ''get all the special-interest money -- all of it -- out of our democracy'' and promised to make legislation to reform campaign financing the first bill he would send to Congress as president.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Phone Surfing For a Few Yen; Japan Web Sites Navigate A Serene Revenue Stream
summary: Spurred by growing Internet use in Japan, Kazutomo Hori in 1995 built Paradise Web, an Internet site that offered chat lines and bulletin boards. The service thrived, but Mr. Hori could not figure out how to get users to pay. ''People talked about obtaining revenue from advertisements and charging users with electronic money,'' said Mr. Hori, who considered asking customers to make bank transfers or even send in stamps for payment. ''But when will that happen? Ten years from now?''

headline: ACCORD IS REACHED FOR MOST WORKERS IN PHONE WALKOUT
summary: The two unions representing more than 86,000 striking telephone workers reached a contract agreement yesterday with the nation's largest telecommunications employer, Verizon Communications, for about two-thirds of the strikers, indicating that organized labor still has a place in the New Economy. Although about one-third of the union locals had still not signed off on the settlement last evening, the company and the union leaders said the 15-day strike was effectively over. They said union workers in the region affected by the strike -- 12 states from Maine to Virginia and the District of Columbia -- could return to their jobs in New York and New England as soon as this morning, although workers in states such as New Jersey and Pennsylvania are still waiting for their local presidents to approve the contract.

headline: A Hollow Lesson
summary: If a phone circuit goes dead and no one is on the line, does it really stop carrying sound? In many ways, a similar question could be asked about the effective end to the strike against Verizon Communications. While the strike is important for Verizon, the walkout and Sunday's agreement with two-thirds of the union membership on strike probably will not have much bearing on the rest of the telecommunications industry. Even for consumers, the strike's effect can fairly be described as only minimal.

headline: Executives Changing Posts and Accounts
summary: Executives are changing posts at agencies owned by the Omnicom Group. Helene Cote, executive vice president and executive creative director at the New York office of Rapp Collins Worldwide, was named to the new post of executive vice president and chief creative officer at the Irving, Tex. office. In her new post, Ms. Cote, 45, will oversee a creative staff of 65 employees on accounts like Dell Computer, J. C. Penney and SBC Communications.

headline: SBC SELLS LEASE RIGHTS FOR 3,900 TOWERS
summary: SpectraSite Holdings, a company that builds, manages and leases wireless communications towers in major cities across the nation, agreed to acquire the leasing rights for 3,900 towers from SBC Communications for roughly $1.3 billion. SpectraSite, which is based in Cary, N.C., will pay $983 million in cash and $325 million in stock to manage the towers for 27 years. The company also agreed to build about 800 new towers for SBC of San Antonio. Simon Romero

headline: SWISS WIRELESS BIDS
summary: The Swiss government has authorized all of the 10 contenders who sought to bid for the third-generation wireless licenses due to be auctioned on Nov. 13. Switzerland anticipates raising as much as $3.5 billion from the sale of the four licenses, the federal communications commission said. Among the bidders are Swisscom A.G., the country's largest phone company, and its smaller rivals, Orange Communications S.A. and a company owned by Diax A.G. and SBC Communications of the United States. A similar wireless license auction in neighboring Germany raised five times the amount expected. Elizabeth Olson

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Gap Says Sales in August To Decline a Surprising 14% Gap stunned investors by announcing after the stock market closed that sales in stores open at least a year, a key industry measurement, would decline 14 percent in August, well below what most analysts expected.

headline: Justice Dept. Clears SBC and BellSouth Venture
summary: SBC Communications Inc. and the BellSouth Corporation won Justice Department approval today to create the nation's second-largest mobile-phone company after agreeing to sell overlapping properties in 16 markets with 20 million people. The companies will sell wireless operations in markets including Los Angeles, New Orleans and Indianapolis. The transaction, which the companies expect to complete late in the third or early in the fourth quarter, still requires approval from the Federal Communications Commission.

headline: Investing; Judging the Odds On Those Battered Phone Stocks
summary: DEATH warmed over: That is how one analyst has described the battered long-distance and local telephone sector of the telecommunications industry. In a sharp reversal, the Standard & Poor's 500 communications services index, which rose 18.2 percent last year, has dropped 28.9 percent from a mid-December high, to 173.55. Telephone stocks climbed last year, and a bit this spring, on excitement about mergers and the entry of local carriers into long-distance service. But Wall Street has done an about-face on the sector, focusing on the dilution caused by acquisitions, on higher-than-expected capital needs and on fear that competition will put pressure on profits.

headline: NEW SBC-COVAD AGREEMENT ON DSL
summary: Hoping to increase sales of high-speed Internet services, SBC Communications yesterday agreed to pay Covad Communications $600 million over six years for the ability to resell its digital subscriber lines. In addition, SBC will acquire a stake of about 6 percent in Covad, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., for $150 million. Covad also said it would add 30 percent more D.S.L. phone lines than expected this quarter. Simon Romero

headline: Nasdaq Climbs 67 Points As Technology Shares Rally
summary: Buoyed by Oracle's reaffirmation of strong prospects, the Nasdaq composite index climbed nearly 2 percent yesterday after losses in eight of the nine previous sessions, a downturn that had dropped the technology-heavy gauge back to the levels of late May. While cautioning that one day's gains proved little, strategists and portfolio managers said they were encouraged by what appeared to be a fresh appetite for beaten-up technology stocks with the waning of the season in which companies have been warning of shortfalls in sales or profits or both.

headline: LUCENT GETS $1 BILLION SUPPLY PACT WITH SBC
summary: SBC Communications agreed to buy more than $1 billion in equipment, software and services from Lucent Technologies in a five-year deal that makes Lucent SBC's main supplier. SBC will use Lucent equipment as it moves into 30 new markets, including Atlanta, Baltimore, Boston, Philadelphia and Seattle. SBC is the nation's second-largest local telephone company and has been aggressively adding long-distance and high-speed Internet connections to increase its customer base. Besides the SBC contract, Lucent said yesterday that it had signed a $180 million contract with Eletronet, a Brazilian company, to provide optical networking systems in several states in Brazil. Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: A Landscape That Grows Art
summary: For seven years, the Public Art Fund has been responsible for the changing landscape of the commons that surround the Metro Tech Center, the complex of corporate offices in downtown Brooklyn that includes Chase Manhattan Bank; Bear, Stearns; and Brooklyn Union Gas. The commons' newest scene is ''Halcyon Days,'' a yearlong exhibition by five New York artists that is to open on Wednesday .

headline: So, Who Wants Long Distance If Even AT&T Spurns It?
summary: IN his heart of hearts, C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman and chief executive of AT&T, still probably wants folks to phone home. But if he has his way, they will do so on someone else's network. Last week, Ma Bell said that it was considering various ways to get rid of its consumer long-distance business, through a sale to another carrier or a spinoff to shareholders.

headline: SBC Is Going National With Its Local Service
summary: East Wareham, Mass., near the Cape Cod canal about an hour south of Boston, is not generally known as one of the telecommunications industry's hotbeds of competition. But do not tell that to Gary D. Powers. Mr. Powers is president of Abbey Glass, a small glass installer and distributor in East Wareham. His company, with nine employees and perhaps a half-dozen phones, is also a pioneer of what could be the most ambitious plan yet to give consumers and businesses across the country a choice in local communications providers.

headline: U.S. May Pressure Landlords to Allow Digital Competition
summary: The Federal Communications Commission is considering issuing new rules today that would take a step toward forcing commercial landlords to open their buildings to almost any communications carrier that wants access to their tenants, according to people close to the commission. As new forms of digital communication have swept the nation and hundreds of companies have emerged to provide them, landlords of apartment buildings and office towers have had an almost inviolable right to determine which companies may set up shop inside their properties. Now that may begin to change. Government officials and industry executives said commission members and their staffs were still battling over the proposals yesterday afternoon and it was possible the F.C.C. could postpone any action. But whether the issue is addressed today or in the near future, the battle lines have been drawn. Consider 450 Lexington Avenue in Manhattan, a building near 44th Street that includes the offices of Davis Polk & Wardwell, a law firm, and Cline Davis & Mann, an advertising agency. Hines Interests, the building's manager, holds stakes in Broadband Office and Allied Riser Communications, young companies that wire office buildings and offer advanced communications services. Hines has allowed the two to install equipment at 450 Lexington and has yet to give other carriers the same access. Davis Polk and Cline Davis refused to comment, as did Broadband Office. But communications companies that think they are being shut out, as well as some consumer advocates, have not hesitated to attack a system they say is unfair. ''Given the paucity of local communications competition that has emerged since the telecommunications deregulation act of 1996, it's absolutely critical to use every mechanism possible to jump-start greater consumer access to multiple telecommunications providers,'' Gene Kimmelman, co-director of the Washington office of Consumers Union, said yesterday. ''This would be one step forward for breaking down barriers to local competition.'' Others see the matter differently. ''To us, a building is a community,'' said Steve Peterson, a vice president at Hines, a commercial real estate company based in Houston. ''In Texas alone there are 419 registered CLEC's,'' he added, using industry jargon for competitive local exchange carriers. ''Can we have 419 carriers and their equipment in our building? The answer is no.'' ''We're not trying to exclude anybody,'' he said. ''But we want to make sure that all of the carriers are there for the long haul, and yes, we want to maintain a little bit of control over the process. It's our building, after all.'' The Telecommunications Act of 1996 directs the commission to foster increased competition in local markets, and the F.C.C. chairman, William E. Kennard, a Democrat, has made that a primary goal. But realizing that any attempt to exert direct jurisdiction over landlords would be fraught with political and perhaps legal difficulties, the commission appeared to be leaning toward trying to deal with the controversy indirectly. Rather than regulate landlords, the F.C.C. was considering issuing rules that would prohibit carriers from agreeing to exclusive real estate deals, according to industry executives and people close to the commission. Under the proposal, the carriers, who almost always are subject to regulatory certification, would not be allowed to sign a contract under which they would be the only company allowed to install a network in an office building. In addition, the commission appeared to be leaning toward requiring communications carriers to share their space within office buildings with competitors. To serve business customers who spend thousands of dollars a month on communications services, some companies prefer to install advanced antennas on roofs. Others like to put some sort of switch or router in the basement. Many want to install wiring throughout the building. The landlords control a company's ability to deploy its system. If this fight sounds familiar, it should. In many ways, the debate is just the latest variation of AT&T's battle to retain control over Internet services delivered over its cable system, or, for that matter, the fight over whether America Online must open its instant messaging system to rivals. With some exceptions, landlords have almost the same power in apartment buildings as in office towers. But the issue has become ripe in the business sector because some carriers prefer to install equipment in the buildings of businesses they serve. Such equipment is generally not required to serve residential consumers. The conflict over access to commercial buildings is bubbling over just now because the real estate industry is more involved than ever in the communications business. Landlords are taking financial stakes in new carriers in exchange for giving those carriers the sometimes exclusive right to install equipment. Phone giants like Verizon Communications and SBC Communications, which already have lines into almost all the roughly 750,000 office buildings across the nation, have not been on the front lines of this debate. Those with complaints are generally smaller, newer companies. ''We're seeing an increasing amount of landlords who are interested in choice only to the extent that they have taken a financial interest in a carrier,'' said David S. Turetsky, a senior vice president at Teligent Inc., a new local communications company, and a former deputy assistant attorney general at the Justice Department. ''What they all have in common is that none of those models respects the ultimate choice of the tenant.'' Broadband Office was formed by a consortium of real estate companies, together with Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the venture capital firm. Joey D. Mooring, a spokesman for Allied Riser, said his company had granted warrants, a form of equity ownership similar to stock options, to some real estate companies that have opened their buildings, but would not be specific. ''Tenants within the buildings should have the ability to choose who their provider is,'' he said. As a business proposition, lobbyists for the real estate industry tend to agree. But as a matter of regulation, they say the government has no right to tell landlords who can and cannot come in. ''This is something that's driven by the tenant market, and tenant choice is the way for people in the real estate industry to be successful,'' said Roger Platt, spokesman for the Real Access Alliance. This group, formed by many of the nation's biggest real estate companies, has lobbied the F.C.C. to back off. ''Building owners are being portrayed as evil characters out of a Dickens novel,'' he said. ''One of the fundamental aspects of being a manager of property is you have the right to both include certain people and to exclude certain individuals. There are narrow constitutional restrictions on that, but otherwise the Constitution is very clear.'' That argument has found some resonance at the F.C.C. At least one commissioner, Harold W. Furchtgott-Roth, a Republican, has made it clear from the start that the case for forced access is weak at best, said Helgi Walker, a legal adviser to Mr. Furchtgott-Roth. ''Even if such statutory authority were within the discretion of the commission,'' she said, ''the exercise of that discretionary authority would at least raise questions about the constitutionality of its action.'' Taking a page from AT&T's playbook, the Real Access Alliance has suggested voluntary guidelines for preserving competition. In addition to other rules, the commission may make a point of trying to hold the alliance's members to those commitments. Some communications experts suggested that having taken intermediate efforts would be a necessary building block in any future effort to regulate property owners more directly. In the end, however, the companies that have complained appear more interested in getting fast access to buildings than in helping the F.C.C. expand its jurisdiction. ''The point is really to create a process that shortens something that already works,'' said William J. Rouhana Jr., chairman of Winstar Communications, a new local carrier. ''We get access to a lot of buildings, but it takes us an average of nine months to do it. Almost every landlord starts out wondering if they shouldn't consider doing an exclusive, and once that's off the table then the whole process is shortened.''

headline: Cingular Wireless Hires 2 Offices of BBDO
summary: Cingular Wireless, a new business 40 percent owned by BellSouth and 60 percent owned by SBC Communications, said yesterday that it had named the Atlanta and New York offices of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle its creative and media account. Billings were estimated at $200 million. Virginia Vann, senior vice president for marketing at Cingular in Atlanta, said the decision came after a three-month review narrowed the field to the offices of BBDO and two other finalists: GSD&M in Austin, Tex., also part of Omnicom, the agency that had handled wireless advertising for SBC; and West Wayne in Atlanta, the agency that had handled wireless advertising for BellSouth.

headline: Communications Lobby Puts Full-Court Press on Congress
summary: As Congress nears adjournment, some of the nation's most powerful corporations have enlisted important lawmakers to tuck provisions into spending bills that could reshape the balance of power among telephone companies, Internet companies, broadcasters and cable operators. The measures would relax restrictions that have made it impossible for AT&T to expand further in the cable industry. They would save the regional Bell companies billions paid to local carriers that some rivals and groups say would be shifted to Internet users. And they would kill a plan to create hundreds of new low-power FM stations for churches, schools and community groups.

headline: AT&T Is Planning To Split Up Again
summary: The board of AT&T, the nation's largest communications company, approved a plan late yesterday to split up the company in what would be AT&T's most significant overhaul since the court-supervised breakup of the company's Bell System in 1984. Under the plan approved yesterday, people close to the company said, AT&T intends to spin off the company's cable television business and wireless units as separate companies over the next 12 to 24 months.

headline: SBC Reports Unchanged Quarterly Profit
summary: SBC Communications said today that its third-quarter profit was nearly unchanged, as it added a record number of wireless customers and data sales soared while expenses rose more than $1 billion. Profit from operations was $1.96 billion, compared with $1.97 billion in the period a year earlier. Per-share earnings were 57 cents in both periods. Sales climbed 8 percent, to $13.5 billion from $12.5 billion.

headline: AT&T, IN PULLBACK, WILL BREAK ITSELF INTO 4 BUSINESSES
summary: Running out of time with impatient investors, AT&T yesterday pulled back from an expensive three-year effort to become the first one-stop shop selling long-distance, wireless, cable television and Internet services across the nation as a single package with a single bill. It announced that instead it would break itself into four parts. The nation's eighth-largest company, which only two decades ago dominated the telephone business and ranked with General Motors and Mobil among the nation's very largest companies, will become four much smaller businesses competing against many formidable, and sometimes larger, rivals.

headline: Once a Monopoly and Still a Threat
summary: The telecommunications dispute between the United States and Mexico that has simmered for most of this year involves pennies. But since those pennies add up to hundreds of millions of dollars a year in interconnection fees, this has become one of the thorniest trade squabbles to test relations between the two nations. American trade officials have gone so far as to threaten to drag Mexico before the World Trade Organization to force Mexican regulators to level the playing field for competitors, including some with American partners, that are seeking part of the country's $12 billion telecommunications market.

headline: SBC MOVES ON LONG DISTANCE
summary: SBC Communications Inc., which is known to most of its customers as Ameritech, Southwestern Bell or Pacific Bell, asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to sell long-distance service to its customers in Kansas and Oklahoma. The Telecommunications Act of 1996 allows local phone companies to enter the long-distance market on a state-by-state basis as they convince the F.C.C. that they have opened their local networks in those states. So far, Verizon Communications Inc. has been allowed to offer long distance in New York and SBC in Texas. SBC is known as an aggressive company, and yesterday's application was an aggressive regulatory move. There is less local phone competition in Kansas and Oklahoma than in either New York or Texas, so the commission's approval could set a new and potentially lower bar for the other Bells to clear. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

headline: The Devolved AT&T: Are 4 Parts More Promising Than One?
summary: Shortly after announcing on Wednesday that AT&T was going to split into four units, C. Michael Armstrong, the company's chairman, was asked in an interview if anything good would be lost as a result of the overhaul. He considered the question for at least 10 seconds, then responded, ''I can't think of anything.'' But in fact, AT&T may be losing something that if not necessarily good, has been a powerful force in its favor for more than 100 years: the fear that its size and power has inspired in competitors. The AT&T-brand companies that remain after the breakup plan is completed by 2002 will be smaller than the AT&T the communications world has known. And the competitive landscape will change accordingly.

headline: Blue Chips Stage Strong Rally While the Nasdaq Slides
summary: The Dow Jones industrial average registered its biggest one-day gain in six months yesterday, as investors plowed money into blue-chip issues and sold highly priced technology shares. Cyclical stocks like Alcoa, International Paper and DuPont led the Dow's advance, but the breadth of the rise in the index was impressive: 26 of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow average rose in price yesterday, while 4 posted declines.

headline: Japan's Mobile Phone Giant Is in Talks on Investing in U.S.
summary: NTT DoCoMo Inc., Japan's largest mobile telephone company, is talking with several wireless carriers in the United States about taking a stake in a company as it pursues its aspirations to become a global operator, a company executive said today. The executive, Kiyoyuki Tsujimura, the head of DoCoMo's global business operations, said the company considered the United States market crucial to making its wireless Internet service a global standard.

headline: With WorldCom's Breakup Plan, Eerie Similarities to AT&T
summary: Mr. Armstrong, meet Mr. Ebbers. A week after AT&T announced that it would split itself into four parts, WorldCom Inc., the No. 2 long-distance carrier, announced a similar plan yesterday, saying it would separate the company's fast-growing Internet and business services unit from its relatively stagnant operation that serves consumers.

headline: BIG WIRELESS CARRIER HITS NEW YORK
summary: In a move that extends the reach of the nation's second-largest wireless carrier to New York City, Cingular Wireless, the company formed by SBC Communications and BellSouth, agreed to swap wireless spectrum with a rival carrier, VoiceStream Wireless. Under the agreement, Cingular will exchange spectrum licenses covering California and Nevada for spectrum in metropolitan New York, St. Louis, Detroit and parts of Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Connecticut. The transaction, which does not involve cash and should be tax free, involves spectrum licenses in areas that each cover about 35 million people. Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: Decisions Made On Several Accounts
summary: Several advertisers have made decisions on accounts. CMGI, the worldwide Internet operating and development company, named FCB Worldwide in New York, part of True North Communications, as its first worldwide agency of record. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

headline: A Start, but Only a Start, Toward an Inevitable Transition
summary: There is little doubt that one of the main reasons America Online Inc. wants to acquire Time Warner Inc. is potential access to Time Warner's extensive cable television network, the second biggest in the nation. America Online is the leviathan of the dial-up Internet, with almost 25 million subscribers worldwide, but has almost no presence in the business of providing links to cyberspace over high-speed, or broadband, connections, which can be as much as 30 times faster than standard analog modems. The pressure on America Online arises from the fact that, one way or another, the majority of its United States subscribers will probably migrate to broadband over the next five years or so. If America Online does not migrate with them, the company could be left behind.

headline: Swiss Auction of Wireless Phone Licenses Collapses
summary: In just a few months, the auction of Europe's high-speed wireless licenses, once ballyhooed as heralding a new generation of Internet-linked mobile phones and other devices, has turned from cash cow to fiasco. Today, Switzerland offered the newest wrinkle with an auction that never was. Just minutes before bidding was set to start in Zurich for four licenses, a string of deals that would effectively merge two of the bidders into one reduced the number of potential buyers from five to four. That along with the earlier withdrawal by 5 of the original 10 contenders, who complained that the licenses would probably be too costly, prompted the Swiss authorities to postpone indefinitely a sale they had hoped would generate more than $3.4 billion.

headline: BellSouth Lowers Earnings Expectations for Next Fiscal Year
summary: The BellSouth Corporation lowered its earnings expectations for 2001 yesterday after reassessing the costs of expanding its Latin American and high-speed Internet operations. The move highlights the difficulty large telecommunications companies are having in increasing their profits. BellSouth expects earnings per share to grow 7 to 9 percent next year, down from previous estimates of 13 to 15 percent. The company attributed the change to the high cost of increasing its business in Colombia, Latin America's third-largest country, and to increased spending on the expansion of its high-speed Internet business.

headline: LATIN PHONE VENTURE SET
summary: Telefonos de Mexico, Bell Canada International and SBC Communications said they had completed a deal to form a joint venture, Telecom Americas Ltd., to expand into the rapidly growing cellular and Internet services markets of Brazil, Argentina, Venezuela and Colombia. Bell Canada and America Movil, a recent wireless spinoff of Telmex, will each own 44.3 percent, and SBC, 11.4 percent. Carlos Slim Helu, president of Telmex, will be chairman of Telecom Americas; Daniel Hajj, now president of America Movil, will be chief executive. Graham Gori (NYT)

headline: Rally Fueled by Election Ruling Slips on Investor Worries
summary: Stocks ended slightly lower yesterday after rallying briefly on hopes that the presidential election would be decided soon and then falling as investors worried about slowing economic growth and the effect that would have on corporate earnings. The news that set off the selling came from BellSouth, the local telephone company for the Southeast. The company, based in Atlanta, said late Thursday that its profit growth next year would shrink to 7 percent to 9 percent, well below the previous forecast of 13 percent to 15 percent.

headline: How Easy Cash Became Hard Debts
summary: IN a Nov. 2 report, ''The Other Side of Leverage,'' Ravi Suria, a convertible bond analyst at Lehman Brothers, examined the consequences of the recent surge in debt at telecommunications companies at a time when intense competition for customers had reduced revenue growth. It is a sobering piece of research. Mr. Suria began by pointing out that in the past four years, debt at a group of seven high-grade telecommunications companies, including AT&T, Verizon and SBC, exploded from $93 billion, to $210 billion, an annualized rate of almost 23 percent. At lesser-quality telecom and media services companies, like Global Crossing, Nextel Communications and PSI Net, high-yield corporate debt and convertible bond issuance ballooned to $275 billion, a compounded annual rate of 60 percent, in the period.

headline: For Most Local Phone Users, Choice Is Not Yet an Option
summary: AT&T's plan to break itself into four pieces has many experts worried that nationwide competition in local telephone service is at risk. Four years after a grand political compromise among telecommunications interests was supposed to usher in a new era of consumer choice, only about 3 percent of household and small-business telephone lines are served by a competitor to the longstanding local phone company, according to recent preliminary Federal Communications Commission data. At most, some experts believe, no more than 1 in 10 households has any real choice at all.

headline: DoCoMo Reported Near to Buying Stake In AT&T Wireless
summary: NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest wireless carrier, is nearing an agreement to acquire a minority stake in AT&T Wireless, a unit of the United States telecommunications giant AT&T that is being spun off as part of AT&T's recent restructuring, according to executives close to the negotiations. DoCoMo is close to taking as much as a 20 percent stake in AT&T Wireless, the executives said, and the price tag could exceed $9 billion. Though the executives cautioned that the deal could still fall apart, they said the two companies planned to announce the transaction as early as next week.

headline: New Economy; Phone Mergers That May Help Competition
summary: And now, a cheery holiday message for the nation's underprivileged investment bankers and takeover lawyers: the long-distance communications industry may need more consolidation. After nearly five years of headlong deal making in telecommunications, it now appears that the long-term health of the $80 billion-plus long-distance sector depends largely on even more mergers.

headline: Corporate Capital Spending Is Slowing Broadly
summary: For the last decade, even as the United States economy has soared, corporate profit has paled next to the boom in companies' spending on new computers and software, industrial machinery and buildings. With the help of bank loans, bonds and most of the time, a willing stock market, companies since 1991 have bought almost $9 trillion worth of equipment, lifting productivity and sustaining the longest economic expansion in American history. Now, however, that explosion in investment is showing broad signs of slowing. Corporate profits are falling in many industries, giving companies less money to spend. Banks have tightened their lending policies, raising the cost of money. And the swoon of technology stocks has forced the very companies that have made some of the most substantial investments in new equipment to reconsider how they operate.

headline: MICROSOFT BRINGS A BANKER IN-HOUSE
summary: Richard Emerson, a former managing director at Lazard Freres and co-head of its technology and telecommunications advisory services, will join Microsoft as senior vice president of corporate development and strategy. Mr. Emerson, who is 38, will take charge of Microsoft's corporate development activities, including mergers, acquisitions and partnerships. He previously worked in Lazard's San Francisco office. Mr. Emerson worked on deals including SBC's acquisition of Pacific Telesis, its wireless joint venture with BellSouth, and its purchase of Sterling Commerce and Gemstar's merger with TV Guide, among others. John Markoff (NYT)

headline: Japan's Top Mobile Phone Company to Buy AT&T Wireless Stake
summary: NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest mobile phone company, agreed yesterday to buy a minority stake in AT&T Wireless for almost $10 billion. For AT&T Wireless, which has 15 million customers and is the third-largest cellular telephone company in the United States, the deal would provide money for growth as it plans to spin off from its parent, AT&T. The investment also comes at a time when all of the nation's wireless companies are preparing to spend heavily to update their networks with new generations of technology.

headline: A Prized Spectrum Goes on the Block; Wireless Licenses Expected to Raise $15 Billion for U.S.
summary: After months of legal tussling, the most precious natural resource of the information age -- a large new batch of licenses to use the airwaves for wireless communications -- will finally go on sale next week in what experts say could become the largest auction ever held by the federal government. Based on auctions held by Europeans for licenses earlier this year and the growing needs of American wireless companies to fill out their national networks and augment service in their existing digital wireless telephone markets, some Wall Street analysts and industry executives estimate that the auction, which is scheduled to begin on Tuesday, could raise more than $15 billion.

headline: The Modern In Queens
summary: The Museum of Modern Art has found a clever solution to a potential image problem. When it closes its West 53rd Street home in June 2002 for a $250 million renovation and expansion, it will temporarily move to the old Swingline stapler factory in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: No End to Upheaval In Telecom Industry
summary: Things are seldom quiet in the telecommunications business, and 2000 was as eventful a year as any of its recent predecessors, with the WorldCom-Sprint merger deal falling apart and AT&T and WorldCom each planning to split themselves into separate units. And as competitive pressure mounts and profit margins narrow, 2001 is likely to experience further upheaval. Here is a quick look at three of the major sectors in telecommunications, with an eye to possible developments in 2001.

headline: 'Software Gap' Solution: Tools and Technology
summary: As Internet technology spreads across the economy, the pace may be uneven and the impact uncertain for companies large and small. Yet at least one thing is certain: there will be a huge demand for more software and more reliable software. Given that writing software remains as much art as science -- irritatingly immune to the automation that computing itself has brought to other endeavors -- the looming software challenge is stirring concern.

headline: Corrections
summary: A chart in the special Outlook issue of Business Day yesterday showing the largest providers of high-speed Internet service omitted one big provider of digital subscriber lines, or D.S.L. SBC Communications Inc. has 517,000 D.S.L. subscribers.

headline: Verizon Opts To Withdraw Application
summary: Verizon Communications Inc. withdrew its application to offer long-distance communications services in Massachusetts yesterday, fearful that the petition would be rejected by federal regulators. Under the Telecommunications Act of 1996, the Federal Communications Commission would have been required to rule on the application by the end of this week.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: While Not Changing Rates, Fed Is Wary of Downturn The Federal Reserve said that it was shifting its sights from fighting inflation to steering the economy away from a possible recession, emphasizing in blunt language problems that could derail the decade-long expansion. The central bank left interest rates unchanged, but made clear it is ready to cut rates if the slowdown that has become increasingly evident in recent weeks appears to be developing into a full-fledged downturn. [Page A1.]

headline: In a Nod to Slower Economy, SBC Cuts Earnings Forecast
summary: SBC Communications, the nation's second-largest provider of local telephone service, lowered its forecasts yesterday for sales and earnings next year in a sign of how the slowing economy is beginning to affect large telecommunications companies. SBC said its problems were caused in part by regulatory hurdles it faces in introducing long-distance service in states like California and also by high-speed digital subscriber line problems at Ameritech, the company with operations in Illinois, Michigan, Ohio, Indiana and Wisconsin that SBC bought in 1999.

headline: Investors Show Displeasure As the Fed Lets Rates Alone
summary: Apparently disappointed that the Federal Reserve did not cut short-term interest rates immediately, investors drove down stock prices yesterday even though the Fed clearly signaled that it was likely to reduce rates soon. Before the Fed's announcement at around 2:15 p.m., major market averages were trending higher, with the Dow Jones industrial average up nearly 140 points shortly before the decision of the Fed's Open Market Committee was released.

headline: Lucent Lowers Expectations For 3rd Time
summary: In what has become an unwelcome routine, Lucent Technologies warned yesterday that it would lose more money than expected in the current quarter, the third time the company has revised its outlook for the period. Lucent also expects revenue to decline about 20 percent in the quarter as customers reduce purchases of the company's products. And Lucent said it would cut $1 billion in costs in the coming year in an effort to return to profitability, in part through large-scale layoffs.

headline: BUCKING TREND, QWEST SAYS IT WILL MEET EARNINGS TARGET
summary: At a time when many telecommunications companies are issuing earnings warnings, Qwest Communications International said yesterday that it expected to match or beat analysts' earnings forecasts of 14 cents a share for the fourth quarter. The company, based in Denver, said its newer equipment, lower costs and concentration on high-growth businesses like wireless communications and broadband Internet service spared it from the problems that competitors like SBC Communications and AT&T were experiencing. Qwest's stock gained $5.13, or 16 percent, closing at $37.50; it had fallen $5.25 a share Tuesday on concerns that regulatory delays were hampering its entry into long-distance service.

headline: Those Black Holes in Your Mobile Phone Service
summary: WHEN Andrea Levy signed up for cellular telephone service, she thought she was getting seamless coverage for the entire country. But Ms. Levy, a marketing executive from Manhattan, complains about being cut off intermittently everywhere from Westchester County to New Mexico, and she sometimes finds unexpected roaming and long-distance charges on her monthly bill. Stewart Cheifet, an independent video producer from Mountain View, Calif., also laments about coast-to-coast disruptions. ''I can drive around the San Francisco Bay area and lose service,'' he said. In New York, he added, ''I couldn't get a signal from a skyscraper on Wall Street.'' He said that he, too, had encountered unexpected charges.

headline: New Economy; Bringing Competition Policy Into the Age of the Internet
summary: So let's see if this makes any sense. The government allows the No. 1 Internet provider, America Online, to acquire the No. 2 cable company, Time Warner, but the No. 1 long-distance carrier, AT&T, was not allowed to acquire the No. 2 local phone company, SBC.

headline: TECHNOLOGY: High-Technology Stew; D.S.L. Service For Linking to Internet Is Problem Ridden
summary: Lauri Salladay had heard the horror stories of how high-speed Internet access can be as much of a curse as it is a blessing. But she never thought it would happen to her. Then one day last month Ms. Salladay, the creative director of a Manhattan company that designs logos for network television channels, found that her company's Internet connection, over something called a digital subscriber line, or D.S.L., was not working. Suddenly, she was unable to quickly retrieve images from the Internet or respond to e-mail messages from clients.

headline: 'Old' Dow Outperforms the New
summary: The Dow Jones industrial average lost 6.2 percent last year, leaving it looking better than either the Standard & Poor's 500, which fell 10.1 percent, or the Nasdaq composite, which plunged 39.3 percent. But the Dow's loss could have been smaller. A significant part of its decline came from Microsoft and Intel, the two technology stocks added in late 1999 in an effort to bring the Dow more in line with the new technology. Without the changes, the Dow would have been down just 3.1 percent.

headline: In Super Commercial Bowl XXXV, the not-coms are beating the dot-coms.
summary: FROM 3 to 17 to 3 may sound like a familiar pattern to dot-coms. This time, though, it's not the share price of a dot-com stock; it's the number of dot-com advertisers buying commercials during the Super Bowl. When Super Bowl XXXV is broadcast by CBS on Jan. 28, only three dot-com companies are likely to be among the three dozen or so marketers paying an estimated average of $2.3 million to $2.4 million for each 30 seconds of commercial time. That compares with 17 of 36 advertisers in Super Bowl XXXIV last year, when dot-com marketing budgets -- and dot-com stock prices -- were soaring.

headline: Court Invalidates Part of SBC-Ameritech Pact
summary: In a decision that could allow more companies to deliver high-speed Internet service over ordinary phone lines, a Federal appeals court yesterday invalidated an important part of the deal that SBC Communications Inc. made with regulators when it won approval for its 1999 acquisition of the Ameritech Corporation. The Telecommunications Act of 1996 says that the nation's big local phone companies, including Ameritech and SBC, generally must provide access to various parts of their networks to other companies. That arrangement is known in the communications industry as unbundling because it allows a smaller competitor to pay for the use of a big company's copper telephone wires, for instance, without having to buy a bundle of other network services.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: California Barely Avoids First Scheduled Blackouts California barely avoided its first-ever planned statewide power blackouts as longstanding electricity shortages combined with a storm that cut output at a nuclear power plant. In midafternoon, state officials said the blackouts, which would have affected about 1.5 million people, were inevitable. But about 5 p.m., the California Independent System Operator said it had just barely managed to avoid the cutoffs by purchasing some more power from out of state and persuading many customers to cut their use. [Page A1.]

headline: A new campaign will try to identify a company's cellular phones with the idea of self-expression.
summary: PEOPLE may be tempted to refer to a big campaign to introduce a national brand of wireless service, which begins Sunday, as ''The joy of talk'' campaign. And why not? The campaign is upbeat, even humorous, focused far more on what is said on cellular telephones than on the technology enabling that speech. Besides, the agency creating the ads, with a budget estimated at more than $200 million, produces the big, upbeat Pepsi-Cola commercials carrying the theme ''The joy of cola.''

headline: Sprint Still Aspires to Offer One-Stop Communications
summary: So what does it take to make a company successful in the telecommunications industry? ''We firmly believe that this business is about having broadband, narrowband, local, long-distance, wireless, and wire-line capabilities, and we think companies that don't have those capabilities are severely limiting their opportunities,'' the executive said. ''It's the synergy, it's the integration of these capabilities that we think is the winner.''

headline: Corrections
summary: A chart in Business Day on Monday showing the ranking of the Sprint Corporation in four categories of the telecommunications industry referred incorrectly to Cingular Wireless, a joint venture of SBC Communications and BellSouth. While the companies have combined their wireless operations into Cingular, their local phone businesses remain separate.

headline: SBC CLEARED FOR LONG DISTANCE IN KANSAS AND OKLAHOMA
summary: SBC Communications Inc., the No. 2 local telephone carrier, won approval from the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to sell long-distance communications services to its customers in Kansas and Oklahoma. Yesterday's approval, which takes effect on March 3, brings to four the number of states where the Bell local phone giants that emerged from the old American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984 have won entry into the long-distance arena. In late 1999, Bell Atlantic, now Verizon Communications Inc., won the right to sell long-distance service in New York. Last year, SBC entered the long-distance market in Texas. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

headline: Big Companies Prove Winners In Airwave Bids
summary: Taking advantage of rules intended to help the smallest telecommunications companies and bolster competition, the nation's largest wireless phone services and their partners are on the verge of winning scores of new licenses in an auction of airwaves that will enable them to expand service and move into new territories. As the Federal Communications Commission prepares to close its $17 billion auction -- the largest ever held by the government -- the small companies that were supposed to have received special treatment to promote competition are complaining that they lost at the expense of giants like AT&T Wireless, Sprint PCS, VoiceStream and Cingular, the joint venture of SBC Communications and BellSouth.

headline: SBC Says Results Gained 5.6%
summary: SBC Communications Inc. said today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 5.6 percent because it sold more data and wireless services and added long-distance customers in Texas. Profit from operations rose to $1.95 billion, or 57 cents a share, compared with $1.85 billion, or 54 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales, including SBC's stake in the Cingular Wireless mobile-phone venture with the BellSouth Corporation, rose 9.1 percent, to $14.1 billion.

headline: A Fight for Survival in the Broadband Wreckage
summary: UP to its knees in uncollected bills from customers that resell its high-speed Internet connections, suffering from a battered stock price, relying on competitors to deliver its product and caught in a severe market downturn, Covad Communications may be facing a technology-sector version of the perfect storm. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., has become a case study in the tumultuous history of the market for broadband Internet access, a market spawned by the 1996 Telecommunications Act.

headline: Generous Political Donors Rewarded on Super Bowl Weekend
summary: It is Super Bowl weekend, which means football, parties and, of course, political fund-raising. On Friday, as the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, was promising a debate on legislation to curb the influence of special interest money in politics, a group of Democratic senators was already gathered in Puerto Rico with Washington lobbyists and other donors of at least $15,000 to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. Their festivities, at the Ritz-Carlton resort in San Juan, include a Super Bowl party, at which they will be watching the game on television.

headline: Weak Reception; U.S. Lagging Behind in Wireless, And That May Be Just as Well
summary: IT is well documented that in the wireless revolution, the United States has fallen behind Europe and parts of Asia. But while the United States is unaccustomed to being a technology laggard, a closer look at the new uses for wireless phones overseas indicates that Americans may not be missing much. In South Korea, women can use their cell phones to calculate their ovulation cycles. In Britain, the user of a mobile phone can book restaurant reservations by laboriously linking to a Web site by typing on the phone's keypad (even though it would probably be faster to call the restaurant). And in Finland, arguably the most cell-phone-obsessed country in the world, consumers can use phones for such edge-of-the-envelope experiences as buying a soft drink from a vending machine.

headline: Luring the Best in an Unsettled Time
summary: FOR much of the last century, employment in America rested on an exchange that contemplated far more than a day's wages for a day's work: it was all about a bundle of unspoken long-term commitments. Employees gave companies their loyalty -- however grudgingly -- in return for training, promotions, steady raises, job security and identity. Smirk all you like about the Organization Man; his trade-off made possible the 30-year mortgages and college educations that the great American dream was historically made of. In its day, the pact could reinforce itself for a lifetime, for the higher one climbed in a company, the greater the rewards and the stronger the incentive to stick around and try for more.

headline: The Super Bowl XXXV commercials, from pleasant surprises to whose idea was this.
summary: AS the biggest day of the year for advertising unfolded on Sunday, the sage advice of that renowned marketing expert Gomer Pyle could be heard echoing across Madison Avenue: ''Surprise, surprise!'' Many of the 54 paid commercials from 30 advertisers that ran nationally during Super Bowl XXXV relied on unexpected twists, particularly surprise endings, to elicit attention from the audience watching some or all of the game on CBS. The network estimated viewership at more than 131 million, down only slightly from last year despite the lopsided results (quoth the Ravens, ''Never score'').

headline: As in the sport, the experts are issuing post-mortems of the plays in Super Sunday's Ad Bowl.
summary: MADISON AVENUE is closely studying the results of the Ad Bowl played during Super Bowl XXXV, examining data from surveys and polls both online and offline to help sharpen the advertising for next year's game, only CCCLXI days away. That scrutiny is hardly surprising now that the Super Bowl has become the biggest day of the year for advertisers as well as for football and its fans. The increasing interest in the commercials that appear during the game has generated a growing spate of post-mortems from academics, pollsters, marketing consultants and agencies, all seeking to capitalize on the attention generated by an event watched by what is usually the largest television audience of the year.

headline: Telmex Completes Spinoff Of 2 Big Parts of Business
summary: Teléfonos de México, the country's dominant telephone company, spun off its cellular and international businesses throughout the Western Hemisphere to its shareholders today as a new company called América Móvil. Its stock began trading in Mexico City and Madrid today; its American depository receipts begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq on Thursday. With nearly 12 million cellular subscribers of its own in 10 countries, América Móvil is already Latin America's largest mobile phone provider, though the great bulk of its subscribers -- nearly nine million -- are concentrated in Mexico. The new stock closed at 9.95 pesos ($1.03) a share after rising modestly in its first day of trading, giving the venture a market capitalization about $340 million. Telmex shares fell about 3 percent, adjusted for the spinoff, to close at 16 pesos ($1.65) a share. Investors received one América Móvile share for each Telmex share they held.

headline: Unit of BellSouth Accused of Bias
summary: The BellSouth Corporation's telecommunications subsidiary is being sued by a government agency over suspected racial bias against black workers at the company's office in Mobile, Ala. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said it filed the lawsuit last week in Federal District Court in Mobile, contending that BellSouth failed to promote its black employees.

headline: F.C.C. Auction Hit With Claim Of Unfair Bids
summary: George D. Crowley Jr., a longtime telecommunications entrepreneur, recalls the day last fall when an old friend contacted him about an intriguing opportunity. The friend represented SBC Communications. As Mr. Crowley knew, the Federal Communications Commission was preparing to begin an auction in December of wireless airwave frequencies that the largest telephone companies desperately needed. But many of the licenses were being set aside for small companies like his, while others available to any buyer could be bought by such companies at a deep discount. What if, the friend proposed, SBC's wireless phone venture, Cingular Wireless, helped to bankroll him in the auction?

headline: A Flawed Wireless Auction
summary: The Federal Communications Commission's recent auction of wireless airwave frequencies raised $17 billion for the Treasury but failed almost completely to encourage the entry of small companies that could foster price competition and technological innovation. The commission set aside some licenses for smaller companies but then allowed those bidders to be financed by the industry's leading players, as reported yesterday in The Times by Stephen Labaton and Simon Romero. The F.C.C. and Congress ought to rethink their approach to these auctions to determine if there is some way to develop genuine set-aside programs. If not, the pretense should be dropped before it erodes public confidence in the regulatory system. The commission, in auctioning off 422 wireless licenses in 195 markets, set aside 170 of them for start-ups and smaller companies. The bids of the small companies for other licenses were accorded a 25 percent bidding credit, which amounts to a federal subsidy. There is an enormous pent-up demand for broadband spectrum among the nation's biggest wireless companies, which are eager to build national networks and roll out new wireless Internet services.

headline: In Quick Recovery, Brazil Sells Three Wireless Licenses
summary: Rebounding from the failure of its auction two weeks ago, when no valid bids were received, the Brazilian government succeeded in selling three wireless telephone licenses for a total of $1.32 billion in an auction at the Rio de Janeiro stock market. The auction is the beginning of what is expected to be a furious scramble among telecommunications companies in Brazil to stitch together a nationwide wireless network with the latest generation of digital features. The consolidation that is expected to follow should bring the number of players down to a handful from about a dozen.

headline: For Some Who Use Calling Cards, The Number Is 1-800-BEWARE
summary: Janet E. Oseroff of Manhattan signed up for her new calling card from the local phone company, Verizon Communications, in December, and the plan seemed quite clear. ''Your calling card has a simple flat rate,'' a letter from the company said. ''That means you never have to worry about what time it is when you use it, you'll get the same, low 35-cent-per-minute rate on your Verizon Communications domestic long-distance calling card calls.''

headline: People
summary: * Wendy Clark was named to the new post of senior vice president and director for client services at GSD&M, Austin, Tex., part of the Omnicom Group. She had been director for advertising at Cingular Wireless, Atlanta, a joint venture of BellSouth and SBC Communications. * Josh Weinstein, president at Torre Lazur-Weber Public Relations, Parsippany, N.J., part of Torre Lazur McCann Healthcare Worldwide, was named president at the Global Advocacy Development Group, a new worldwide communications unit. Torre Lazur is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: LOSS WIDENS AT PRODIGY
summary: The Prodigy Communications Corporation, an Internet service provider that is based in Austin, Tex., said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss more than doubled from a year earlier to $72.9 million, or $1.04 a share. The company, which revised strategic and marketing pacts with a major shareholder, SBC Communications, in January, will focus on digital subscriber line customers in the coming year. The company reported that it had 2.8 million total Internet subscribers as of the end of the quarter, 425,000 of whom receive D.S.L.-based services. Prodigy said it expected to have 3.1 million to 3.7 million subscribers by the end of the year. Andrew Zipern

headline: SBC COMMUNICATIONS TO CUT JOBS AT TELECOM UNIT
summary: SBC Communications Inc., the No. 2 U.S. local-telephone company, will cut an unspecified number of jobs at its SBC Telecom unit to reduce expenses, an SBC spokesman, Selim Bingol, said. The unit, which sells services outside the company's traditional territories, which are in the Southwest and Midwest, has offices in New York, Boston, Philadelphia and other cities. On Thursday, SBC said it expected to earn 50 cents to 53 cents a share this quarter. The average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial is 59 cents.

headline: 2 Advertisers, Different Outcomes
summary: One advertiser's relationship with its agency is coming to an unexpected end as another advertiser begins a review to find an agency. The Minneapolis office of Fallon Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe, and the OmniSky Corporation, which offers wireless Internet services and devices, are parting ways after working together less than two months. Billings for the account, which Fallon was awarded in mid-January, were initially estimated at $40 million to $50 million, but ''our overall marketing needs really diminished,'' said Kristine Stebbins, vice president for marketing at OmniSky in Palo Alto, Calif., confirming a report of the decision in the online edition of Adweek.

headline: Metro Business Briefing; OFF THE AIR
summary: SNET Personal Vision has received permission from the Connecticut Department of Public Utility Control to shut down its cable television operations in the state, state officials said yesterday. SNET is expected to close its cable service, which operates in 26 towns, by the end of the summer, said Beryl Lyons, a spokeswoman for the department. Personal Vision has about 30,000 customers in Hartford, Fairfield and New Haven Counties. SNET, the former Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation, is a subsidiary of SBC Communications Inc., the telecommunications giant based in San Antonio. State officials said SNET would be required to pay $50 to each customer to get cable service elsewhere. SBC has been moving out of the cable business to concentrate on its telephone, wireless and Internet operations. Jayson Blair

headline: Gauging The Outlook For the Flow Of Deals
summary: DURING times of sharply falling stock prices, one investor's adversity is often another's opportunity. So far, not many have pounced, with merger and acquisition activity sluggish so far this year. But if the market falls further -- or just stabilizes -- that could change, to the benefit of investors who own acquisition targets. Further declines in interest rates could loosen up financing for deals.

headline: Former Qwest Executive Will Head Consumer Unit at AT&T
summary: Trying yet again to find a leader for its troubled consumer-services operation, AT&T announced yesterday that Betsy J. Bernard, most recently a top executive at Qwest Communications International Inc., would become the unit's chief executive next month. Ms. Bernard, 45, represents the sixth generation of leadership at AT&T's consumer unit in five years. Once a cornerstone of AT&T, the consumer operation saw its growth stop in recent years as competition in the residential long-distance market drove prices for many consumers below 10 cents a minute.

headline: Despite Emboldened Critics, Jesse Jackson Isn't Yielding
summary: The Rev. Jesse Jackson could not have picked a better place to make his point. It was a high school basketball championship game at the United Center, the huge arena where the Chicago Bulls usually play, and it was packed to the rafters.

headline: Positive Consumer Confidence Report Gives Shares a Lift
summary: Stock prices climbed again yesterday after investors were heartened by an unexpectedly strong report on consumer confidence, raising some hopes that personal spending will revive the weakened economy. Still, some market strategists said investors appeared to be rallying around a rally since stocks made a stunning reversal late Thursday from their recent steep losses.

headline: A Turf Fight for the Airwaves; The Military Holds. Wireless Is Hungry. Small Users Worry.
summary: Msgr. Michael J. Dempsey of Brooklyn came to Washington earlier this month, hoping to save his small educational television network from becoming a casualty in a fight between the nation's largest telephone companies and the Pentagon. The monsignor founded the network 35 years ago and it now provides educational and Roman Catholic religious programming not only to 70,000 children in parochial schools in Queens and Brooklyn, but to hundreds of thousands more around the nation as well. Within his tight budget, he has decided to allocate $500,000 to retain a former top telecommunications adviser to Vice President Al Gore, a former member of the Federal Communications Commission and the public relations man representing Marc Rich's embattled Washington lawyer.

headline: In a major consolidation, Verizon places most of its creative campaign work under one umbrella.
