summary: IN one of the largest shifts ever of advertising assignments, Verizon Communications, the nation's biggest local telecommunications company, unexpectedly announced yesterday that it would consolidate most tasks involved with creating campaigns aimed at consumers and businesses by naming the New York office of Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide to handle those duties. Verizon, formed last year by the merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE, spends $400 million to $500 million a year on ads for local, long-distance and broadband services; products like call waiting; promoting the Verizon brand name; and burnishing its corporate image.

headline: SBC Is Penalized On Ameritech Deal
summary: SBC Communications has paid the United States government more than $17 million since January for failing to meet requirements of its 1999 purchase of the regional phone company Ameritech Corporation, a federal document showed. From September to January, the company, which provides local phone service, missed targets used to monitor treatment of rivals like Covad Communications Group Inc. and the Allegiance Telecom Corporation when leasing lines and other pieces of its network, according to a document filed at the Federal Communications Commission. Last December, SBC paid $6.1 million for similar deficiencies.

headline: Stranded D.S.L. Customers Weigh Options
summary: LORI WESTIN, the manager of Oasis Family Practice in Denver, has weathered her share of headaches while coordinating her medical office's high-speed Internet service, but the past few days have been especially trying. Her service provider, HSA, relied on NorthPoint Communications for digital subscriber line, or D.S.L., service. And last week NorthPoint, in bankruptcy, said it was shutting down. Oasis was left without Internet access, and without access to its patient schedules, which were online.

headline: Telecom Start-Up Will Cut Jobs and Halt Expansion
summary: Yet another once-promising upstart has demonstrated how difficult it can be to achieve a foothold in the telecommunications industry. Winstar Communications said yesterday that it would eliminate 2,000 jobs -- 43 percent of its work force -- and halt expansion of its network, which provides telephone and Internet service to 32,000 business customers nationwide.

headline: Private Sector; Once Burned, but Still Bold
summary: RARELY does Robert E. Knowling Jr. find himself in a corporate situation that does not lend itself to a line borrowed from one of his favorite films. A staff meeting, say, might call for ''Failure is not an option'' (from ''Apollo 13),'' or a convention speech might include an aphorism from ''The Lion King'': ''You can either run from it, or learn from it.'' So, in November, when an earnings shortfall prompted his resignation after two years as chief executive of the Covad Communications Group, the wholesaler of high-speed Web access, Mr. Knowling began to regather his forces and consider his options for a sequel to what had been his first shot as a chief executive.

headline: PrivateSector; Once Burned, but Still Bold
summary: RARELY does Robert E. Knowling Jr. find himself in a corporate situation that does not lend itself to a line borrowed from one of his favorite films. A staff meeting, say, might call for ''Failure is not an option'' (from ''Apollo 13),'' or a convention speech might include an aphorism from ''The Lion King'': ''You can either run from it, or learn from it.'' So, in November, when an earnings shortfall prompted his resignation after two years as chief executive of the Covad Communications Group, the wholesaler of high-speed Web access, Mr. Knowling began to regather his forces and consider his options for a sequel to what had been his first shot as a chief executive.

headline: Another F.C.C. Clearance For Verizon Long-Distance
summary: Verizon Communications received approval yesterday from federal regulators to provide long-distance service in Massachusetts, bringing to five the number of states where large Bell local telephone companies can enter into the fast-changing long-distance communications business. The approval by the Federal Communications Commission of Verizon's request in Massachusetts comes after the F.C.C. approved similar petitions in New York, Texas, Kansas and Oklahoma. By next year, analysts expect that the Bell companies, created from the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in the 1980's, could compete with AT&T and other long-distance companies in as many as 20 states.

headline: Regional Bells Win Lower Fees
summary: Regulators agreed today to lower the fees large local phone companies must pay rivals for linking customers to Internet service providers, a victory for regional carriers like BellSouth. The Federal Communications Commission voted 3 to 1 to adopt a three-stage plan for reducing the fees.

headline: Sitting Pretty: How Baby Bells May Conquer Their World
summary: HERE is what the United States telecommunications industry may well look like in 2004: Of the Baby Bell local phone carriers, once seven in number, three remain -- Qwest Communications, SBC Communications and Verizon Communications -- and they are by far the most powerful and important communications companies in the nation. The corporations once known as long-distance carriers, like AT&T, are shells of their former selves.

headline: Verizon Would Extend Connecticut Long Distance
summary: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it would seek permission from federal regulators to offer long-distance telephone service in Connecticut, an initiative aimed at building on the company's modest foothold there. If approved, the application would allow Verizon to sell long-distance service to Connecticut's 2.4 million customers. Verizon, the nation's largest regional phone company, already provides long-distance service in New York and last week gained approval to offer it in Massachusetts.

headline: SBC Reports Drop In Earnings of 9%
summary: SBC Communications Inc. said today that its first-quarter operating earnings fell 9 percent because it was spending more on Internet and long-distance services and announced that its profit for the full year would miss forecasts. In the first quarter, profit from operations fell to $1.74 billion, or 51 cents a share, compared with $1.91 billion, or 56 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales rose 4.7 percent, to $13.1 billion, including the company's interest in the Cingular Wireless venture with the BellSouth Corporation.

headline: Share Prices Gain on Better-Than-Expected Housing Sales
summary: Stocks gained yesterday for the first time in four days after housing sales rose faster than expected in March, lifting investor optimism that the economic slowdown may end soon. Pulte and other home builders were among the biggest gainers in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. General Electric led the advance on optimism that it would soon complete the purchase of Honeywell International. Philip Morris rallied on a report that the Justice Department might not have adequate financing for its lawsuit against the tobacco industry.

headline: Texan Finds That Pay Phones Can Pay Off
summary: Wireless phones do not frighten Charlie Sullivan. He has one himself and talks on it all day long while he drives around Texas seeking new places to put pay phones. He has 1,375 of those. Lots of people say wireless phones ought to scare Mr. Sullivan, president of ComChoice, a privately owned pay phone company based in Canyon Lake, in central Texas, about midway between San Antonio and Austin. But Mr. Sullivan intends to belie the widespread notion that cell phones are pushing pay phones off the American landscape.

headline: SBC IS SELLING ITS CELLULAR PHONE STAKE IN TAIWAN
summary: SBC Communications Inc., the second-largest local phone company in the United States, will sell its 44 percent stake in TransAsia Telecommunications Ltd., ending a four-year investment in Taiwan's cellular phone industry. SBC is selling its stake as part of a $410 million transaction that will cede control of TransAsia to the Taiwan Cellular Corporation, the largest cellular company in Taiwan. The purchase of Trans-Asia, based in Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second-largest city, may herald further consolidation in the local wireless industry.

headline: Microsoft shakes up beleaguered San Francisco agencies by shifting its account for Ultimate TV.
summary: THERE may be a shortage of jobs and clients in the San Francisco advertising market as a result of the dot-com meltdown. But there is no shortage of drama as evidenced by big changes that involve Microsoft and several local agencies. Microsoft is dismissing FCB Worldwide in San Francisco, which had served as the creative agency for Ultimate TV, the digital video recorder being introduced to compete against brands like TiVo and ReplayTV. Microsoft is hiring a San Francisco start-up shop, Venables/ Bell & Partners, to create campaigns for Ultimate TV with an annual budget estimated at $50 million.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Telecom Merger Talks
summary: The state-controlled Telenor of Norway said it was in early talks to buy 42 percent of TDC of Denmark, formerly TeleDanmark, possibly foreshadowing a $16 billion merger that could yield the first cross-border combination of Europe's former state telecommunications monopolies. Telenor said in Oslo that it was negotiating with SBC Communications to buy its stake in TDC. Telenor already has a 53.3 percent stake in Sonofon, Denmark's No. 2 wireless operator, raising probable regulatory hurdles to a takeover of TDC. Alan Cowell (NYT)

headline: Temporary Jobs Have Become the Victims of a Slow Market
summary: For most of the last three years, the dozens of temporary-employment agencies in this city have had a problem. They could not find enough qualified workers for the openings that local companies needed to fill. Renate Hartman, who runs a branch of Snelling Personnel Services, noticed last year that many of the available candidates did not dress up for job interviews. Lee Rachelson, the founder of a small staffing company, said she had to post job listings on the Internet so she could recruit people from other cities to move to Tampa.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
summary: SBC COMMUNICATIONS INC., San Antonio, the second largest local telephone company in the United States, has agreed to sell the assets of its Ameritech New Media cable television unit to closely held WideOpenWest L.L.C., Castle Rock, Colo., for an undisclosed amount.

headline: In Brazil, Phone Service for All?
summary: It seemed like the perfect marriage of a new technology and an underserved market. Last year, a company called Vésper started advertising a type of wireless residential telephone service that could be installed much faster than could traditional phone lines and would be cheaper to use than mobile cellular phones would be. People like Rosa Marta, a 31-year-old housekeeper, jumped at the chance. ''I had a phone in my house in three days,'' said Ms. Marta, recalling the installation, which was made last September. She had been waiting years for a conventional phone from the local telephone company. ''I sold my cellular phone, and now I spend only about 70 reais [about $30] on my phone bill,'' she said, noting that her cell phone bill had been about 200 reais, or $85, a month. ''I think it's wonderful.''

headline: AT&T to Raise Some Rates By as Much as 11 Percent
summary: AT&T said yesterday that it would raise basic residential phone rates as much as 11 percent, beginning July 1. The company, facing a decline in consumer long-distance revenue this year, will increase basic weekday rates to 30 cents a minute from 29.5 cents; night-time rates to 25 cents a minute from 22.5 cents; and weekend rates to 16 cents from 14.5 cents. A basic rate for calls made at any time will rise to 17.5 cents a minute from 16 cents.

headline: Cable Giants Block Rival Ads In Battle for Internet Customers
summary: As the battle to provide high-speed Internet service heats up, the cable television giants are increasingly using a defensive tactic: refusing to sell advertising time to phone companies to promote D.S.L., an advanced telephone network technology that competes with cable modems. From big markets like New York City, where Time Warner Cable has refused D.S.L. advertisements by the telephone company, Verizon Communications, to small towns like Newtown, Conn., cable companies are saying ''thanks, but no thanks'' as phone companies try to buy local advertising time to promote their high-speed service. D.S.L. -- or digital subscriber line service -- can deliver torrents of Internet data over normal phone lines.

headline: FALSE FILINGS BY SBC COMMUNICATIONS ARE INVESTIGATED
summary: Regulators said they were investigating more admissions by SBC Communications that it filed false information as it sought government approval to sell long-distance phone service in Kansas and Oklahoma. On April 13, SBC told the Federal Communications Commission it submitted incorrect information on fast Internet lines and the agency started investigating. In a filing with the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit yesterday, the F.C.C. cited a June 8 letter in which SBC said details about computer systems rivals use might also be inaccurate. The agency said it was looking into that data.

headline: Market Place; As AT&T Wireless strikes out on its own, the other bits and pieces of AT&T remain in play.
summary: THE complex breakup of AT&T could become a bit less complicated today when the company plans to complete its spinoff of AT&T Wireless to shareholders. Under the transaction, AT&T shareholders who opted last month not to exchange all of their shares for AT&T Wireless stock will receive about a third of a share in the wireless company for each share they own of AT&T.

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Telephone Privatization
summary: South Africa announced that the long-planned public offering for Telkom South Africa would be in November. South Africa is undertaking a sweeping effort to sell significant stakes in its biggest state-owned companies, but with labor balking at the scope of the effort, progress has been slow. The global downturn in technology and telecommunication stocks has made the government more circumspect about taking Telkom public. Telkom Malaysia and SBC Communications, which together own 30 percent of Telkom South Africa, are in talks with the government, which owns the remaining 70 percent, over which will sell shares and how much of the company will go public. Henri Cauvin (NYT)

headline: The View From/Avon; A Tournament Entwines Golf, Community and Charity
summary: TWO years ago during the first SBC Futures Golf tournament in Farmington Valley, the weather in July was so hot that everyone was uncomfortable. So last year the organizers moved the women's golf tournament to May, only to see torrential rains wash out one day of competition. This year the tournament has moved back to July, and Susan Glasspiegel, the tournament chairwoman, said she hoped the conditions would be perfect for the Lincoln Futures Golf Classic, which starts Tuesday and runs through Saturday at the Blue Fox Run Golf Club in Avon.

headline: Against All Odds, A Telecom Rebirth
summary: BY the time Theodore B. Olson walked into a Washington courtroom on a cloudy morning in March, it would have taken close to a miracle to save his client, NextWave Telecom, from ruin. Founded by a former top executive at Qualcomm, Allen B. Salmasi, and financed by a group of veterans of Drexel Burnham Lambert, the defunct investment banking firm, and a coterie of hedge funds, NextWave had been stuck in bankruptcy since 1998; the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia was its last hope.

headline: Dutch Phone Company Still in Merger Talks
summary: In an attempt to defray speculation that merger discussions with a Belgian phone company had stalled, Royal KPN, the large Dutch telecommunications group, said today that talks were continuing, but had not progressed to an advanced stage. At the end of May, KPN said it was exploring a merger with several telecommunications companies, and named Belgacom, the former Belgian phone monopoly, as its preferred partner.

headline: The new president of BBDO North America reflects on life and business in the colonies.
summary: WILL the executive recently named to head North American operations for BBDO Worldwide one day have colleagues and clients singing, ''And here's to you, Mr. Robertson''? That's one question being asked as Andrew Robertson settles in as president and chief executive at BBDO North America in New York, a post he assumed in April after serving as chief executive at a sibling agency, Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO in London, the largest British agency.

headline: Lucent Announces Big Further Job Cuts, and a Large Loss
summary: Lucent Technologies, the once-mighty telecommunications equipment giant, announced a large loss yesterday and as many as 20,000 additional job cuts, continuing a dizzying downward spiral that will leave the company with far fewer than half the workers it employed only a year ago. The new cutbacks, along with some 75,000 Lucent jobs that are already being eliminated through layoffs, early retirement or corporate spinoffs, rank among the largest and fastest in the history of big American corporations. Lucent's work force -- 155,000 employees a year ago -- will total about 60,000 when the latest round of layoffs is completed in the next several months.

headline: Group Is Said To Accuse Pacific Bell Of Monopoly
summary: A group of California Internet service providers, which rely on the Pacific Bell telephone network to offer high-speed service, plans to accuse Pacific Bell and an affiliate of engaging in anticompetitive practices. The California Internet Service Providers Association, a trade group, is expected to file a complaint today with the California Public Utilities Commission asserting that Pacific Bell is using its dominance of the infrastructure used for high-speed D.S.L. service to create a new monopoly over access to the service.

headline: Dow and Nasdaq Gain After Two Days of Heavy Selling
summary: After two days of heavy selling, stocks rallied yesterday as investors took their cues from a few good earnings reports despite the preponderance of bad ones. Still, some stocks rose for little reason other than that they had been battered in recent days.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cingular To Enter Utah Markets
summary: Cingular Wireless, the second-largest United States mobile phone company, agreed to buy airwaves in Utah from Leap Wireless International for $140 million to enter two new markets. Cingular, a venture of BellSouth and SBC Communications, will buy 15 megahertz of spectrum, or capacity, in Salt Lake City and in Provo, Utah, the Atlanta-based company said. Leap will retain 15 megahertz of spectrum in each market to continue providing its flat-rate, unlimited local wireless service.

headline: Clinton Lays Out Future for Library, and Himself
summary: In a pep talk to a receptive hometown crowd, former President Bill Clinton said today that he would use his presidential library and policy center here to advance themes that were central to his presidency. Among them, he said, were spreading economic opportunity to the disadvantaged; improving schools, health care and the environment; fostering understanding of the world economy; and promoting peace and reconciliation across racial and religious lines.

headline: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Clinton To Focus On Racism
summary: Former President Bill Clinton said in Little Rock that he would use a $250,000 grant to his presidential library to promote racial and religious reconciliation. Mr. Clinton said he would focus domestically on racial disparities in health, education, economic opportunity and criminal justice. The grant is from SBC Communications, the parent company of Southwestern Bell. Kevin Sack (NYT)

headline: Digitally Disenfranchised; Bell Companies Are Blamed For the Slow Start Of a Fast Internet Service
summary: A year ago, Hossein Farmani, president of aNet Communications, a small Internet service provider in Los Angeles, catered to a loyal group of longtime customers. ANet was no AOL, but Mr. Farmani was content to preside over a small community of 5,000 or so users. Yet the customer loyalty proved to be highly elastic. Mr. Farmani discovered that providing competitively priced D.S.L. service -- a form of high-speed Internet connection -- had become close to impossible. Lured by lower prices to Pacific Bell Internet, the big telephone company's own Internet unit, half of Mr. Farmani's customers had deserted aNet.

headline: Alltel in Hostile $6.1 Billion Bid for Phone Rival
summary: The Alltel Corporation, the large telecommunications company, made an unsolicited $6.1 billion takeover bid yesterday for CenturyTel Inc., a smaller rival that provides phone services in rural areas, suburbs and small towns. The hostile offer by Alltel, which would also assume $3 billion in debt, represents the company's latest move to capture more market share at a time when valuations for telecommunications companies are considerably lower than they have been in the recent past.

headline: A Place Where Beer and Noise Flow Freely
summary: IT was an odd sensation, being the only people over 30 in a large restaurant that throbbed with high-decibel music and shrieks of happy chatter. In fact, the hostess at SBC Downtown in Stamford took one look at us and said, ''How about a quieter table upstairs?'' Upstairs is quieter, but only by degrees. We were able to talk at a normal conversational level, that is until celebratory laughter and shouting started up at a nearby table occupied by a group of eight. (On weeknights the place quiets down somewhat -- at least upstairs -- by 9 p.m.)

headline: The Black Caucus, Once a Foe, Enjoys Soft-Money Games
summary: The dozens of shiny new green golf carts were lined up with military precision, like rows of miniature tanks prepared to charge onto a well-groomed battlefield. But that was where the war analogy ended. These golfers -- House Democrats who are members of the Congressional Black Caucus, joined by a group of Washington's most powerful corporate lobbyists -- said they were adversaries only on the links, not in the halls of Congress.

headline: In Capitol, AT&T and Bells Fight to Control Web Access
summary: The country's regional Bell telephone companies and the cable giant AT&T are engaged in a furious fight on Capitol Hill over the rules managing the rollout of high-speed Internet access into Americans' homes, in the process reopening one of the most bitter lobbying clashes of the last decade. The battle is over the two main technologies that give consumers high-speed, or broadband, Internet access: cable modem service offered by companies like AT&T and digital subscriber lines, or D.S.L., provided by phone companies. Both sides say they have consumers' interests at heart.

headline: BellSouth's Down-Home Strategy; Local Telephone Service Has Become a Haven For Cautious Company
summary: The oak furniture. The neckties and starched shirts. The hushed banter of secretaries outside large corner offices. And the steady, predictable stream of profits generated by the dominant local telephone company in the Southeast. At its corporate headquarters in a nondescript high-rise here, it seems as if BellSouth remains untouched by the frenzied changes that have shaken the telecommunications world in recent years.

headline: New Economy; House to Focus On Net Access And Competition
summary: Shortly after Congress reconvenes tomorrow, the House will take up a complex bill that raises two simple, essential questions about the nation's digital future. In the effort to deliver high-speed Internet service to consumers, what is the ideal number of competitors? And should the government make that decision? In recent years, the battle for high-speed, or broadband, access has been dominated by two technologies. One is digital subscriber lines, or D.S.L., which use telephone wires. The other is cable modems, which use cable television lines. Despite the development of satellite and land-based wireless systems, the broadband media world will continue to be ruled by phone wires and cable lines for many years.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel To Supply Cingular
summary: Nortel Networks said yesterday that it would provide equipment to Cingular Wireless to help build an asynchronous transfer mode network that will connect 87 markets. Cingular Wireless, a partnership of SBC Communications and BellSouth, has 21 million subscribers. Terms were not disclosed. Nortel says the deal will help Cingular develop third-generation networks, reduce costs and deliver voice and data services more efficiently. Nortel shares closed down 33 cents, to $5.67. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline: A Surprisingly Steady Day for the Major U.S. Markets
summary: The stock market was a surprise yesterday, rallying from early losses to finish the day little changed. The steady performance -- instead of the feared continuation of the sharp declines at the end of last week -- was enough to help European stock markets rebound from their early losses. And longer-term bond prices fell and yields rose as investors saw stocks hold the line and, maybe, thought that the pessimism about the economic outlook might be a little overdone.

headline: Americans Reach Out To Neediest
summary: In scarcely two weeks, The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund has received pledges or donations totaling nearly $13 million. That is far more than has ever been raised in one year of the newspaper's annual Neediest Cases holiday charity drive, which took in a record $8 million last year. ''The comparisons with the ordinary Neediest Cases Fund are meaningless,'' said Jack Rosenthal, the president of The New York Times Company Foundation, which runs the annual campaign and set up the 9/11 fund after the terrorist attack last week. He said that he was impressed with the way people from all over the country had responded. ''When you turn on the Yankee-White Sox game at Comiskey Park in Chicago and see people waving signs saying 'We Love New York,' you understand the power of this event,'' he said.

headline: SBC COMMUNICATIONS SEEKS TO ACQUIRE ALL OF PRODIGY
summary: SBC Communications Inc. offered to acquire the 58 percent of the Internet service provider Prodigy Communications that it does not already own for $384 million, or $5.45 a share, an SBC spokesman, Selim Bingol, said yesterday. SBC, which is based in San Antonio, said in a statement that the offer represented a 54 percent premium to Prodigy's closing price of $3.54 yesterday, and a 35 percent premium to the average closing price for the year to date.

headline: SBC's Bid for Prodigy Shares Is Making a Big Investor Even Bigger
summary: Carlos Slim Helú, Latin America's richest man, is about to be made a little richer by SBC Communications. SBC, one of the nation's largest local telephone companies, offered on Friday night to acquire the 58 percent stake it does not already own in Prodigy Communications, an Internet service provider, for $384 million, or $5.45 a share. That translates to a premium of 54 percent above Prodigy's closing price of $3.54 on Friday. After SBC, Mr. Slim and companies he controls are Prodigy's largest shareholders.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Energy Prices Decline; Stocks Rise on Optimism Oil and natural gas prices plunged on fears that a worldwide recession would cut energy demand. But stocks worldwide soared on optimism that the recession would be brief and that the United States economy would eventually shrug off the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. The price of a barrel of crude oil dropped $3.96, or 15 percent, to $22.01, in trading in New York. The drop marked the biggest one-day decline since 1991. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 367.63 points, or 4.5 percent, after closing Friday with its biggest weekly loss since the Depression. [Page A1.]

headline: Shares End Slightly Higher After a Day of Fluctuation
summary: Stocks eked out modest gains after a directionless day yesterday, as Wall Street paused after last week's market plunge and Monday's surge. Investors continued to have trouble evaluating the economic and corporate prospects in the wake of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon two weeks ago, and their difficulty was evident in stock prices. The major market gauges swung up and down throughout the day.

headline: AT&T Looks To Baby Bells For a Buyer
summary: AT&T, the stumbling communications company once known as the mighty Ma Bell, is seeking to sell its telephone operations to one of its Baby Bell offspring. AT&T has approached at least three of the nation's largest local telephone companies -- Verizon Communications, SBC Communications and BellSouth -- about buying its consumer and business telephone operations, people close to the companies said.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 During a Yearlong Intifada, Fear Has Gripped Mideast Among the facts upon which Israelis and Palestinians disagree is what day the intifada began. Palestinians say Sept. 28, 2000, when Ariel Sharon, now the Israeli prime minister, visited a site sacred to Muslims; Israelis tend to say the day before or the day after. But people on both sides describe similar effects of the events since: fear and desperation. A3 Shooting Rampage in Swiss Hall A 57-year-old gunman stormed into a crowded regional legislature in Zug, killing 14 people and detonating a hand grenade before shooting himself dead. It was the bloodiest episode in the normally tranquil country's recent criminal history and prompted talk of tightening Switzerland's relaxed security. A6

headline: Investing; Forecasters Try to Assess the Terror Factor
summary: SENDHIL MULLAINATHAN, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has spent the last two weeks plugging worst-case possibilities into his economic and market forecasts. Even if there are no further terrorist incidents, he is concerned that just a minor change in the outlook of consumers and investors could wreak havoc with the economy and drive down the price of stocks.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Wins Big Cingular Contract
summary: Lucent Technologies said it had won a five-year contract to provide wireless equipment to Cingular Wireless, the nation's second-largest cellular carrier. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but the contract was said by people close to the companies to be worth at least $1 billion. The deal with Cingular, a venture formed last year by BellSouth and SBC Communications, comes after Lucent signed similar contracts with two other big carriers, Verizon Wireless and Sprint PCS. Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: With Cellphones, Who Knows Where the Time Goes?
summary: A PROFESSOR I had in college once remarked that Americans are not adequately schooled in making estimates. And if my experience in trying to gauge how many cellphone minutes I've used up is representative of the rest of the population's, we may be in worse trouble than my professor thought. Most cellphone plans limit customers to a specific number of minutes each month covered by a set fee. Users who exceed the limit can incur steep charges per minute, yet few people know how to keep track of how much time they have spent on the phone.

headline: Now Playing at a Restaurant Near You
summary: THERE'S dinner theater, and then there's dinner as theater. For those who like the latter, Connecticut has plenty of choices. To get that Florida feel while sticking close to home, try Ocean Drive in South Norwalk, whose cool, white nautical interior evokes the style and smarts of South Beach, the hip hangout in Miami. The raw bar and largely seafood menu add to the shore-side illusion. And hanging dramatically from the ceiling is a huge orange and teal hand-blown glass sculpture by Dale Chihuly.

headline: Rivals Worry About Access As Verizon Seeks Buffer
summary: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local telephone company, is raising the ire of competitors who worry that its efforts to increase security in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks will restrict their access to Verizon work locations. Verizon, which was formed last year in the merger of Bell Atlantic and the GTE Corporation, has told the Federal Communications Commission and the New York State Public Service Commission that it needs additional protection against attacks on its property.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Insurer Is Seeking to Limit World Trade Center Claims Swiss Re, the biggest insurer of the World Trade Center, frustrated by unsuccessful negotiations, went to court to try to limit how much it will pay to half of what the buildings' managers and owners are asking. The real estate executive whose companies hold a lease on the property has said he will seek $7 billion from insurers. He argues that each of the airliners that crashed into the towers constituted a separate attack covered by $3.5 billion in insurance. But Swiss Re asked the Federal District Court in Manhattan to determine that it and the other insurers be liable for only $3.5 billion because both crashes amounted to a single incident. [Page B5.]

headline: 30% Drop in Profit Leads SBC To Job and Web Project Cuts
summary: SBC Communications said here today that its third-quarter profit fell 30 percent and that it would eliminate several thousand jobs and reduce spending on an Internet project. Profit totaled $2.1 billion, or 61 cents a share, compared with $3 billion, or 88 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose less than 1 percent, to $13.5 billion, including SBC's 60 percent share of Cingular Wireless. SBC did not specify how many of its 216,000 workers would be let go.

headline: Lucent Reports $8.8 Billion Loss and a Dim Outlook
summary: Lucent Technologies Inc. announced a quarterly loss of $8.8 billion yesterday that was within analysts' expectations, but the company offered an industry outlook for next year that was more dismal than its previous forecasts. Lucent, whose losses for the year so far now exceed $16 billion, said it expected its customers, which include large companies like AT&T, SBC Communications and Qwest Communications, to spend 15 percent to 20 percent less on equipment next year than they did this year. Just three months ago, Lucent had said it expected next year's sales to decline only 5 percent to 10 percent.

headline: WorldCom Net Slips 47% as Sales Skid at MCI
summary: WorldCom Inc. said today that its third-quarter earnings declined 47 percent after sales dropped at the MCI Group's consumer long-distance phone business and profit fell at the company's data and international unit. Net income slipped to $493 million from $935 million in the period a year earlier. Sales fell 11 percent, to $8.97 billion from $10 billion.

headline: A Pivotal Choice for Cingular Wireless
summary: Cingular Wireless, the nation's second-largest mobile phone carrier, intends to announce broad changes in its technology today, people close to the company said yesterday. The decision will benefit some of Europe's largest communications equipment companies at the expense of competitors in the United States and Canada. Cingular, which has 21.3 million customers, has decided to overlay a cellular communications technology called global system for mobile communications, or GSM, across its nationwide network, the people close to the company said. The decision is part of a shift to a technology that is widespread in Europe and Asia but that has only recently gained ground in the United States.

headline: Privatization Snag in South Africa
summary: When South Africa announced this week that the initial public offering of Telkom South Africa, by far the largest telecommunications company south of the Sahara, would be delayed yet again, the news threw cold water on the whole privatization effort here -- not to mention the national budget. The decision, while disappointing, was not really a surprise. Even critics who complain that privatization is moving too slowly said delaying the Telkom deal into late 2002 or early 2003 was the only prudent course.

headline: Business; A Phone Upstart, Still Annoying the Giants
summary: THROUGHOUT Chicago, where Ameritech is the reigning local telephone company, billboards popped up during the summer showing the face of the tough-talking football legend Mike Ditka. ''Make the smart call -- bench Ameritech,'' he says on one of them. ''Staying with Ameritech is just plain dumb,'' he advises on another. And last week, a new series of billboards began appearing in the city, as well as in Detroit and Pittsburgh, recommending: ''Choose Wisely. Because Now You Can.'' The billboards are part of a major advertising campaign by Z-Tel Technologies, a small, publicly traded residential-phone company based in Tampa, Fla., that is struggling to make a name for itself. Z-Tel is also taking on other regional phone giants like Verizon Communications, based in New York, and SBC Communications, the parent of Ameritech, based in San Antonio, using direct mail and advertising on radio and television.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: BellSouth Brightens Forecast
summary: BellSouth, the largest local telephone company in the Southeastern United States, surprised analysts yesterday with sales and earnings estimates for the coming year that were more optimistic than forecasts. BellSouth said yesterday that it expected revenue to grow 5 percent to 7 percent next year, compared with sales growth of 8 percent to 9 percent this year. The company, which is based in Atlanta, also said it expected earnings per share to increase 7 percent to 9 percent in 2002. BellSouth's estimates were a surprise after more pessimistic outlooks were provided by other large local telephone companies like SBC Communications and Qwest Communications. Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: Incredibly Shrinking AT&T And the Armstrong Agenda
summary: C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman of AT&T, has sympathizers in high places these days. The way Mr. Armstrong tells it, he was stepping down from a panel discussion in Manhattan on Monday when another panelist put an arm around him and drew him aside.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As he tries to generate revenue, Yahoo's chief moves the company away from its old culture.
summary: FOR Terry Semel of Yahoo, this is where the hard part begins. It's been seven months since Mr. Semel, the longtime co-leader of the Warner Brothers studio, was named as chief executive of Yahoo. After what many investors felt was a slow start, he has begun to outline his plan to revive the once highflying Internet portal.

headline: Disputed Phone Licenses Transferred to Big Carriers
summary: The Federal Communications Commission reached a deal yesterday to transfer ownership of $16 billion worth of disputed mobile phone licenses to some of the nation's biggest wireless carriers, while providing a windfall for the bankrupt NextWave Telecom. The settlement, which must be approved by several federal authorities, would end five years of wrangling over the licenses and allow the wireless carriers to expand service in urban areas like New York, Los Angeles and Washington.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Envoys Discuss Peace For Russia and Chechnya Top envoys from the Kremlin and the Chechen rebel government met publicly in Moscow to discuss peace for the first time since war erupted 27 months ago between Russia and Chechnya, a separatist province. Both officials, Akhmed Zakayev, the deputy prime minister of Chechnya, and Viktor G. Kazantsev, above, a representative of President Vladimir V. Putin, were reported to have said that the talks were productive and that they would continue. A10 Sharon Won't Budge on Talks Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel, concerned about possible new pressure by the Bush administration to accelerate steps toward peace negotiations, rejected the idea of easing a requirement that seven days of quiet must precede other formal steps endorsed by both sides. News media have reported that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell will request that Mr. Sharon drop the condition in a speech scheduled for today. A10

headline: An Old Politician Moves to the Boardroom
summary: William M. Daley, the campaign chairman of Al Gore's unsuccessful presidential bid, has decided to move down to what was once enemy territory, Texas, to become president of SBC Communications. The appointment to a newly created position places Mr. Daley second in command behind Edward E. Whitacre Jr., chairman and chief executive of SBC, the giant regional Bell company, based in San Antonio. The move was approved last week by the SBC board and is to be formally announced today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Gore Campaign Manager To Be President of SBC William M. Daley, the campaign manager for Al Gore's unsuccessful presidential bid, has decided to move down to what was once the enemy's territory, Texas, to become president of SBC Communications. The appointment to the newly created position places Mr. Daley second in command behind Edward E. Whitacre Jr., SBC's chairman and chief executive. The move is set to be formally announced today. [Page C2.]

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Company Continues Network Upgrade
summary: Cingular Wireless reaffirmed yesterday that it would acquire gear from three European communications equipment companies as it proceeds with an upgrade of its nationwide wireless network, although its estimates for the contracts were less than those reported in Europe. Cingular, which is based in Atlanta and owned by SBC Communications and the BellSouth Corporation, said its contracts might total more than $1 billion each for Ericsson and Nokia, while the contract with Siemens is estimated in excess of $500 million. Clay Owen, a Cingular spokesman, said the upgrade might cost $2.6 billion to $2.8 billion but not as much as the $4 billion cited in some reports. Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: For Cable-Modem Customers, a Switch Causes a Scramble
summary: PHONE company or cable company? Just when it seems as though a clear winner is emerging in the race to offer the most exasperating Internet service, the other pulls ahead. The latest leg seems to have been won by the cable companies, at least those offering service from Excite@Home, a bankrupt provider of high-speed Internet access.

headline: Market Place; A buyout company may plan some tough love for two telecoms, and holders of their debt and stock.
summary: EVEN though the crisis in the telecommunications industry was well under way a year ago, XO Communications and McLeodUSA were well received by some investors. How quickly things change. The stocks are below $1, and both XO and McLeodUSA are mired in debt. Saying there is no other way for the companies to avoid bankruptcy filings, the buyout firm Forstmann Little has announced huge restructuring plans the last two weeks for both XO, a telephone and Internet company based in Mclean, Va., and McLeodUSA, a telephone company in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

headline: The Broadband Economy
summary: Karen Kornbluh Op-Ed article says America needs to put its unused Broadband fiber-optic network to use since it is vital to improvement of American economy; drawing (M)

headline: Technology & Media; Telecommunications Industry Too Devastated Even for Vultures
summary: The resounding boom in telecommunications investments from 1996 to 2000 fizzled in 2001, when at least 27 telecommunications companies, each with more than $100 million of liabilities, filed for bankruptcy protection. The industry may require a year, or perhaps even two, before a muted recovery starts to take place. Even the vulture investors, like hedge funds, private equity companies and funds within investment banks that specialize in distressed businesses, may not be attracted to the carcasses of once-ambitious companies that now litter the industry's landscape.

headline: Fish to FedEx: Bowl Name Game
summary: Match the sponsors with the correct bowl game: AXA, Capital One Florida, Chick-fil-A, Culligan, FedEx, Mainstay, SBC, Sega Sports, Tostitos and Visit Florida. Actually, you don't have to. My guess is that it would take too long, requiring a lifeline or two, and only annoy the marketing types from each corporation. They do not want to sit in a conference room and explain why AXA is not synonymous with the Liberty Bowl and the matchup between Brigham Young and Louisville. Besides, the sponsors are only continuing a long tradition among college football aficionados of giving fans what they want -- a game long after the regular season is over.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Covad Exits Bankruptcy
summary: Covad Communications, a provider of high-speed Internet services, emerged from bankruptcy yesterday after reaching a deal to eliminate $1.4 billion of debt by offering a combination of cash and equity to its debt holders. Covad, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., also received $150 million of loans and service payments from SBC Communications, providing it with a cash cushion. Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: A Telecom Umbrella Extends Its Shadow
summary: Jean C. Monty has a vivid description of how Bell Canada Enterprises would look if it were an American company. Start by combining the telephone businesses of Verizon Communications and SBC Communications, says Mr. Monty, chairman and chief executive of BCE, as his company is widely known. Then add Verizon's wireless operations, and America Online's Internet customers. Fold in ABC's television network, the ESPN cable sports network and the DirecTV satellite service. Finally, tack on The New York Times.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: E.E.O.C. Sues Allstate In Discrimination Case After 15 months of unsuccessful negotiations to settle accusations that Allstate discriminated against its agents, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued the insurer. The suit centers on a decision made by Allstate to convert its agents into independent contractors. Those who wished to remain were required to agree not to sue the company. Agents who did not become contractors were dismissed and given the choice of rejoining as contractors or leaving the company. Many of them then filed complaints. [Page A1.]

headline: Yahoo Wins Race for HotJobs As TMP Declines to Raise Bid
summary: The takeover battle for HotJobs .com, the Internet's second-largest career site, ended before it began. Yahoo wrested HotJobs.com away from TMP Worldwide yesterday as TMP, parent company of Monster .com, surrendered without firing a shot. TMP said it would not engage in a bidding war for HotJobs.com, which it had agreed to buy six months ago, refusing to top Yahoo's unsolicited offer of $436 million.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Main Stock Gauges Fall For Second Year in a Row The three major stock market averages have now fallen for two consecutive years for the first time since the brutal recession years of 1973 and 1974. But a rally in the final three months helped to create optimism that the worst is over for both stocks and the economy. With moderate declines on the final day of the year, the Dow Jones industrial average finished 2001 off 7.1 percent, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 13 percent and the Nasdaq composite sank 21 percent. [Page A1.] The last three months of 2000 were wonderful for foreign stocks, but the first positive quarter in the last seven made the year only a little less painful. [World Business, Section W.]

headline: AT&T Plans To Lay Off 5,000 Workers
summary: In a continued attempt to reduce its costs, AT&T announced yesterday that it planned to lay off 5,000 employees this year. The company said it would take a charge of about $1 billion, before taxes, in the fourth quarter of 2001 to cover the costs of these layoffs and the costs of having already dismissed 5,100 employees. About 2,000 of the employees laid off last year and this year work in New Jersey, where many of the company's operations are based, according to Eileen M. Connolly, a spokeswoman for AT&T.

headline: Mr. Semel's Internet Search; How a Former Hollywood Man Is Trying to Make Yahoo Click
summary: Terry Semel wanted to have a fast start turning around Yahoo. He has had to settle for some extended on-the-job training. The first hard lesson come last August, two months after Mr. Semel took over as chief executive of Yahoo, when he tried to buy the online job-listings site Headhunter.net. Headhunter would have provided a needed new source of revenue for Yahoo, the popular Web portal, which has been trying to reduce its dependence on the fickle market for online advertising.

headline: Personal Business; When Pension and Unemployment Checks Don't Mix
summary: JANICE SWEET FAIRLEY spent virtually all of her working career at the telephone company, starting as an operator for Michigan Bell, and rising to a manager of data services after the company was reorganized as Ameritech. ''I was Miss Ameritech to the world,'' said Mrs. Fairley, who lives in Clark Lake, Mich. But in December 1997, several months before SBC Communications acquired the company, she was laid off as part of a general downsizing. She had just turned 50.

headline: REGULATORY AGENCY PROPOSES $6 MILLION FINE FOR SBC
summary: The Federal Communications Commission proposed fining SBC Communications Inc. $6 million yesterday, accusing it of failing to offer rivals fair terms for access to part of its network in five states. The fine is the largest ever proposed by the agency. In approving SBC's 1999 purchase of the Ameritech Corporation, the F.C.C. required the telephone carrier to offer competitors terms similar to those offered in Texas when transporting certain local toll traffic to SBC central offices. The commission found that SBC appeared to have violated that condition in each of the five former Ameritech states: Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin, the F.C.C. said. SBC denied wrongdoing.

headline: Verizon Is Told to Cut Access Rates
summary: The New York State Public Service Commission voted yesterday to require Verizon Communications, the state's main local phone carrier, to lower the prices it charges to competitors that use its network. The decision is expected to bolster efforts to increase competition among local phone companies.

headline: Fair Local Phone Rates
summary: The New York Public Service Commission helped jump-start competition for local phone service yesterday when it ordered Verizon to further discount the wholesale rate at which it leases its lines to competing companies trying to enter the New York market. The move is not only beneficial to state consumers; it could be of vital importance to the nation's overall economy. In recent years, healthy competition has revolutionized the market for many telecommunications products, from long distance to cellphone services. Local service, however, remains a near-monopoly, firmly in the hands of the Baby Bells, including Verizon, that were created by the breakup of AT&T in 1984 and control the ''last mile'' of wire into consumers' homes and offices. Nationwide, competitors to the Baby Bells provide local service to less than 10 percent of all phone lines, and only 5 percent of all residential lines.

headline: Profit at SBC Declined 4% in 4th Quarter
summary: SBC Communications said fourth-quarter profit fell nearly 4 percent on lower sales and the cost of eliminating 5,000 jobs. Profit declined to $1.25 billion, or 37 cents a share, from $1.3 billion, or 38 cents, a year earlier. Sales slipped 2.5 percent, to $11.9 billion.

headline: Corrections
summary: A report in the Company News column of Business Day last Saturday about a $6 million fine proposed by the Federal Communications Commission against the SBC Corporation, over rivals' access to part of its network in five states, carried an erroneous credit. It was by Reuters, not Bloomberg News.

headline: 5 Years and $15 Billion Later, A Fiber Optic Venture Fails
summary: Global Crossing Ltd., which spent five years and $15 billion to build a worldwide network of high-speed Internet and telephone lines, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, unable to find enough customers to make its network profitable. The company had attracted many notable business and political figures as investors, including Terry McAuliffe, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, who profited by selling Global Crossing stock before it declined.

headline: Earnings Data For Quarter Is Delayed By Williams
summary: The Williams Companies said yesterday that it was delaying the release of its fourth-quarter results to complete an assessment of the financial health of the Williams Communications Group, the telecommunications company Williams spun off as an independent business in April. At issue is a total of about $2.2 billion of Williams Communications debt and fiber optic leases for which Williams may be responsible.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Messaging Company Names A Chief
summary: Odigo, a New York-based provider of instant-messaging services, said it had named Howard Woolf as its new president and chief executive. Mr. Woolf was formerly president for the Americas at Intel Dialogic, a software and telecommunications services company. ''Howard is exactly the right leader for Odigo,'' Lewis Pell, Odigo's chairman, said in a statement. Founded in 1998, Odigo has licensed its software to customers like NEC, British Telecommunications and Prodigy/SBC. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 2 Big Names Said to Drop Idea of Bidding For WorldCom
summary: Verizon and SBC Communications, the two biggest local telephone companies, each considered bidding to acquire WorldCom Inc. in recent months but backed out amid concerns that WorldCom's core long-distance businesses face continued difficulties, people close to Verizon and SBC said yesterday. Verizon and SBC may have also been scared by WorldCom's accounting practices, according to some telecommunications executives. Some investors and analysts have worried that WorldCom has used aggressive accounting techniques in the past, particularly in reporting revenue.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Powell Says Nuclear Pact With Russia Is On Track Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said the United States expected to meet Russia's demand for a ''legally binding'' deal on reducing nuclear warheads. A1 Military Aid Plan for Colombia The Bush administration is proposing to expand military aid to Colombia by training the Colombian Army to protect a 500-mile-long oil pipeline from leftist rebels, senior American officials visiting Colombia said. A6

headline: Long-Distance Market
summary: To the Editor: Your Jan. 24 editorial ''Fair Local Phone Rates'' overstated the significance of the decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia regarding SBC Communications' entry into the Kansas and Oklahoma long-distance markets.

headline: Are Investors Too Worried About Cable?
summary: THERE are times when investors grow so worried about what might go wrong that they overestimate the chance that disaster will happen. Eleven years ago, during the last recession, investor fears crystalized around banks. After a wave of bank failures, it was clear that many banks had abused accounting rules to make themselves look healthier than they were. Many banks traded as if failure was a real possibility. Some did fail, but most did not. It was a great time to buy a portfolio of bank stocks.

headline: A Spinoff Of Williams May Seek Bankruptcy
summary: The Williams Communications Group, the troubled provider of broadband network services, said yesterday that it was looking to restructure its debt obligations and that it might seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from its creditors. Several weeks ago, Williams said that it was not considering filing for Chapter 11. But the announcement yesterday did not surprise analysts or investors.

headline: Stuffing the Pillowcase With Soft Money
summary: Congressional leaders, including some who denounce unlimited contributions from big corporations to political parties, have been raising this so-called soft money as if it were going out of style, according to a report by the liberal interest group Public Citizen. As it may well be. If the campaign finance legislation passed by the House 10 days ago is enacted, this sort of fund-raising will be against the law.

headline: Technology; Congressional Broadband Fight Intensifies
summary: Two weeks after the House of Representatives approved legislation to limit the influence of money in politics, the House is expected to approve a telecommunications bill that is largely shaped by the huge campaign contributions it has generated. The measure, a bill to deregulate the high-speed Internet market, has become known informally on Capitol Hill as the big bucks bill of the year, although it has little chance of becoming law any time soon. As a result, experts predict it will continue to be lucrative for lawmakers for years to come, encouraging the telecommunications industry to find ways to make tens of millions of dollars in contributions long after Congress completes its work on the campaign finance legislation. Senate leaders say the bill, to be taken up by the House on Wednesday, has virtually no hope of approval by the Senate this year.

headline: Broadband Bill Advances, but Its Survival Is Doubtful
summary: The House overwhelmingly approved a measure today to unshackle the nation's largest telephone companies from regulations that impede their expansion into the high-speed Internet market. While the broadband legislation, which was approved 273 to 157, has little prospect of surviving in the Senate, supporters of deregulation still have a strong chance of achieving many of their goals. The Federal Communications Commission has recently begun proceedings that are widely expected to conclude in the next few months with the removal of many impediments to the expansion of broadband services by the nation's four regional Bell operating companies.

headline: Creditors Resist Asian Bid for Global Crossing
summary: Creditors of Global Crossing are strongly resisting an offer by two Asian companies to acquire the bankrupt company's assets after reports of a competing bid emerged over the weekend, people close to the company said yesterday. The creditors, which have strong influence over Global Crossing's future after it filed for bankruptcy protection in late January, have told the Asian companies, Hutchison Whampoa of Hong Kong and Singapore Technologies Telemedia, that their $750 million offer was unacceptable, these people said.

headline: New Economy; The Web world watches closely as British Telecommunications stakes a patent claim on a now-ubiquitous function: hyperlinking.
summary: THE software industry has long been a staging ground for huge battles over intellectual property, starting perhaps 15 years ago when Apple Computer accused Microsoft of stealing the look and feel of the Macintosh. Today, the industry is awaiting an early-stage decision in the case of British Telcommunications v. Prodigy, another closely watched patent fight that, as have many before it, challenges a ubiquitous computing operation. At a preliminary hearing in a federal court in Westchester County, N.Y., last month, British Telecommunications, a subsidiary of the BT Group, asserted that it owned a patent on what is now known as hyperlinking, the process of linking Web pages so users can move from one page to another by simply clicking on highlighted text. Hyperlinking, a function about as basic to the Web as ramps are to a highway, is used by nearly every Web page, so that virtually no browsing can take place without it. According to British Telecom's arguments, without the technology that the company says is covered in its patent, now nearly 13 years old, computer users would have to know the address of a page before they could jump to it.

headline: Cisco and Sprint Venture Has First Big Client
summary: As it tries to regain the torrid pace that briefly made it the world's most valuable company, Cisco Systems is counting heavily on winning new customers among telecommunications providers, one of the sectors hardest hit by the slowed economy. Cisco's routers and switches sit at the heart of many corporate networks, but the company has found trouble replicating that success when it comes to the huge voice and data networks run by the Baby Bells. Lucent Technologies and Nortel Networks, though struggling themselves, dominate that market.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Ruling In Hyperlink Case
summary: After a hearing last month, a federal judge has issued an opinion in a patent suit by British Telecommunications, a subsidiary of the BT Group, against Prodigy, the online service now owned by SBC Communications, inching the case closer to trial in September. In the suit, British Telecommunications says a patent it was granted in 1989 covers hypertext linking on the Internet. In her initial ruling, Judge Colleen McMahon of Federal District Court in Manhattan effectively limited the arguments British Telecommunications can make on the basis of the patent, based largely on the fact that it was issued before the development of the Internet. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

headline: Nordic Telephone Companies Are Reconsidering a Merger
summary: Nordic phone companies are talking mergers again, with Sonera of Finland and Telia of Sweden confirming that they are back at the bargaining table. Discussions between the two have gone nowhere before, and the region is littered with failed attempts at combinations. Still, some analysts say the long odds that Sonera and Telia will reach an agreement have shrunk somewhat since summer, when the two companies last held formal negotiations.

headline: Market Place; Will Ma Bell Be Taken Over By Offspring?
summary: Will AT&T stand alone as a telecommunications company? Many industry executives say they believe that by the middle of next year, a big local phone company like SBC Communications or BellSouth will try to acquire what remains of AT&T.

headline: Metromedia Fiber Slides Toward a Bankruptcy Filing
summary: Metromedia Fiber Network, a major provider of optical fiber communications networks in and around large cities, replaced its top executives yesterday and said that it had violated several loan agreements, moving to the brink of bankruptcy. The company missed an $8.1 million interest payment Friday on $231 million in notes issued to Nortel Networks. The missed payment automatically put it into default not just on the Nortel notes but on more than $440 million in notes and other loans from major creditors and banks.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: An Andersen Accountant Is Expected to Plead Guilty David Duncan, left, the Arthur Andersen accountant whose destruction of records related to Enron led to a criminal indictment of his firm, has agreed to plead guilty to obstruction of justice and serve as a government witness, people involved in the case said. The plea, to a single felony charge, is scheduled to be entered today in Federal District Court in Houston. Mr. Duncan, who until now has maintained his innocence, will plead to what is known as a criminal information, which will describe the offense. The terms of his cooperation agreement will be entered with the court at that time. [Page A1.]

headline: Microsoft Tries to Discredit Antitrust Testimony From SBC
summary: The Microsoft Corporation suggested in court today that SBC Communications was seeking tough antitrust restrictions against it to cripple its ability to compete in the telecommunications market. SBC, the second-largest local telephone company in the United States, was the latest target of Microsoft's strategy of questioning the motives of executives who testify in support of the nine states that are seeking tighter controls on Microsoft's activities.

headline: Yahoo Gains in Revenue, Aided by Online Dating Service
summary: A series of hot dates has spiced up the otherwise bleak business at Yahoo. While advertising revenue continues to decline for Yahoo, the big Internet portal, fee income, especially from its rapidly growing online personals service, is making up the difference.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; AT&T, Hardly a Penny Stock, Plans 1-for-5 Reverse Stock Split
summary: Is it conceivable that shares of AT&T, one of the world's signature corporations, might trade for less than $5? Not to AT&T's board apparently. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, AT&T said it planned to ask shareholders to approve a 1-for-5 reverse stock split. The move would have no substantive effect on AT&T's operations or finances. Instead, it is being proposed for its supposed psychological effect on investors, according to people close to AT&T.

headline: Shares Drop Sharply on General Electric's Profit Decline
summary: Stocks tumbled yesterday after profit at General Electric dropped for the first time in more than seven years and a newsletter said that the Securities and Exchange Commission was questioning I.B.M. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Dow Jones industrial average had their biggest declines since Feb. 4, with stocks losing $265.9 billion of value.

headline: Recent Good News for WorldCom May Only Mask Deeper Problems
summary: Things have been looking a bit brighter for WorldCom Inc. in recent weeks. The company won a major contract from the Pentagon. A federal judge in Mississippi dismissed claims that WorldCom defrauded investors. Even the company's announcement that it needed to cut costs by laying off 3,700 employees, or 4 percent of its work force, was not as drastic as analysts had predicted. Yet investors have continued to flee from WorldCom, the nation's second-largest long-distance phone company and one of the most troubled giants in the hard-hit telecommunications sector. Last week, it briefly joined equipment makers like Lucent and Nortel Networks, whose shares traded in the realm of so-called penny stocks, below $5, before rallying to close on Friday at $5.01.

headline: SBC AND ECHOSTAR AGREE TO SELL EACH OTHER'S SERVICES
summary: SBC Communications, which sells local telephone service in the Midwest and the West, and EchoStar Communications, the cable TV provider, have agreed to sell each other's services to compete with cable TV. Financial terms were not disclosed. SBC, which is based in San Antonio, will sell EchoStar's Dish network in its 13-state region starting in May, said a spokesman, Jason Hillery. EchoStar, based in Littleton, Colo., will sell SBC's high-speed Internet access.

headline: After a disappointing year, an advertising executive tells his colleagues to mend their ways.
summary: A FRANK and provocative call to arms by the chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies caused a stir here yesterday at the opening general session of the organization's 2002 Management Conference. The conference is being held as Madison Avenue struggles to recover from what O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the association, described in his opening remarks as a ''crummy year, a year a lot of us would like to forget.''

headline: Phone Companies' Woes Raise Wider Fears for Investors
summary: Stocks fell yesterday as WorldCom and Ericsson reduced their forecasts for sales and suggested that the slump for telephone and computer-related businesses might stunt a broader profit rebound. ''The few bad apples are enough to spoil the whole market,'' said Dave Briggs, head of trading at Federated Investors in Pittsburgh. He added that earnings in the first quarter had not been strong enough to convince investors that the recovery would be quick.

headline: Chief Quits at Phone Giant In Canada, and Stock Soars
summary: Jean C. Monty resigned today as chairman and chief executive of BCE, Canada's dominant telecommunications company, after telling investors at a conference here that the company was backing away from its beleaguered Teleglobe unit. Mr. Monty, 54, said BCE would sharply limit its financial support for Teleglobe and would write down the value of its investment in it by about 8 billion Canadian dollars ($5.1 billion) in the second quarter. Teleglobe, based in Reston, Va., operates a worldwide voice and data network.

headline: A Silent Drain on Time: Children's Sports
summary: MY son broke his ankle a few weeks ago, while bouncing on a neighbor's trampoline. He is now hobbling on crutches, his foot encased in a bright blue fiberglass cast. Evan's broken ankle has changed the rhythm of our family. I drive him to school every morning now, which means we all wake up earlier and race around more frantically. He can't carry anything, and stairs are a problem, which means his brother is doing a lot of carrying and fetching.

headline: Losses Persist As BlackBerry Gains Rival
summary: James Balsillie, co-chief executive of Research in Motion, likes to compare the company to a country house whose owners wake up one morning and discover they have a spectacular view of the ocean. ''We were as surprised as anyone to have a beachfront property,'' Mr. Balsillie said.

headline: Telecommunications Issues Fall Sharply
summary: Investors in the troubled telecommunications sector stepped up their pace to the exits yesterday. The hardest hit were Qwest Communications International and WorldCom, two concerns with heavy debt loads and enough questions about their accounting to be the subjects of investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission. But companies like Verizon Communications, SBC Communications and BellSouth, which had fared well by comparison this year, also sagged under the selling pressure yesterday.

headline: WORLDCOM LEADER DEPARTS COMPANY IN TURBULENT TIME
summary: Bernard J. Ebbers, who spent 19 years building WorldCom into one of the biggest long-distance companies and Internet carriers in the world, has resigned as chief executive, president and director, the company said yesterday. If any executive represented the entrepreneurial epoch that was supposed to make telecommunications cheaper and the choices abundant in an era of deregulation, it was Mr. Ebbers. It was he who exploited the deregulation of the telecommunications industry more than anyone else during the last two decades. With ruthless cost-cutting and fervent deal-making, he showed for years that it was possible to undercut AT&T in the long-distance market and still make a lot of money.

headline: As WorldCom Struggles for Stability, Its MCI Phone Unit Underwhelms Wall St.
summary: As the new president and chief executive of WorldCom, John W. Sidgmore, tries to restore Wall Street's faith in the company, one big question involves the future of MCI, WorldCom's most visible link to the typical phone user. With 20 million customers, 28,000 employees and revenue last year of $13.83 billion, MCI is the nation's second-largest long-distance phone company, after AT&T, and a leading provider of the networks that Internet service companies need to connect consumers and small businesses.

headline: Investing; Where Telecom Bargain Hunters Turn
summary: IT has been two months since Ivan G. Seidenberg, the chief executive of Verizon Communications, mused at an investment conference that his company might bid for WorldCom ''for the fun of it'' if the stock price of that long-distance and Internet carrier continued falling. Since then, WorldCom's shares have dropped 80 percent, to $1.58 on Friday. But as Mr. Seidenberg wryly suggested, conditions in the communications sector are so tough that Verizon has no real interest in WorldCom at any price. Verizon, along with rivals like SBC Communications, BellSouth and Deutsche Telekom, all have plenty of their own problems without taking on WorldCom's, which include gigantic debt and an accounting investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Phone Start-Ups Win the Latest Round in Court
summary: The Supreme Court handed a huge victory to start-up telephone companies today by broadly affirming rules that permit them to lease equipment from the largest phone companies at relatively low costs. The pricing regulations are meant to let rivals viably compete with the entrenched local phone companies by leasing access to their networks rather than having to build expensive duplicate systems. Although local telephone competition has been slow to catch on for a variety of reasons, rivals have blamed the intransigence of the dominant local companies.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC To Cut 5,000 Jobs
summary: The big local telephone company SBC Communications Inc. will eliminate 5,000 jobs, or 2.6 percent of its work force, this quarter. Jobs will be cut in 13 states and include management and nonmanagement employees who do not directly serve customers, SBC said. The company pared 4,000 jobs in the first quarter and said last month that it would cut 4,000 more this year.

headline: U.S. Appeals Court Order Is Victory for Regional Bells
summary: A federal appeals court ordered regulators to reconsider two important rules today intended to spur competition in the local phone and high-speed Internet markets. The decision was a victory for the regional Bell companies and a setback to their competitors that rely on leasing equipment to challenge the incumbents. The court vacated one rule known as line-sharing that permits smaller rivals to lease space on the lines of the regional Bells to provide high-speed Internet service. The other rule, which was sent back for reconsideration, requires the incumbents to lease to competitors at discounted prices a variety of separate, or unbundled, elements of the phone network.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexican Cellphone Concern Expands
summary: The Mexican mobile telecommunications operator América Móvil S.A. agreed to more than double its stake in Telecom Americas Ltd., a leading cellular phone provider in Brazil. América Móvil, Latin America's largest mobile phone service provider, will buy a 39 percent stake in the company from Bell Canada International for $146 million in cash and a $220 million interest-free note, Bell Canada said. América Móvil will also exercise an option to buy SBC Communications Inc.'s 11 percent interest in Telecom Americas, increasing its stake to 93 percent from 42 percent.

headline: Heads I Win, Tails I Win
summary: Every year, in an annual rite of spring, SBC Communications discloses the principles that it follows in setting pay for its top executives. As with all companies, this information is contained in the annual proxy statement, and as is also common, SBC purports to follow some basic credos of American business.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: BCE Forecasts Lower Cash Flow
summary: BCE Inc., Canada's largest telephone company, said reductions in the fees it can charge rivals for network access would reduce annual cash flow at its Bell Canada unit by 250 million Canadian dollars ($162 million). BCE owns 80 percent of Bell Canada, and SBC Communications Inc. of San Antonio, Tex., owns the rest. On May 30, Canadian regulators lowered the fees that former phone monopolies like BCE may levy by 15 percent to 20 percent to help increase competition.

headline: For Qwest's New Chief, A Question of Longevity
summary: Is Richard C. Notebaert the right man for the job at Qwest Communications International? And just what is that job, anyway? In tapping Mr. Notebaert to succeed Joseph P. Nacchio as chief executive on Sunday, Qwest chose a longtime telecommunications executive best noted for two achievements. First, from 1994 through 1998 Mr. Notebaert delivered five consecutive years of double-digit earnings growth at Ameritech, the regional Bell company based in Chicago. Then, in 1999, he negotiated the sale of Ameritech to SBC Communications in a $72 billion deal that created the nation's largest local phone company.

headline: Telecommunications Outlook: First the Bad News, Then the Bad News
summary: The turmoil continues in telecommunications, making the long-awaited turnaround increasingly difficult to call. Indeed, in light of a wave of bad news last week and through the weekend, some analysts say the industry's problems could actually become worse before they become better. News over the weekend that Joseph P. Nacchio was leaving the beleaguered telecommunications company Qwest Communications International and that the fiber optic carrier XO Communications would file for bankruptcy protection came in the wake of more bad news from two more established players. Lucent Technologies, the large maker of communications equipment, said last week that its sales would decline much more than expected, about 15 percent this quarter, as its main corporate customers reduce spending. Sprint, meanwhile, had its debt rating lowered to a notch above junk status as it said it would sign up fewer wireless customers.

headline: Microsoft and Verizon in D.S.L. Deal
summary: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it would begin using Microsoft's content, software and marketing support for its high- speed D.S.L. Internet service and would pay Microsoft a portion of the revenue. As for Microsoft, it said yesterday that it now offered a D.S.L. version of its MSN online service in 70 markets nationwide, representing 90 percent of the households that can get D.S.L. service. Until yesterday, MSN was available in only 33 markets, primarily in the Western states served by the local phone unit of Qwest Communications. Now, MSN is buying wholesale D.S.L. access from BellSouth, SBC Communications and Verizon and reselling them with MSN content and software.

headline: No Records Found to Back WorldCom's Shift of Billions
summary: Investigators looking into the WorldCom scandal have found no records to support decisions to shift billions of dollars in expenses on the company's books, people close to the company said yesterday -- a fact that increases the likelihood that the transactions involved criminal fraud. Instead, investigators have found that the sums involved -- which reduced reported operating expenses over the last five quarters -- were exactly those needed for WorldCom to meet its profit margin goals, these people said.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bell Canada Stake Bought
summary: BCE Inc., the Canadian telecommunications and media group, said it would regain full ownership of Bell Canada, the country's dominant telephone company, by buying back a 20 percent stake from SBC Communications for 6.32 billion Canadian dollars ($4.2 billion), in promissory notes, cash and stock. Michael Sabia, above, who took over as BCE's chief executive less than three months ago, said that regaining full ownership of Bell Canada would help BCE ''diminish uncertainty and focus our operations.'' In recent years, the company has diversified into media ownership, e-commerce and other internet services.
