SBC, which is based in San Antonio, acquired the stake when it bought the Ameritech Corporation. Bernard Simon (NYT)

headline: Trying to Catch WorldCom's Mirage
summary: ON Dec. 6, 1999, AT&T replaced the chief of its huge business services division, Michael G. Keith, after barely nine months on the job. To the outside world, it appeared that C. Michael Armstrong, the company's chairman and chief executive, had moved Mr. Keith to the company's wireless unit simply because he was not getting the job done. Now some people close to AT&T say Mr. Keith was actually transferred mostly because his division could not match the reported profit margins of its biggest competitor, WorldCom.

headline: More Battles Are Expected Over Vivendi
summary: The Bronfman family, overruled by the Vivendi Universal board last week in its call for the resignation of the chairman, Jean-Marie Messier, has its lawyers looking for a loophole that would allow it to try again to oust Mr. Messier, according to a person close to the discussions. The Bronfmans, who became the largest shareholders in Vivendi Universal and acquired three seats on the board by selling the Seagram Company and its Universal media properties for $34 billion in Vivendi stock in 2000, have seen their fortune dwindle with each downward tick of the company's shares. Vivendi's stock, which trades in Paris and as American depository receipts in New York, has fallen 60 percent in the United States so far this year.

headline: Cingular Wireless arrives late in New York, but comes bearing orange umbrellas and M&M's.
summary: CINGULAR WIRELESS is hoping that its risky and expensive effort to break into the crowded New York market will be received more like the return of the Dodgers to Brooklyn than the resumption of alternate-side-of-the-street parking after a holiday weekend. Cingular, the nation's second-largest provider of wireless telephone services, plans to spend about $20 million on the extensive effort. The campaign, which begins this week with elements that include print advertisements, commercials, a dedicated Web site, promotions and retail marketing, is tailored to the tastes and ''all right, already'' tone of New Yorkers.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Names Finance Officer
summary: Qwest Communications International, the telephone company whose shares were down 87 percent this year, said it had hired Oren G. Shaffer as chief financial officer to increase investor confidence. Mr. Shaffer, 59, worked for Qwest's new chief executive, Richard C. Notebaert, at the Ameritech Corporation, a local phone company bought by SBC Communications. Mr. Shaffer will also be vice chairman at Qwest, which is based in Denver and is the biggest local-phone-service operator in 14 Western states. He replaces Robin R. Szeliga, who will stay at Qwest and focus on reducing its $26.4 billion in debt. Last month, Joseph P. Nacchio stepped down as Qwest's chief executive after its shares plunged amid a Securities and Exchange Commission accounting inquiry and doubt about the company's ability to repay its debt.

headline: Seeking to Calm Investors, Vivendi Says It Is Near a Deal for New Credit
summary: Seeking to soothe investors who have become increasingly alarmed by the company's dwindling levels of cash, Vivendi Universal said today that it was close to reaching an agreement with its banks to secure fresh loans. Vivendi is putting the finishing touches on an agreement for a one billion euro line of credit ($988 million), and an announcement is expected this week, a person close to the discussions said. Although the credit line will not solve Vivendi's cash problems, it will provide some breathing room until a longer-term solution can be reached, the person said.

headline: Move to Oust Chief Seen at Phone Giant
summary: Whatever may happen next to Ron Sommer, the embattled chief executive of the German telephone giant Deutsche Telekom, few analysts expect him to willingly part company with VoiceStream Wireless, the American cellular company whose $24 billion acquisition Mr. Sommer oversaw last year. But Mr. Sommer may soon no longer be calling the shots at Deutsche Telekom. The company said yesterday that it would hold a special board meeting next Tuesday, when analysts expect his fate to be decided.

headline: Proposed Successor at Deutsche Telekom Chills Market
summary: The German government's trouble-prone campaign to oust Ron Sommer as the chief executive of Deutsche Telekom hit a new snag today as investors reacted harshly to his proposed replacement. Shares of Deutsche Telekom fell more than 15 percent after reports here that a longtime company executive, Gerd Tenzer, would be presented to Deutsche Telekom's supervisory board at a special meeting on Tuesday.

headline: Taking Hold Of the Wheel
summary: At one point yesterday afternoon, George W. Bush was beginning to look like the president with perhaps the worst market touch since Herbert Hoover. Every time he tried to sound reassuring, a few hundred points vanished from the Dow Jones industrial average. ''This economy is coming back,'' Mr. Bush said in Alabama, assigning the blame for Wall Street's current problems in no small part to the ''economic binge'' of the late 1990's, when someone else was president. ''That is the fact.''

headline: ON THE GROUND: In Detroit; Shaking Off the Rust of the Urban Core
summary: Detroit has made great strides in shaking off the effects of Rust Belt neglect that had left much of the downtown abandoned. In recent years, new sports and cultural facilities have opened and big business has rediscovered the urban core. By the end of the year, the computer software maker Compuware plans to begin moving 3,000 employees from an outlying suburb to new headquarters in the central business district, while General Motors expects to finish relocating 10,000 employees to the landmark Renaissance Center by next year.

headline: Bankruptcy's Taut Wiring
summary: The crisis in the telecommunications industry just became worse. Even though WorldCom's bankruptcy filing had been expected for weeks, its reality has created a cascade of problems in the interdependent industry of local and long-distance phone carriers, as well as their equipment suppliers. The two-year slump in telecommunications has been a major factor behind the limping economy and the falling stock market, with telecommunications stocks having lost about $2 trillion of value in the last two years. So, continued turmoil for the industry could have broader negative repercussions.

headline: Compressed Data; How One Telecom Thrives Amid Slowdown
summary: One could ask how the Harris Corporation, a 107-year-old company that once made industrial printing equipment, beat out WorldCom to win a prime Federal Aviation Administration communications equipment contract. But it might be more to the point to ask how a company is turning a profit these days in a business as beleaguered as telecommunications. While nearly every other telecommunications company is struggling to keep its head up, Harris' stock is trading up at $34.75, from a low of $26.50 a year ago.

headline: Regional Bell Giants No Longer Invulnerable
summary: Shortly after BellSouth, the nation's No. 3 local phone company, sent its stock plunging yesterday by saying it would fail to meet its financial targets for 2002, one analyst released a report titled, ''It's Official -- There Is No Place to Hide.'' In some ways, the pronouncement was as startling as it was apt. Just 18 months ago, the nation's big local phone service providers, led by the huge regional Bell companies, seemed poised to emerge from the telecommunications industry's troubles in a position of strength. While the long-distance carriers pummeled one another in savage price battles, and start-up local carriers withered, the Bell companies could sit back with their near-monopolies and reap growth, profits and the adulation of investors.

headline: MARKETS CONTINUE DOWNWARD TREND; BANKS LEAD WAY
summary: Stocks fell again yesterday as concerns grew about the fate of telecommunications and energy trading companies and as Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill traveled to Wall Street to discuss the markets and economy with senior brokerage executives. On a day when news from Washington dominated the market, banks and energy stocks were hurt by the latest revelations regarding the Enron investigation, with officials of Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase defending their banks at a Senate hearing against accusations they had helped Enron cover up the extent of its debt. Those two stocks accounted for most of the 1.1 percent decline in the Dow Jones industrial average. [Page C1.]

headline: Phone Giant In Canada Writing Off $5.7 Billion
summary: BCE Inc., Canada's biggest telephone and media group, today announced write-downs of close to 9 billion Canadian dollars ($5.68 billion), yet another reflection of the costs of a big diversification drive in the late 1990's. Still, the company managed to eke out net earnings of 11 million Canadian dollars ($6.9 million), or one Canadian penny a share, in the second quarter. Net earnings a year earlier were 6 million Canadian dollars, also one cent a share.

headline: Can AOL Keep Its Subscribers In a New World Of Broadband?
summary: Is America Online's subscriber base about to peak? For its owner, AOL Time Warner, most of the concern last week that drove its stock below $9 a share for a day revolved around the precipitous decline in the company's online advertising, and a government inquiry into the accounting for some of those ads.

headline: Making Your Own Luck
summary: IN the 1950's, there was still a fair amount of industry in northwest London, where I grew up. My brother and I loved to stand in the back of our house and watch steam engines transporting coal to a power station in the distance. We even had names for them. Years later, when the Thomas the Tank Engine toys came out, they really resonated with me. I worked in a butcher shop when I was a teenager and learned the finer arts of dressing meat. One of the benefits was being able to take things home, like pigs' feet -- pigs' trotters, in England -- to scare my younger brother. I'd put one up my sleeve and tried to shake hands with him. At school, when we were covering dissection, I showed up with sheep's eyeballs.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: BCE Sells New Shares
summary: The Canadian communications group BCE said it had signed an agreement with an underwriting group to raise 2 billion Canadian dollars ($1.3 billion) through a public stock offering. The proceeds will be used mainly to finance BCE's proposed purchase of the 20 percent of the Bell Canada phone company that it does not already own from SBC Communications. Bernard Simon (NYT)

headline: Quarterly Loss at Qwest Is $1.14 Billion
summary: The heavily indebted Qwest Communications International said yesterday that it had met its goal of generating more cash than it spent in the second quarter. Qwest also said it was negotiating new loans and a relaxation of the terms of some existing loans. Investors rewarded Qwest's efforts to gain financial breathing room by sending the shares up as much as 19 cents in early trading yesterday. But they subsided and closed unchanged, at $1.20, on doubts that the quarterly earnings report might have been a case of too little too late.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cingular Widens Rollover Plan
summary: Cingular Wireless, the nation's second-largest provider of wireless telephone services, said yesterday that it would create a nationwide plan that allows customers to keep their unused monthly minutes. Customers who have not used their minutes in one month will have them rolled over into the next month for up to a year, said Cingular, a joint venture of BellSouth and SBC Communications. The offer is available for customers who select a Cingular plan costing $39.99 a month or more. A spokeswoman said that more than 50 percent of Cingular customers would be eligible to roll over their minutes. The plans will also include nationwide long distance at no extra cost. ''Rollover lets customers keep what they're paying for,'' said Virginia Vann, Cingular's chief marketing officer, in a statement. ''These plans bring a new value proposition to wireless customers. If they don't use their package minutes, they don't lose their package minutes.'' Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline: Qwest to Sell Yellow Pages For $7 Billion
summary: Qwest Communications International, the debt-laden telephone company, agreed last night to sell its yellow pages directories business to a group of financiers for $7 billion in a move that would help it avert a bankruptcy filing. Under the agreement, Qwest, the dominant provider of local phone service in 14 Western states, will sell its yellow pages unit to the politically influential Carlyle Group and Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe, executives close to the auction said. The deal would be the largest leveraged buyout since Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company's hostile takeover of RJR Nabisco in 1989.

headline: How to Make Yourself Reachable in 5 Places at Once
summary: IN the quest to be always within reach, many people have resorted to carrying a cellphone at all times. But a cellphone isn't a perfect solution: for one thing, unless people know to call you on it, they may miss you by calling a land-line number instead. Even eliminating the land line at home won't necessarily help; callers may still miss you by dialing only your office phone. But there are other ways to ensure that you are never out of touch no matter what phones you use. A variety of services are available that make it easy for callers to find you. These services can be particularly useful for families in which one member travels a lot, the children are away at school or elderly relatives need to stay in touch.

headline: Bubble Beneficiaries
summary: Telecommunications executives made billions of dollars selling company stock over the last three and a half years, often shortly before their profit predictions were proved wrong and the stock price dropped. Many benefited by creating business plans that raised investors' expectations to unrealistic levels and then selling shares before reality set in. Here are many of the insiders, and in some cases their relatives, who made the most. Some of the people on this list are no longer with the companies whose stock they sold. headline: Weak Spell for Shares Reaches the Five-Month Mark
summary: The stock market finished August on a sour note yesterday, leaving investors facing the same doubts that have plagued them for months. Is the economy heading for another recession or bouncing back from a short downdraft? And are corporate earnings finally about to recover?

headline: Executive Life; Squeezing Yourself Out (for the Company)
summary: HALFWAY into it, Hugh C. Martin realized that the merger he had initiated to protect his fiber optic company would cost him his job. Mr. Martin had joined the company, ONI Systems of San Jose, Calif., as chief executive in 1998, shortly after it was started. By 2000, ONI, a maker of equipment for routing phone calls and computer data, had become one of the fastest-growing companies in Silicon Valley.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: AOL To Use Covad High-Speed Network
summary: Covad Communications said yesterday that AOL Time Warner would use Covad's network to provide high-speed Web connections to America Online customers. The five-year agreement gives AOL Time Warner, based in New York, access to a network covering 40 million homes and businesses in the United States, Covad said in a statement. Shares of Covad, which emerged from bankruptcy in December, rose as much as 29 percent, before ending the day at $1.32, up 18 cents, or 15.8 percent. As the number of new consumers using dial-up Internet access slows, AOL Time Warner is trying to add customers through agreements with companies like Verizon Communications and SBC Communications, which have regional high-speed networks. Covad sells high-speed links to the Internet through digital subscriber lines. AOL Time Warner will pay Covad an undisclosed amount a month for each subscriber. A Covad spokeswoman, Martha Sessums, declined to give the amount. An AOL Time Warner spokesman, Ed Adler, did not return phone calls seeking comment.

headline: New Economy; Problems within the telecommunications industry have stalled the consolidation of wireless companies.
summary: THE beleaguered wireless industry seems to be defying conventional logic these days. Just last week, for instance, millions of customers of VoiceStream Wireless, one of the nation's largest cellular carriers, received notice that their service was being renamed T-Mobile, as the company's parent, Deutsche Telekom, embarked on an effort to give its wireless properties in the United States and Europe a single brand.

headline: Flying as a Statement Of Defiance to Terror
summary: WE may count Tancred Agius as a no-show for tomorrow's stage-managed commemorations of the anniversary of last September's terrorist attacks. Mr. Agius, who sells advertising in the Yellow Pages to national clients, has bigger fish to fry. So does Bob Cullinan, a marketing consultant from San Rafael, Calif. The two business executives are among what I would guess will be a significant number of frequent business travelers who will be flying tomorrow on discretionary trips they could have made some other time. They're doing it to make a statement that no crazed religious terrorist is going to tell them what to do.

headline: The Board Of WorldCom Begins Search For Next Chief
summary: WorldCom's board decided yesterday to begin a formal search for a new chief executive as the company, hampered by investigations into its accounting, struggles to emerge relatively intact from the nation's largest bankruptcy filing. Among the candidates mentioned for the top job at WorldCom are Edward A. Mueller, a former chief executive at Ameritech, a unit of SBC Communications, and Ronald T. LeMay, a high-ranking executive at the Sprint Corporation, people involved in the search process said yesterday.

headline: Restrained End To Volatile Year In Stock Markets
summary: A subdued trading session produced only small moves in the stock market yesterday as a quiet day of remembrance ended an extraordinarily volatile year on Wall Street that reflected increased uncertainty in the wake of the terrorist attacks. The Dow Jones industrial average, up for much of the abbreviated session, slipped in the final hour and ended down 21.44 points, or 0.2 percent, to 8,581.17, leaving it off 10.7 percent since the World Trade Center and Pentagon were attacked. Other averages have suffered more, making 2002 appear likely to be the third consecutive losing year, something that last happened early in World War II.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Antitrust Penalty Upheld
summary: The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit has upheld a 2000 ruling that Southwestern Bell, a subsidiary of SBC Communications, had violated antitrust laws in the pay telephone market in Oklahoma. The court, based in Denver, found the phone giant liable for more than $25 million on Tuesday. Charlie Sullivan, who with 10 partners formed Coin Link, an independent pay phone operator that sued Southwestern, said: ''We know that Southwestern Bell was trying to monopolize the market. In reality, they still have such a great percentage.'' In 2000, an Oklahoma jury awarded the plaintiffs $7.4 million in damages. State antitrust law permits the damages to be tripled, bringing the total to more than $22 million, plus lawyers' fees. The award could eventually total $29 million to $30 million, including interest, Robert Edinger, a lawyer representing the plaintiffs, said. The judges said that Southwestern Bell froze out competition through long-term contracts with the owners of sites for pay phones. The contracts included stiff penalties for early termination. Southwestern also ''employed several other measures to freeze out competition,'' including failing to remove its pay phones when site owners requested removal, the judges wrote. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: BCE Sells Phone Directory Unit
summary: BCE, Canada's dominant communications group, said that it was selling 90 percent of its telephone directories unit for $567 million cash plus the assumption of $1.3 billion in debt to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts of New York and the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan. The unit publishes more than 200 white pages and yellow pages directories in Ontario and Quebec. Money from the sale will be used to help finance BCE's proposed $3.9 billion purchase of the 20 percent stake in its Bell Canada telephone subsidiary presently held by SBC Communications of San Antonio. Bernard Simon (NYT)

headline: Lucent Plans To Eliminate More Positions
summary: Lucent Technologies, the nation's largest maker of communications equipment, warned yesterday that it would continue to eliminate jobs as sales plunge, an indication of worsening problems in the telecommunications industry. A Lucent spokeswoman declined to provide figures for the cuts and said the company would elaborate on its plans on Oct. 23, when it discusses quarterly financial results. Analysts expect the company, which is based in Murray Hill, N.J., to cut about 5,000 to 10,000 more jobs, leaving the work force at 33,000 to 38,000 employees, down from a peak of more than 123,000 two years ago.

headline: Still Very Much a Player, Scowcroft Straddles the Worlds of Business and Government
summary: Brent Scowcroft, the former national security official whose voice on Iraq policy has attracted considerable attention, plays so many different public and private advisory roles that even he has trouble keeping them straight. ''All of this sounds confusing,'' Mr. Scowcroft said in an interview at his consulting firm just a few blocks from the White House. ''In a way, it is. I do my best to keep all these things quite compartmentalized.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Hyundai Predicts Tripling Of Sales in U.S. by 2010 Hyundai Motor America intends to sell a million vehicles a year in the United States by the end of the decade, nearly triple its current pace. The push is a primary element in the company's quest to become one of the world's five largest automakers by 2010. By then, Hyundai Automotive Group, which includes Kia Motors, wants to sell five million vehicles a year worldwide, compared with fewer than 3 million in 2001. [Page C3.] DaimlerChrysler has taken a plunge into the Asian truck market, spending $1.14 billion to buy stakes in the truck operations of Hyundai Motor of South Korea and in the Fuso truck division of Mitsubishi Motors of Japan. [C3.]

headline: R.H. Donnelley To Purchase Yellow Pages From Sprint
summary: The Sprint Corporation agreed to sell its yellow pages directory business yesterday to R. H. Donnelley -- which published the first yellow pages directory in 1886 -- for $2.23 billion. The deal is expected to ease concern over a decline in revenue at Sprint's long-distance operations and weakening prospects at Sprint PCS, its large wireless subsidiary. Shares in Sprint have declined 44 percent the last month to $9.02.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Introduces Fee-Based Game Service
summary: Yahoo, owner of the most-used Internet search site, introduced a fee-based video-game service for customers yesterday, featuring high-speed Internet connections. Users of the Games on Demand service can download and play more than 40 titles, including Zapper, Civilization III and Star Trek Armada II. Prices start at $4.95 for the rental of one game for three days, and rise to $14.95 to rent 10 games for 30 days, Yahoo said. The games are being offered through Yahoo's high-speed Internet-access service with SBC Communications Inc. The companies agreed earlier this month to sell the service over SBC's phone lines in 13 states. Yahoo is working toward gaining more revenue through subscriptions and less through advertising, it has said.

headline: Vivendi Seen Refocusing On Telecom
summary: When the chairman of Vivendi Universal clarifies the company's strategy on Wednesday, he will propose focusing it in the direction of broadcasting and telecommunications, the chief executive of one of Vivendi Universal's biggest units said today. Since taking the reins of Vivendi Universal in July, the chairman, Jean-René Fourtou, has not publicly ruled out selling any of its parts. But the chief executive of Vivendi Environnement, Henri Proglio, said today that Mr. Fourtou intended to recommend to the parent company's board on Wednesday that it give ''more autonomy'' to Vivendi Environnement and gradually make Vivendi Universal a ''company dedicated to communication.''

headline: Vivendi Will Move Quickly to Sell Many Assets
summary: The chief executive of Vivendi Universal, Jean-René Fourtou, announced a shake-up of the troubled company's board today and said Vivendi would speed up sales of assets and focus on entertainment and telecommunications. Mr. Fourtou said the company also would seek to form a closer partnership with executives in the United States to aid management of its media assets, which include the Universal movie, television, music and theme park businesses.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: A German Stock Market To Be Dissolved in 2003 Deutsche Börse, which runs the Frankfurt stock exchange, announced that it would close the Neuer Markt -- the technology-related market that is Germany's answer to the Nasdaq -- by the end of 2003. In its place, Deutsche Börse plans to establish two new categories of shares. One category will have much more stringent standards of corporate disclosure than were required by the Neuer Markt. [World Business, Section W.] Plea Bargain Seen in Stewart Case Shares in Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia sank almost 8 percent after reports that prosecutors were close to reaching a plea agreement with Douglas Faneuil, a broker's assistant at Merrill Lynch. He is a central figure in the investigation of Ms. Stewart's sale of stock in ImClone Systems. As part of the agreement, experts said, he will probably testify against Ms. Stewart and others, including Peter E. Bacanovic, her stockbroker. [C6.]

headline: Ann Gnuse, Daniel Diederich
summary: Ann Kathryn Gnuse, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Thomas Gnuse of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Daniel Louis Diederich, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce H. Diederich of Pleasant Prairie, Wis. The Rev. Mich Zeman, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at Talmadge Hill Community Church in Darien, Conn. The couple work at Intuit, the financial software and services company in Mountain View, Calif. She is the general manager of a team of people that are working on a new software product. He leads a marketing team for the company's QuickBooks product.

headline: War of the Browsers Resumes With More Players This Autumn
summary: Are we heading into Browser War II? It has been several years since Microsoft and Netscape constantly added new features to their Web browser software, each hoping to win more users.

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Once a Sure Bet, Utilities Funds Now Pose More Risks
summary: INDIVIDUAL investors have been moving out of utility mutual funds, one of the worst-performing sectors recently. But some fund companies are joining the exodus, too. The Vanguard Group, the second-largest American mutual fund company, behind Fidelity Investments, announced plans last month to replace its utilities fund with one that focuses on dividend-paying companies from a wide range of industries. Shareholders will vote on the change, from the Vanguard Utilities Income fund to the Vanguard Dividend Growth fund, in early December.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: As Baby Bells Struggle, A Debate Over What to Do Investors, lawmakers, regulators and consumers are debating what should be done with, or for, the Baby Bells, the large local phone carriers that are struggling with their first decline in customers since the Depression. The erosion is fueling talk of whether the government should step in. At the heart of the debate is regulation that forces Verizon Communications, SBC Communications, BellSouth and Qwest to sell access on their networks to competitors at prices that can be determined by state regulators. Market Place. [Page C2.]

headline: Market Place; The Baby Bells shake the industry as they lose ground to local phone companies.
summary: WHAT should be done with, or for, the Bells? Investors, lawmakers, regulators and, increasingly, consumers, are engrossed with that question as the large local phone carriers known as the Baby Bells struggle with their first decline in customers since the Depression. The erosion is fueling talk of whether the government should step in to strengthen these companies to protect a vital public service.

headline: 2 Companies Seek to Delay Merger Ruling
summary: Scrambling to save their proposed merger from rejection by regulators, EchoStar Communications and Hughes Electronics urged the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to delay a decision on the $26 billion deal. The companies sent a letter to the F.C.C. chairman, Michael Powell, asking him to postpone the decision so that they could make ''major revisions'' to their proposal. The F.C.C. had been expected to reject the deal in the next few days.

headline: SBC SAYS IT IS LOSING BUSINESS TO PHONE RIVALS
summary: SBC Communications, the local-telephone service provider for the Midwest and the West, said yesterday that its profit per share would be at the low end of the range it previously forecast for this year as it loses customers to rivals. Full-year profit, before one-time costs, will be $2.26 a share, matching the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call, SBC said. The company said in July that its profit would be $2.26 to $2.35 a share, down from a previous estimate of as much as $2.51. SBC, which is based in San Antonio, said that it had lost about 4.2 million lines to competitors.

headline: Yahoo's Profits and Sales Are Better Than Expected
summary: Yahoo Inc. posted better-than-expected sales and profits yesterday as it gained market share in both advertising and job listings from its rivals. It also said it had renewed its contract with Google to provide results for searches of Web pages. Many people expected Yahoo to abandon Google, which has become one of the most popular sites, in part because of the credit it received on Yahoo's pages.

headline: Vodafone Moves to Acquire Control of Cegetel of France
summary: The Vodafone Group moved to tighten its grip on the European wireless market today, with an offer to buy the 85 percent of Cegetel, France's second-largest phone company, that it does not already own for 13 billion euros, or about $12.8 billion. Vodafone said it had agreed to pay 6.3 billion euros ($6.2 billion) in cash for the 26 percent held by the BT Group and the 15 percent owned by SBC Communications. The purchase of those shares would increase Vodafone's stake in Cegetel to 56 percent, enough to appoint directors and assume management control, Sir Christopher Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, said in an interview.

headline: A Tricky Maze for Consumers
summary: Businesses, responding to lawmakers and consumers, say they are giving customers more ways than ever to control how their personal information is used and sold. But, in fact, many companies all but frustrate their customers' attempts to exercise that control. Barbara Bechtold of Sacramento recounts the unending process of trying to keep companies from selling her e-mail address and the details of her credit card accounts, insurance policies and mortgage inquiries.

headline: Knicks Not Quite Ready To Welcome Back Sprewell
summary: Even as the Knicks' play this week brought smiles to the faces of Don Chaney and Scott Layden, the ugliness of the Latrell Sprewell controversy hovered over them, promising to push basketball to the periphery again. Since Oct. 7, when the Knicks said they fined Sprewell $250,000 and barred him from practices and games until he could make a ''positive contribution,'' the club has been expected to welcome him back Monday. That is when the Knicks will hold their first closed practice upon returning from their road trip.

headline: Vivendi Moves Up Deadline On Bids for Publishing Unit
summary: Vivendi Universal is rushing suitors of its publishing business, which includes Houghton Mifflin, to submit final bids by today, executives involved in the discussions said. Vivendi, which is trying to sell assets to cut its enormous debt, moved up the bidding deadline so that it could negotiate a higher bid, or possibly counter, an offer by the Vodafone Group for Vivendi's stake in Cegetel, the large French phone company.

headline: F.C.C. Chief Says Telecom Isn't Doomed By Cutbacks
summary: Don't send out an S.O.S. for the telecom equipment industry just yet. Michael K. Powell, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, urged in a speech early this month that telecommunications companies spend more on new equipment to insure the survival of big suppliers like Lucent Technologies, Nortel Networks and Cisco Systems. The carriers' own recovery, he said, depended on the ability of those and smaller equipment makers to remain solvent enough to continue developing new technology.

headline: Deal Reported For Vivendi Sale Of French Assets
summary: Vivendi Universal has agreed to sell its French publishing business and other non-American assets to Lagardère, the French conglomerate that publishes Elle and Car and Driver magazines, for about $1.2 billion in cash, executives involved in the negotiations said last night. The decision by Vivendi's board to sell a part of its publishing unit instead of the entire division, which includes the educational publisher Houghton Mifflin, is another setback in Vivendi's effort to pay down its $18.6 billion debt load.

headline: AT&T Posts a Small Profit After Three Quarters of Losses
summary: AT&T said yesterday that it had a small profit in the third quarter after three consecutive periods of losses, and attributed it to cost-cutting and improved sales of communications services to large businesses. The company, the nation's largest long-distance carrier, reported net income of $207 million, or 5 cents a share, compared with $11.3 billion, or $3.13 a share, a year earlier, when it had a large one-time gain from the spinoff of AT&T Wireless.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; New WorldCom Losses Hint at a Disputed Future
summary: Despite its troubles, WorldCom is still an immense company, generating about $80 million in revenue daily, according to data WorldCom released yesterday. It is also a deeply unprofitable company. So how WorldCom may behave if it emerges from bankruptcy protection next year has become a hotly debated question in the telecommunications industry in recent weeks. It is a debate with important ramifications for consumers, business customers, WorldCom's myriad creditors and its competitors.

headline: Suspension of Childs Has Nets Concerned
summary: When the Nets suspended Chris Childs Tuesday for being grossly out of playing condition, his weight gain -- about 25 pounds -- put a strain on his teammates, most noticeably the man he was supposed to back up, Jason Kidd. ''We need him -- I need him -- to give me a little rest,'' Kidd said, with emphasis. ''He's behind the eight ball in that sense, with the offense. We wish he was here. Watching it is one thing, but being involved is totally different.''

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Legal Dispute Over Cegetel
summary: Vivendi Universal is suing the Vodafone Group in an attempt to gain more time to put together a counterbid for Cegetel, the large French phone company. Last week, Vodafone offered to buy the 85 percent of Cegetel it did not already own for 13.1 billion euros ($12.8 billion). The offer includes the stakes held by the BT Group, SBC Communications and Vivendi. Under the terms of a shareholder agreement, Vivendi has the option of counterbidding and can supersede Vodafone's offer for the BT or SBC stakes. Vodafone has given Vivendi a deadline of Nov. 10 to make a counteroffer. Vivendi's plans to either buy those stakes or try to get Vodafone to offer a higher price suffered a setback this week, when Vivendi received unacceptable offers for its publishing division, which includes Houghton Mifflin. It has now decided to auction Houghton Mifflin at a later date if it does not receive higher bids by tomorrow. Vivendi is arguing that the Nov. 10 deadline violates part of the Cegetel shareholder agreement, which stipulates that any offer for Cegetel must be accompanied by a 30-day grace period for due diligence. Vodafone says that rule does not apply to existing shareholders, who are already familiar with the company. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

headline: Court Gives Vivendi More Time for Bid
summary: Vivendi Universal received an extension from a French court today in its battle with the Vodafone Group for control of Cegetel, the French phone company. The court, the Tribunal de Commerce de Paris, ruled that Vivendi would have another month, until Dec. 10, to make a counter bid for the minority stakes in Cegetel that are owned by the BT Group and SBC Communications.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Vivendi Rebuffs Vodafone's Bid For Phone Stake
summary: Vivendi Universal's board struck back today at its onetime partner, the Vodafone Group, intensifying a battle for control of a French phone company. The Vivendi board, after three hours of deliberations, voted tonight to reject Vodafone's unsolicited $6.67 billion offer for Vivendi's 44 percent stake in the French phone company Cegetel, saying that the price did not ''reflect the true value'' of the company, which owns SFR, a highly profitable and fast-growing wireless operator.

headline: Market Place; Vivendi Is Said To Be Near Sale Of Houghton
summary: Vivendi Universal is planning to sell Houghton Mifflin, the publisher of ''Curious George,'' ''The Lord of the Rings'' and a wide range of textbooks, to a consortium of financiers led by the Blackstone Group, for about $1.7 billion, executives involved in the discussions said yesterday. An announcement is expected by tomorrow, the executives said, though they cautioned that an agreement had not yet been completed.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cingular Wireless Names New Chief Executive
summary: Cingular Wireless, the big American mobile-telephone company, said yesterday that it would replace its chief executive, Stephen Carter, with Stanley Sigman, the chief operating officer of SBC Communications, after third-quarter profit fell and customers defected. Mr. Sigman will move into the job immediately, Cingular said. He has worked with SBC Wireless, which merged with the mobile-phone business of BellSouth in 2000 to form Cingular Wireless. SBC owns 60 percent of Cingular Wireless and BellSouth owns the rest. Cingular's third-quarter pretax profit fell 44 percent as it lost 107,000 subscribers. The carrier has held talks to merge with Deutsche Telekom's American wireless unit to add customers, analysts have said. Discussions may be faltering amid disagreements over price, an analyst said yesterday. Mr. Sigman had worked at SBC and predecessor companies since 1965.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Vodafone Renews Cegetel Bid
summary: The Vodafone Group renewed its 6.77 billion euro ($6.75 billion) cash offer for Vivendi Universal's 44 percent stake in Cegetel, a French phone company. Vivendi has until Dec. 10 to decide whether it wants to accept Vodafone's offer or retain its stake and make a counter bid for the shares of Cegetel held by two other minority investors, the BT Group and SBC Communications. Vodafone has already bid for those stakes. Vivendi originally rejected Vodafone's offer, saying it did not reflect the full value of Cegetel. But then a French court extended the deadline for bids, paving the way for Vodafone to renew its offer. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

headline: WorldCom Sees More Revisions Of Its Figures
summary: WorldCom expects to add to its financial restatements, even beyond the $9 billion in fraudulent results the company has disclosed, WorldCom executives said in an interview late last week. The further restatements, which the executives declined to estimate in value, would come as part of the company's continuing talks to settle fraud charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Baby Bells Are Hoping for a Reprieve
summary: In the clubby world of Senate policy-making, a single senator in a critical position can effectively bring legislation to a standstill. Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, largely accomplished just that in the costliest lobbying battle over the last year -- one that may decide which companies will have an edge in the next generation of telecommunications.

headline: Deutsche Telekom Names Chief Executive
summary: Deutsche Telekom, the debt-burdened German telephone colossus, named the 41-year-old son of one of its former bosses as chief executive today, ending a four-month search that was distinguished by the number of people who did not want the job. The official, Kai-Uwe Ricke, will take over a fragile company, still struggling to digest the expensive overseas acquisitions made by his predecessor, Ron Sommer, who was ousted last July in a boardroom purge orchestrated by the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder.

headline: SBC Will Combine Its Billing
summary: SBC Communications, the nation's No. 2 local communications company, intends to announce today that it is beginning to offer local phone service, long-distance calling, wireless service and Internet access on one combined bill.

headline: With few words, a Hewlett-Packard campaign draws on the theme of technology in action.
summary: WHEN Carleton S. Fiorina was unexpectedly chosen to become chief executive of Hewlett-Packard in 1999, many people in the computer industry questioned whether she was up to the job. But no one really doubted her skills as a marketer. She had made her reputation at Lucent Technologies as the executive who repositioned and rebranded the telecommunications equipment maker prior to its spinoff from AT&T in 1996. Ms. Fiorina brought her confident marketing touch to Hewlett-Packard and quickly put a new focus on the company's marketing and branding program. A fragmented system, with product divisions and sales regions doing their own marketing, was streamlined and centralized. Its advertising carried a unifying logo, ''hp invent'' -- an attempt to link the Silicon Valley company's innovative past with its present.

headline: Will Canada Open Border To Investors?
summary: Canada's industry minister said today that the government would review the country's limits on foreign ownership of communications companies and consider changing them to encourage investment and competition. Any such change is sure to be debated intensely. The limits are widely seen as an important defense of national sovereignty and of a distinct Canadian culture against domination by American or other foreign companies.

headline: Market Place; Vivendi says its cash crisis is a thing of the past and a battle with Vodafone may be in its future.
summary: VIVENDI UNIVERSAL boasted Tuesday that its cash crisis was over. The company said it was now storing ammunition in case it decided to take on the Vodafone Group of Britain, the world's largest wireless operator, in a battle for control of the French phone company Cegetel. The upbeat stand by Vivendi is a remarkable turn for a company that was on the brink of bankruptcy last summer, forcing it to put assets up for sale and to assemble ambitious refinancing packages.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
summary: R. R. DONNELLY & SONS CO., Chicago, the printer of telephone directories, said it would publish directories for SBC Communications Inc., San Antonio, a local phone company, through 2015, expanding existing agreements to more than 700 titles. Terms were not disclosed. BOEING CO., Chicago, the airplane maker, said it had been awarded a $301 million contract from NASA to complete the X-37 spaceplane.

headline: Donnelley and SBC in Deal
summary: R. R. Donnelley & Sons, the world's largest printer of telephone directories, will publish directories for SBC Communications units through 2015. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: BCE Sells Directory Unit
summary: BCE Inc. has completed the sale of its Bell Canada telephone directory unit to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan for 3 billion Canadian dollars ($1.92 billion) in cash.

headline: Vivendi to Control France's 2nd-Largest Phone Company
summary: Showing signs of renewed vigor after declaring last week that its cash crisis was over, Vivendi Universal said today that it would pay 4 billion euros to acquire a controlling stake in Cegetel, France's second-largest telephone company. The acquisition would help Vivendi maintain a strong position in telecommunications while also thwarting efforts by Vodafone, the world's biggest wireless operator, to wage a battle for control of Cegetel and its lucrative mobile phone unit, SFR.

headline: Consumers Finding Ways To Zap Telemarketer Calls
summary: In their continuing struggle against telemarketers, consumers are powerless no more. Telemarketers who call the home of Tono Kessler in Perkasie, Pa., are likely to hear this recorded message: ''The number you are calling has Call Intercept, a service that requires callers whose telephone number does not appear on the Caller ID display to identify themselves before the call can continue.'' Few telemarketers take the trouble.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
summary: SBC COMMUNICATIONS, San Antonio, was given permission by the Federal Communications Commission to provide long-distance service in California within two weeks.

headline: In Telecom, Optimism On Overseas Companies
summary: It is certainly too early to declare that the telecommunications industry is rising like a phoenix from its ashes. But there are signs that the decline in the business may have ended. This quarter, investors have actually been buying the stocks: the Morgan Stanley World Telecommunication Services index is up 29 percent. Still, for the year, the index is down more than 30 percent. And it is trading at well under half its value in 1998, when the index was created.

headline: Investing; Companies Are Divided On Providing Online Data
summary: INVESTORS who turn to company Web sites for financial information may not find much there. Although all 30 of the companies in the Dow Jones industrial average keep copies of their current annual reports on their Web sites, only 16 retain reports for at least five years. Of those, Wal-Mart Stores has the richest online archive, offering reports going back to 1972, the year it started trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The second-deepest trove belongs to Home Depot, which offers data back to 1982.

headline: A Seesawing Market Finishes a Bit Higher
summary: It was an up and down week, with losses on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday sandwiched between nice gains on Monday and Friday. But there was enough in the plus column for the three main market gauges to finish the week barely higher, ending a two-week decline. The Dow Jones industrial average, led by SBC Communications and Citigroup, rose 77.61 points, or 0.9 percent, to 8,511.32. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, lifted by Bed Bath & Beyond and Novell, climbed 6.28 points, or 0.7 percent, to 895.76. And the Nasdaq composite, paced by Sepracor and BEA Systems, inched up 0.63 point, or less than 0.1 percent, to 1,363.05.

headline: Qwest Investors Agree to Swap $5.2 Billion in Bonds
summary: Qwest Communications International said yesterday morning that investors had agreed to exchange bonds with a face value of about $5.2 billion for $3.3 billion in notes that have higher interest rates and more security behind them. Later in the day, Qwest received its long-awaited approval from the Federal Communications Commission to begin selling long-distance phone service in nine of the 14 Western states in which it is the largest local phone company.

headline: Cable Bills Add a Line: The Phone
summary: ALL Peter Odabashian wanted was a second phone line. But when the phone company said it needed to run new wiring into his apartment, which would cost nearly $300 and require waiting several weeks, he found an alternative: the cable company. Mr. Odabashian turned to the RCN Corporation, a cable company that offers telephone service as well as ''The West Wing'' and ''The Sopranos.'' ''RCN said it would install the line for free and throw in a month of service,'' said Mr. Odabashian, a film editor in New York who previously had cable service from Time Warner. ''I signed up for the full works. Now I have two phone lines, TV and a cable modem from them.''

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Gazing Into 2003: Economy Intrudes on Dreams of New Services -- Internet Service; Finding Customers At Market's Low End
summary: America Online and Microsoft spent much of the last six months talking about how to get consumers to pay a premium for their Internet services. But in many ways, the hottest area for Internet service right now is discounts. In the third quarter of 2002, AOL added a net 129,000 customers, largely for its $23.90-a-month dial-up service. But United Online, which sells $9.95 service under the Juno and NetZero brands, added 141,000. (Microsoft's MSN, which charges $21.95 for dial-up, added the most subscribers: 269,000 in the quarter.)

headline: Markets & Investing; Big Names Expected To Plot Mergers
summary: THE corporate chess game of mergers and acquisitions, an indicator of confidence in boardrooms and the stock market, may offer some intriguing matches this year. The days of industries' being reshaped and transformed by megamergers are clearly over, but dozens of Kasparov-like moves are now being mapped out for 2003 that could make rivals rethink their strategies. Big-name companies like Bristol-Myers Squibb, the H. J. Heinz Company, AT&T Wireless Services and the Bank One Corporation of Chicago, among others, are expected to end up in headlines this year. Of course, scores of asset sales by companies that need to raise cash and those in bankruptcy proceedings are also predicted.

headline: Phone Calling Over Internet Is Attracting More Interest
summary: Phone calls over the Internet may finally be catching on. When the technique was first used in the mid-1990's, Internet telephone conversations were hailed as a way to make long-distance calls without paying toll charges. The most zealous advocates predicted that the conventional public telephone network would quickly become obsolete. That has yet to happen, of course.

headline: Verizon Tops Sprint to Gain No. 3 Spot in Long Distance
summary: Less than two years after becoming the first regional Bell telephone company allowed into the long-distance market in its home territory, Verizon Communications has surpassed Sprint to become the nation's No. 3 consumer long-distance carrier by one measure. Verizon said yesterday that according to surveys by two market research firms, the company -- already the nation's biggest local telephone and wireless carrier -- provides more households in the United States with primary long-distance service than does Sprint.

headline: Investing; Tax Plan Throws a Bone to the 'Dogs of the Dow'
summary: TAX-FREE stock dividends? Sure, Wall Street likes the idea, but the prospect has one breed of stock pickers virtually yelping for joy. That group, the followers of the ''Dogs of the Dow'' strategy, stands to reap handsomely if the Bush administration's proposal to eliminate taxes on most dividend income becomes law. That is because the strategy leads investors to high-yielding stocks: payouts would be worth more if they escaped the government's tithe, and the dividend-paying shares themselves would likely receive a boost if investors flocked to them.

headline: Yahoo Plans Big Expansion Of Broadband
summary: Buoyed by its growing sales and profits, Yahoo is planning to take its high-speed Internet access service nationwide. Yesterday, the big Internet portal announced better-than-expected financial results for the fourth quarter of 2002. It was able to expand its sales of online advertising, even as it added new services that generate monthly fees from users.

headline: AT&T's Gloom Shows the Sector Is Still Flagging
summary: Shares of AT&T, the nation's biggest long-distance communications carrier, plunged 19.1 percent yesterday after the company said that it did not expect the dismal telecommunications market to improve significantly in 2003. Scalded by flagging demand in corporate communications markets and by consumers' continuing migration to wireless phones and e-mail, AT&T reported weak results for the fourth quarter, matching Wall Street's expectations. Moreover, the company said it expected its financial performance in the current quarter to disappoint investors.

headline: Users Uneasy On SBC Claim To Patent On Web Tool
summary: When British Telecom claimed in 2000 that it had patented the Web's ubiquitous hyperlink, the Internet erupted in a fit of protest that lasted until the company lost its test infringement case against Prodigy Communications last summer. But that has not stopped Prodigy's parent company, SBC Communications, from asserting a patent claim on a Web navigation technique nearly as widely used. According to letters SBC sent out last week, the company believes that any Web site that has a menu that remains on the screen while a user clicks through the site may owe it royalties.

headline: As Broadband Gains, The Internet's Snails, Like AOL, Fall Back
summary: America Online now has some company in the Internet doghouse. Last week, the company said the number of subscribers to its flagship Internet service, by far the nation's largest, had fallen in the fourth quarter, the first decline in its history, further contributing to the woes of its parent, AOL Time Warner. But executives at the America Online division can at least find solace that its plight is shared by the other leading dial-up Internet access providers, EarthLink and Microsoft's MSN, which also have shrinking numbers of dial-up subscribers.

headline: BellSouth Moves to Block Hiring by Sprint
summary: BellSouth, the third-largest local phone company, said yesterday that it was seeking to prevent its vice chairman from accepting the job leading the Sprint Corporation, in a surprise twist to Sprint's search for a successor to William T. Esrey, its chairman and chief executive. Lawyers for BellSouth received a restraining order in state court in Atlanta on Friday requesting that Gary D. Forsee, the company's No. 2 executive and heir apparent to its chief executive F. Duane Ackerman, honor a part of his contract that prevents him from working for a competitor for 18 months after leaving.

headline: Lucent Chief Plans a Path Back to Black
summary: The last year has been a harrowing one for Patricia F. Russo, the chief executive of Lucent Technologies. The next few months may reveal whether this year will be any easier. The company is still the nation's leading maker of communications switching equipment for telephone companies -- and a global leader in the field. But when Lucent was seeking a chief in late 2001, a number of high-ranking technology executives turned down the position as thankless because the company had been so battered by the telecommunications recession and the bear stock market.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 350,000 Subscribers For Virgin Mobile
summary: Virgin Mobile U.S.A., the wireless carrier venture between Sprint PCS and the Virgin Group of Britain, is expected to announce today that it signed up 350,000 subscribers in its first six months of operation in the United States. The company, which focuses on providing prepaid cellular service from Sprint's network to young consumers, had 245,000 new subscribers in the fourth quarter of 2002, representing about 6 percent of total net subscriber additions in the period. Virgin Mobile succeeded in attracting subscribers at a time when other carriers, including Sprint and Cingular Wireless, a joint venture of BellSouth and SBC Communications, suffered from customer defections. Daniel H. Schulman, above, Virgin Mobile's chief executive, said in an interview that he expected the company to become profitable within two and a half years. Shares of Sprint PCS fell 8 cents, to $3.69. Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: Corrections
summary: An article and a chart in Business Day on Monday about a decline in the number of dial-up subscribers to Internet services misstated the percentage change for two services from 2001 to 2002. The combined total of dial-up and high-speed subscribers for Earthlink rose by 3 percent, to 4.8 million; it was not unchanged. The number of dial-up customers for SBC-Prodigy declined by 22 percent, to 1.4 million, not by 61 percent.

headline: Sprint's Shares Rise, but Its Woes Are Rising Faster
summary: Management tumult at the telecommunications company Sprint reached a new level yesterday as the chief executive, William T. Esrey, acknowledged that he was the subject of an Internal Revenue Service audit, while the executive whom the company has chosen to succeed Mr. Esrey became the target of a second lawsuit meant to keep him from joining Sprint. Those developments all but overshadowed an unexpectedly strong fourth-quarter financial report yesterday by Sprint. The company said its local and long-distance telephone operations had turned a profit for the quarter, while losses narrowed in its wireless business, which gained a quarter-million customers in the period.

headline: Wireless Rivalries Fuel Fight Over a BellSouth Executive
summary: With the wireless industry's largest carriers in an all-out struggle to increase subscribers and sales, it is no wonder BellSouth reacted so fiercely to the announcement last week by its vice chairman, Gary D. Forsee, that he planned to become chief executive of the rival Sprint Corporation. After all, Cingular Wireless, which BellSouth operates with SBC Communications, is struggling as it seeks to compete with other nationwide carriers, including Sprint's wireless operation. In an illustration that Cingular is going in one direction and the industry's other big players in another, Cingular lost customers in the most recent quarter as its competitors gained them.

headline: SBC Dismisses Goodby, Silverstein
summary: SBC Communications said yesterday that it had dismissed Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, which handled product advertising for the company since 1997. Though billings were not disclosed, SBC spent $52 million to advertise in major media during the first 11 months of 2002, according to CMR, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres. Larry Solomon, a spokesman for SBC, the regional Bell company based in San Antonio, confirmed a report of the decision in the online edition of Advertising Age. The company ''decided to go in a different direction,'' Mr. Solomon said, declining to elaborate.

headline: INSIDE
summary: DeLay Disavows Letter Tom DeLay, House majority leader, disavowed a letter bearing his signature that accuses ''labor bosses'' of seeking to expand their power at the expense of national security. PAGE A11 20 Die in Colombia Blast A bomb rocked an exclusive club in Bogotá, killing more than 20 people, leaving about 100 injured and setting the 10-story building on fire. PAGE A6

headline: SBC Said to Be in Talks to Buy DirecTV
summary: With its core local phone business in decline, SBC Communications has entered serious negotiations to acquire the DirecTV satellite television operation of General Motors in a deal that could be worth more than $10 billion, people close to the talks said yesterday. SBC's interest in DirecTV, the nation's No. 2 pay television provider after Comcast, sets SBC in direct competition with the News Corporation, controlled by Rupert Murdoch. Mr. Murdoch has been pursuing DirecTV for at least three years as he tries to add the United States to his global satellite empire.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-6 France and China Rebuff U.S. Over Action in Iraq The leaders of France and China rebuffed efforts by President Bush to line up support for the use of force against Iraq within the next month or two. Their resistance made clear the difficulty the White House faces in its attempt to win new authorization for military action. A1 The British government admitted that large sections of its most recent report on Iraq, praised by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, had been lifted from magazines and academic journals. However, a spokesman for Prime Minister Tony Blair defended it as ''solid'' and ''accurate.'' A9

headline: Decision Is Near on Bells and Their Rivals
summary: Hordes of ''Gucci Gulch'' lobbyists besieged the Federal Communications Commission last week as the agency rushed to rewrite vital and arcane telephone rules that could help determine the next generation of winners and losers in the marketplace. The agency has announced its intention to release new rules this Thursday that will govern how much the four regional Bell companies can charge their rivals for using their networks and equipments. With Michael K. Powell, the agency's chairman, so far unable to find a majority of support from among the four other commissioners, that deadline could slip.

headline: A Bid by SBC For DirecTV Would Confirm Cable's Reach
summary: The cable industry calls it the triple play. To Edward E. Whitacre Jr., the chairman of SBC Communications, the cable industry's ability to offer telephone, high-speed Internet and television services might as well be called the triple threat. With SBC's core local phone business in decline and the triple threat increasingly becoming a real threat, Mr. Whitacre has good reason to consider making a bid to take over the DirecTV satellite television operation of General Motors.

headline: INSIDE
summary: Education Gap for Hispanics Only 16 percent of Hispanic students earn a four-year college degree by age 29, the lowest rate of any group. A study says culture or language often stand in the way. PAGE A14 Weighing a Bid for DirecTV With its core phone business in decline, SBC has good reason to consider a bid for the DirecTV satellite operation. But such a move carries a risk. NEWS ANALYSIS, PAGE C1

headline: F.C.C. Puts Off a Session on Phone Rules
summary: The Federal Communications Commission today postponed until Feb. 20 a meeting to review rules that require Verizon Communications Inc. and other local-phone companies to lease their networks at discounts. The meeting, previously scheduled for Thursday, was delayed to give commissioners ''more time to discuss the various proposals being considered,'' an F.C.C. spokesman, David Fiske, said today.

headline: For Sprint Chief, a Hard Fall From Grace
summary: To hear the Sprint Corporation's board tell it, the fall from grace of its longtime chief executive, William T. Esrey, is the consequence of his having followed bad tax advice in handling stock options that Mr. Esrey and his No. 2, Ronald LeMay, received in 1999 and 2000. But critics say that a look at Sprint's financial performance in recent years would provide enough justification for the board's forced ouster of Mr. Esrey and Mr. LeMay -- even if their tax shelters had not become the targets of an Internal Revenue Service inquiry.

headline: Yahoo Outlines Plans for Adding Premium Services
summary: At its last meeting with analysts, 15 months ago, Yahoo gave each of them a gift of a yo-yo to make the point that what goes down can come up. At a dinner on Tuesday before its meeting yesterday, the company gave analysts a set of balls, to show that it has stabilized its finances and is now juggling several opportunities for growth. In the meeting yesterday, at Yahoo's headquarters in Sunnyvale, Calif., the company spent much of its time outlining plans for new premium services it intends to introduce to its Web portal later this year. These include a mix of new services -- like video programming to be watched on computer screens, and expanded versions of its core offerings like e-mail.

headline: F.C.C. Ruling Is Expected To Favor Bells
summary: Unable to muster a majority of support, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission is preparing to issue a rare dissent over aspects of the most significant changes in the regulation of the telephone industry since the Telecommunications Act of 1996, people involved in the proceedings said late this afternoon. Facing a Thursday morning deadline to complete regulations on one of the most heavily lobbied telecommunications issues in recent times, the commission was planning to ease some rules that require the four large regional Bell companies -- Verizon, SBC Communications, BellSouth, Qwest Communications International -- to lease their networks and equipment to smaller rivals and long-distance carriers at low rates.

headline: High-Speed Service May Cost More
summary: Of the roughly 20 million users of high-speed Internet service, only a few hundred thousand customers are likely to have their rates increased as a direct result of yesterday's ruling by the Federal Communications Commission. But some executives argue that eliminating this form of price competition will lead to increased overall prices for the service, also known as broadband. The companies that will be hardest hit are those that have built high-speed data networks that share the lines of local telephone companies into homes and offices. The F.C.C. voted to eliminate, over three years, a rule that forced local Bell companies to let these rivals offer broadband services using their networks.

headline: LOCAL PHONE RULES TO STAY IN PLACE
summary: A deeply divided Federal Communications Commission today largely left in place rules that are meant to foster local telephone competition by requiring the four regional Bell companies to lease their local networks to their rivals at low prices set by state regulators. But in a compromise order, the agency relieved the companies of their obligation to give rivals low-cost access to many of the crucial elements of the Bells' new high-speed Internet networks. [News analysis, Page C1.]

headline: Land-Line Rules in a Wireless World
summary: In fits and starts, local telephone competition has taken hold in many parts of the country since the Telecommunications Act of 1996 -- most significantly in New York, the home state of the nation's biggest local phone company, Verizon Communications. And yet, in many ways local competition is taking forms, like the remarkable growth of wireless communications and the emergence of Internet-based telephone systems, that were beyond the imagination of many policy makers of the mid-1990's.

headline: Los Angeles Is Called Example Of Competitors Not Competing
summary: Given the size and affluence of Los Angeles, the presence of the biggest names in the telephone business, and the efforts of aggressive state regulators, the city would seem an ideal place for vibrant competition in telecommunications. But competition has been slow to develop -- not just there, but in many other local markets as well -- leaving a long way to go before regulators realize their ideal of encouraging more services at significantly lower prices.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
summary: HILTON HOTELS, Beverly Hills, Calif., the hotel chain, said its partnership with CNL Hospitality, Orlando, Fla., a unit of CNL Financial Group, had bought five hotels for $249 million as part of a $402 million venture. SBC COMMUNICATIONS, San Antonio, the provider of local phone service, said the Justice Department had advised federal regulators that SBC met legal requirements to offer long-distance service in Nevada.

headline: Revolt of the Shareholders
summary: THE annual-meeting season is here, and one thing seems certain from a glance at the resolutions shareholders have filed: the persistent bear market and recent corporate scandals have taken as great a toll on trust in management as they have on investors' wallets. State pension funds, unions and other investors, big and small, are clamoring for their say on executive compensation packages, board elections, even choosing where companies are incorporated. They want General Electric to trim severance packages, Citigroup to eliminate golden parachutes, Sprint to stop repricing the stock options granted to management and Delta Air Lines to charge stock options against earnings. They want Qwest Communications to link options to performance, Wal-Mart to split the job of chairman and chief executive into two posts and General Motors to protect the environment.

headline: F.C.C. Delivers Some Cheer To Slumping Silicon Valley
summary: The decision by the Federal Communications Commission last week to retain many of the rules that govern local telecommunications markets but to exempt high-speed Internet services has given some Silicon Valley companies reason to cheer. Under the ruling last Thursday, states will still have the right to order the regional Bell telephone companies to provide network access to their local competitors at relatively low wholesale prices. But because high-speed Internet, or broadband, services are exempt from those forced-access rules, some makers of broadband equipment -- like Cisco Systems and Juniper Networks -- look forward to a new wave of buying as competitors in broadband services arm themselves for battle.

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Earthlink Said To Be Near Pact With Vonage
summary: EarthLink, the nation's third-largest Internet service provider, is expected to announce soon a deal with Vonage, an Internet telephone company, to provide nationwide telephone service to its users, people involved in the transaction said yesterday. EarthLink is planning to sell Vonage's service, which allows broadband users to place an unlimited number of local and long-distance calls for $39.99 a month, under its own name, these people said. The deal is expected to extend the reach of Internet-based telephone services, which compete with traditional service from large local phone companies like Verizon Communications and SBC Communications. Financial terms of the deal were not released. Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: Cingular's New Chief Replaces Campaign
summary: The new chief executive of Cingular Wireless in Atlanta, brought in to help reverse the company's flagging fortunes, said yesterday that Cingular would make a change in its national advertising campaign by replacing ads that celebrate self-expression with ones that ''give customers a reason to buy Cingular.'' Stanley T. Sigman, who became chief executive in November, said in a speech in New York that the campaign would adopt the theme ''Cingular fits you best,'' which is intended to offer consumers ''legitimate, tangible reasons'' to buy Cingular services like ''coverage, quality, service and attractive price and plans.''

headline: F.C.C. Members Defend Proposals on Bell Companies
summary: The five members of the Federal Communications Commission defended their new telephone and broadband policy in front of a Congressional hearing today, but they conceded that their compromise proposal, which requires the regional Bell companies to continue to share their phone lines with competitors, left no one happy and was not certain to pump up the flailing telecommunications sector in the near term. The sharp divisions among the commissioners were aired in their first public appearance together since the widely anticipated vote last week for the new regulations. The regulations passed on a 3-to-2 vote. The commission members appeared before a panel of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. Most of the lawmakers' questions, as well as some anger, were directed at the F.C.C. chairman, Michael K. Powell, and a commissioner, Kevin J. Martin, a Republican who had brokered a compromise with the two Democratic members of the commission.

headline: Cisco Seeks Bigger Role in Phone Networks
summary: The telecommunications boom of the late 1990's was cruel to Cisco Systems. Now the company is trying to benefit from those harsh lessons. Cisco, which built its reputation in data networking equipment, angered many major telephone companies a few years ago by trying to expand its small share of the voice-and-data market by focusing on a group of upstarts that were competing with the telephone companies. Because Cisco acted as lender in a lot of those purchases, the company lost tens of millions of dollars on the deals when many of those start-up companies went bankrupt.

headline: Nets' Kidd, a Free Agent to Be, Gets the Attention of the Spurs
summary: The grass is greener in San Antonio these days, greener after a week of rain, and greener on the dozen championship golf courses surrounding the second largest city in Texas. In the next 36 hours, fans and the local news media will most likely try to send away Jason Kidd, the Nets' All-Star point guard, with a mental souvenir that says something catchy like, ''Remember the Alamo.''

headline: With Kidd In Town, Point Guard Lifts Spurs
summary: Tony Parker dashed to the basket in a blur all night, Tim Duncan attached himself to the glass and Emanuel Ginobili hit soft-arching shots from everywhere on the court. Jason Kidd was not watching these San Antonio Spurs selling points. He was too busy watching his shots roll out of the basket and too busy trying to lift the Nets out of their prolonged slump.

headline: Bear Market May Be On Its Last Legs
summary: MARCH 10, 2000. For many investors, it was the day the music died. Three years ago tomorrow, the Nasdaq composite index peaked at 5,048.62. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index did not stop rising until two weeks later, but investors look back on that Nasdaq peak as a turning point, the end of a decade-long run.

headline: Altered reality: ABC's new show 'All American Girl' will work in the products of sponsors.
summary: ABC is clambering aboard the bandwagon of networks that allow advertisers to place products in reality series by signing two major marketers, Schick and Cingular Wireless, to embed brands in all 13 episodes of a new show, ''All American Girl,'' which has its premiere tonight. In the show, which is billed as ''a national search for the ultimate all-American girl,'' Schick will sponsor segments devoted to examples of ''women's intuition.'' The company just so happens to have a new women's shaver named Intuition.

headline: Betting on Speed, Pure and Simple; In Broadband, Comcast Lets Users Find Their Own Flourishes
summary: High-speed service may be the future of the Internet, but it has been nothing but trouble for most companies involved. Comcast, the newly crowned king of cable, is the accidental exception. So far the three leaders that emerged in the first Internet wave, with service based on slow telephone modems -- America Online, Microsoft's MSN, and Earthlink -- have attracted few customers for the speedier access known as broadband. And they have lost considerable money trying to resell fast connections bought wholesale from cable or telephone providers.

headline: At Telecom Research Firm, The Forecast Is Never Sunny
summary: It is hard to find much cheer among the analysts who follow the telecommunications industry, with sagging share prices for some of the largest telephone companies and the occasional forecast of a recovery quickly dashed by the latest regulatory rulings in Washington. But there is gloom and then there is utter bleakness, a specialty of Probe Research, which issued its latest dose of hopelessness last week in the report ''Debt, Demographics and Telecom.''

headline: Patents; Some corporations take generous tax write-offs for donated patents, an industry gadfly says.
summary: GREGORY AHARONIAN is intent on exposing what he says may turn out to be the next big tax accounting scandal: patent donations. Mr. Aharonian, in a recent issue of his e-mail newsletter, Internet Patent News, decries what he says is the alarming trend of companies ''donating bogus patents to universities and claiming big tax deductions on their federal taxes.''

headline: Market Place; A Financier by Another Name Was a Self-Described Con Man
summary: Theodore Roxford seems like a big wheel. Henry Kravis has called upon him for advice, and the buyout giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has paid him thousands of dollars for his work. David Bonderman of the Texas Pacific Group recently corresponded with him about working together. Earlier this month, he went public with a $108 million offer for Zapata, the one-time oil and gas company founded by former President George Bush.

headline: Some Companies Quietly Profit From War Fever
summary: American businesses have not been waiting for this week's moving- target deadlines to prepare for war. Many are already figuring out how to profit from events -- all the while taking pains not to look as though they are profiteering. When the sales staff of the Candlewood Suites hotel in Yorktown, Va., heard that the army was calling up reservists, they immediately visited nearby Fort Eustis to remind the officers that Candlewood puts up military personnel at their per diem rate, or less. It was a good business move: 40 of the hotel's 59 rooms are now occupied by reservists.

headline: News Corp. to Raise Up to $1.5 Billion With Bond Issue
summary: The News Corporation said today that a subsidiary would raise as much as $1.5 billion in capital by issuing bonds that are convertible into shares of British Sky Broadcasting, a pay television company in which the News Corporation has a stake. Proceeds from the bond issue are meant to help the News Corporation finance its widely expected bid to acquire DirecTV, another satellite pay television operator.

headline: Houston Helps Knicks Forget About Duncan
summary: The word before tonight's game was that Tim Duncan would sit out with a sprained right ankle. As a prank, Duncan even showed up at San Antonio's morning shoot-around hobbling on a crutch. An hour before game time, though, Duncan wrecked the Knicks' dream of skipping town without facing him.

headline: Options Calculus: Who Gets It Right?
summary: LURKING in the small type of corporate financial statements is a new problem that threatens the ability of investors to divine the true health of a company's earnings. Companies are taking widely varying approaches to estimating the cost of the stock options they award to their executives and employees, and the differences are sometimes large enough to make comparisons between companies difficult.

headline: Shares Rise on Expectations of Strong Growth After War
summary: Stocks rose for the first trading day in five yesterday as some investors speculated that economic growth would accelerate once the war with Iraq ends. Shares of SBC Communications gained on reports that it would not bid for the DirecTV satellite television unit of General Motors.
