Shares of Concord EFS, which owns a large network of automated teller machines, surged on speculation the company was in talks to be acquired by First Data, a processor of credit card transactions.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 War News Summary B2 AIDS Patients in Uganda Are Preserving Their Memories Borrowing an idea from cancer patients in Britain, health workers in Uganda are urging parents with AIDS to preserve memories for their children. Memory books are becoming an increasingly popular way for Africans to continue coddling their beloved offspring from the grave. A3

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC Starts Unlimited Calling Plan
summary: Highlighting a trend in the marketing of telephone calling plans, SBC Communications Inc. yesterday became the latest company to introduce a package that permits unlimited long-distance and local calling for a single price. SBC's introduction of All Distance Connections follows similar announcements in the last several months by Verizon Communications and BellSouth, according to Aurica Yen, an analyst with the Yankee Group, a market research firm. In the case of SBC, the company is offering its unlimited calling plan for around $50 depending on the state where the consumer lives. The plan is available initially only in California, Texas, Kansas, Oklahoma, Missouri and Arkansas, SBC said. Shares of SBC fell 47 cents, or 2.1 percent, to $21.68. Matt Richtel(NYT)

headline: Executive Pay: A Special Report; Expectations (and Pay) Climb for Directors
summary: SCANDALS, lawsuits, government scrutiny. These have been dark days for corporate board members. But that doesn't mean directors aren't being paid well. In fact, they are compensating themselves even better as a result.

headline: Cablevision Is Said to Drop Out of Bidding for DirecTV
summary: Cablevision Systems has abandoned its plan to bid for Hughes Electronics and its DirecTV satellite television operation, people close to the company said yesterday, leaving Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation as the sole suitor for Hughes. Cablevision's decision, which was made late Friday, came a few days after SBC Communications also decided to drop out of the bidding for control of Hughes, which is a unit of General Motors.

headline: G.M. Board Set to Sell Control Of Hughes Unit to News Corp.
summary: The board of General Motors is planning to meet today to approve a deal worth about $7 billion that would give control of its Hughes Electronics unit and the DirecTV satellite operation to the News Corporation, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday. The executives said the deal, if approved, could be announced as early as today.

headline: Profits Exceeded Expectations at Yahoo in First Quarter
summary: Better-than-expected advertising sales, along with steady growth of its fee-based businesses, helped Yahoo earn better-than-expected profits in the first quarter. Yahoo is the largest Web portal and has been the most successful major Internet company in rebuilding its advertising business after the dot-com collapse two years ago. The company said ad sales grew fastest for the text advertisements it displays along with Internet search results. But it also reported strong demand for graphic advertising by companies trying to promote consumer products online.

headline: Who Knew Numbers Could Be So Heavy?
summary: LIKE millions of other Connecticut residents, Lorraine Beauchaine of Morris receives a new set of telephone directories from SBC SNET each year. But for the last few years, she has rarely opened the new ones, letting them pile up unused. ''I hate the new phone books,'' said Mrs. Beauchaine, 54, a nurse coordinator for the Edward L. Miller Adult Day Care Center in Shelton. ''The print is so small I was wondering if my eyes were going. The business pages drive me to drink. I can't find things anymore. I've kept the 2001 phone book just for that reason, so I can find things. It all makes me think of the old saying, 'If it ain't broke, why fix it?'''

headline: Boldly Defending Their Options in a Penitent Age
summary: IN the 1990's, corporate executives were allowed to siphon off so much shareholder wealth for so long that it seems some of them still cannot see why shareholders -- the true owners -- are finally taking issue with their grasping ways. Times have changed. But executives, at least at some companies, are still in me-first mode. Consider what officials at TIAA-CREF, the big public pension fund, found when they approached about 50 companies about reforming their pay practices.

headline: AT&T Trying to Collect Bills From the Victims of Hackers
summary: Victims of a telephone hacking swindle are disputing a contention by AT&T that they are responsible for costly long-distance calls fraudulently made through their voice mail systems. The dispute revolves around a string of incidents in which hackers broke into business voice mail systems and rigged them to accept international collect calls from the Philippines and other countries. The charges for these calls, which occurred when the businesses were closed, typically run in the thousands of dollars. While most of the victims so far have been in California, similar incidents have recently been reported in Texas and Ohio.

headline: Canada Seeks Phone Rivalry
summary: More than a decade after barriers to competition began to come down in Canada's telephone industry, politicians and regulators are venting their displeasure at how little has been accomplished. In contrast to the United States, where AT&T was broken up long ago and curbs placed on the new regional operating companies, regulators in Canada have taken a softer approach, seeking to encourage competition without destabilizing the entrenched incumbents. The hope has been that new entrants would gain market share by building networks of their own, and, with some help from regulators, by gaining access to existing lines at reasonable cost.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: I.R.S. to Ask Working Poor For Proof on Tax Credits The Internal Revenue Service is planning to ask more than four million of the working poor who claim a special tax credit to provide the most exhaustive proof of their eligibility ever demanded of any class of taxpayers. But some tax experts criticize the higher burden of proof as unfair and a wasteful allocation of enforcement dollars. They say that corporations, business owners, investors and partnerships deprive the government of many times more than the working poor could -- through illegal means and legal shelters -- yet these taxpayers face no demands to prove the validity of their claims in advance. [Page A1.]

headline: SBC Swings to Profit, but Continues to Lose Local-Line Customers
summary: SBC Communications, the local telephone company, said yesterday that it returned to profitability in its first quarter, helped by gains from accounting changes and the sale of its stake in the French phone company Cegetel S.A. Net income was $5 billion, or $1.50 a share, in contrast to a net loss of $193 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell 1.8 percent, to $10.3 billion, as sales from local calling dropped.

headline: DataBank; Profits Recover. Jobs Vanish. Stocks Rise.
summary: The three major stock market indexes rose last week as upbeat corporate earnings announcements cheered many investors, despite a report that unemployment deepened in April. It was the third consecutive positive week for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which is up 5.7 percent for the year, and for the Nasdaq composite index, which has risen 12.5 percent. By contrast, the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell the previous week, is up only 2.9 percent for the year.

headline: Lakers, as a Team of 2, Can't Catch the Spurs
summary: A whole team of contributors against essentially two players would not seem to be a fair fight, but Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant almost made the best of it tonight. With the supporting cast from three championship teams crumbling behind them, the Lakers' reigning superstars created tense moments to the finish for the San Antonio Spurs before succumbing, 87-82, in Game 1 of the Western Conference semifinals at the SBC Center.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Fined For Long-Distance Violation
summary: Qwest Communications, the No. 4 local telephone company in the country, was fined $6.5 million yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission. The fine was for selling long-distance calling without permission. Qwest sold long-distance service before regulators cleared it to do so in some of the 14 Western states where it dominates local calling, the F.C.C. said. Qwest agreed to the fine as part of a settlement. The fine exceeds a $6 million penalty the F.C.C. gave to SBC Communications in October for denying competitors access to its phone network, an F.C.C. spokesman, David Fiske, said. Regional phone companies like Qwest must prove that their local phone networks are open to rivals before they can sell long-distance. Qwest has done so in 12 states and awaits a ruling on Minnesota next month. Shares of Qwest fell 32 cents, or 7.2 percent, to $4.11. They have dropped from a high of $66 in March 2000.

headline: Spurs Have the Lakers Looking Vulnerable
summary: The Los Angeles Lakers' run of three straight N.B.A. championships and Coach Phil Jackson's streak of 25 straight victorious playoff series have officially entered the danger zone. The Lakers left south Texas early, defeated and physically depleted after getting blown out of the SBC Center tonight by the San Antonio Spurs, 114-95. The Lakers were never in the game after the early minutes and after three quarters were behind by 30 points.

headline: Sports of The Times; Parker Should Make Spurs Forget Kidd
summary: ON the sore and speculative subject of Jason Kidd's hightailing it out of northern New Jersey next season for a charmed championship life here in steamy South Texas: not so fast. The Spurs already have an irresistible point guard who can flat-out fly. For a truly informed evaluation of how quick Tony Parker is, we thought it best to consult a man named Speedy.

headline: Verizon Sets Up Phone Booths For Internet Use Without Wires
summary: Verizon Communications yesterday introduced one of the oldest items in its inventory -- the humble phone booth -- as its newest weapon in the bitter competition to dominate the broadband communications market of the future. Verizon said that subscribers to its high-speed Internet access service would be able to go online wirelessly at no charge when they are near a Verizon phone booth in Manhattan.

headline: Lakers Ignore the Spurs' Lead, Until It's Too Late
summary: With just over a minute left in the first half tonight, Kobe Bryant and Shaquille O'Neal chatted as they walked onto the court after a timeout. As the conversation ended, Bryant gripped O'Neal on the back of his head, and the two shared a laugh. The moment belied the 22-point deficit the Los Angeles Lakers faced. Evidently, Bryant and O'Neal were not worried, probably believing they had another rally-against-all-odds comeback up the sleeve of their purple-and-gold warmups. They almost did. But Robert Horry's 3-point attempt just before the buzzer sounded fell halfway into the basket and bounced out, leaving the Lakers short of pulling off one of the greatest comebacks of their three-year reign.

headline: DataBank; Investors Hear Bad News but Buy Anyway
summary: Despite hints of slower economic growth, the Nasdaq composite index and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed for a fifth consecutive week and the Dow Jones industrial average finished higher for the fourth week in a row. Declines in retail sales and industrial production last month, coupled with falling consumer and producer prices in April, didn't deter investors. Neither did a falling dollar.

headline: Moratorium on Merger Talks Expires at AT&T
summary: Let the takeover talks begin. The AT&T Corporation, which was effectively prevented from holding merger negotiations for the last six months because of a potential multibillion-dollar tax penalty, may have become a company in play yesterday as the moratorium expired.

headline: Mavericks Trump Spurs To Cap Wild Comeback
summary: Dirk Nowitzki traveled 274 miles downstate for a wild game of Texas Hold 'Em on Tim Duncan's porch. When the two best players left standing in the West had anted up and raised each other, they finally showed their hands. Duncan had a full house, 18,997 frenzied people at the SBC Center who watched the league's most valuable player put on a virtuoso, 40-point performance in Game 1 of the Western Conference finals.

headline: MCI Agrees to Pay $500 Million In Fraud Case, S.E.C.'s Largest
summary: MCI, the former WorldCom, agreed today to settle accusations of fraud by the Securities and Exchange Commission by paying a $500 million penalty that will ultimately be given to investors. The penalty was the largest ever sought by the commission, and the agreement resolves the biggest fraud case ever filed by the agency. If it is approved by a federal judge in Manhattan, it will also remove one of the last significant obstacles to MCI's emerging from the largest Chapter 11 bankruptcy ever filed.

headline: Coach Keeps the Mavericks' Opponents Off Balance
summary: Hard off the River Walk, around one torch-lit bend, is Dirty Nelly's. Yes, Don Nelson nodded proudly with a Bud Light in his hand, he has been to that bar.

headline: Mavs Battle Refs and Rally, But Spurs Put a Stop to It
summary: A Michael Finley fall-away jump shot, a Dirk Nowitzki rainbow from beyond the arc. There they went again, the most potent offensive team in pro basketball, moving swiftly in the fourth quarter, inching up on a scared lot of San Antonio Spurs. Without two of their coaches and most of their composure for the first 40 minutes -- all but buried with less than 10 minutes left at the SBC Center -- the Dallas Mavericks were on the verge of crawling out of another deep Texas well.

headline: Phone Companies See Their Future In Flat-Rate Plans Of Many Services
summary: Fifteen years ago, Arthur C. Clarke in the science-fiction novel ''2061: Odyssey Three'' predicted a future as follows: ''With the historic abolition of long-distance charges on 31 December 2000, every telephone call became a local one, and the human race greeted the new millennium by transforming itself into one huge, gossiping family.'' That future may be at hand, only a few years behind schedule, as a result of the telephone industry's declining economic fortunes, increasing competition and recent technological advances. Starting with MCI, which introduced its Neighborhood plan in April 2002, most leading phone companies -- AT&T, BellSouth, Qwest Communications, SBC Communications and Verizon -- have rolled out programs that allow customers in some states to make unlimited local and national calls for one flat monthly price.

headline: Sprint's New Boss Is Handcuffed By His Past Job
summary: Gary D. Forsee's office, while ornately appointed, still has few personal touches. Two months after he began his job as chief executive of the troubled telecommunications company Sprint, Mr. Forsee's bookshelf is mostly empty, except for a photograph of his wife and daughters. He is still awaiting the arrival of belongings and work files from Atlanta. Even when the cartons do show up here in this Kansas City, Mo., suburb, a handful of his possessions will remain glaringly absent. ''I won't be taking the boxes marked 'BellSouth,' '' he said, laughing.

headline: Deal Is Seen For NextWave Spectrum Sale
summary: NextWave Telecom is nearing an agreement to sell nearly a fifth of its radio spectrum licenses to one of the nation's largest wireless carriers, Cingular Wireless, in a deal that would allow NextWave to start paying off some of its billions of dollars of debt, executives involved in the transaction said yesterday. The deal, described as imminent by one of those executives, would transfer roughly 20 percent of NextWave's spectrum licenses to Cingular for $1.3 billion to $1.5 billion in cash.

headline: Spurs' March to Finals Takes a Detour to Dallas
summary: After one half of basketball tonight, the Dallas Mavericks appeared to be done, one of their finest seasons 24 minutes from ending. Down by 11 points and with their best player, Dirk Nowitzki, sidelined by a sprained left knee, the Mavericks were prime candidates for a rout. But in one of the most remarkable comebacks in a postseason full of rallies, the Mavericks stunned the San Antonio Spurs and 18,797 fans at the SBC Center. Behind the hustle, heart and skill of Michael Finley, the streak shooting of Nick Van Exel and the complexity of a hard-to-figure match-up zone defense, Dallas outscored the Spurs by 23 points in the second half to win Game 5 of the Western Conference finals, 103-91.

headline: The Spurs' Geezers Give All They've Got
summary: P. J. Carlesimo was grasping, trying to figure out how a 37-year-old bench player could so dramatically alter the Western Conference finals. He ran his fingers through his full beard, then through his hair, before he finally yelled across the locker room. ''Hey, Jack,'' Carlesimo said gruffly to Stephen Jackson, a 25-year-old swingman who, along with the rickety and reliable Steve Kerr, shot down Dallas and pushed the Spurs into the N.B.A. finals on Thursday night. ''Who's on the floor after practice every day?''

headline: Behind Media Rule and Its End, One Man
summary: Nearly 30 years ago, a young Republican lawyer named Richard E. Wiley led the Federal Communications Commission as it approved a landmark regulation that restricted a company from owning both a newspaper and a broadcast station in the same city. On Monday the F.C.C. is expected to repeal that rule in more than 100 cities as part of the most significant overhaul of media regulations in a generation. The change would be the culmination of a long campaign by the nation's biggest media conglomerates, which are intent on entering new local markets and expanding in those where they already have a presence. And it would come despite objections from an array of politically liberal and conservative critics who fear broad consolidation in the news and entertainment businesses.

headline: Gripped By Manu Mania
summary: To Argentine sports fans, a Boca Juniors-River Plate soccer game is the equivalent of a Yankees-Red Sox matchup. Yet last Saturday, one day before this year's grudge match, the front pages of sports sections of the country's main newspapers focused on a basketball player who plays for a team nearly 6,000 miles away, in San Antonio. With the N.B.A. finals scheduled to start Wednesday, this soccer-obsessed nation is being swept by basketball fever and, more specifically, what is being called Manu Mania. Thanks to the playoff exploits of Manu Ginóbili, the San Antonio Spurs' gifted 25-year-old rookie guard, Argentina suddenly has a new hero, a new passion and new hopes.

headline: Martin's Deeds Back Up His Words
summary: If there were any images of the Nets in the 2002 N.B.A. finals, they were fleeting at best. On the last night of the series, though, Kenyon Martin left an indelible impression. His mother, Lydia Moore, always taught him: ''If you have something to say, don't be afraid to say it.''

headline: Only Thing Certain in Finals Is That Lakers Won't Repeat
summary: The National Basketball Association finals are back, revitalized and juiced up, loaded with suspense for the first time since Michael Jordan sank his famous jump shot against the Utah Jazz in 1998. Amid a backdrop of interesting story lines, the San Antonio Spurs, having survived three taxing series in the wild Western Conference, play host to the Nets, runaway winners in the middling East, on Wednesday in Game 1 at the SBC Center. There is Tony Parker's battle with his potential replacement, Jason Kidd; the first finals meeting between two former American Basketball Association teams; Stephen Jackson's chance to serve comeuppance to the Nets, who disowned him two years ago; and David Robinson's quest to end his storied career with a second championship.

headline: Duncan Has His Way as Nets Lose Theirs
summary: After Tim Duncan dunked over Aaron Williams with whiplash force four minutes into the fourth quarter tonight, he unleashed an uncharacteristic roar. The Nets, who had stormed to 10 straight victories in the Eastern Conference playoffs on the way to their second consecutive trip to the N.B.A. finals, had no response. Their emotional juggernaut, Kenyon Martin, was on the bench with four fouls. By then, Duncan, the Spurs' cool superstar, had given the Spurs a 14-point lead in Game 1. When Martin returned, Duncan drilled a 16-footer over him, punctuating his point.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 3 Companies Plan Package Of Calling Minutes
summary: SBC Communications, BellSouth and their mobile telephone joint venture, Cingular Wireless, plan to sell a package of calling minutes that for the first time could be used for both mobile and home phone calls. SBC and BellSouth, both leading providers of local phone service, are seeking to win back business from wireless carriers, including Cingular. SBC and BellSouth lost a combined 497,000 local lines in the first quarter as some customers started using cellphones, exclusively, to save money. The plan, called MinuteShare, is being tested in Texas and will be available later this year, SBC and BellSouth said yesterday. The alliance underlines phone companies' desire to attract customers in a shrinking market by linking products. Wireless companies like Cingular sell calling packages that include 900 minutes for as little as $39.99 a month. Under MinuteShare, a Cingular customer paying a fixed monthly fee for a certain number of minutes could use those minutes to make long-distance calls over the SBC or BellSouth networks, an SBC spokesman, Michael Coe, said. He declined to say how much the new call package would cost. SBC shares rose 35 cents, to $26.53. BellSouth shares fell 14 cents, to $26.89.

headline: Squabbling Nets Hoping They Will Improve Tonight
summary: After routing the Nets in Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals and deflating the drama of the series, the San Antonio Spurs were at ease today while some Nets showed signs of strain and questioned their coach's strategy. The Nets are 0-5 in N.B.A. finals games and do not expect to be swept again by a dominating big man. Tim Duncan had an M.V.P. game on Wednesday night -- 32 points, 20 rebounds 7 blocks and 6 assists -- after scoring only 8 points in the first half.

headline: Kidd Controls the Nets' First Finals Victory
summary: On second thought, the series is not over. On second glance, Jason Kidd and the Nets adjusted effectively to San Antonio's SBC Center and the presence of the 7-foot Tim Duncan.

headline: The Wait for Mutombo Is Worth It for the Nets
summary: About a month ago, Dikembe Mutombo began watching the San Antonio Spurs' playoff games religiously. He knew the Nets were surging, even as he rode the bench, and he sensed that it was San Antonio's year in the West. With his gaze set firmly on Tim Duncan, the league's most valuable player, Mutombo studied his footwork, his moves on the block, his tendencies on the perimeter and how the opposition defended him. Mutombo knew he would get his chance against Duncan if the Nets met the Spurs in the N.B.A. finals. Despite failing to remove his warm-ups in game after game after game, he just knew it.

headline: Nets Return Home Buoyed After Not Being Bullied
summary: Until Jason Kidd and Dikembe Mutombo restored hope that the Eastern Conference could play with the big bullies of the West, the San Antonio Spurs and the Los Angeles Lakers had collected nine consecutive victories in the N.B.A. finals as if they were taking lunch money. The Nets were responsible for five of those losses before Friday night's Game 2 in San Antonio, where they claimed the franchise's first finals victory.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Health Plans Force Workers To Pay More for Treatments After a decade of soaring spending on prescription drugs, employers and health plans are forcing their workers to pay more for most drugs and refusing payment for certain medicines that they reject as not essential. The shift comes as Congress considers a government-subsidized drug benefit for 40 million Medicare beneficiaries, and at a time when many plans have eased restrictions on hospital care and doctor visits. [Page A1.]

headline: Cable Is Confident of Internet Lead Over Phone Rivals
summary: The cable industry has grown up, and it has taken on a new swagger. The industry that started out with the transmission of television programs has matured into a broad-ranging provider of telecommunications, using digital technology to offer video-on-demand, phone service and, in particular, high-speed Internet connections.

headline: Martin Is Slowed by Flu In a Setback for the Nets
summary: The flu had drained him of his energy, stolen the quick burst from his first step, eliminated his power moves to the basket. So Kenyon Martin did his best to manufacture ferocity, but it kept coming out in strange and unproductive ways. Unable to blow by Malik Rose as he did throughout the first four games of the N.B.A. finals, Martin tried to bully past his opponent, swinging a vicious elbow at his chin. All it got the Nets' power forward was an offensive foul.

headline: Kidd Will Explore All of His Options
summary: Queen's ''We Are the Champions'' was blaring at an ear-splitting level, confetti was falling like snow at the SBC Center, the San Antonio Spurs were hugging and dancing and laughing, and Jason Kidd had a slight smirk on his face. Was he picturing himself wearing black and silver next June, jumping for joy alongside Tim Duncan?

headline: RUNNER-UP REPEAT
summary: The Spurs' championship party began in earnest tonight with 35.6 seconds left in Game 6 of the N.B.A. finals, when Kevin Willis checked into the game to replace David Robinson, the Admiral, and give him his due. Willis, the 40-year-old backup center who had never won a championship in 19 seasons, hugged Robinson, the 37-year-old retiring role model for a city and a franchise, and the SBC Center erupted in admiration.

headline: There's Lots of Blame To Share on the Nets
summary: The fluttering confetti fell like taunts on the Nets' hanging heads as they witnessed another championship celebration that was not for them. Crushed by the Spurs' 88-77 triumph Sunday in Game 6 of the N.B.A. finals, some Nets walked disgustedly off the SBC Center court into an uncertain future. The team flew back to New Jersey yesterday for a day of rest before confronting the pressing questions and potential changes -- involving the future of Jason Kidd; the assistant coach Eddie Jordan, who will interview with the 76ers and the Wizards this week; the chief executive Lou Lamoriello, whose contract expired yesterday; and Coach Byron Scott, who had one year left on his contract.

headline: Bush Names Lobbyist As Leader Of G.O.P.
summary: Over the past decade, Ed Gillespie, who was chosen today by President Bush to be chairman of the Republican National Committee through next year's election, has worn many hats, some of them simultaneously. Mr. Gillespie has been the party's spokesman, the manager of the 2000 Republican convention, a Congressional aide, a campaign strategist and consultant, an official on Mr. Bush's transition team, an outside adviser to the president, a political fund-raiser, a television pundit and, most recently, a lobbyist for big corporations and trade associations.

headline: Sports of The Times; Spurs Show Kidd What's Missing In New Jersey
summary: THIS city is still glowing from the excitement of winning the N.B.A. championship. The franchise won its second title since 1999, but that title was won during a lockout-shortened season. After Sunday's victory over the Nets, an usher proudly proclaimed, ''No asterisk on this one.'' The snapshot I will take from the finals was a scene at the SBC Center on Sunday night as time ran out and multicolored confetti poured from the rafters. Hard-driving soul music rocked the house and unadulterated celebrations broke out. The place was in an uproar. Fans danced and hugged in the aisles. On the court, Spurs players, team officials and family members celebrated.

headline: Union and Verizon at Odds on Focus of Talks
summary: Threatened with a strike in a month, Verizon Communications has a simple message for its unionized workers: Let's form a partnership so Verizon, one of the few unionized telecommunications companies, can compete in a fiercely competitive industry. But the president of Verizon's largest union said it was well-nigh impossible to take talk of a partnership seriously when management was battling unionization efforts at Verizon's wireless operations.

headline: Employers Seek To Shift Costs Of Drugs to U.S.
summary: The bills to provide drug benefits through Medicare that were passed by the House and the Senate last week offer some of the country's largest employers a long-sought prize: shifting at least some of their burden of soaring drug costs to the federal government. With billions of dollars at stake, those companies are lobbying hard to make sure that those gains survive in the final version of the law.

headline: As Kidds Visit Spurs, Nets Wait
summary: Tim Duncan, most valuable tour guide, will welcome Jason Kidd and his wife, Joumana, to San Antonio this afternoon. No doubt Duncan, the Spurs' star forward, will extol the virtues of Texas living while showing the Kidds around the homestead. He will most likely sing the praises of Gregg Popovich, the N.B.A.'s coach of the year, and pause by the twin Larry O'Brien trophies so Kidd can see his reflection, alongside Duncan's.

headline: Yahoo's Earnings Double As Revenue Sets a Record
summary: Profits more than doubled at Yahoo, the big Internet portal, in the second quarter as its revenue also grew briskly and even exceeded the record it set at the peak of the Internet boom. But those results were not enough to satisfy investors who have bid up Yahoo's shares by 28 percent over the last month.

headline: Sports of The Times; The Winners, but Not Yet Champions: The Nets
summary: There is no known nirvana in professional sports, no perfect place or team or coaching staff. There are only situations, good, bad or what the Nets formerly were, unbearably ugly. Here at the intersection of New Jersey roadways, Jason Kidd made the smart choice at the free-agent crossroads today, announcing he would spend the rest of his playing prime where he has just enjoyed the best years of his basketball life.

headline: Two Agencies Name Executives
summary: Two agencies have selected top creative executives. Tom Moudry was named executive creative director at Martin Williams Advertising in Minneapolis, succeeding Tom Kelly, who is leaving, the agency said. Mr. Moudry, 42, had been vice president and executive creative director at the Omnicom Group, working from the office of a client, SBC Communications in San Antonio. Martin Williams Advertising is part of Martin Williams, a unit of Omnicom.

headline: Some Bet the Future of Broadband Belongs to Regional Bells, Not Cable
summary: To Jim Hjartarson, the future of Internet access lies in telephone lines, not television cables. That is not a popular view these days. From the moment Mr. Hjartarson joined four fellow Canadians in 1998 to develop high-speed Internet equipment, their venture, Catena Networks, hitched its wagon to the regional Bell companies.

headline: EchoStar Deal Lets SBC Offer Satellite TV On Phone Bill
summary: In a move intended to allow it to compete more effectively with cable companies, SBC Communications, the nation's second-largest local phone company, announced a deal with EchoStar yesterday to offer satellite television service as part of a package of telecommunications services on a single bill. Qwest, the country's fourth-largest local phone company, announced separately that it was working with EchoStar, which is based in Littleton, Colo., to market satellite services in Colorado and Nebraska. Qwest also announced that it would sell DirecTV satellite television service in parts of Arizona and Washington State. But those agreements do not involve the same degree of integration and customer support as the SBC-EchoStar agreement.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 U.S. Troops Land in Liberia As Fighting Engulfs Capital United States marines arrived to protect the American Embassy and evacuate foreigners from the Liberian capital of Monrovia as fighting raged and as residents lay bodies of their loved ones at the shuttered gate to the embassy. By day's end, reports from hospitals and clinics suggested that roughly 90 Liberians had been killed and more than 360 had been wounded. A1 The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, joined West African leaders in imploring the Bush administration to send peacekeepers to Liberia. Administration officials resisted, insisting that Liberia's neighbors take the lead in stabilizing the country, and calling on rebels and the government of President G. Charles Taylor to respect a cease-fire agreement. A3

headline: SBC Communications Is Target of Antitrust Suit
summary: Four California companies that sell broadband Internet service over telephone lines filed an antitrust complaint yesterday against SBC Communications, the Baby Bell that controls the lines to customers. The suit, filed in federal court in Los Angeles, asserts that SBC squeezes competitors that lease its lines out of the market. It does so, the suit charges, by bundling offerings for the high-speed service, known as D.S.L., for digital subscriber line, with equipment like free modems and by engaging in actions intended to discourage customers from switching to independent vendors, like delays in filling change orders.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Net Rises 21% at Viacom; Company to Pay Dividend Viacom posted a 21 percent increase in second-quarter profit, buoyed by a strong comeback in advertising. The company also said that it would pay a quarterly dividend of 6 cents a share beginning Oct. 1. The announcement of a dividend comes at a time when taxes on corporate dividends have been reduced, prompting some big companies to offer one. [Page C4.]

headline: MCI FACES INQUIRY FOR FRAUD ON FEES FOR LONG DISTANCE
summary: Federal prosecutors have opened an investigation in the United States and Canada into accusations that MCI, the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier, defrauded other telephone companies of at least hundreds of millions of dollars over nearly a decade, people involved in the inquiry said. The central element of MCI's scheme, people involved in the inquiry said, consisted of disguising long-distance calls as local calls to avoid paying special access tariffs to local carriers across the country. Those tariffs are the largest single source of MCI's costs for carrying calls and data transmissions.

headline: AT&T to Offer New Allegation In MCI Inquiry
summary: AT&T will offer evidence that domestic telephone traffic diverted by MCI through Canada to avoid tariffs included calls that were placed by the State Department and other government agencies, a senior executive at AT&T said today. The executive said the evidence was to be formally disclosed to government investigators and a bankruptcy court in Manhattan on Monday.

headline: MCI's Competitors Are Quick to Make Use of Federal Inquiry
summary: MCI came under attack today from rival phone companies, which seized on the news that it is the focus of a criminal investigation. One competitor criticized MCI in bankruptcy court, another challenged its government business and a third made public letters suggesting that MCI's new management team had been aware for some time of the problems at the center of the inquiry. MCI, whose lawyers met today with federal investigators, said it intended to conduct an internal inquiry into accusations that it improperly diverted phone traffic to avoid paying access fees on long-distance calls to other companies.

headline: The Line Between Cost Management and Deceit
summary: No one in the phone industry is surprised that MCI wanted to cut the access payments that it makes to local phone companies like SBC Communications, Verizon and BellSouth to complete its customers' calls. The question is whether MCI engaged in tactics that crossed the line between deft cost management and fraud. MCI faces accusations that it used at least two schemes to reduce its access charges.

headline: Accusations Against MCI Could Drive Clients Away
summary: Whether true or not, accusations that MCI used fraudulent methods to reduce the access charges it pays to other phone companies could make it harder for the company to keep some of its current customers and to sign up new ones, according to industry consultants. The accusations are raising new questions about the reliability of the financial data and projections that MCI is giving to creditors and to the federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan overseeing its reorganization.

headline: Verizon and Unions Meet With Mediator
summary: Verizon and its labor unions met yesterday with a top federal mediator in an effort to avoid a strike this weekend that could affect local and long-distance telephone service in 13 New England and Middle Atlantic States and the District of Columbia. The meeting, which was held in Washington at the mediator's request, came hours after Verizon announced its second-quarter earnings, getting mixed reviews from Wall Street. Verizon, the country's largest local telephone company, reported continued erosion of its core local phone service, but surprised investors by delivering unexpectedly strong growth in the brutally competitive wireless business, which is not unionized.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cingular-NextWave Deal
summary: Cingular Wireless agreed to buy some wireless-spectrum licenses from the bankrupt NextWave Telecom for about $1.4 billion, people close to the matter said. The sale, which is subject to approval by a federal bankruptcy court and the Federal Communications Commission, would be NextWave's first transaction since it won a Supreme Court battle in January over ownership of the licenses. Cingular, based in Atlanta, is owned by SBC Communications and the BellSouth Corporation. Michael Wack, senior vice president at NextWave, and a Cingular spokeswoman, Jennifer Bowcock, declined to comment. Nextwave, based in Greenwich, Conn., won the licenses in a 1996 auction but filed for bankruptcy protection in 1998.

headline: Cable or Satellite? Please Stay Tuned
summary: MICHAEL G. MANSOUR, a 28-year-old Manhattan financial professional, used to watch television the way most people do. For his favorite shows, like ''The Sopranos,'' he would make a point of being home when they were scheduled. If the show was something he more or less liked, he would put up with the commercials. If he felt like watching a movie, he went to the video store. ''Basically, I would try to remember my shows and flip to them if I could remember,'' he recalled this week.

headline: Efforts to Stop Music Swapping Draw More Fire
summary: The recording industry's stepped-up pursuit of online music swappers faced two new challenges yesterday, as SBC Communications questioned the constitutionality of the industry's tactics in a lawsuit and Senator Norm Coleman opened an inquiry on whether the anti-piracy campaign is violating the privacy rights of innocent people. ''If you're taking someone else's property, that's wrong, that's stealing,'' Senator Coleman, Republican of Minnesota and chairman of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, said in a telephone interview. ''But in this country we don't cut off people's hands when they steal. One question I have is whether the penalty here fits the crime.''

headline: Plan to Move More Inmates Out of State Draws Criticism in Connecticut
summary: Since Connecticut began moving some of its convicts to out-of-state prisons four years ago to ease overcrowding and save money, it has paid a steep price in lawsuit settlements and stinging criticism over two prisoners who came home in body bags. The program has fared better in the last few years, and does better still in the budget lawmakers approved this week. Tucked into the fine print of the budget, which cleared the State Senate last night, is a plan to quintuple the number of prisoners shipped to other states.

headline: Credibility of Witness Is Challenged in MCI Inquiry
summary: A Minnesota telephone company at the center of the most recent criminal inquiry into MCI today attacked the credibility of a whistle-blower who may be the most important witness in the case. The company, Onvoy Inc. of St. Louis Park, Minn., is under investigation by federal authorities after accusations that it took part in a conspiracy with MCI to improperly avoid paying access fees owed to other phone companies.

headline: MCI Disputes Fraud Claim By AT&T
summary: Beginning an aggressive counterattack on its rivals, MCI said today that AT&T had falsely accused it of defrauding AT&T by diverting domestic phone calls through Canada. In the first formal response to its accusers -- three other telephone companies and a former employee -- MCI said its internal inquiry preliminarily revealed no evidence that it had improperly redirected telephone traffic to reduce the access fees it pays to local phone companies to complete long-distance calls.

headline: Shares Are Mostly Higher, Led by Telecommunications
summary: Stocks advanced yesterday, led by telecommunications shares. Qwest Communications International said that it was talking to several potential bidders for its mobile-telephone network, encouraging investors that phone shares would rally. Verizon Communications climbed as it resumed talks with unions representing 78,000 employees after making ''significant progress'' in contract negotiations.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cingular and Nextwave Sign Deal
summary: Cingular, a leading wireless phone company, has signed an agreement to buy wireless licenses for 34 markets from NextWave Telecom for $1.4 billion, the companies said yesterday. The sale, representing about one-fifth of NextWave's spectrum licenses, is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission and the federal bankruptcy court that is overseeing NextWave's reorganization. Other companies have the right to bid a higher price. NextWave will maintain a presence in 20 of the 34 markets. The licenses would give Cingular, a joint venture of BellSouth and SBC, room to grow in some of the most lucrative urban markets, including Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Houston, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington. In addition, the deal will give entry into a handful of other markets, including El Paso, Portland, Ore., and Salt Lake City. Executives of NextWave, which owns licenses in 95 of the largest markets nationwide, said the money would be used to pay the debt owed the F.C.C. and to help finance future ventures as it tries to emerge from bankruptcy protection. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Cisco's Profit Climbs a Bit, But Sales Slowed in Quarter Cisco Systems reported a higher profit but slightly lower revenue for its fiscal fourth quarter as it continued to weather the downturn in corporate technology spending. Its president and chief executive, John T. Chambers, said that corporate spending remained constrained and that Cisco's gains were due more to internal efforts and cost-cutting than to an improving sales environment. After declining 40 cents, to $18.86, shares of Cisco fell sharply after hours. [Page C5.]

headline: SBC to Offer Wi-Fi Access at 6,000 Spots
summary: SBC Communications is expected to announce today plans to provide wireless Internet access at 6,000 hotels, airports, convention centers, restaurants and other public locations. The initiative draws SBC into an intensifying competition with start-ups and other telecommunications giants looking to deploy wireless Internet ''hot spots.'' SBC, which is based in San Antonio, says it will deploy its network over the next three years at locations mostly in its 13-state territory, which includes Texas, California, and Connecticut. Some service will be available by the end of the year, the company said, but SBC has not disclosed how much it will charge users for network access.

headline: A Marriage, and Divorce, of Convenience at Verizon
summary: Negotiations between Verizon Communications and its two main unions appeared to grow more thorny yesterday, with a settlement now unlikely in the next few days. But while the company and its workers currently find themselves on opposite sides of the bargaining table, they have often found themselves fighting on the same side, lobbying politicians and petitioning regulators.

headline: Internet Providers Question Subpoenas to Stop File Swapping
summary: Arguing that the record industry is trying to force its members to become the ''police of the Internet,'' a group representing over 100 Internet service providers plans to deliver a letter to the industry's trade association today. The letter asks a series of pointed questions about plans to sue people suspected of illegally trading music files online. The letter from NetCoalition is the latest objection from Internet service providers to a flood of subpoenas from the record industry seeking the identities of Internet subscribers suspected of swapping files.

headline: Jostling for the Wi-Fi Lead in a Crowded Field
summary: Is there any advantage in having been ahead of the crowd now that just about every telecommunications company is rushing into the Wi-Fi wireless world? Wayport, a pioneer in installing high-speed Internet access in hotels and airports, is about to find out. Wayport, based in Austin, Tex., is a name known to thousands of laptop-toting business travelers. It started providing wireless Internet connections in 2000 with the popular Wi-Fi networking standard in airports including Dallas-Fort Worth, Seattle, and San Jose, Calif. Even earlier, Wayport had placed wired broadband connections in hotels around the country, which it now often complements with Wi-Fi in common areas.

headline: U.S. Details Ground Rules For Baby Bells and Rivals
summary: The Federal Communications Commission today detailed the rules the Baby Bells and their rivals must follow in using existing and future telecommunications networks. The rules elaborate on a contentious F.C.C. decision six months ago that local telephone companies generally must share older equipment for voice transmission at wholesale rates but not newer technology dedicated to high-speed data.

headline: U.S. DENIES SBC ON LONG-DISTANCE REQUEST
summary: SBC Communications has failed to win Justice Department support for its bids to enter the $7 billion market for long-distance service in four states. SBC applied last month for long-distance approval in Illinois, Indiana, Ohio and Wisconsin, where it has 15 million local-phone lines, or 27 percent of its total lines. The Justice Department said yesterday in its decision that SBC had issued inaccurate bills to carriers who buy wholesale local services on its network. The Federal Communications Commission, which can rule on the application independently of the Justice Department's recommendation, has until Oct. 15 to make its decision.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Demand Is Up Sharply For Stomach Operations Doctors and hospitals across the country are scrambling to satisfy the booming demand for surgery that shrinks the stomachs of severely obese people. Dozens of hospitals are adding operating suites for the procedure, called bariatric surgery. The procedures surged more than 40 percent last year, to 80,000. Spending for the operation is approaching $3 billion a year, about $25,000 for each procedure. [Page A1.]

headline: Local Phone Companies Challenge F.C.C. Rules
summary: SBC Communications and other local telephone companies asked a court yesterday to overturn new federal rules that give states more authority to decide if the phone companies must lease network components to rivals at discounts. SBC, the BellSouth Corporation, Qwest Communications International and the United States Telecom Association, a trade group that represents local companies, filed their request with the United States Court of Appeals in Washington, a week after the Federal Communications Commission issued the final version of the rules.

headline: Verizon's Pact Seen as Critical To Its Industry
summary: Verizon's unions were quite happy with the settlement they reached Thursday night with the company, but some analysts contend that the deal could make it harder for the nation's large telephone service providers to face increasing threats to their business from the cable industry and a variety of upstarts. The settlement comes as companies in the traditional local telephone industry, like Verizon, SBC Communications and Bell South, are moving from the effective monopoly control over direct access to consumers and business they long enjoyed to a much more challenging situation contending with powerful cable companies like Cox and Comcast that are offering rival data and voice services through their own pipes into homes and offices.

headline: Criticism Arises Over the Way Calling Plans Advertise Rates
summary: A telemarketer talked to Jeff Kane in April about an alluring offer to reduce his monthly phone bill. The pitch was for an unlimited calling plan that would let him pay a flat rate for all local and long-distance calls. Mr. Kane, tired of watching his minutes on the phone, snatched up the offer. Now he is keeping close watch on something else: his phone bill. He said he was assured that he would pay $49.99 for the Neighborhood plan from MCI. But with taxes and surcharges included, the bills have been around $65.

headline: Day in Court For Bid to End WorldCom's Bankruptcy
summary: Has WorldCom devised an acceptable plan to emerge from the largest bankruptcy on record as a healthy competitor in the struggling telecommunications industry? To the dismay of competitors who want the company liquidated, most of its creditors have voted yes.

headline: People
summary: * Mike Teasdale, who is in charge of planning at AMV BBDO, London, part of BBDO Worldwide, was named vice president and executive planning director at the BBDO Atlanta office, responsible for planning on the office's large Cingular Wireless account. BBDO is part of the Omnicom Group and Cingular is owned by BellSouth and SBC Communications.

headline: WorldCom Hearing Starts, Then Stops for More Talks
summary: Soon after a hearing began yesterday on whether WorldCom has come up with a viable and fair plan to emerge from bankruptcy protection, lawyers for the company and a group of creditors that has been among the plan's most vocal critics asked for more time to negotiate. Judge Arthur J. Gonzalez of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan said the negotiators could have last night to try to settle their differences. A settlement would pave the way to quicker approval of a plan, shaving time from a trial that some lawyers expect to last for more than six weeks and ultimately allowing WorldCom to emerge from bankruptcy protection sooner.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cingular Fined $12.1 Million By Regulator
summary: Cingular Wireless has been fined $12.1 million by California's utility regulator after it ruled that the company had provided inadequate service and violated state law. From January 2000 to May 2002, Cingular did not allow new users a grace period to cancel service without paying contract-termination fees as high as $550, the state agency, the California Public Utilities Commission, said in a decision posted on its Web site yesterday. The company also did not tell users about problems with its wireless network in 2001, the decision said. A spokesman for Cingular, a joint venture of SBC Communications and BellSouth based in Atlanta, did not immediately respond to a call for comment. Earlier yesterday, Cingular and 22 other United States cellular companies adopted voluntary customer rights standards, trying to derail tougher rules proposed by the California commission. The commission also ordered Cingular to reimburse customers who paid the contract-termination fee during the period.

headline: Cellphones That Reach Alter Egos
summary: ON Oct. 1, Cingular will begin selling a unique $40 cellphone cradle called the FastForward. What it does can be described by a single sentence: whenever you slip your cellphone into it, the FastForward automatically routes incoming cell calls to your home or office phone. The implications of this simple idea, though, constitute a much broader topic. In fact, you could write a whole column on it.

headline: SBC Won't Name Names in File-Sharing Cases
summary: As the recording industry pursues its lawsuits against those it says are digital music pirates, SBC Communications has emerged as the only major Internet service provider that has so far refused to identify computer users whom the industry suspects of copyright infringement. Since early July, major high-speed Internet providers -- including BellSouth, Comcast, EarthLink, Time Warner Cable and Verizon -- have complied with more than 1,000 subpoenas from the record industry's lobbying arm, the Recording Industry Association of America, to turn over the names of their customers who are otherwise known only by the murky screen names and numeric Internet Protocol addresses used in cyberspace.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Iraqis Are Losing Patience As Postwar Worries Grow Questions over whether the United States can transform Iraq are being asked with increasing frequency. Grim statistics confirm to Iraqis that they have entered what they see as a terrifyingly lawless twilight zone. While the Americans counsel patience, the Iraqis say they could follow that advice if someone explained the postwar plan in a coherent way. A1 At the site of a memorial museum dedicated to the 5,000 people who lost their lives in a 1988 chemical attack, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said it was a reminder of why the United States went to war. A10

headline: In Court, Verizon Challenges Music Industry's Subpoenas
summary: As Congress intensifies its scrutiny of the special subpoenas that the recording industry is using to track down and sue people who share music over the Internet, a federal appeals court panel questioned today whether legislators had intended the subpoenas to be used in such a way. But the three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia also had tough questions for Verizon, which is challenging the record industry's interpretation of a 1998 law that allows copyright holders to force Internet service providers to identify customers suspected of copyright infringement.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Airwaves Sale Advances
summary: Cingular Wireless's planned $1.4 billion purchase of airwaves from NextWave Telecom has moved closer to completion. Other cellphone providers had until noon on Monday to submit bids. None were made, Michael Wack, a NextWave senior vice president, said in a telephone interview. The licenses cover 83 million potential customers in 34 markets. NextWave, which is under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, would receive $666 million. The transaction is subject to the approval of the Federal Communications Commission and Judge Adlai S. Hardin Jr. of Federal Bankruptcy Court in White Plains; he will hold a hearing on the matter on Sept. 25. Cingular, based in Atlanta, is a joint venture of SBC Communications and the BellSouth Corporation.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
summary: BANK ONE CORP., Chicago, said it had agreed to buy some real estate operations from a unit of General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn. Terms were not disclosed. LEHMAN BROTHERS HOLDINGS INC., New York, the fourth-biggest securities firm by capital, agreed to buy the Crossroads Group, Dallas, a private equity fund manager. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Patricia Kim, Craig Niemeyer
summary: Dr. Patricia Annette Kim, a daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Jai Bin Kim of Lewisburg, Pa., was married in San Francisco yesterday to Craig Anthony Niemeyer, the son of Carolyn Burns Weiss of Bacalar, Quintana Roo, Mexico, and Joel A. Niemeyer of Vallejo, Calif. The Rev. Rachel Rivers performed the ceremony at the Swedenborgian Church. Dr. Niemeyer, 37, is an interventional radiologist who practices at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in Santa Clara, Calif. She graduated from Princeton and received her medical degree from the University of Pennsylvania. Her father is a professor and the former chairman of the civil engineering department at Bucknell University in Lewisburg.

headline: Verizon Reduces Profit Forecast As Demand Falls and Costs Rise
summary: Verizon Communications Inc. reduced its 2003 profit forecast yesterday on disappointing demand from business customers and increased costs from a new labor agreement. Profit will be $2.56 to $2.60 a share, excluding certain costs and gains, Verizon said, compared with an earlier forecast of as much as $2.80. Annual sales will be unchanged to up 2 percent as revenue from corporate customers fell below expectations.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
summary: UNIONBANCAL CORP., -- San Francisco, agreed to acquire Business Bank of California from Business Bancorp, San Rafael, Calif., for an amount to be determined, but falling to $117.7 million to $134.9 million, to add branches in the Bay Area. SBC COMMUNICATIONS INC., -- San Antonio, the nation's second largest local telephone company, said it would make a one-time payment of 10 cents a share in addition to its quarterly dividend of 28.25 cents, a share, to be paid on Nov. 3 to shareholders of record on Oct. 10.

headline: Your Own Affair, More (VCR) or Less (MP3)
summary: THE Internal Revenue Service is not used to hearing ''no.'' In 1998, it was investigating Kent Hovind, an evangelist and Internet radio host in Pensacola, Fla., and his wife, Jo Delia. Mr. Hovind said he had not filed a federal tax return since the early 1970's. Naturally, that got the agency's attention.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC To Pay $1.35 Million Penalty
summary: SBC Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to pay a $1.35 million penalty to resolve an investigation into whether the company sold long-distance service in states where it was not yet permitted. Under a settlement with the Federal Communications Commission, SBC will revise training and compliance programs and alter some computer systems, the F.C.C. said in a statement. SBC, based in San Antonio, which will make the payment to the Treasury, did not admit any violation or liability as part of the agreement. SBC, which said the incidents were inadvertent, had five types of potential violations, like providing long-distance connections in California for some customers before receiving F.C.C. approval last December. In October 2002, the F.C.C. fined the company $6 million for not giving rivals access to its local network as required in five Midwest states. Shares of SBC rose 35 cents, to $22.60.

headline: Yahoo's Resurgent Profit Is Led by Strong Advertising
summary: When Terry S. Semel took over as chief executive of Yahoo two years ago, a crucial part of his turnaround plan was to diversify the company, the big Internet portal, away from online advertising and into other services that relied on paying users. The turnaround is going quite nicely. Yesterday, Yahoo said that its third-quarter profit more than doubled. But the biggest and the fastest-growing driver of revenue and profit has been advertising, not fees.

headline: Keeping Tabs on Baby And Her Toasty Blanket
summary: Chilly fall weather often means a good night's sleep for adults, but the seasonal effect on an infant's room may keep some new parents awake and obsessing. To reduce the need for trips down the hall to check on climate conditions in the nursery, Philips Electronics has come up with its SBC SC769 Read-and-Rest Easy baby monitor, which has a built-in room thermometer and temperature display. The parental half of the Read-and-Rest Easy monitor system features an L.C.D. screen showing the room temperature as recorded by the baby's unit. With a range of 600 feet, parents can putter about the house with the monitor in tow while still listening in on the child. The parental unit displays the monitor's signal strength, battery-charge status and, by means of lights that work in sync with the speaker, the level of noise in the baby's room -- so that a hungry child can be both heard and seen.

headline: Cellphone Deals Sweeten in Face Of New Rule on Keeping Number
summary: Bet Sirianni is the subject of an intensifying courtship. The overtures -- like the recent offer for a free second cellular phone -- may win her over to a longer-term relationship. Her mobile phone service provider, AT&T Wireless, wants her to commit to an additional two years on her contract. ''I'm thinking about it,'' Ms. Sirianni, a 40-year-old corporate art director in San Francisco, said of the free phone proposal. ''I may give it to my son.''

headline: Sports Briefing
summary: HOCKEY Hatcher Is Out 4 to 6 Months Detroit Red Wings defenseman Derian Hatcher will miss four to six months after tearing a ligament in his right knee in a 3-2 victory against Vancouver on Thursday. The Red Wings hope he will be able to return in time for the playoffs, which begin in April. Hatcher was the runner-up in voting last season for the Norris Trophy, awarded to the N.H.L.'s top defenseman.

headline: AT&T's and SBC's Results Aren't Enough for Wall St.
summary: Reflecting continued turmoil in the telecommunications industry, two giant phone companies reported third-quarter earnings yesterday that disappointed investors. AT&T, the largest long-distance telephone company, reported results that in fact exceeded Wall Street estimates.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: New Questions Are Raised About Halliburton Pricing The head of an Iraqi oil agency said that his group has been trucking in gasoline and other needed fuels to Iraq for considerably less money than Halliburton, which has so far received more than $700 million from the Army Corps of Engineers to stave off shortages. Separately, a report by the Congressional Research Service, the nonpartisan public policy research arm of Congress, warned that the Corps of Engineers might be paying too much to import fuel. [Page C9.]

headline: Communications Shares Lead 30-Point Slide in the Dow
summary: The Dow Jones industrial average declined yesterday, led by AT&T after it said that earnings slid 13 percent and that it had fired four workers for understating costs. SBC Communications dropped as profit fell short of estimates. Semiconductor shares rose after Texas Instruments, whose chips run half the mobile phones sold last year, had better-than-expected profit and predicted that results this period would exceed analysts' forecasts.

headline: Corrections
summary: An article in Business Day yesterday about third-quarter earnings for AT&T and SBC Communications misstated AT&T's operating profit for the period a year ago. It was $525 million, not $458 million.

headline: It Isn't Just the Peddlers of Pills: Big Companies Add to Spam Flow
summary: Ever wonder how a certain company sending unsolicited e-mail messages got your address? Michael Rathbun, the director of policy enforcement at Allegiance Telecom, an Internet service provider in Dallas, says he thinks he has much of the answer.

headline: BellSouth Said to Halt Talks With AT&T
summary: BellSouth called off preliminary merger talks with the AT&T Corporation late yesterday, executives close to the talks said. The two companies, which have been in on-and-off negotiations for almost three years, ended their latest round of discussions yesterday when F. Duane Ackerman, BellSouth's chairman and chief executive, called David W. Dorman, AT&T's chairman and chief executive, and told him that he was not prepared to proceed, the executives said.

headline: Cisco's Strong Profit Propels Nasdaq to 22-Month High
summary: Stocks rose yesterday, led by technology companies, as Cisco Systems reported a record quarterly profit and the most sales in almost three years. The Nasdaq composite index closed at its highest in 22 months. ''This is going to be a very positive sign,'' said Tim Leach, who helps oversee $140 billion at Wells Fargo Private Client Services in San Francisco. ''If technology is recovering, it says a lot of good things about the market in general.''

headline: Forecasts of an ad blitz by wireless services providers ahead of a key rule change may prove wrong.
summary: CONSUMERS being barraged by a relentless flood of pitches from the giant wireless service providers are bracing for an additional onslaught, to be unleashed as a result of rules taking effect Nov. 24 that allow consumers to keep their cellphone numbers when they change carriers within the same calling area. Or not.

headline: Spurs' Visit Recalls One Made by Kidd
summary: Rod Thorn dreaded the thought of this game. Jason Kidd pondered whether he would be booed during the introductions. The Nets must have wondered whether they would be blown out or merely beaten. At several points during this past summer, Thorn believed that Kidd, the Nets' franchise point guard, would be coming back to Continental Arena on Wednesday night as a visitor with the San Antonio Spurs.

headline: Charles Brown, 82, Former AT&T Chief, Dies
summary: Charles L. Brown, the former chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, who agreed to the historic breakup of the Bell system, died yesterday in Richmond, Va. He was 82 and had lived in Princeton, N.J., since 1975. Mr. Brown, a soft-spoken and reserved executive who preferred to be called Charlie, decided in 1982 to settle the government's long-running antitrust case against AT&T by agreeing to dismantle the company, which provided phone service to the entire nation and had roots stretching to 1887, when Alexander Graham Bell founded the Bell Telephone Company.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC To Sell Internet Calling Service To Businesses
summary: SBC Communications Inc., the second-largest local-telephone company, is selling Internet-based calling and data services to businesses nationwide in an effort to stem declines in revenue. The service, which uses voice-over-Internet-protocol technology to let users make calls from personal computers, is available in 18 cities, SBC, which is based in San Antonio, said in a statement. Such calling is unregulated and can be less expensive for carriers and customers. SBC said its new service included local and long distance and would extend to the markets of other regional-phone companies by year's end.

headline: Sooners Leave No Doubt
summary: OKLAHOMA 56 TEXAS TECH 25 For the first time in a month, an Oklahoma opponent looked as if it had a hint of a chance Saturday. Texas Tech trailed by only 17 points in the fourth quarter, which is nip-and-tuck business for the No. 1-ranked Sooners.

headline: Cingular Is in Front in Promoting Portability
summary: Cingular Wireless may be the only cellphone service provider addressing local number portability in any significant way in its advertising this week. In a television, radio, print and online campaign that began yesterday, Cingular discusses number portability as well as the minutes-rollover service that it has been selling for some months.

headline: Opening Pandora's Flip Phone
summary: The mobile telephone business is one of the most competitive sectors in the American economy. It is an arena of brutal marketing wars, aggressive price competition and heated technological one-upmanship. The battles will become more intense as federal rules go into effect today allowing customers to keep their cellphone numbers when they move from one wireless carrier to another. With this new freedom, tens of millions of consumers are expected to switch companies, but what is less certain is the answer to a multibillion dollar question: Will the chaos created by the new rules prove fatal to weaker companies and lead to industry consolidation?

headline: The Bells Struggle to Survive A Changing Telephone Game
summary: When the United States telecommunications industry imploded a few years ago, with upstart carriers disappearing by the dozens and investments vanishing by the billions, it looked as if the regional Bell companies had won the telecom wars. But it is clear now that the Bells merely survived the first wave of what may be decades of difficulties. In the 1990's, new companies tried (and generally failed) to beat the Bells at their own local telephone game. Now, the local communications game itself is changing -- and not in the Bells' favor.

headline: MCI Tries for a Comeback
summary: Welcome back MCI? It was taken over in 1999 by WorldCom, became tangled in a historic accounting fraud and was restructured in bankruptcy. Now, MCI is looking for a 2004 that is calm by comparison. But MCI, the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier, after AT&T, faces a tough challenge in rebuilding profits as revenue from its long-distance telephone business erodes. It would not surprise many analysts if MCI once again disappeared as an independent entity before the year is over. SBC Communications, Verizon and BellSouth are seen as potential acquirers.

headline: Checking Your Bill for a New Charge Called 'Oops'
summary: EVERY few years, economists identify another mutant variation of inflation to keep them awake at night. In the 1980's, it was stagflation. Three years ago, it was deflation. And now, meet the economic specter of the new millennium: stealth inflation. That's when phone companies and just about anybody else who sends you a bill manages to extract more money from you without actually raising their rates.

headline: Market Place; It was the summer of 2001. Here's how one analyst improperly changed his story on SBC's earnings.
summary: In the summer of 2001, the once-lofty stock price of SBC Communications was coming down, but the company still appeared strong. On July 25, it issued its second-quarter earnings report, boasting that ''disciplined financial management'' had driven its earnings higher despite the recession. Its stock rose 6.3 percent that day as investors took heart.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: UAL Nears Deal for Money To Leave Bankruptcy United Airlines, which filed for bankruptcy protection a year ago, is close to securing $2 billion in exit financing. United also plans to resubmit its application for federal loan guarantees as soon as next week, even though it has not resolved financing issues involving its employee pension plans, the single biggest stumbling block to emerging from bankruptcy. [Page C9.]

headline: Dow Closes Above 10,000 for First Time in 18 Months
summary: The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 10,000 yesterday for the first time in more than 18 months, adding its own ratification to this year's economic rebound. The Dow, which briefly pierced the 10,000 barrier in trading on Tuesday, rose 86.30 points yesterday, to 10,008.16, a high for the year. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also reached a high, while the Nasdaq composite index is crawling back toward 2,000.

headline: And You Thought Pension Funds Were Scary
summary: UNDERFUNDED pension plans rank high on investors' fright lists, but now comes another specter: post-employment health plans. At some major companies, they are in even more dire shape than pensions. Only an estimated 5 percent of American companies offer such health plans, according to the Labor Department. But many that do, like Ford Motor, I.B.M., and Merck, are large companies whose stocks are widely held by investors.

headline: Phone Service Over Internet Revives Talk Of Regulation
summary: Politicians have worked hard to keep access to Internet connections and many forms of Internet communication free from regulation and taxation. But the debate over how government treats the Internet is likely to reach a new level of intensity now that Internet technology is colliding with one of the nation's most lucrative businesses, telephone service. Last week AT&T and Time Warner Cable announced that they intended to make Internet-based phone service available to millions of consumers next year, allowing those consumers to bypass traditional phone companies. Those moves signaled the start of a technological shift that could change one of the biggest and most important industries in the American economy. Central to that shift is whether and how Internet phone service should be regulated, a question that the Federal Communications Commission started to explore in hearings two weeks ago.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC Signs Equipment Deal With Alcatel
summary: SBC Communications said yesterday that it had reached a four-year deal with Alcatel for it to supply equipment for SBC's much-awaited push to build high-speed fiber optic connections to homes and offices. Beginning in June, SBC evaluated proposals from 20 companies before deciding on Alcatel, a company spokesman, Jason Hillery, said. Alcatel was among the favorites because SBC had already used Alcatel equipment to outfit a San Francisco business and residential complex with what is known as fiber to the premises, or F.T.T.P. SBC, BellSouth and Verizon Communications say F.T.T.P. will counter the growing threat from the nation's top five cable companies, which within the last year began complementing their cable TV and broadband services with local and long-distance dialing over an Internet connection.

headline: A Voice in the Calling Wilderness
summary: MAYBE you have had the fantasy while sitting at home for an entire afternoon and waiting for a 10-minute visit from the phone company to install a new telephone line. Or maybe the dream has come to you while were you on hold, once again, hoping to resolve the latest billing mix-up caused by Verizon, SBC or whichever local phone company dominates your market. For me, it began when my family moved into a new apartment this year and Verizon informed us that we would need to wait two weeks for a working phone line. Once that service began, we would have to pay about $50 a month even though we wanted to make only local phone calls on the line. Thinking we were without any better options given the dodgy quality of mobile phones, we grudgingly said yes.

headline: The Competitors; A Game of Phone Catch-Up on the Net
summary: THE big telephone companies are scrambling to catch up with upstart competitors in the race to provide low-cost telephone service over the Internet. They may be late to the game, but they say their services will offer better voice quality -- a claim questioned by the smaller operators and industry analysts. The larger companies' system, known as voice over Internet protocol, or VoIP, transforms a standard phone call into a series of packets that are streamed across the Internet like any other piece of digital information, and later reassembled.

headline: Markets & Investing; The Bounceback Year
summary: IT was the year that almost every stock went up and volatility plunged. Small stocks had their best year ever and some stars of the bubble era made impressive comebacks. But can such good fortune continue? The rise of the stock market began well before most economic forecasters saw any sign of an end to the business doldrums that had depressed both spirits and economic growth since the bubble burst in the spring of 2000.

headline: A Debate on Web Phone Service
summary: Charles Davidson, a self-proclaimed gadget freak in Tallahassee, Fla., began using Internet-based telephone service last week. He can call anyone -- not just the other 100,000 pioneers around the nation using such service, but any of the millions of people who use conventional telephones, like his parents in Elizabethton, Tenn. But Mr. Davidson is more than an adventuresome consumer. As a member of the Florida Public Service Commission, he is a regulator who is eager to see Internet telephone service spread because he predicts it can make the nation's phone services less expensive and richer in features.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint PCS Adds Customers
summary: The Sprint Corporation's PCS Group, a leading cellphone company, added 390,000 subscribers in the fourth quarter, defying some analysts' expectations that a new federal rule would hurt it. The monthly rate of customer defections was 2.7 percent, Sprint said, the same as in the third quarter, when PCS added 184,000 customers. Beginning Nov. 24, the Federal Communications Commission required cellphone companies to let customers keep their phone numbers when switching companies. The chief executive of the BellSouth Corporation, F. Duane Ackerman, said yesterday that Cingular Wireless, a joint venture of BellSouth and SBC Communications, also experienced less switching than forecast. Sprint plans to report full results on Feb. 3.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Supreme Court Rejects W WorldCom Appeal
summary: The United States Supreme Court rejected an appeal yesterday by WorldCom in a dispute with SBC Communications over rules for letting competitors connect into local-phone markets. WorldCom and Wisconsin regulators had sought to reinstate the state's rule for reaching network-connection agreements. A federal appeals court threw out the state rule, saying federal law pre-empted it. The 1996 Telecommunications Act requires the former Bell regional phone companies to open their markets to competition by leasing network components to new competitors. Under the law, leasing plans are reached by negotiation or arbitration and then must be approved by state regulators, with a possible federal court appeal. WorldCom said Wisconsin's procedure would let competitors enter the market sooner.

headline: Justices Give Regional Bells Some Shield on Antitrust Suits
summary: The Supreme Court ruled yesterday that Verizon Communications and other local telephone service providers could not be sued by consumers on antitrust grounds under a federal law requiring the companies to give competitors access to local networks. Under provisions of the law, successful damage claims are tripled, and the ruling yesterday protects the telecommunications companies from a risk of millions of dollars in damages.

headline: Chicago's Financial Center Could Lose Its Last Pillar
summary: When J.P. Morgan Chase acquires Bank One, probably sometime later this year, the city of Chicago seems all but certain to lose its last major banking headquarters. Indeed, people here are already lamenting the deal as one more step toward the demise of Chicago as a major financial center. ''Emotionally, it's upsetting,'' said Paul O'Connor, executive director of World Business Chicago, a nonprofit economic development corporation for the city.
