''In my line of work, headquarter pelts are prized, but the economic impact is the real question.''

headline: Shares Rise Broadly; Technology Issues Fall After Hours
summary: Shares were broadly higher yesterday, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advancing for the sixth time in eight trading days. A regional report of economic strength from the Federal Reserve contributed to the market's strength, as did an unexpected decrease in the monthly trade deficit and investor expectations of strong earnings by technology companies.

headline: Yahoo Posts Strong Profit On Strength Of Ad Sales
summary: There is a new king of online advertising: Yahoo. The company reported strong profit and revenue yesterday for the fourth quarter, meeting analysts' expectations.

headline: Zane Barnes, 82, Telephone Executive; Was First Southwestern Bell Chairman
summary: Zane Edison Barnes, who started as a telephone lineman and became the first chairman of what is now SBC Communications, died Jan. 9 at his home in St. Louis. He was 82. The cause was complications of injuries sustained in a fall during a trip in 2001, the company said.

headline: Reception May Be Cool for Kidd's Return to San Antonio
summary: Jason Kidd is returning to San Antonio on Wednesday, and he cannot even be sure that one of his favorite restaurants, Rosario's Mexican Cafe, will embrace him anymore. The reception for Kidd is sure to be much different from the last time he was in town. In July, he was treated to a free-agent recruiting bonanza, led by Spurs Coach Gregg Popovich, and chauffeured by the league's most valuable player, Tim Duncan.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Yahoo Makes Deal With Rogers Cable
summary: Yahoo said yesterday that it would take its high-speed broadband service to Canada in a deal with Rogers Cable, the largest cable television system in the country. Starting sometime this year, customers of Rogers's high-speed Internet service will have the option of using e-mail, content and other services provided by Yahoo. Terms of the arrangement were not disclosed, but Yahoo said the deal resembled a venture with SBC Communications in the United States. SBC pays more than $1 a month per subscriber to Yahoo. The move is a response to Bell Canada's deal last year to offer similar services from Microsoft's MSN to its high-speed data customers, said Brahm Eiley, president of the Convergence Consulting Group, a market research firm in Toronto. Saul Hansell (NYT)

headline: Market Place; AT&T Wireless for Sale As a Shakeout Starts
summary: The worst-kept secret in the telecommunications industry is now out in the open: AT&T Wireless is for sale. The board of AT&T Wireless authorized the company yesterday to entertain offers after receiving overtures from nearly a half-dozen suitors, including Cingular, Nextel Communications, Vodafone, NTT DoCoMo and others, executives close to the company said. The move by AT&T Wireless and its potential buyers indicates that one of the nation's most fiercely competitive industries is heading toward a long-awaited consolidation that may be the tip of a multilayered and complex merger process around the world.

headline: With Big News at Home, Nets Flop on the Road
summary: Despite all their assurances to the contrary, the Nets might have been more preoccupied with business than basketball Wednesday night. Many players learned before the game that a deal had finally been struck to sell the franchise to Bruce C. Ratner, who plans on moving the Nets to Brooklyn. If Ratner saw his new acquisition at the SBC Center, he might have asked for a markdown.

headline: AT&T Wireless Says It Wants a Suitor
summary: AT&T Wireless issued an earnings report yesterday that showed that technological and operational problems took a toll in the fourth quarter, hampering its subscriber growth. The company also formally announced that it was considering buyout offers. Some critics attribute the company's circumstances to management missteps. Others say, however, that the turbulent dynamics of the telecommunications industry is partly to blame. Over all, AT&T Wireless has posted solid numbers in recent years, doubling its number of subscribers since it went public in 2000 and developing a niche in the profitable corporate market. But it nonetheless has failed to keep pace in an arena where relatively small missteps can give rivals a big advantage.

headline: AT&T Wireless Stakeholder Makes a Move
summary: NTT DoCoMo, Japan's biggest mobile phone operator, took a step on Tuesday to join the bidding war for AT&T Wireless, intensifying the intrigue and global gamesmanship gripping the cellular industry. DoCoMo presently owns 16 percent of AT&T Wireless and controls two seats on the company's board. But in a filing on Tuesday, DoCoMo recused itself from evaluating bids for AT&T Wireless, a move widely understood to put DoCoMo itself in a position to join the auction.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC Posts 62% Plunge In Earnings
summary: SBC Communications, the nation's No.2 local telephone company, said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings dropped 62 percent on shrinking sales of telephone access lines and one-time charges. SBC also said a decline in revenues would stabilize in 2004, but added that its expansion into the large-business services and satellite television markets would weigh on 2004 earnings. The company said net income totaled $905 million, or 27 cents a share, compared with $2.36 billion, or 71 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding 7 cents a share in one-time items like costs for job cuts and pension settlements, profit totaled 34 cents a share, down from 49 cents a year ago. The results were in line with Wall Street expectations. Revenue fell to $10.07 billion, from $11.22 billion. Shares of SBC fell 74 cents, to $25.95.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Xerox Shares Surge On Earnings News
summary: Xerox said yesterday that quarterly earnings soared on a resurgence in demand for color and digital printers, sending its shares up 8 percent. Xerox posted its biggest annual profit since 1999. Xerox over the last year has picked up momentum and seen its share price rise as it distances itself from years of accounting scandals and other internal troubles with strong sales of its core products. The company said fourth-quarter net income rose to $222 million, or 22 cents a share, from $19 million, or 1 cent a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose about 1 percent, to $4.29 billion from $4.25 billion. For the full year, the company's net income more than tripled to $360 million, or 36 cents per share, from $91 million, or 2 cents a share. Revenue fell to $15.7 billion from $15.8 billion. Shares rose $1.20, to $15.15.

headline: The Cable Guy Reimagined as Wireless Guru
summary: WHEN Daniel Russo and Monique Chang-Russo decided they wanted a wireless home network for their Manhattan apartment, they called in an expert: their cable guy. ''I'm a little nervous about doing it myself,'' Mr. Russo said. So when Time Warner Cable, which provides his high-speed Internet service, began offering installation and support of wireless home networking for a few dollars extra in monthly charges, Mr. Russo was game. Although he had twice installed wired home networks on his own, both times it had cost him hours of frustration, and he wasn't sure he could guard a wireless system against security breaches.

headline: Corrections
summary: Two reports in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day yesterday, about quarterly results for Xerox and SBC Communications, carried incorrect credits. They were by Reuters, not Bloomberg News.

headline: Corrections
summary: Two reports in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day yesterday, about quarterly results for Xerox and SBC Communications, carried incorrect credits. They were by Reuters, not Bloomberg News.

headline: A Lure to Leap Time Zones; As foreign phone carriers eye U.S., questions about potential for profit
summary: As Vodafone of Britain and NTT DoCoMo of Japan mull bids for AT&T Wireless with an eye toward creating globe-girdling cellular networks, they may want to ask one simple question: Are people like Andrew Cole worth all the trouble? Mr. Cole, a telecommunications consultant in Boston, is part of a lucrative but relatively rare breed: the fewer than two million frequent international business travelers. He recently received a $550 monthly wireless phone bill because he ran up hefty per-minute fees while he was in Spain and Britain.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC Ends Discount On Some High-Speed Access
summary: SBC Communications has ended a discount for high-speed access to some customers, lifting the price by 11 percent. On Sunday, the San Antonio-based company raised the price of some Web access to $29.95 a month from $26.95, a spokesman, Joe Izbrand, said. The change applies to orders placed online and customers who buy certain other services, like local and long-distance calling. The lower price will still apply when customers buy a range of services that include wireless calling. SBC cut the prices last quarter to extend the company's lead in DSL. The discounts ended to help fulfill a pledge by the chief executive, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., to stem profit-margin declines this year. Shares of SBC rose 96 cents, or 3.8 percent, to $26.46. At the end of last year, SBC had 3.5 million so-called digital subscriber lines, which let customers download information more quickly than dial-up connections. If DSL is the only product purchased besides local calling, the price will be $34.95 a month, Mr. Izbrand said. SBC sells a faster version of DSL for $44.95 a month.

headline: Vodafone Says It May Seek AT&T Wireless
summary: Just in case there was any doubt that Vodafone was considering making a bid for AT&T Wireless, the company came out and said it on Monday. But contrary to dozens of newspaper reports here and in the United States, Vodafone has not yet decided whether it will submit an offer by the deadline on Friday.

headline: List of Suitors Said to Narrow For Mobile Giant
summary: For several weeks, speculation has been rampant on Wall Street and in the industry about which of the global telecommunications giants might make a move for AT&T Wireless when the company is put up for auction on Friday. It now appears unlikely that more than two will make bids for the nation's third-largest mobile phone company, according to people close to the auction. Cingular is expected to submit a cash bid, and Vodafone may do so as well. Nextel is a long shot but could submit an offer to buy AT&T Wireless for stock. NTT DoCoMo is not expected to participate, those people said.

headline: Officials Say Mob Stole $200 Million Using Phone Bills
summary: Forget gambling, loan-sharking and labor racketeering. New York organized crime figures bilked millions of unsuspecting consumers out of more than $200 million over five years by piggybacking bogus charges on their telephone bills, federal authorities said yesterday. The scheme, involving a network of companies stretching from Midtown Manhattan to Overland Park, Kan., marked what federal authorities believe was the first time organized crime figures have been charged with using the billing fraud known as ''cramming'' to fill mob coffers.

headline: Vodafone Said to Be Preparing a Bid for AT&T Wireless
summary: The Vodafone Group, the world's largest cellular telephone operator, is preparing to make an offer worth as much as $35 billion for AT&T Wireless, executives close to Vodafone said last night. While Vodafone has not made a final decision on whether to proceed with a bid, its preparations come as the company is near an agreement on how it would unravel its stake in Verizon Wireless should it prove successful in acquiring AT&T Wireless. While Vodafone and Verizon Communications, the largest regional phone company in the United States, have yet to reach a final deal on the joint venture, executives close to the talks said the two sides were near an agreement on a price that Verizon would pay for Vodafone's stake. Vodafone's 45 percent share of Verizon Wireless is estimated to be worth $20 billion to $26 billion.

headline: F.C.C. Opens Phone Lines To Plug-Ins Over the Net
summary: Homes could start being connected to the Internet through electrical outlets, and consumers and business may find it easier to make cheaper telephone calls online under new rules that the Federal Communications Commission began preparing on Thursday. Taken together, the new rules could profoundly affect the architecture of the Internet and the services it provides. They also have enormous implications for consumers, the telephone and energy industries, and equipment manufacturers.

headline: AT&T Wireless Bids Heat Up In an Apparent 2-Way Fight
summary: A bidding war erupted yesterday for control of AT&T Wireless as Vodafone, based in Newbury, England, and Cingular Wireless, a joint venture of BellSouth and SBC Communications, submitted new bids that value the company at more than $37 billion or about $14 a share, executives close to the negotiations said. AT&T Wireless was still negotiating with both companies last evening and a decision to accept one of the offers could come as early as today, the executives said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Authorities in Turkey Seize Companies of Uzan Family Turkish financial authorities intensified pressure on the powerful Uzan family by seizing a large number of its companies in an effort to recover debts totaling nearly $6 billion. The state news agency, Anatolian, put the number of concerns, whose interests range from media to cement, at 219. Turkey has accused leading members of the family, including the patriarch, Kemal Uzan, of involvement in a multibillion-dollar bank fraud. Authorities are seeking their extradition from the United States, where they are said to have gone into hiding. [C5.]

headline: E-Commerce Report; Search engines look for advertising dollars from small businesses that don't have a presence on the Internet.
summary: CAN small businesses be persuaded to pay for online advertising even if they do not sell their products or services on the Web? That is a big question for Internet companies like Google and Yahoo, as well as Yellow Pages publishers like Verizon and SBC, which are stepping up their efforts to sell online ads to plumbers, dry cleaners and other small businesses, most of which do not have Web sites.

headline: VODAFONE IS SEEN AS FAVORED BUYER OF AT&T WIRELESS
summary: AT&T Wireless, the nation's third-largest wireless telephone operator, appears to be leaning toward a buyout offer from the Vodafone Group of Britain, executives close to the talks said last night. While the board had not yet approved a deal, the executives said that AT&T Wireless was working to strike a deal with Vodafone within 24 hours. The auction appeared to turn yesterday when Vodafone indicated that it would be willing to raise its $38 billion cash bid, while Cingular Wireless, which had been the favorite to win the auction, refused to increase its offer. Vodafone's board is expected to meet today to review, and possibly sign off on, the final bid, executives said.

headline: Verizon Wireless May Benefit if Either Bidder Buys AT&T
summary: No matter who ends up with AT&T Wireless, one company could end up a winner: Verizon Wireless. The sale of AT&T Wireless is expected to change the state of competition in the industry, Wall Street and industry analysts said. Although Verizon Wireless is not a bidder, the turmoil could actually help strengthen its position as the nation's dominant mobile phone company, analysts say, if the company maintains its quality of service and exploits its strong brand name.

headline: $41 Billion Deal, But What's in It For Consumers?
summary: The blockbuster merger of Cingular Wireless and AT&T Wireless -- and the consolidation of the wireless industry to five major competitors from six -- may not lead to higher consumer prices for mobile phone service anytime soon, according to industry analysts. And the merger could spur better quality of service, they said. Nonetheless, consumer groups plan to challenge the $41 billion merger on the grounds that it could reduce competition in the South and Southwest United States, where BellSouth and SBC, Cingular's parents, are dominant. Consumers Union, an advocacy group, said it thought the acquisition of AT&T Wireless and its 22 million customers could give those two telephone giants excessive power in their local markets.

headline: Share Prices Advance as Investors Respond to Mergers
summary: Stocks advanced yesterday on optimism that an increase in mergers was a sign that shares are inexpensive even after an 11-month rally and that corporate profits would keep rising. AT&T Wireless Services jumped after Cingular Wireless agreed to buy it for $41 billion in cash, outbidding the Vodafone Group. Provident Financial Group rose after the National City Corporation said it would pay $2.1 billion in stock for the bank.

headline: $41 BILLION OFFER BY CINGULAR WINS AT&T WIRELESS
summary: One of the most frantic takeover battles in recent times ended in the early hours of yesterday morning as a legion of bankers and lawyers for Cingular Wireless scurried on foot through the near-empty streets of Midtown Manhattan to hand-deliver a $41 billion bid that snatched AT&T Wireless from the hands of Cingular's rival. The victory by Cingular over Vodafone of Britain -- whose executives went to sleep in London after believing they had won the contest -- will reshape the cutthroat wireless phone business in the United States.

headline: It's Not Enough to Be Just a Phone Company
summary: If there is one thing Cingular Wireless's acquisition of AT&T Wireless shows, it is that being either a traditional phone company or a mobile phone carrier may not be quite enough anymore. The industry is moving into an era of telecommunications megacarriers; smaller, independent operations -- whether offering wireless or traditional phone calling -- are likely to feel increasing pressure to find partnerships and joint ventures, industry analysts said.

headline: Personal Business; Cutting the Home Cord, Not the Home Number
summary: MELANIE BROEMSEN, a technology specialist from Canton, Ohio, has moved several times over the last few years, and almost every time she has had to set up new land-line telephone service or change numbers. She did neither when she moved to another part of town in December. Just a month before she got her new apartment, the federal government made it possible for her and other people who live in the 100 largest metropolitan areas to keep their land-line home numbers when they switch their regular phone service to a wireless carrier. ''I wanted the stability of keeping my home number for me, my family and friends,'' Ms. Broemsen, 33, said. ''Changing my land-line into my cell number, and therefore only paying one bill, seemed like the perfect solution.''

headline: The Search Engine That Isn't a Verb, Yet
summary: IN July 2001, three months after Terry S. Semel, the former Warner Brothers studio co-chief, took over as chief executive of Yahoo, he excitedly called a news conference with Sir Howard Stringer, the chairman of the Sony Corporation of America. The past and present movie moguls described in glowing but vague terms a new partnership. Sony would buy some advertising on Yahoo, and Yahoo would help Sony develop a new Web site. ''We're not quite married,'' Sir Howard told reporters, hinting at possible closer ties between the companies in the future. ''But at least we're holding hands.''

headline: WorldCom And AT&T Settle Dispute
summary: Ending a heated dispute between telecommunications companies, AT&T has agreed to drop its claim that WorldCom defrauded it of tens of millions of dollars in telephone fees, the two companies said yesterday. Under the settlement, the two sides have agreed to drop multimillion-dollar claims against each other in a separate matter, WorldCom's Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. The proposed settlement is subject to the approval of the federal bankruptcy court overseeing the reorganization of WorldCom, which plans to change its name to MCI.

headline: S.&P. 500 and Dow Decline a Fifth Consecutive Day
summary: Stocks fell yesterday, pushing the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Dow Jones industrial average down for a fifth straight day, the longest losing streak since January 2003. An index of consumer confidence had its biggest monthly drop since the start of the Iraq war, damping optimism that the 11-month rally would continue.

headline: Health Care Issue a Priority In SBC Contract Discussions
summary: With two contracts that could affect 6,000 workers in the state set to expire April 3, negotiations between SBC Connecticut and the Communications Workers of America began last week. Both company and union officials said the cost of heath care benefits would be a major issue.

headline: Sprint Seen as Jockeying For Place in Merger Game
summary: By moving over the weekend to combine its wireless tracking stock with the stock of its traditional phone operations, Sprint has helped stoke anticipation on Wall Street that it is preparing to join in the consolidation of the telecommunications industry by becoming either an acquirer or a takeover target. That may not be what Gary D. Forsee, Sprint's chief executive, intended. Mr. Forsee has gone out of his way recently to say that Sprint is well positioned to compete as a stand-alone company.

headline: Shares Fall on Fear Prices Already Reflect Profit Outlook
summary: Shares declined yesterday, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropping for the first day in five, amid concern that prices already reflect prospects for profit growth. The dollar had its biggest rally against the euro in a year and surged to a four-month high against the yen, on speculation that employment growth is accelerating.

headline: An Attractive Candidate For a Takeover Emerges
summary: WorldCom, the telecommunications giant that was brought to the brink of collapse from accounting fraud, is poised to emerge from bankruptcy protection as its co-founder and former chief executive, Bernard J. Ebbers, faces criminal charges related to the $11 billion accounting scandal. But the company confronts a competitive climate significantly changed and far less hospitable than when it filed for bankruptcy protection in July 2002.

headline: Appeals Court Favors Bells On Rates For Access
summary: A federal appeals court handed a big victory to the four large regional Bell telephone companies on Tuesday, striking down regulations that had required the Bells to lease their local networks to rival companies at low prices set by state regulators. If Tuesday's decision survives further legal challenges, it would be a substantial blow to AT&T, WorldCom and smaller companies that have relied on inexpensive access to the local networks to reach their customers. By increasing the cost of access, the ruling could significantly reduce competition in local markets and lead to higher prices for callers, according to competitors of the Bell companies, consumer groups and some analysts.

headline: SBC, Tired of Courts and Regulators, Offers to Settle Network Leasing Issue
summary: A day after a federal court rejected government regulations intended to govern competition in the telephone industry, SBC sent a letter to rival carriers suggesting that they settle their differences outside of the regulatory structure. But at least one major competitor, AT&T, the long-distance giant, rejected the effort as a cynical attempt to capitalize on Tuesday's court decision, which has been seen as a big victory for SBC and other major local telephone companies.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Under Investor Pressure, Disney Picks New Chairman In a remarkable vote of no confidence against a once unassailable executive, shareholders owning an estimated 43 percent of the Walt Disney Company withheld their support to re-elect Michael D. Eisner, the chairman and chief executive, to the board. The mounting shareholder dissent prodded the board to strip Mr. Eisner of the chairman's title and give it to George J. Mitchell, Disney's presiding director and a former United States senator. [Page A1.]

headline: Telefónica Seeking BellSouth's Latin Assets
summary: Telefónica, the Spanish telecommunications giant, said on Thursday that it was in talks to buy the Latin American assets of BellSouth for as much as $6 billion, a move that would further consolidate the region's mobile phone market. The negotiations come at a time BellSouth is looking to finance its share of the $41 billion that its joint venture, Cingular Wireless, has offered to acquire the AT&T Wireless Group, industry analysts said.

headline: The C.E.O.'s Mad, Mad World
summary: THE fireworks at Disney's annual meeting last week prove that shareholders are finally becoming intolerant of me-first managers. Disney's reaction, however, also shows how loath entrenched executives are to sit down, shut up and do what is right. For example, Michael D. Eisner resigned as chairman of Walt Disney but is remaining as chief executive. That's his answer to smoldering shareholder rage?

headline: Telefónica Buys BellSouth Unit
summary: Telefónica of Spain said Monday that it would buy the BellSouth Corporation's remaining Latin American wireless assets in a deal worth $5.85 billion, strengthening the company's position across the region. Telefónica said the deal was still subject to regulatory and government approval. Under the deal, Telefónica expects to pay BellSouth $4.2 billion in cash, while the rest is made up of minority shareholdings and debt transferred to Telefónica.

headline: F.C.C. Chairman Urges Phone Companies to Settle on Rates
summary: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission urged the nation's telephone companies yesterday to sit down for 30 days to settle on the appropriate rates for gaining access to local networks. If they cannot agree, the chairman, Michael K. Powell, said he will propose that the commission adopt interim rules for the use of the networks. The commission issued rules last year that were intended to make local phone markets more competitive and gave a great deal of regulatory authority to the states in setting discounted prices for access to local telephone networks. That rule was struck down last week by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, which said that the rule delegated too much authority to the states. The ruling could increase the cost of access for local-phone competitors like AT&T and MCI and, by extension, their customers.

headline: Share Sale Raised $4.4 Billion for Belgacom
summary: Belgacom, Belgium's dominant phone company, said yesterday that its share sale raised as much as 3.59 billion euros ($4.4 billion) for minority stockholders in Europe's biggest initial public offering in three years. Shareholders including SBC Communications, Singapore Telecommunications and TDC A/S sold Belgacom shares at 24.50 euros each, in the middle of the initial range of 23 to 26.50 euros. A total of 133.1 million shares were sold for 3.3 billion euros, and that could rise to 146.4 million shares should the so-called over-allotment option be exercised.

headline: Airport Medical Resources Are Far From Standard
summary: Gary Terry bent down to pick up his briefcase at Austin-Bergstrom International Airport in Texas one night in 2001 and collapsed from cardiac arrest. Luckily, Mr. Terry, a regional vice president at SBC Communications in Fort Worth, crumpled 18 feet from an automated defibrillator in a wall cabinet. A passer-by rushed over to give him cardiopulmonary resuscitation and called security. An airport police officer grabbed the defibrillator and sent an electric shock to Mr. Terry's heart, which started pumping again normally 4 minutes 19 seconds after he fell.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: SBC To Offer Wi-Fi Net Access At UPS Outlets
summary: SBC Communications will offer high-speed wireless Internet access in United Parcel Service stores this year to attract more business customers. The service, known as wireless fidelity, or Wi-Fi, will be available at 1,500 UPS and Mail Boxes Etc. locations by year's end and in 3,000 stores by the end of 2005, an SBC spokesman, Michael Coe, said yesterday. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

headline: 3 Substitutions Made in List Of Dow 30
summary: The Dow Jones industrial average is shedding some losers, again. Dow Jones announced yesterday that it was dropping AT&T, Eastman Kodak and International Paper from its list of 30 industrial stocks, and adding Pfizer, the American International Group and Verizon Communications.

headline: Executive Pay: A Special Report; Is C.E.O. Pay Up or Down? Both.
summary: THE message from corporate directors to shareholders who are fuming about elephantine executive pay is: We're working on it. The response they get back may very well be: Thanks, but this is not quite what we had in mind. On paper, the days of rapidly rising executive compensation appear to be ending. Many excesses of the 1990's have been wrung out, and the chances that chief executives will reap hundreds of millions of dollars from cashing in stock options have diminished.

headline: SBC Negotiates a Deal to Let a Rival Use Its Lines
summary: SBC Communications, the nation's second-largest local-service telephone company after Verizon, said over the weekend that Sage Telecom had signed a contract to use SBC's lines, the first such deal since a court struck down federal rules setting discounts for network leasing. The seven-year agreement covers SBC's 13-state territory, which is mainly in the Midwest, the Southwest and California, the companies said.

headline: Cut-Rate Calling, By Way of the Net
summary: EVERY time an important piece of our lives goes electronic, much is gained, but something is lost, too. Audiophiles say that compact discs don't sound as warm as vinyl records. Home theaters are neat, but don't offer the communal fun of a movie theater crowd. And no matter how efficient e-mail may be, it can't touch the joy of receiving a handwritten letter on fine stationery, thoughtfully composed and concluding with the words ''check enclosed.'' So stand back. The latest life component to make a radical, Internet-driven shift is ordinary home telephone service.

headline: Yahoo Reports a Surge In Quarterly Earnings And Plans a Stock Split
summary: When Yahoo, the Internet portal company, announced first-quarter financial results yesterday that were far stronger than expected, the canyons of Wall Street seemed to echo with the yodel the company uses in its advertising campaign. Shares of Yahoo rose more than 10 percent in after-hours trading, reaching as high as $53.40 after ending regular trading at $48.35. The company also announced a two-for-one stock split, payable May 11 to shareholders of record as of April 26.

headline: Say Hey, Say Goodbye as Bonds Ties Mays at 660
summary: It was a great day for Barry Bonds before he hit home run No. 660 into the water beyond the right-field brick wall on Monday. After being booed and taking his lumps in Houston and in San Diego, Bonds returned home and was showered with love. Not only from his family, but from his fans. The SBC Park capacity crowd of 42,548 gave Bonds two standing ovations before the home opener started. The third standing ovation came in the fifth inning, when Bonds turned on a 3-1 inside fastball from Milwaukee's Matt Kinney and hit a 442-foot home run that tied his godfather, Willie Mays, for third on baseball's career home run list. Everyone at SBC Park knew the ball was gone the second he hit it, and Bonds immediately threw up his arms and let out a big sigh.

headline: Verizon Plans To Raise Fee Of Digital Net Service
summary: Verizon Communications announced plans yesterday to add a $2 to $3 monthly surcharge to the cost of its high-speed Internet connections, a move that could fuel further debate over the taxation of online services. Verizon said its new charge would start appearing next month on the bills of roughly 2.5 million subscribers to its high-speed data line service in Eastern states. The company said that, because of logistical problems, the surcharge would not be levied on high-speed Internet customers in Western states until June.

headline: Bonds Breaks Tie With Mays by Hitting 661st Homer
summary: Sometime after Barry Bonds hit his 660th homer against the Brewers on Monday, Milwaukee Manager Ned Yost said, ''Maybe I'm just not smart enough to walk Barry Bonds every time.'' That was the case again in the Giants' 4-2 victory Tuesday night, when Bonds hit his 661st home run in the bottom of the seventh inning to pass Willie Mays for third on the career list.

headline: Kayaker Is Just Waiting For the Sock of the Bay
summary: The afternoon after, fans were still buzzing. After Barry Bonds hit his 660th career home run on Monday and his 661st on Tuesday to pass Willie Mays, people at SBC Park were talking about the guy in the kayak. Larry Ellison, 53, who works for a computer company and is known in these parts as ''the dude in the Schwarzenegger mask,'' retrieved both of Bonds's blasts into McCovey Cove, the part of San Francisco Bay behind the right-field stands.

headline: On and Off the Baseball Field, Bonds Prefers to Go for Distance
summary: Those who want to get close to baseball's most untouchable player generally position themselves more than 400 feet away from him. They cram onto a narrow landing high above right field, where they shiver in 25-mile-an-hour winds. They paddle kayaks in McCovey Cove, where the water is 40 degrees and the only view is of the stadium's concrete facade.

headline: SBC Proposes a Higher but Uniform Rate for Rivals Using Its Lines
summary: SBC Communications, the regional telephone giant, proposed yesterday that it permit its competitors to use its local phone network at a set, uniform price through the remainder of the year. SBC, which provides service in a 13-state territory that blankets much of the Midwest, the Southwest and California, characterized the offer as an interim deal aimed at bringing stability to a confusing system of telephone access fees while telephone companies try to work out more permanent agreements.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Rivals Offered Higher Rate-Leasing Plans
summary: Verizon Communications, the telecommunications giant based in New York, introduced a contractual framework yesterday for leasing its lines to competing telephone companies. Verizon said that it would lease its lines in customized three-year deals to competitors. Verizon, which operates in 30 states, said the price would vary by state but would typically range from $20 to $24 per telephone line a month, with the cost rising each subsequent year. The offer from Verizon follows similar proposals by other regional telephone giants, like SBC and BellSouth. Generally, the offers come after a recent appeals court decision that threw out federal rules forcing the dominant local phone companies, like Verizon, to lease their networks to competitors at low rates set by state regulators. Matt Richtel (NYT)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Loses Bid On Part-Internet Calls
summary: The Federal Communications Commission rejected AT&T's bid to pay lower fees to local telephone companies for completing calls routed partially over the Internet, a victory for SBC Communications. By a 5-to-0 vote yesterday , the F.C.C. turned down AT&T's October 2002 request. The agency did not decide whether AT&T owes payments it has withheld from local phone carriers while the agency reviewed the matter. Any such claims will be decided on a case-by-case basis, an F.C.C. spokesman, David Fiske, said. The F.C.C. chairman, Michael K. Powell, who has said Internet phone service should be subject to few regulations, decided the AT&T calls are not different enough from conventional circuit-switched phone service. AT&T, trying to pare some of its $10.8 billion in annual access costs, has said the ''arcane'' fees discourage investment in Internet-based technology that benefits consumers.

headline: Higher Earnings Ease Fears of Increase in Interest Rates
summary: The major stock indicators rose as higher-than-forecast earnings from companies including Motorola and Ford helped the market rebound from losses tied to concern that interest rates may increase. Share prices advanced after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said in a second day of Congressional testimony that the economy's expansion had yet to bring broad-based inflation. Investors were disconcerted Tuesday when he suggested that the Fed might raise rates sooner than expected.

headline: Kerry Releases a List Of His Lobbyist Meetings
summary: In the last 15 years, Senator John Kerry has met with more than 300 lobbyists and other advocates representing interests as diverse as organized labor and major corporations, according to a partial list released Thursday by his campaign. The list, detailing meetings between 1989 and late last year that were often held over lunch, dinner or cocktails, identifies many participants who have contributed to his campaigns and, in some cases, become fund-raisers for his presidential run.

headline: Sports Briefing
summary: PRO BASKETBALL Jamison Is Top Sixth Man After five losing seasons in Golden State, Antawn Jamison was so excited about being on a winning team in Dallas that he was willing to become a backup for the first time in his life.

headline: Head of Mexican Phone Giant Hands Duties Over to His Son
summary: Carlos Slim Helú, Latin America's richest man, stepped down as chairman of Teléfonos de Mexico and handed over the responsibilities to his eldest son, Carlos Slim Domit. The change is part of the 64-year-old Mr. Slim's efforts to turn over to his three sons management control of his business interests, including Telmex, Mexico's largest fixed-line telephone company; Grupo Financiero Inbursa, a financial services company; and Grupo Carso, an industrial holding company.

headline: After an Outage, SBC Looks Into Severed Cable
summary: SBC said its D.S.L. and dial-up Internet customers in Connecticut were without service for more than five hours last Monday after a fiber optic cable under a highway in Mount Vernon, N.Y. was accidentally severed. An SBC spokeswoman, Beverly E. Levy, said service went out around 9:30 a.m. and was restored shortly after 2:30 p.m., when the company's Internet traffic was rerouted through a fiber optic system in Newark. Ms. Levy said that tens of thousands of customers were affected.

headline: Spurs Ground Air Bryant In Midflight
summary: Kobe Bryant seemed to be thumbing his nose at all of it, at the charges that threaten his freedom, at the predictions of San Antonio's superiority, at the reports of his teammates' fuming behind his back. At his floating, flying best, he was carrying the Los Angeles Lakers past the San Antonio Spurs in the third quarter Sunday, defying the notion that the Spurs could not be beaten at the SBC Center.

headline: Looking Past Cable's Profits To the Rivals on Its Heels
summary: Call them nervous Nellies. No matter how strong the numbers are for the country's biggest cable companies, investors are still panicky about the intensifying competition for customers from telephone and satellite companies. Last week, three major cable companies reported strong results. The Comcast Corporation, the nation's largest cable operator, said that revenues from Comcast Cable Communications, its cable unit, were up 9.8 percent, to $4.6 billion. On the same day, Time Warner said its cable unit revenues were up 11 percent, to $2.04 billion. Then on Thursday, Cox Communications said its revenue was up 13 percent, to $1.5 billion. All three reported sharp increases in operating cash flow for the quarter as well.

headline: Payton's Moniker, The Glove, Isn't Fitting
summary: For the better part of 14 N.B.A. seasons, Gary Payton has been a nuisance for opponents, covering them like clothing -- hence the nickname the Glove -- while dispensing an earful of insults. At 35, Payton is not as quick as he once was. Houston's Steve Francis spent part of the opening round of the playoffs blowing past him, and on Sunday, San Antonio's Tony Parker, 21, left him with windburn.

headline: In Court Filled With Stars, Spurs' Parker Stands Out
summary: The move was scintillating enough to bring street-ball fans to their feet with a roar. Tony Parker, isolated in the left corner against an overmatched Devean George, executed a crossover dribble that nearly removed George from his sneakers. Shaquille O'Neal was still in Parker's path, but even while giving up 11 inches and 160 pounds, Parker had something for him, too. Lofting a 3-foot floater over O'Neal, the game's most intimidating player, Parker scored sweetly with 3 minutes 38 seconds to play, pouring water on a torrid rally by the Los Angeles Lakers.

headline: Bryant's Long Days, Opponents' Long Nights
summary: At some point in the fourth quarter Tuesday night, all but one of the Los Angeles Lakers became spectators. Even the great ones -- Shaquille O'Neal, Karl Malone and Gary Payton -- were turned into mere fans, overwhelmed and astonished by what they were witnessing. Kobe Bryant, after flying to Eagle, Colo., at 5 a.m., sitting in a courtroom for several hours, pleading not guilty to charges of sexual assault, flying nearly two hours back to Los Angeles and napping before the game at the Staples Center, was demonstrating brilliance on the basketball court.

headline: The Spurs Win ... No, Wait, the Lakers Win
summary: With fans standing a few feet away screaming, ''It ain't good, it ain't good,'' three referees and a host of players gathered around a television monitor Thursday night at the SBC Center. One of the greatest finishes in National Basketball Association history, and perhaps the deciding moment in this Western Conference semifinal series, was at stake. For about a minute, the lead official, Danny Crawford, crouched and stared at the replay showing on the monitor. Then, ignoring the Spurs' faithful nearby, he stood and yelled, ''The basket's good,'' giving the Los Angeles Lakers a miraculous 74-73 victory over the San Antonio Spurs.

headline: BBDO Worldwide's two-time chief executive is stepping down to make way for a new generation.
summary: ALLEN ROSENSHINE, the chairman and chief executive of BBDO Worldwide in New York, the largest agency of the world's largest agency company, the Omnicom Group, is stepping down as chief executive for the second time. And this time, he says, he means it.

headline: J.P. MORGAN CHASE NAMES DALEY AS REGIONAL CHAIRMAN
summary: J.P. Morgan Chase, which plans to merge with Bank One this year to become the second-largest bank in the United States behind Citigroup, has hired William Daley, a former commerce secretary, as chairman of its Midwestern banking division. Daley is the brother of Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago and the son of Richard J. Daley, the city's mayor and political boss for more than two decades. Daley resigned as president of SBC Communications, a local telephone company, last week after running the company since December 2001. He was commerce secretary under President Bill Clinton from 1997 to 2000.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A2-11 Intimidation Tactics in Iraq Approved by U.S. Officers The use of dogs to intimidate prisoners during interrogation at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq was approved by military intelligence officers there, and was one of several aggressive tactics they adopted even without approval from higher commanders. A1

headline: Qwest, the Runt of the Bells, Tries to Stand Its Ground
summary: When Richard C. Notebaert took over two years ago as chief executive of Qwest Communications International, the smallest of the Baby Bell phone companies, he assumed the helm of an enterprise saddled with debt, facing myriad lawsuits and investigations and crippled by financial plans that left it near bankruptcy. But what also troubled Mr. Notebaert was something more palpable.

headline: T-Mobile Gaining Spectrum By Ending Cingular Venture
summary: T-Mobile USA, the nation's fifth-largest cellular operator, announced yesterday that it had reached a deal to acquire control of some much- sought-after wireless spectrum from Cingular Wireless to improve its national network. Deutsche Telekom, T-Mobile's parent company, will pay Cingular $2.3 billion to dissolve their three-year joint venture that allowed them to share their networks in several crucial states. Under the new deal, T-Mobile will take over part of Cingular's network in California and Nevada, and regain exclusive control of some of its network in New York. In the process, T-Mobile will give Cingular part of its network in New York.

headline: The Express Lane to the Internet, Now With Fewer Bumps
summary: LIKE most busy people, Gina Gellerman had better things to do on her Sundays than watch her computer struggle to download Web sites. A preschool teacher in Napa, Calif., Ms. Gellerman wanted to use her days off to catch up on the news, check the entertainment in her town and, most important, plan for her wedding in July. Frustrated with the slow speeds in her dial-up plan with AOL, she asked her friends and family about their high-speed Internet connections. After weighing the merits of broadband sold by cable providers and others, she chose a plan from her telephone company, SBC, which offers a service jointly with Yahoo at $29.95 a month.

headline: At (Your Name Here) Arena, Money Talks
summary: GET your scorecard. You will need one to traverse a peculiar, fast-growing marketplace in which companies craving public recognition and customers vie for the rights to name arenas and stadiums after themselves. To paraphrase the sportscaster Al Michaels, do you believe in Petco Park? Or Heinz Field? Or the Edward Jones Dome? (Who knew that nice Eddie from the cul-de-sac even owned a dome?)

headline: A Labor Agreement For SBC and Union
summary: SBC Communications and the Communication Workers of America reached a five-year labor agreement last Tuesday, just hours after the union returned from a four-day work stoppage. The deal, which affects 5,500 SBC workers in Connecticut, calls for an average yearly wage increase of 2.5 percent, along with an average annual payment of $300; the maintaining of current health benefits for members and retirees, but with an increase in co-pays and other associated costs; guaranteed employment for current members whose jobs might be eliminated in the future, and access to new jobs for anyone now doing traditional phone work.

headline: Trying to Revive Struggling AT&T: A Job Made, It Seems, for Sisyphus
summary: When he is not trying to rebuild his company, David W. Dorman, the chief executive of AT&T, has been known to go angling for bonefish. The silvery fish swim in full view in shallow water, yet move so fast that a whole day can go by without a bite. When one does take the bait, the fight can last half an hour. Mr. Dorman's experience in the surf is an apt analogy for his day job running the world's best-known telephone company. The problems facing the heir of Ma Bell are obvious to everyone in the industry, yet hard to grasp, let alone fix. And when AT&T finds a solution to one of its many problems, another struggle develops.

headline: Qwest and MCI Break Impasse to Reach Pact on Network Leasing Rates
summary: Qwest Communications and MCI Inc. have reached an agreement over network leasing rates, officials and industry executives said yesterday, becoming the first of the major telecommunications companies to break a longstanding impasse over the rates. Other major phone companies, meanwhile, failed to resolve similar issues despite a weekend of intense negotiations involving top regulators and senior executives.

headline: Court Rejects Extension Of Phone Rule
summary: In a ruling that could reduce competition in local phone markets, a federal appeals court Friday rejected a request by regulators and the two largest long-distance telephone providers to extend regulations that give the companies and small rivals deep discounts for leasing the network equipment of the four Bell operating companies. The decision puts pressure on the Bush administration to take sides in the long-running telephone wars, as the Justice Department will have to decide whether to take an appeal to the Supreme Court.

headline: Where Entrepreneurs Go And the Internet Is Free; Wi-Fi Providers Rethink How to Make Money
summary: Linda Branagan would seem to be the ideal customer for entrepreneurs and telecommunications companies looking to make money selling wireless Internet connections. But, like thousands of business road warriors, Ms. Branagan often does not pay for the service because she gets it free. At cafes, malls and downtown business districts, there has been an explosion of Internet access points, or Wi-Fi hot spots, that let computer users log on to the Internet for free. That growth is a fundamental reason -- though not the only one -- that technology start-ups, investors and industry analysts who had high hopes for Wi-Fi are scrambling to find sustainable business models.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
summary: UNILEVER, Rotterdam, the Netherlands, the world's largest manufacturer of food and soap, said it is selling its approximately $46 million stake in Elizabeth Arden Inc., severing its last ties to the No.2 perfume maker in America. The stake is about 2.32 million shares. The offering's manager, Morgan Stanley, will sell an additional 231,793 shares if there is demand.

headline: New Service by TiVo Will Build Bridges From Internet to the TV
summary: The Internet, in jumping past the personal computer and into the living room television set, is starting to give viewers the possibility of bypassing traditional cable and satellite services. TiVo, the maker of a popular digital video recorder, plans to announce a new set of Internet-based services today that will further blur the line between programming delivered over traditional cable and satellite channels and content from the Internet. It is just one of a growing group of large and small companies that are looking at high-speed Internet to deliver video content to the living room.

headline: BUSH BACKS OFF RULE THAT EASED PHONE LINE FEES
summary: In a move that critics say could lead to higher telephone rates, the Bush administration on Wednesday sided with the four regional Bell companies in a court case over the fees they charge their rivals for access to their networks. The administration's decision, which could affect the phone bills of nearly 50 million customers across the country, was a significant policy reversal in a case making its way to the Supreme Court.

headline: Long-Distance Carriers Take A Blow, but It's No Knockout
summary: Phone companies like AT&T, MCI and Sprint, with their long-distance businesses in trouble, suffered a big blow on Wednesday with the Bush administration's decision to side with the regional Bell companies on the issue of local access fees. But that decision is unlikely to cause any immediate consolidation in the industry or damage the long-distance giants as quickly or harshly as they have predicted, industry analysts said. That is because those carriers have been pushing to develop new sources of revenue, the analysts said, and this week's bad news will most likely accelerate those efforts. Legal challenges by the long-distance carriers, state governments and others could also delay any damage.

headline: States' Big Role in Phone Rates May Be Only a Cameo
summary: Now comes the states' turn. For the next few months, state regulators could play an important role in setting wholesale telephone rates if the Supreme Court decides, as many expect, not to intervene and extend federal regulations that require the regional Bell companies to offer their rivals deep discounts for access to their networks.

headline: The White House Hangs Up
summary: The Bush administration is abandoning the landmark 1996 Telecommunications Act, which spawned a new era of competition in telephone service. That is the net effect of its refusal to appeal to the Supreme Court a federal court decision striking down rules that gave local phone companies access to the Baby Bells' networks. Even more disturbing, the administration pressured the Federal Communications Commission, ostensibly an independent agency, to abstain from filing its own appeal in defense of its own rules. The core of the 1996 legislation was a requirement that local phone companies -- the regional Baby Bells, like Verizon and SBC, created with the breakup of Ma Bell a decade earlier -- open up their local markets to competition by leasing access to their lines and other equipment before being allowed to offer long-distance service. The Baby Bells have grudgingly complied, and some 20 million households get their local service from competitors.

headline: Taking a Swing With Steroids
summary: In the four-tenths of a second it takes for a 101-mile-an-hour fastball to fly from the pitcher's hand to home plate, the San Francisco Giants slugger Barry Bonds sizes up the seams and gauges the spin, projects where the ball is headed and decides what he wants to do with it. One night this season, Bonds used this sliver of time to plant his right foot, jackhammer his hips and thrust his hands so violently that he yanked the ball out of the stadium, about 60 feet foul.

headline: The Bells and the Ruling on Access Fees
summary: The decision by the Bush administration last week to side with the regional Bell companies in their legal fight over the access fees they charge others to lease their phone lines has set off alarm bells among consumer groups, long-distance providers and state utility commissions. The groups say that an appeals court decision to remove the cap on these access fees, which goes into effect today, will give the Bells a free hand to raise the prices they charge AT&T, MCI and hundreds of other companies trying to get into the local phone market. It will also push many smaller phone companies out of business, they say, and ultimately lead to higher phone rates for consumers.

headline: School Internet Program Lacks Oversight, Investigator Says
summary: Representative Joe L. Barton listened to an hour or so of Congressional testimony on Thursday about waste and fraud in the federal program that helps poor schools connect to the Internet before questioning an official who has been investigating it. ''Is it your view that these applicants view this program as a big candy jar, free money?'' Mr. Barton, Republican of Texas and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, asked H. Walker Feaster III, inspector general for the Federal Communications Commission, the agency that oversees the program.

headline: SBC SELLS SHARES IN TELKOM SOUTH AFRICA
summary: SBC Communications and Telekom Malaysia sold 14.9 percent of Telkom South Africa Ltd. to institutional investors for 6 billion South African rand ($923 million) to take advantage of the stock's rise since last year's share sale. The price, 73 rand a share, is 1.7 percent less than the closing price of Telkom shares on the JSE Securities Exchange South Africa on Thursday, Telkom South Africa said in a stock exchange statement. SBC, based in San Antonio, is reducing its stakes in phone companies worldwide.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC To Develop New Fiber Optic Lines
summary: SBC Communications said yesterday that it intends to spend $4 billion to $6 billion over the next five years to deploy fiber optic lines capable of delivering next-generation television, Internet and voice services. The company said the deployment would be contingent on whether regulatory rules remain intact that would not force SBC -- and other regional Bell operating companies -- to lease their networks to competitors at low rates set by states. The company said that once the regulatory rules were clarified, it would deploy a network designed to deliver high-definition television, high-speed Internet service, and telephone calls delivered via the Internet through technology known as VOIP. SBC said it was already testing various applications of the network, including working with Microsoft to create digital television services. Matt Richtel (NYT)

headline: Communications Equipment Makers Lead Shares Higher
summary: Stocks rose yesterday, led by communications equipment makers, after telephone companies said that they would spend billions of dollars upgrading networks. ''It seems like the tech sector's playing catch-up here,'' said Pat Becker Jr., who helps manage $2.2 billion at Becker Capital Management in Portland, Ore. ''I don't think it's participated very much in the past week or so.''

headline: AT&T to Halt Some Residential Marketing
summary: AT&T said yesterday that it would stop marketing its phone services to residents in seven states, an action the company said was in direct response to the Bush administration's decision not to intercede in the dispute over the fees carriers like AT&T pay to the Bell phone companies for the use of their networks. AT&T also scaled back its revenue and operating income forecasts for the year, citing the administration's decision and industrywide pressure to cut prices.

headline: Yahoo's Quarterly Earnings Double but Disappoint Investors
summary: Yahoo said yesterday that its profit more than doubled in the second quarter, driven both by acquisitions and a surging online advertising market. But the numbers only matched Wall Street estimates; investors, who had been hoping for much better results, pushed the company's shares down in after-hours trading. In the first quarter, Yahoo's results, buoyed by a rapidly growing market for Internet advertising, were surprisingly strong, and many investors were looking for a repeat in the latest period. But the company did not deliver that and only slightly raised its forecast for the year. Before the results were announced, Yahoo's shares closed at $32.60, down 62 cents, but fell as low as $28.86 after hours.

headline: A Prized Project, a Mayor and Persistent Criticism
summary: Even in a city with a worldwide reputation for innovative urban design, the opening this month of a spectacular new park and performance center near Lake Michigan promises to be a huge event. The site, Millennium Park, is opening four years late and at three times the original budget, but few here are complaining. The park boasts an outdoor music pavilion designed by Frank Gehry, complete with his signature swirls of shiny metal; an underground theater with 1,500 seats; elaborate gardens with 250 varieties of plants; and other attractions that include an ice skating rink and a shower room for bicyclists.

headline: Leucadia Seeks to Buy Controlling Stake in MCI
summary: The Leucadia National Corporation, the New York-based investment group, is seeking permission from regulators to buy a controlling stake in MCI, the troubled telecommunications company that emerged from bankruptcy protection in April. The announcement, made by MCI yesterday, comes two days before the company, the nation's second-largest long distance carrier, relists its shares on the Nasdaq market, according to an executive at the company.

headline: A Crucial Vote for Venezuela and a Company
summary: Most Venezuelans see the coming referendum on the rule of President Hugo Chávez as a chance to rebuild this divided nation. But Antonio Mugica, chief executive of the networking company Smartmatic, sees a phenomenal marketing opportunity for his company's voting technology. Smartmatic's voting machines will be used for the first time in the Aug. 15 referendum that is likely to be one of Venezuela's most hotly contested elections, making the company's baptism by fire an all-or-nothing gamble that its first electoral count will be flawless.

headline: Cingular, Sprint and Nextel Report a Strong 2nd Quarter
summary: Cingular Wireless, Sprint and Nextel Communications, three of the nation's largest phone companies, reported yesterday that revenue rose in the second quarter as they continued to court new subscribers aggressively with handsets, lower prices and additional free minutes. A fourth carrier, AT&T Wireless, continued to show signs of decline ahead of its planned merger with Cingular later this year. The company said profit and revenue slipped.

headline: Verizon Seen Introducing Phone Service Via Internet
summary: Verizon Communications, the nation's biggest telephone company, will announce today that it is introducing Internet-based phone service to customers across the nation, according to executives close to the plan. Verizon is the latest and largest player to offer the technology, which divides voice calls into packets of data and sends them over high-speed Internet lines. The service can be significantly cheaper than traditional phone calls because sellers of the service do not typically have to pay access charges and other fees related to telephone transmission.

headline: Sales Edge Up at SBC, but Profit Falls
summary: SBC Communications Inc., the nation's second-largest local telephone company after Verizon, has reported its first sales gain in 15 quarters as more people subscribed to its high-speed Internet service. The company cut 1,200 jobs in the latest quarter. Sales rose less than 1 percent, to $10.3 billion, from $10.2 billion a year earlier, SBC said yesterday. Net income fell 16 percent, to $1.17 billion, or 35 cents a share, from $1.39 billion, or 42 cents.

headline: AT&T Won't Seek New Residential Customers
summary: AT&T, which for more than a century was synonymous with telephone service in the American home, announced yesterday that it would stop seeking new residential customers. The move comes as the company struggles to survive in the increasingly volatile and competitive telecommunications industry that was created after the breakup of AT&T's near-monopoly in 1984.

headline: Bells Win a Battle, Not Necessarily the War
summary: AT&T's capitulation is not necessarily the Bells' victory. AT&T's announcement yesterday that it would withdraw from the consumer phone market gives at least a temporary advantage to the four regional Bell telephone giants, analysts said. But the future poses its own uncertainties for the Bell companies: BellSouth, Qwest Communications, SBC Communications and Verizon Communications.

headline: Qwest Steps Up to Lure AT&T's Customers
summary: Qwest Communications, the telecommunications company based in Denver, said yesterday that it planned to take out full-page newspaper advertisements starting on Sunday to court customers of AT&T. The move is the first visible fallout from AT&T's announcement on Thursday that it would stop seeking new local and long-distance residential customers.

headline: Internet Sales Help BellSouth Increase Profit 4.7% in Quarter
summary: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 4.7 percent as it cut costs and increased sales of high-speed Internet connections. Net income increased to $996 million compared with $951 million a year earlier. Sales rose less than 1 percent, to $5.08 billion.

headline: Wi-Fi Service Expands Its Reach
summary: Wi-Fi is finally rolling into America's airports. In the last couple of years, Wi-Fi, or high-speed wireless Internet access, has invaded Starbucks stores and McDonald's restaurants as well as Marriott and Wyndham hotels. But it has been hard to find in airports, the one place that business travelers are most likely to have time on their hands.

headline: Now a Message From a Sponsor Of the Subway?
summary: Facing what it says could be budget gaps of more than $1 billion in the coming years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the keeper of the region's mass transit system, is exploring selling naming rights to its subway stations, bus lines, bridges and tunnels. Transportation authority officials quietly issued a formal request for proposals this month from marketing firms that they would charge with landing sponsorship deals that could include anything from renaming historic stations to attaching corporate monikers to building projects like the long-awaited Second Avenue subway. Indeed, the authority's officials said they could easily imagine the Delta Times Square Shuttle or, say, I.B.M.'s adopting the Tarrytown station on Metro-North's Hudson rail line.

headline: S.&P. Hits Lowest Point in '04 as Profit Forecasts Fall
summary: Stocks fell yesterday, sending the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to a 2004 low, as disappointing earnings projections reinforced concern about a profit slowdown later this year. The S.&P. 500 lost 2.13 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,084.07. An index of health care shares accounted for half of the slide. The index, which has shed 2.5 percent this year, is at the lowest since Dec. 17.

headline: Battle Brews on Regulation of Internet-Based Telephone Service
summary: Deregulation is the mantra of the main players in Internet-based phone service, a new technology that could increase competition and further drive down phone prices. But behind the scenes, a fierce battle is emerging among rival companies and between federal and state regulators over the shape of new government regulations and control of the service, which has the potential to be the most significant development in telecommunications since the breakup of the AT&T monopoly 20 years ago.

headline: Bells Are Catching Up In Battle for Broadband
summary: The regional Bell phone companies, long dismissed as laggards stuck with a declining fixed-line businesses, are coming back into favor again. The companies have gained the upper hand in their battle with the country's long-distance carriers, and are now stealing momentum from the cable industry in the fight for broadband customers. Verizon Communications, the country's largest telecommunications company, said yesterday that its net profit hit $1.8 billion, or 64 cents a share, in the second quarter, with strong performance from its broadband division and its wireless phone group.

headline: S.&P. Rises From Year's Low as Profits Beat Forecasts
summary: Stocks climbed yesterday, helping the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rebound from a 2004 low, after companies including Verizon Communications reported better-than-expected profit. The S.&P. 500 rose 10.76 points, or 1 percent, to 1,094.83, and the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 123.22 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,085.14. Both benchmarks had their biggest gains since June 7. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 30.08 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,869.10.

headline: After Layoff, a Start-Up
summary: Soon after David Riedel lost his job two years ago as an equity analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in a wave of layoffs on Wall Street, his entrepreneurial juices kicked in. He knew that more investors, in the wake of a research scandal, were looking for advice at small, independent research firms with no conflicts of interest that could taint their reports. He knew that he had valuable expertise about a part of the world that American securities firms generally did a poor job of covering. And he knew that the Internet could deliver tools that would have been unimaginable a few years earlier.

headline: Big Cable Companies See Next Challenge Around the Corner
summary: Cable companies, which have been weighed down for years by heavy investments and sagging subscriber growth, are starting to turn the corner. But as they do, they are meeting formidable foes in emboldened phone companies. Comcast, the nation's biggest cable operator, said yesterday that it earned $262 million in the second quarter, after losing $22 million in the same period last year, thanks to an increase in the number of customers signing up for digital video services and an increase in advertising revenue. Comcast's revenues rose 10.2 percent, to $5.1 billion, compared with a year earlier.

headline: SBC TO SELL STAKE IN DIRECTORY UNIT TO DONNELLEY
summary: SBC Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its stake in a yellow-pages business in Illinois and northwest Indiana to the R.H. Donnelley Corporation for $1.45 billion. Donnelley will buy SBC's share of a joint venture between the two companies that publishes 129 directories in the two states, SBC said. SBC, which is based in San Antonio, said it would record an $850 million gain from the sale this quarter. SBC, with about $18 billion of debt, is raising funds to pay for its portion of a $41 billion joint bid for AT&T Wireless Services Inc. with the BellSouth Corporation. Donnelley is based in Purchase, N.Y.

headline: SBC Is Latest to Seek AT&T's Customers
summary: The AT&T Corporation's rivals have not wasted any time in taking advantage of the company's woes. SBC Communications Inc., the second-largest long-distance carrier after AT&T, became the latest phone company to start playing advertisements inviting AT&T's customers to jump ship. Competition in the long-distance market was already fierce when, on July 22, AT&T said it would stop marketing to consumers and instead focus on its business clients. This retreat essentially invited AT&T's enemies to poach its existing customers.

headline: Cox Is Said To Consider Move to Take Cable Private
summary: Cox Enterprises, the privately held parent of the cable giant Cox Communications, is planning to make an $8 billion offer today to buy out the public minority shareholders in its cable business, the company said yesterday in a letter to its board. The offer is a bold gamble by Cox's controlling shareholders, the Cox-Anthony family, that shares in its cable business are undervalued and that the company can do better as a private business without the pressure to meet quarterly earnings targets.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: BellSouth To Offer DirecTV Service
summary: BellSouth, the third-largest regional Bell phone company, plans today to start offering its customers in nine states digital satellite service from DirecTV. BellSouth, like its rivals Verizon Communications and SBC Communications, is trying to win new customers from the cable companies by offering a similar bundle of television programming, phone lines and high-speed Internet connections. BellSouth customers will be able to receive at least 125 channels through DirecTV for prices starting at $36.99. BellSouth will also offer a $10 monthly discount for customers who subscribe to at least one other service, replacing a more limited discount program the companies operated. Ken Belson (NYT)

headline: AT&T Plans to Raise Its Rates For Residential Calling Plans
summary: AT&T Communications plans to reach out and put the touch on its customers. It has proposed raising its rates on several local calling plans in 40 states to increase revenues from its residential business. AT&T's decision to increase rates for most of its 4.7 million local phone customers comes less than two weeks after it decided not to seek new residential customers or to work to retain them.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Strike Looms At Bellsouth
summary: Member of the Communications Workers of America who work for BellSouth decided to allow their leaders to call a strike, if needed, when their current contract expires on Saturday. The union represents 47,000 workers of BellSouth, which has operations in nine states. The sides have been negotiating since June about wage increases, sickness and death benefits and pensions. C.W.A. members working at SBC Communications, another big phone company, held a four-day strike before eventually settling with the company in May. Ken Belson (NYT)

headline: Fittingly, Team Effort Lifts Maddux to Mark
summary: All week, Greg Maddux said he was not going to get too worked up about his 300th victory. His job, taking the mound every fifth day, was about team, not about him, he said. Which is a good thing, because Maddux's 300th victory Saturday had very little to do with him.

headline: The Poker Player
summary: ON a wall in Brian L. Roberts's office overlooking Philadelphia hangs a picture by Alexander Calder. It shows two poker players sitting at a table, clutching playing cards and swapping chips. Behind them are three stylized cards, including the ace of diamonds. The picture is a favorite of Mr. Roberts's, not just because it adds a bit of dash to the otherwise ordinary corporate suite he occupies as the chairman and chief executive of the Comcast Corporation, but also because it fits his image of how he and his father, Ralph, have built the nation's largest cable operator -- through guile, smarts and a succession of ever-bolder deals.

headline: Years Later, the Way a Rowland Friend Profited Is Criticized
summary: People in New Haven's business and political circles are still talking about how Robert V. Matthews, a friend of former Gov. John G. Rowland's, made a fortune in 2000 by selling a downtown office building for $27.5 million -- 55 times what he paid a little more than three years earlier. Now some investors say the deal was even sweeter than it initially appeared: they contend that state regulators, who approved the deal, discouraged another suitor from bidding against Mr. Matthews for the property.

headline: Two Big Cable Companies Report Losses Amid Competition
summary: Charter Communications Inc. and the Cablevision Systems Corporation, two of the largest cable television providers in the country, lost money in the second quarter, even as revenue from their high-speed data and media groups rose. Charter, the fourth-largest cable operator, said yesterday that it lost $415 million, or $1.39 a share, compared with a loss of $37 million, or 13 cents a share, in the period a year ago.

headline: A Wi-Fi Thief Unmasked: Guess It's Time to Move On
summary: A FEW weeks ago, after a refreshing twilight swim in the community pool, I returned to my apartment in downtown Los Angeles, opened my Apple iBook, and fired up the browser, ready for some high-speed urban surfing. Instead of my usual home page, what appeared on the screen was an unfriendly looking digital blockade bearing the Verizon logo. It read, as snippily as text can sound, ''Please enter your 10-digit evening contact telephone number that you provided when ordering your Internet service, or your Login Code. (No spaces or hyphens.)'' Annoyed, I typed in my own Web address, and then another, and another. Each time, the browser refused to budge.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC And BellSouth Can Buy Back Licenses
summary: SBC Communications Inc. and BellSouth can buy back wireless licenses in California and Indiana that the companies sold four years ago when they secured federal antitrust approval for their Cingular Wireless venture, the Justice Department said yesterday. The announcement is a preliminary step toward antitrust approval of Cingular's planned $41 billion purchase of AT&T Wireless Services. The Justice Department said it had not made a decision on that accord. When they formed Cingular, SBC and BellSouth signed a settlement in which they agreed to sell wireless businesses in California and Indiana markets to AT&T Wireless. Cingular would reacquire those licenses in a takeover of AT&T Wireless. In its announcement yesterday, the Justice Department said the new agreement modified the original settlement so that SBC and BellSouth would not be in violation of the accord once they acquire AT&T Wireless. The Justice Department said new competition in the Indiana and California markets had eliminated the antitrust concerns that prompted the 2000 settlement.

headline: A Texas Race For the House Or the F.C.C.?
summary: Becky Armendariz Klein is widely expected to lose her bid for Congress in Texas. But that has not stopped executives and lawyers from the nation's largest telephone and energy companies from pouring money into her campaign. Indeed, some of her strongest supporters expect her to fail.

headline: Giants Waste No Time Showing an Aching Trachsel No Mercy
summary: When Steve Trachsel dropped into a crouch on the pitcher's mound on Friday night, it was unclear whether his anguish was physical or emotional. Trachsel came into the game complaining of a sore right shoulder, and the ensuing events could not have made him feel any better. The Mets must hope that Trachsel's outing was simply a poor performance, and not the result of another injury.

headline: Mets Finish, Finally, What Glavine Started
summary: The game was started by a pitcher wearing fake teeth in his mouth and finished by a reliever wearing snake oil on his arm. It included 32 hits, 20 runs, a major-league-record 10 double plays and one memorable encounter between a precocious rookie and a legend.

headline: Mets' Aggressive Bonds Strategy Backfires
summary: Barry Bonds lounged in his personal leather recliner, watching his personal big-screen television, flanked by three of his devoted handlers. One of them was rubbing his left leg.

headline: F.C.C. Says It Extended Discounted Phone-Line Rates
summary: AT&T, MCI and other telephone companies that provide local calling by renting other carriers' equipment have received a six-month extension on discounted leasing rates while regulators work on new competition rules. After the period ends, local phone companies like Verizon Communications will be able to raise prices for existing customers ''moderately,'' or as much as 15 percent, the Federal Communications Commission said on its Web site on Friday.

headline: Verizon and Qwest Ask Court to Overturn F.C.C.'s Price Freeze
summary: Verizon Communications Inc. and Qwest Communications International Inc. asked a federal court yesterday to overturn the government's decision to freeze prices paid by competitors for use of local-telephone networks. The Federal Communications Commission last week ordered companies including Verizon, Qwest, the BellSouth Corporation and SBC Communications Inc. to maintain for six months discounted rental rates charged to the AT&T Corporation, MCI Inc. and other telephone companies. The regulations requiring the discounts expired in June after a federal appeals court ruled them illegal.

headline: Bonds's 700th Will Be Pricey, but Not Ruthian
summary: Imagine this scene: Barry Bonds slams his 700th home run out of SBC Park sometime next month and offers $20 to the fan who wrestles the ball from an armada of angry kayakers before it is waterlogged in McCovey Cove. Bonds would be deemed a miser and the fan would probably sue him for mental cruelty. Yet when Babe Ruth hit his 700th, on July 13, 1934, he got away with the $20 swap.

headline: Corporate Sendoff For Schwarzenegger
summary: The trip to New York by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger ofCalifornia to address the Republican National Convention is being financed by a variety of major corporations. Mr. Schwarzenegger, who is scheduled to speak in a prime-time slot on Tuesday night, came to office promising to rid Sacramento of ''special interests.'' But he has accepted hundreds of thousands of dollars in contributions from companies and interest groups with business before state government.

headline: One Way to Get Online: Piggyback
